webTitle: Carlton ratings rise at new midlands station

fields.headline: Carlton ratings rise at new midlands station
fields.standfirst: Palmer at the heart of Coventry push for Wembley
fields.trailText: By the time Carlton Palmer strides off the training pitch and through the canteen, Gordon Strachan is warming himself with a mug of tea. "You're playing better than ever," the Coventry manager shouts with a nod of admiration. Not hard, Palmer's legions of critics will say.
fields.body:
By the time Carlton Palmer strides off the training pitch and through the canteen, Gordon Strachan is warming himself with a mug of tea. "You're playing better than ever," the Coventry manager shouts with a nod of admiration. Not hard, Palmer's legions of critics will say.

At the start of the season the 34-year-old Palmer was not even in the first team at Nottingham Forest after refusing to sit on the bench in a friendly. David Platt, he claims, wanted to force him out.

"He tried to insult my intelligence," Palmer says, "and I wouldn't have that. If he'd said: 'Carlton, I need to sell you to get some money', fine. But to leave me out of a poor side? He said he made a mistake but once I lose respect for somebody, it doesn't matter if they apologise."

Strachan, of course, is not complaining. Palmer is as energetic as ever, stealing passes, making tackles, surging forward. Before he arrived in September Coventry had lost six of their nine matches and conceded 18 goals. Since then their record reads played 17, lost two, goals against 13. Charlton visit in the FA Cup tomorrow.

"I was expecting to move back to Sheffield Wednesday and I wouldn't have said Gordon Strachan would have fancied me," Palmer admits. "We were together at Leeds and we're similar characters - we desperately want to win. But we clashed often about the way I lived my life. The gaffer doesn't drink a lot and at that time... well I think I get paid to play football and as long as I do my job that's all that matters. That's how I was then."

Yet Strachan says he would have signed Palmer sooner but for the midfielder's notoriously outspoken manner. He was worried whether he could cope with such a forceful figure; concerned about the signals it might send to the younger players when discipline was not at the standard he liked.

"I've said to him his opinions will be listened to but it's only my opinion that counts," Strachan says. "He's still not really learned that but he's getting better at it. The key is to treat him the right way and not rubbish him. Sometimes his mouth's in the wrong place but his heart's always in the right place.

"I never had any doubts about him as a footballer. I admire the way he's reacted to criticism and kept going throughout his career. It's been unfair but he's never really complained about it.

"Any manager that worked with him will tell you he's good to work with. I think George Graham said to him I like you as a player but not for my team. You ask Big Ron [Atkinson] and Howard [Wilkinson]. Not a problem."

Meeting Palmer explains why. His will to win is obvious even in training. He is constantly cajoling and encouraging. In person he is affable and honest, confident rather than arrogant. The barbs, he says, do not bother him, though he believes they cut short his international career.

"I know for a fact that Terry Venables didn't pick me for England because of the media," he says. "I was player of the year at Leeds, playing exceptionally well, yet other people were getting capped ahead of me. I was very, very disappointed. I went to Southampton and Glenn Hoddle came to watch me but he wouldn't pick me because of the media. It's like Andy Cole. How the hell has Andy Cole not been playing for England?

"Rightly or wrongly, people believe what they read. Yet people see me play and they say 'Hang on, he's not a bad player'. And when they meet me they say, 'Hang on, he's not a bad person'. But in this world you're either a hero or a villain."

Palmer has a long leg in both camps. There is the 'Do I not like Carlton' brigade who forever associate him with England's failure under Graham Taylor. Yet he is a cult figure to many fans whose clubs he has played for.

One website describes him as having the "engine of a Rolls Royce, the heart of a lion and the skill of Diego Maradona". Whether the skill referred to the Argentine's heyday or his current state was unclear.

"People's opinions don't really bother me," he insists. "I'm very single-minded. When I finish people will have to say I was a decent player. There are a lot of so-called good players who haven't achieved anywhere near what I've achieved."

webTitle: United shake up the young brigade

fields.headline: United shake up the young brigade
fields.trailText: Manchester United put Jonathan Greening up for sale yesterday in a clear signal that Sir Alex Ferguson is embarking on a clear-out of fringe players from Old Trafford.
fields.body:
Manchester United put Jonathan Greening up for sale yesterday in a clear signal that Sir Alex Ferguson is embarking on a clear-out of fringe players from Old Trafford.

It appears Ferguson is prepared to part not only with the highly rated England Under-21 forward but at least three other players in their early 20s and replace them with another batch of young hopefuls as he refreshes the United squad.

Greening, plucked from York City almost two years ago, arrived at Old Trafford amid high expectations and Ferguson believed he would make further progress this season, in which he has made three senior starts and three substitute appearances. But now, after a contract stand-off lasting nine months, United have called time on the 21-year-old's Old Trafford career.

Greening may be followed out of United by a trio of players now considered to have little prospect of long-term United careers. This embraces John Curtis, the 21-year-old full-back currently on loan to Barnsley, his fellow defender Michael Clegg and the midfielder Mark Wilson, who has also yet to sign a new contract. All three have come through the ranks at Old Trafford.

Ferguson said the club were not prepared to budge further in their contract negotiations with Greening. "We offered him a new deal last summer, as we do with all our young players who come through and do well," said the manager. "Unfortunately when young players emerge they start looking for better contracts.

"We've gone as far as we can with Jonathan on the contract and he obviously doesn't want to sign. It's disappointing because he's going to be a very good player, but that's life."

Greening, who had played only 25 league games for York before being snapped up by Ferguson, was signed in a deal worth up to £1m depending on appearances. Celtic have already shown interest, as have several Premiership clubs, who will have to pay at least that sum to acquire him.

Leicester City have parted company with the chief executive Barrie Pierpoint, who was the leading member of the "gang of four" defeated in the recent power struggle at Filbert Street.

Pierpoint has left "by mutual consent" after a nine-year association with the club. He and his fellow directors Gilbert Kinch, Roy Parker and Phil Smith unsuccessfully tried to oust the club chairman John Elsom and the plc chairman Sir Rodney Walker.

webTitle: Svensson departs as Palace pay their way

fields.headline: Svensson departs as Palace pay their way
fields.trailText: Charlton yesterday signed the Sweden striker Mathias Svensson for £600,000 from Crystal Palace, who were forced to listen to offers for their top scorer to cover next month's wage bill as they will have only one home game in February.
fields.body:
Charlton yesterday signed the Sweden striker Mathias Svensson for £600,000 from Crystal Palace, who were forced to listen to offers for their top scorer to cover next month's wage bill as they will have only one home game in February.

Svensson, 25, has agreed a 3-year deal and Charlton will also pay him the outstanding signing-on fee and wages owed to him by the Selhurst Park club, for whom he has scored nine goals this season.

 Nottingham Forest have agreed personal terms with Jack Lester of Grimsby Town and Martin Smith of Sheffield United, who are expected to sign for the club today for £300,000 apiece. However, Forest now seem unlikely to finalise an agreement with Spencer Prior, for whom Derby had accepted their £650,000 offer.

 The proposed takeover of Cardiff by the brother of the Sunday Sport's publisher David Sullivan is back on. A £2.5m deal was blocked by the Football League last week but after meeting Clive Sullivan and Cardiff's chairman Steve Borley yesterday the league's financial controller Chris Griffin has given a verbal go-ahead.

 Joe Ashton has agreed to "hold fire" in his battle with Sheffield Wednesday's chairman Dave Richards after last week joining with three other city MPs to call for the club's manager Danny Wilson to be sacked.

fields.headline: Running scared of bad company
fields.trailText: Another week in the life Football Unlimited's fave pro wingback.
fields.body:
Monday

Demo, the coach from hell, calls us alltogether after training for one of his lectures. "Listen, lads, I don't want to lecture you..." Oh aye. "But lads, the point is, you've got to be careful just now the company you keep. Your private life is your own affair, obviously, lads, maybe you should be careful not to go mixing with the wrong sort in the wrong places."

"Sorry, I'm just not going to take that," pipes up Old Grandad, Mickey Scanlan, for once speaking a bit of sense. "You are talking to adult professional athletes here. I think we are all perfectly capable of making the right choices about who we socialise with."

"Aye, Mickey lad, it's all right for lads like you, what I call the sensible lads, what takes every precaution to preserve health and fitness," says Demo, looking over towards where me, Wattsy, Vic and Bob has opened a book on how many times he'll use the word "lad" in a single sentence. "I can trust lads like you, lad, it's other elements what worry me, lad."

"Yesssss," I yell at that precise moment. "That's a century you lot owes us: three in one sentence."

Tuesday

Demo pulls us aside after training. "What the bloody hell is this, lad?" he says, thrusting a bit of paper under me nose.

"Means nothing to me," I says.

"It's the player profile from the match-day programme. It's about you, you prat, lad."

"What's up with it, Deems?" I says.

"Up with it, lad? Shall I read it to you?

Player Profile: Darren Tackle.

Nickname: The Dog's (as in Bollocks).

Favourite drink: Toss-up between Indonesian lager top with a vodka and Red Bull chaser, or Southern Comfort and Irn Bru.

Favourite food: Doner with extra chilli from AbraKebabra after a night on the bevvy.

Good night out: One you can't remember the next morning.

He chucks the paper at us. "I will not go on, just suffice it to say, I have withdrawn it from the match programme for the Liverpool game, lad."

"Behave, Deems," I says. "It's important to make the right impression when Robbie and the boys are in town."

"It's in one ear and out the other with you, Dazz lad, isn't it?" says Deems. "Were you not at the media awareness seminar last month? Did you not attend the player profile module? And, Dazz lad, watch the company you keep."

Wednesday

One bit of old company I wouldn't mind shedding rings at his usual ungodly.

"Awight, boy?"

It's Rodney.

"Listen up. You done that questionnaire for the match programme like I asked? If not, give an associate of mine a little mench, boy. For your favourite night out, tell them it's that new Italian behind the station. Big Luigi would be very grateful. Could be a bread stick and a glass of Valpolicella in it for you, boy."

Thursday

At a bit of loose end tonight. Vic's at home tie-dying his hair, Bob's gone down with a bad case of turning off the mobile, and Wattsy's staying in with the missus to watch Who Wants To Be A Millionaire. "Try it, Dazz," he says. "We always have a good laugh, cos whatever the punters win, it's nowt compared to my take-home."

"Wattsy, we're out of the Cup, we've not got a game this weekend. Dell's calls."

"No, Dazz, I'm keeping a low profile."

Sod him, Darren Tackle is not too proud to fly solo. As it happens, on me way Dellwards, waiting at a bus stop I sees Marco, the geezer what was always useful for a G or two before he went down for a three stretch in the summer.

"All right, Marcs?" I says, winding down the window of the Jeep. "Fallen on hard times, have we? Hop in, I'll give you a lift to Dell's."

"Sorry, Dazz," he says. "Part of me deal for early release, probation officer tells me I've got to watch the company I keep. Fact is, I can't risk being seen with you, mate."

Blimey. Still, beggars can't be choosers. Wonder if Rodney's at a loose end.

fields.headline: Bradford back for Stan
fields.trailText: Bradford are making renewed attempts to sign the Aston Villa outcast Stan Collymore and have opened negotiations with Benfica for their out-of-favour forward Jorge Cadete.
fields.body:
Bradford are making renewed attempts to sign the Aston Villa outcast Stan Collymore and have opened negotiations with Benfica for their out-of-favour forward Jorge Cadete.

"Paul Jewell [the manager] and I met Stan Collymore and his representatives on Tuesday," said Geoffrey Richmond, the Bradford chairman who described it as the biggest gamble in the club's history.

"We found him to be articulate, intelligent and charming. He has been through a lot and he feels he still has a lot to offer. He just wants to make sure he gets things absolutely right. We are now due to have a second meeting early next week."

Villa's chairman Doug Ellis is seeking about £2m for Collymore but Bradford, who still face competition from Leicester, hope to agree a free transfer to let them come close to meeting the player's £20,000-a-week wage demand.

As for Cadete, a former Celtic striker who scored 38 goals in 49 games before leaving Park head "for family reasons" in 1997, Bradford are hoping to arrange a loan deal which they might make permanent at the end of the season.

"We are meeting with the player on Monday," Richmond added. "He and his advisers are flying in for talks, which is a significant step for us."

Benfica's president Joao Vale e Azevedo said: "Bradford have made an offer which is being looked at by the player and his agents."

 Southampton have completed a £600,000 deal with Skonto Riga for the Latvian winger Imants Bleidelis, 24 who has 40 caps, and Bristol Rovers signed his club-mate Vitaly Astafyev, a 28-year-old midfielder, for £150,000 after both internationals were granted work permits on appeal to the department for education and employment.

 The former England defender Bert Sproston, whose career included spells at Leeds United, Tottenham and Manchester City before he became a coach at Bolton Wanderers, has died aged 84.

webTitle: Robson can save his scalp at Old Trafford

fields.headline: Robson can save his scalp at Old Trafford
fields.standfirst: Mike Hodgkinson, our man with the pigeons in his sitting room, on a unlikely upset and some likely draws
fields.trailText: Coral's offer of 10-1 on Middlesbrough beating Manchester United at Old Trafford this Saturday may not look like a massive price - but it's definitely worth setting out the case against the home side. After all football is occasionally like Petrocelli, the Seventies TV court-room drama series in which the hopeless underdog wins out against the odds.
fields.body:
Coral's offer of 10-1 on Middlesbrough beating Manchester United at Old Trafford this Saturday may not look like a massive price - but it's definitely worth setting out the case against the home side. After all football is occasionally like Petrocelli, the Seventies TV court-room drama series in which the hopeless underdog wins out against the odds.

First up for consideration is the corresponding fixture last season in which United crashed 3-2, unable to regain the initiative after two first-half goals from the visitors. The message to Bryan Robson's side this weekend must surely be "rattle them early doors" and, on the evidence of Jaap Stam and Gary Neville's recent goofball defending, they might just succeed. Of course, last season Boro were lying a handy fourth in the Premiership and Robson was still king of his Riverside castle - 12 months on and the serfs are baying for his blood. But what better place for Robson to re-establish his reputation than Old Trafford.

The seeds of a Boro revival were scattered all around Anfield last week when, inspired by former Red Devils Paul Ince and Gary Pallister, Boro battled to a well-deserved draw. More of the same this week, with the occasional counter attack thrown in for good measure, and a shock could be in the offing. So there you have it - the 10-1 looks far too big already.

The FA Cup dominates the rest of the weekend's fixtures. On Sunday, Chelsea play host to penalty specialists Leicester, who will fancy their chances of grinding out another bruising cup result. The stats suggest that the home side have won seven of their last eight home matches against Martin O'Neill's bruisers but that's a little misleading - in their last five encounters with the Foxes, Vialli's side have won only once.

Vialli's side are expected to come out all guns blazing and the visitors' double barrelled silverware assault may take its toll on strength and fitness. Emile Heskey, Phil Gilchrist and Stefan Oakes are doubtful and no side can play for penalties forever. All the same, the draw after 90 minutes seem likely. Take the best priced 5-2.

On Monday, Blackburn's FA Cup adventure continues at home to Newcastle. The home side were battered 5-1 by Barnsley last week despite enjoying a run of decent form. However, a late Nathan Blake goal did for Liverpool at Anfield in the fourth round and, on the strength of that performance alone, they should be able to hold the Magpies. With Solano, Shearer and Ferguson fully wound up Newcastle have looked dangerous - then again, they were pretty tame in defeat against Wimbledon last weekend. The percentage call is again the draw - this time at 9-4.

Recommended bets FA Cup
Chelsea v Leicester - draw
Blackburn v Newcastle - draw
Premiership
Manchester United v Middlesbrough - away win

More of the same this week, with the occasional counter attack thrown in for good measure, and a shock could be in the offing. So there you have it - the 10-1 looks far too big already. The FA Cup dominates the rest of the weekend's fixtures. On Sunday, Chelsea play host to penalty specialists Leicester, who will fancy their chances of grinding out another bruising cup result. The stats suggest that the home side have won seven of their last eight home matches against Martin O'Neill's bruisers but that's a little misleading - in their last five encounters with the Foxes, Vialli's side have won only once. Vialli's side are expected to come out all guns blazing and the visitors' double barrelled silverware assault may take its toll on strength and fitness. Emile Heskey, Phil Gilchrist and Stefan Oakes are doubtful and no side can play for penalties forever. All the same, the draw after 90 minutes seem likely. Take the best priced 5-2. On Monday, Blackburn's FA Cup adventure continues at home to Newcastle. The home side were battered 5-1 by Barnsley last week despite enjoying a run of decent form. However, a late Nathan Blake goal did for Liverpool at Anfield in the fourth round and, on the strength of that performance alone, they should be able to hold the Magpies. With Solano, Shearer and Ferguson fully wound up Newcastle have looked dangerous - then again, they were pretty tame in defeat against Wimbledon last weekend. webTitle: Dismal England but that is no surprise

fields.headline: Dismal England but that is no surprise
fields.trailText: England's performance this evening was what is technically known as a shocker. You thought they were bad in the World Cup? They were much worse here.
fields.body:
England's performance this evening was what is technically known as a shocker. You thought they were bad in the World Cup? They were much worse here.

It has happened so often, it ought not be a shock. But it is. Zimbabwe are the team who have been playing so badly lately, they have allowed England to move up to eighth out of nine in the Wisden World Championship. But that is Test cricket, and this is the one-day game. And despite playing far more of this stuff at domestic level than any other country, our boys are, on their day, spectacularly bad at it.

It¹s been quite a week for England: first they thrashed a very good team, then they threw away a winning position and lost to the same team by one run, now they get thrashed themselves by a very moderate team.

It was an exact re-run of that awful day three years ago when England had their heads bitten off by a chicken farmer, Eddo Brandes, except (a) the batting this time was even more feeble and (b) the destroyer with comic potential was a cabbage-patch doll. Actually, that¹s unfair to Henry Olonga, a brisk seamer with some cunning variations who deserves far more credit than he will get in tomorrow¹s British newspapers. Olonga showed in the World Cup that his laid-back air hides a killer instinct, and the ball that made the first incision here was a banana-shaped inswinger to the left-handed Nick Knight.

On Wednesday, as night follows day ­ in fact at that very moment ­ Knight followed Hick. This time, Hick followed Knight, once again within two balls. England, for the seond time this winter, are trying to get by with only three senior batsmen, and when two of them go in three balls a Hick-up turns into a cock-up.

Hope sprung briefly from the middle of Vikram Solanki¹s bat with a classy pull and a dreamy square-smear, but then he went the way several England players had gone already in this tournament, carving to backward point. Don¹t blame Solanki: there is no way he should be batting at No.4, any more than Michael Vaughan should in the Test series (Vaughan¹s one fifty came when he was demoted to No.6). Nasser Hussain, a highly promising captain, is also, so far, a highly disappointing selector.

It was all a horrible waste of the good work done by Gough and Caddick in mid-innings, when they redeemed their wayward start, restricted Zimbabwe to 25 in 11 overs, and led Neil Johnson to add a new phrase to cricket¹s lexicon: the nonsenical nineties.

Chris Read again covered himself in respectability and Mark Alleyne did well as a bowler and fielder, though when it comes to batting, Gavin Hamilton¹s big-hitting flair must be more use. Read observed yesterday that the white ball turns to a "haggis" late in the innings. In which case, you surely need a Scotsman out there.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly.

webTitle: Abject England fold without a whimper

fields.headline: Abject England fold without a whimper
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe 211 for 7 (Neil Johnson 97)
England 107 all out (Henry Olonga 6-19)
Zimbabwe won by 104 runs
fields.trailText: England have probably crashed to more spineless defeats than this over the years, but it's hard to recall them at the moment. Today their batsmen were simply abysmal. Set a target of 212 to win the fourth Standard Bank Triangular Tournament game against Zimbabwe at Cape Town, they didn't even get close. They were bowled out for 107 in 34.2 overs as Henry Olonga claimed career-best figures of 6 for 19. It was gruesome, X-rated stuff.
fields.body:
England have probably crashed to more spineless defeats than this over the years, but it's hard to recall them at the moment. Today their batsmen were simply abysmal. Set a target of 212 to win the fourth Standard Bank Triangular Tournament game against Zimbabwe at Cape Town, they didn't even get close. They were bowled out for 107 in 34.2 overs as Henry Olonga claimed career-best figures of 6 for 19. It was gruesome, X-rated stuff.

The England innings began amid optimism after their bowlers had fought back well to limit Zimbabwe to 211 for 7 on a decent wicket. But that optimism quickly evaporated in a flurry of poorly-conceived strokes and some incisive new-ball bowling from Olonga. He claimed the first five England wickets, beginning with a double-wicket maiden in the fifth over of the innings: after Nick Knight had been trapped lbw for 5 (11 for 1), Graeme Hick drove flat-footedly at his second ball and was caught behind for a duck. Hardly the way to make your former countrymen regret your change of nationality.

Vikram Solanki sparkled briefly but became Olonga's third victim when he slashed a wide ball straight to Murray Goodwin in the gully for 14. It left England tottering at 37 for 3, but even that soon looked like riches from heaven when three wickets followed in quick succession. Olonga bowled Nasser Hussain for 10 off an inside edge (42 for 4), and then had Chris Adams steering in familiar fashion to second slip (47 for 5). Zimbabwe had obviously been watching the Test series against South Africa. Then Mark Alleyne nudged John Rennie to Andy Flower behind the stumps for four, and England were 47 for 6. Olonga took a rest at that point, leaving the field with figures of 8-3-18-5. Some England fans began leaving the stadium.

Bored with offering catches behind the wicket, England contrived new ways of getting out. Mark Ealham went for a dubious third and was run out by a throw from square-leg by Heath Streak to make it 61 for 6. Craig White then chipped Neil Johnson to Alistair Campbell at short midwicket for 18, moments after Andy Flower dropped him off Guy Whittall. England were 73 for 8 - the darkest of many pits they have dug for themselves in recent times.

It was 91 for 9 when Gough launched the off-spin of Andy Whittall to Stuart Carlisle at deep midwicket for three. Chris Read postponed the inevitable and drove Guy Whittall superbly through the covers for four to bring up the hundred, accompanied by ironic cheers from the Barmy Army. But with the score on 107, and with Olonga back in the attack, Read smashed him high to Guy Whittall to deep midwicket for 23 and it was all over. England had lost their sixth one-day international out of eight against this opposition.

Earlier, England's bowlers had done well to limit Zimbabwe to 211 for 7 after the opening batsmen had got off to a flier. The fifty came up in the 10th over, and Zimbabwe were threatening a total of 270 plus when they reached 150 for 3 with almost 17 overs remaining. But Caddick returned to bowl a magnificent second spell (7-1-13-1) and the innings fell away. Johnson, with 97, did his best to hold things together, but departed to a fine catch on the square-leg boundary by Hick as a century beckoned. At the time it looked like England might have done enough. But, for the second time in three days on this ground, England failed under the lights. At least Wednesday was close.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

fields.headline: Through the Ulster time warp
fields.standfirst: As the peace process again approaches crisis point, former Northern Ireland correspondent Derek Brown traces the development of the province's key players from fighters to politicians
fields.trailText: In the early hours of February 6, 1971, an IRA gunman shot dead Gunner   Robert Curtis, the first British soldier to die in the modern Troubles. As a   minor consequence of that event, I was dispatched to Belfast on the first of   a series of assignments which would eventually coalesce into a five-year   stint as the resident Guardian reporter.
fields.body:
In the early hours of February 6, 1971, an IRA gunman shot dead Gunner Robert Curtis, the first British soldier to die in the modern Troubles. As a minor consequence of that event, I was dispatched to Belfast on the first of a series of assignments which would eventually coalesce into a five-year stint as the resident Guardian reporter.

Nearly 30 years on, it is sobering to reflect how much has changed - and how much has remained the same. Many of the contacts I made in the 1970s have since died, a shocking proportion of them violently. Yet a surprising number are not only still alive, but kicking hard. Martin McGuinness, Gerry Adams, and David Trimble, to name but three.

McGuinness was the first I came across. He commanded the Provisional IRA's Derry 'brigade'. A taciturn but amiable enough young man, he used to hold occasional court in his operational headquarters in the Bogside gasworks, then in the heart of barricaded so-called Free Derry.

Adams was more elusive. He could be found from time to time in the Republican movement's chaotic office in the Falls Road in Belfast. His exact role was shrouded in mystery until Keith Graves, then a BBC correspondent, revealed that he had become the IRA's chief of staff: the top job. Adams indignantly denied it, but made himself even more scarce. Graves, meanwhile, was given a health warning: leave Belfast tonight, or die. He left.

Trimble never carried a gun. But when he first came into public view, he was part of the murky movement which brought down the first power-sharing executive in 1974: a loose coalition of diehard Unionists and paramilitary forces which bullied and coerced the province into a paralysing general strike. Trimble was then a young pup, yapping excitedly at the heels of his master, Bill Craig, the quasi-fascist and drink-sodden leader of the mercifully short-lived Vanguard party.

McGuinness, Adams and Trimble have come a long, long way since those days. (So have we all). They have, to borrow a famous phrase coined by a parliamentary sketchwriter, glimpsed the black underwear of power. They are mature men now, more excited by holding office than by street action. Still, given their backgrounds, it is little short of miraculous that they have signed the same piece of paper, and that they are sitting at the same table of government.

McGuinness and Adams may have renounced violence, but they represent a significant strand of Irish thinking which wallows in it. The culture of Republicanism is steeped in misty legend of heroic 'battles' involving maybe a dozen men; of sordid ambushes posing as heroic operations; of casual murders represented as judicial executions. For the hard men of the movement, armed resistance is not an option; it is their very raison d'etre.

Trimble too, though he now belongs squarely in mainstream, respectable Unionism, carries the baggage of history. All those years ago, he fought in his own way for exclusive majority rule, and he is surrounded still by people who find the idea of power sharing, especially with Republicans, utterly repugnant.

The current confrontation over arms has as much to do with mindset as with the mechanics of disarmament. The Republicans have a valid point when they say the latest Unionist deadline for movement - the party council meets on February 12 - is arbitrary and provocative. But Trimble's men too are justifiably exasperated with the Republicans' endless circumlocution and whining self-pity.

It is madly unrealistic to expect the politicans of Northern Ireland, or the long-suffering people they represent, to discard the lumber of the past, call it quits and start again. The province must somehow learn to live with its past, as it comes to terms with its future.

Simple logic demands that the IRA must now make a move, and rather more than a symbolic one, towards dismantling its arsenal. It also requires that the Unionists recognise that true peace can only be made through compromise, not surrender. As they square up for yet another contest of wills, McGuinness, Adams and Trimble would do well to remind themselves of how far they have come. It might help them realise how much further they have to go.

webTitle: Tim Roth and Pinter take on King Lear

fields.headline: Tim Roth and Pinter take on King Lear
fields.standfirst: Also today, Blair Witch stunt mystifies Sundance | The patter of tiny feet for Zeta-Jones and Douglas | Soderbergh is the hippest kid on the block | No Love lost for Courtney, and Rupert Everett scores again in the US
fields.trailText: Also today, Blair Witch stunt mystifies Sundance | The patter of tiny feet for Zeta-Jones and Douglas | Soderbergh is the hippest kid on the block | No Love lost for Courtney, and Rupert Everett scores again in the US
fields.body:
His directorial debut The War Zone dealt with child abuse, and for his next directing project, Tim Roth has decided upon the ultimate dysfunctional family - King Lear.

Harold Pinter is currently writing a script for an adaptation which Roth says will be similar in style to either Baz Luhrmann's Romeo + Julietor Akira Kurosawa's Ran, which swapped Lear's daughters for sons.

The director says he got the idea while making his first film. "We were talking about films revolving around a family, and the biggest case scenario was King Lear. Soon, we were tossing around ideas and we were on the phone with Harold Pinter, who quickly said yes. It is absolutely terrifying to me, really, but I guess that's the challenge".

Roth will begin shooting the British-funded project next winter, after playing Hitler's clairvoyant in Werner Herzog's upcoming filmInvincible.

Blair Witch stunt mystifies Sundance

How do you repeat the success of a phenomenal internet marketing campaign? That was the quandry facing Eduardo Sanchez and Daniel Myrick, directors of last year's shoestring horror, The Blair Witch Project, as they promoted their new film The Heart of Love at the Sundance Film Festival.

The duo do not start shooting the picture for another four months but, anxious that the hype start as soon as possible, Sanchez and Myrick pulled a stunt at the close of Sundance that mystified journalists, uncertain if they were being made fun of or not.

Sanchez and Myrick joined forces with The Lovians, a Texas-based religious organization who dress in off-yellow robes and believe, according to a leaflet from their leader the Most High Kashesh, that "beginning with Adam and Eve all the way through the annals of time up to the Trump Towers, Heart of Love has been there." Group members were out in force at the Festival with founder member Paigamber leading the puzzled hacks in prayer on a makeshift stage in Park City, a quiet town above Sundance.

Myrick claimed that The Lovians had approached the film makers: "We're trying to figure out the connection, ourselves. Like in 'Witch,' we have a starting point. We're creating a folklore, [they] have a folklore, and we'll just embellish and have fun with it.''

 Those seeking further enlightenment can visit the new site at www.holthemovie.com

Patter of tiny feet for Zeta-Jones and Douglas

Catherine Zeta-Jones and Michael Douglas have yet another happy announcement to make, reports an exclusive in the Sun - the star of Entrapment who recently announced her engagement to Douglas, is said to be three months pregnant.

According to a source close to the actress, who broke the story to the paper, she has been suffering from "terrible" morning sickness for a fortnight and it was this which prevented her from attending last Sunday's Golden Globe awards. It is also the reason why she pulled out of co-starring with Kevin Costner in the romantic thriller Beyond Borders.

The couple, who plan to marry in the autumn, are said to be "thrilled" about the surprise baby which is due at the beginning of July.

Soderbergh is the hippest kid on the block

Out of Sight and The Limey may not have done great shakes at the box office but they did confirm Steven Soderbergh's reputation as one of the hippest directors in Hollywood. Now everyone is queuing up to get a bit of indie cred from his upcoming projects.

According to mr showbiz the list of stars who want to feature in Ocean's 11 - a remake of the 1960 film starring the Ratpack (Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin and Sammy Davis Jnr) as five friends who plan to rob five Las Vegas casinos simultaneously - is racking up. Brad Pitt, Johnny Depp, Julia Roberts and Mike Myers have all expressed interest in the film and Pitt has already met Soderbergh to discuss playing the Dean Martin role.

And Harrison Ford, who recently hired a new agent to seek out more exciting roles, is being touted for Soderbergh's other project, Traffik. The director is keen to cast him as a drugs czar who discovers his daughter is a drug addict. Catherine Zeta-Jones is also attached to star but recent happy events may have put paid to that.

No Love lost

Never diss a film critic. That's what Courtney Love found out the other evening when the wife of the Hollywood Reporter's chief film critic took a photograph of the singer turned actress without her permission.

The fracas took place at a dinner in honour of Love's new movie Beat, the story of the writer W.S. Burroughs, in which Love plays opposite Kiefer Sutherland as the beatnik writer's wife Joan Volmer Burroughs.

According to witnesses, Kirk Honeycutt's wife took a picture of Love as she was leaving the restaurant after getting permission from a publicist. Unaware of this Love saw red, took the camera and threw it on the ground. Honeycutt stepped in and fought with Love until a friend broke it up. The two finally made it up and all seemed to be forgotten until Love asked the film reviewer whether he still intended writing about the film. "Under the circumstances,'' he replied, "No.''

News in brief

Rupert Everett has had his onscreen time in the forthcoming comedy drama The Next Best Thing increased because American preview audiences are ecstatic about his performance. Everett stars as a gay man who impregnates his best friend, played by Madonna, and gets embroiled in a nasty custody battle when she falls for a straight man and wants to take the child away. This is the second time Everett has wowed the American audience: his role in My Best Friend's Wedding was also expanded because he was so popular.

Welsh bands The Manic Street Preachers, Catatonia, Super Furry Animals and Gorky's Zygotic Mynci are to collaborate with former Velvet Underground man John Cale on the score for a film called Beautiful Mistakes. In an interview with NME Cale described the film as an unsentimental celebration of Wales and the successful people who come from the country. It will be directed by Chris Foster who made the black and white landscape film, Minim, and released in selected cinemas this spring.

Casting couch

 Amy Jenkins, writer of the hit BBC series This Life, has had her forthcoming novel, Honeymoon, bought by Columbia Pictures. The novel is a romantic comedy about a new bride who, on her honeymoon, finds herself next door to another newly-wed who just happens to be her first love. The couple ditch their spouses and run away to Mexico where they find the course of true love does not run smooth.

The couple, who plan to marry in the autumn, are said to be "thrilled" about the surprise baby which is due at the beginning of July. That's what Courtney Love found out the other evening when the wife of the Hollywood Reporter's chief film critic took a photograph of the singer turned actress without her permission. Burroughs, in which Love plays opposite Kiefer Sutherland as the beatnik writer's wife Joan Volmer Burroughs. Welsh bands The Manic Street Preachers, Catatonia, Super Furry Animals and Gorky's Zygotic Mynci are to collaborate with former Velvet Underground man John Cale on the score for a film called Beautiful Mistakes. The novel is a romantic comedy about a new bride who, on her honeymoon, finds herself next door to another newly-wed who just happens to be her first love. The couple ditch their spouses and run away to Mexico where they find the course of true love does not run smooth.

webTitle: National Trust rejects move to end ban on stag hunting

fields.headline: National Trust rejects move to end ban on stag hunting
fields.standfirst: The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: The National Trust is to keep its ban on stag hunting despite a concerted attempt by scientists, financed by the pro-hunting Countryside Alliance, to say it was not cruel.
fields.body:
The National Trust is to keep its ban on stag hunting despite a concerted attempt by scientists, financed by the pro-hunting Countryside Alliance, to say it was not cruel.

The 52-member National Trust council yesterday decidede to back the original findings by Patrick Bateson, the provost of King's College, Cambridge, that chasing deer with hounds was cruel.

Yesterday's meeting had a report before it from Roger Harris arguing that although deer may suffer from stress it was no worse than that suffered by a professional footballer after a match.

At the meeting Prof Bateson was backed by 12 eminent scientists.

There is no difference in the data between the two reports although they draw different conclusions.

The National Trust's decision was welcomed by the League Against Cruel Sports and the RSPCA.

Dr R Atkinson, head of wildlife at the RSPCA, said: "The RSPCA has looked at both the Bateson and Harris studies and believes that data from both of them show clearly that deer suffer from being pursued by dogs. Deer hunted by hounds flee in fear of their lives, for many kilometres over several hours. We believe that to knowingly induce such fear is cruel."

The National Trust said last night it would review its decision after the report by the independent inquiry headed by Lord Burns into the implementation of a fox-hunting ban and how it would affect the rural economy.

Its decision is a blow to one of the independent inquiry's members, Lord Soulsby, who had argued that deer hunting by hounds was not cruel. Lord Soulsby will be examining animal cruelty as part of his brief on the inquiry.

fields.headline: Hatching Dora
fields.standfirst: Labour is keen to prove it loves the countryside. One of its options is to create a super-department of rural affairs
fields.trailText: Dora is doing the rounds in Whitehall again. She is the would-be department of rural affairs - a heavy-hitter in the machine, a super-ministry combining economic, agricultural, social and environmental agendas. Dora would be living proof that Labour is succeeding in "joining up" government - Mo Mowlam, chair of the cabinet committee for harmonising rural policy, is favourite to head it.
fields.body:
Dora is doing the rounds in Whitehall again. She is the would-be department of rural affairs - a heavy-hitter in the machine, a super-ministry combining economic, agricultural, social and environmental agendas. Dora would be living proof that Labour is succeeding in "joining up" government - Mo Mowlam, chair of the cabinet committee for harmonising rural policy, is favourite to head it.

There is much joining-up to do - the chart shows the various official fingers in the rural pie - quite apart from the political task of reassuring country dwellers who are living through the worst agricultural recession since the 30s. They are suspicious of a "townie" housing invasion and protective of country pursuits.

Whitehall heard the alarm bells ringing late over what happens to rural post offices when pensions and benefits get paid direct into bank accounts from 2003. The department of trade and industry has been accused of failing to understand the problems besetting rural small businesses, most of which employ fewer than 10 people. The government's predilection for "action zones" to lever up standards in health, education and employment and its regeneration policy depend on very tight targets and big private investment to match the money coming in from public funds and the European Union. That is not easy to achieve in sparsely populated areas.

Labour's rural recipe depends on more tourism, the internet and other new technologies, but that plan depends on bullying communication companies into spending some of their profits on uneconomic social ends. An arm's-length countryside agency was created last year with the very purpose of integrating approaches. But its focus has shifted. It has moved away from trying to save village services - many schools, shops, pubs and banks have already disappeared - to saving market towns and making them hubs of prosperity that reinvigorate surrounding areas.

The clamour for a super-department of rural affairs is not new. It coincides with MAFF's declining reputation and the fall-out from the BSE fiasco. Making the new food standards agency responsible to the health department heightened debate about MAFF's future. The early retirement of Sir Richard Packer, its combative permanent secretary, presents an opportunity to reshape Whitehall structure. Some say MAFF should be shut down and its functions split between DTI and the department of environment, transport and the regions.

Yet no one, so far, has been quite able to suggest what Dora might be responsible for beyond agriculture. The biggest political issue is the spread of suburbia and how to make cities more attractive to live in. But big departments are not going to let go. Doing away with MAFF might send the wrong signals, convincing critics of Labour's hostility to the countryside. Agriculture has by far the biggest single budget distributed through Brussels and not having a dedicated agriculture minister fighting Britain's corner might be risky.

A less radical solution has been encouraged by the Country Landowners' Association. This is a department of the countryside and agriculture, daughter of Dora. It would lighten the load of the huge department of environment, transport and the regions. Taking away some of its environmental work might chime with the way European policy is slowly moving away from subsidy for farmers to general rural development. Britain likes to take credit for this. Integrated departments for the countryside, agriculture and forestry already exist in Scotland and Wales. In England, however, planning and service delivery is for councils; strategic issues have now been devolved to regional development agencies.

John Prescott will not be keen to lose control. Yet the government is so sensitive to charges of lack of interest in the countryside that Prescott will rattle off achievements as if the countryside were a lucky recipient - £170m extra for buses and other rural transport, safeguards for village shops through rate relief, a reversal of the policy of closing small schools, NHS Direct saving people from visits to the doctor, improved access for walkers...

But no one, even the treasury, has much idea how much is spent in rural areas in total. Civil servants are trying to make the calculations and there is the possibility of a dedicated rural budget under "a lead ministry". "Rural proofing" will be introduced, a way of evaluating all policies for their impact on rural areas. The countryside agency has been eagerly pushing for this role, offering a yearly "state of the countryside" report designed to shame Whitehall departments which fail the joined-up test. This would mean a more political role for an arm's-length body, however. Some feel this evaluative work should be done by a unit reporting directly to Number 10 or by the cabinet office.

A quick decision on the place of rural affairs in the hierarchy is unlikely but Labour wants to prove it really does love the countryside. Next week Tony Blair leads off a series of speeches and events. On Tuesday (unless Northern Ireland is in a state demanding his attention) he addresses the National Farmers' Union where he may deliver hope and a little more cash for hard-pressed farmers. Later in the week he visits the southwest of England.

James Meikle is our agriculture correspondent

webTitle: Marketing professor is best-paid academic - on £252,000 a year

fields.headline: Marketing professor is best-paid academic - on £252,000 a year
fields.standfirst: Visit our education site at www.educationunlimited.co.uk
fields.trailText: John Quelch, head of the London Business School, is today named as Britain's highest paid academic, on £252,000 a year - £100,000 more than his closest rival. He also secured the biggest pay rise, a 21.7% increase on the salary of his predecessor, George Bain.
fields.body:
John Quelch, head of the London Business School, is today named as Britain's highest paid academic, on £252,000 a year - £100,000 more than his closest rival. He also secured the biggest pay rise, a 21.7% increase on the salary of his predecessor, George Bain.

A 12.9% rise to £149,000 took Sir Stewart Sutherland to the second best-paid position, as vice chancellor of the University of Edinburgh. Third is Robert Boyd of St George's hospital medical school in south London, on £148,280.

The figures are given in the annual survey of pay for vice chancellors and top academics, published today by the Times Higher Education Supplement. Vice chancellors received an average rise of 4.9% in the year ending last July.

The survey also shows that female vice chancellors are paid far less than their male counterparts. University lecturers last year received a rise of 3.5%, and the survey will be seized on by unions pursuing pay claims to wipe out decades of underpayment.

Prof Quelch was recruited as dean of the London Business School from Harvard university in the United States, where he was professor of marketing. He is an expert in global business practice, international marketing and human resource management.

Speaking from Davos in Switzerland yesterday, he said his salary, and others at the school, reflected its need to compete internationally. "In the US, salaries in business and other professional postgraduate schools are higher than in the arts and sciences, at all levels. Salaries at the London school reflect its Financial Times ranking [published earlier this week] as the best business school in Europe and eighth in the world."

The school, in central London, has 1,000 postgraduates, with a further 4,000 students on four to six-week courses. It describes itself as "self-financing" and reported a surplus of £18.5m in 1998-99.

A spokeswoman for the Association of University Teach ers, which has 40,000 members, said of Prof Quelch's pay: "Most academics would be gobsmacked and think he's had an evening with Chris Tarrant rather than a university payslip. In any section of the UK economy you want the top people with the top skills to be paid internationally competitive salaries, but percentage increases should be in line with staff."

Elsewhere in the survey, Colin Lucas, vice chancellor of the University of Oxford, received £90,915, less than the £103,000 for Graham Upton, head of Oxford Brookes. Mike Fitzgerald, ex-vice chancellor of Thames Valley university, got £91,500, a year's pay, in compensation for loss of office.

Universities and higher education colleges yesterday reported a 1.8% fall to 320,450 in applications by the December 15 deadline to start this year. The service said an important factor could be tuition fees.

The figures show a 11.7 % increase in applications from overseas outside the European Union, but a continuing fall from within the EU. Computer science applications were up by 10.3 %, and applications for combined sciences and business studies were also up.

fields.headline: The Cubie Report explained
fields.trailText:
When was the report commissioned and why?
Scottish devolution created a ruling Labour-Lib Dem coalition. The two parties faced problems arising from their many conflicting policies and the issue of tuition fees proved to be the most volatile. Although both parties had promised to look into the issue of student funding, the Lib Dems made abolition of the fees the "non-negotiable" centrepiece of their election manifesto. Which raised a major conflict of interest between they and Labour, who abolished student grants and introduced a £1000 means-tested fee in September 1998.
fields.body:
When was the report commissioned and why?
Scottish devolution created a ruling Labour-Lib Dem coalition. The two parties faced problems arising from their many conflicting policies and the issue of tuition fees proved to be the most volatile. Although both parties had promised to look into the issue of student funding, the Lib Dems made abolition of the fees the "non-negotiable" centrepiece of their election manifesto. Which raised a major conflict of interest between they and Labour, who abolished student grants and introduced a £1000 means-tested fee in September 1998.

Furthermore, in order to abolish up-front tuition fees for all Scots, EU law would demand that the Westminster government pay the fees of all 99,000 EU students studying in Britain. The Cubie committee - named after Edinburgh lawyer Andrew Cubie who chaired the 14-strong body - formed in July 1999, in an attempt to find a solution to the problem which was threatening to undermine the fragile Scottish coalition. Charged with conducting a comprehensive review of tuition fees and the finances of Scottish students, the committee then made recommendations for any changes to the system.

What were Cubie's main recommendations?
Tuition fees were to be replaced by a Scottish graduate endowment scheme, whereby the Scottish executive paid the fees and students would be required to pay £3,000 of it back when their earnings reached £25,000 a year.

Scottish students from low-income families would also be entitled to a bursary of up to £2,050, akin to the old maintenance grant. Single parents and mature students would receive even more.

Universities should develop part time employment schemes and advise students on how to establish a reasonable balance between supplementing their income and maintaining studies. A term-time maximum of 10 working hours a week was suggested.

The threshold for parental and spousal contributions should be set so that families with earnings below £23,000 would not have to make a contribution.

How much would Cubie's recommendations have cost?
£71 million a year.

How much of the report has been excepted by the Scottish executive?
The executive has agreed to abolish up-front tuition fees and has announced a replacement graduate scheme similar to Cubie's proposals. Students will now pay back £2,000, not £3,000, but repayments will start once their earnings reach just £10,000, which is significantly less than the average national wage and a long way off Cubie's £25,000.

How has this been received?
Cubie himself was said to be "broadly pleased" with the reforms package, though he admitted he would have preferred his report to have been adopted in full. However, student leaders in Scotland strongly rejected the reforms, accusing the executive of "back-pedalling". Graeme McAulay, president of Edinburgh University Students Association, said: "Changes such as the ones proposed are not merely a watering-down of the Cubie recommendations but new proposals which go against the whole spirit of the Cubie report."

How much will it cost and where will the money come from?
The executive has said the yearly cost will be £50 million. £17 million is expected to come from the graduate endowment scheme and the rest will be found by the Department of Enterprise and Lifelong Learning.

What problems has this caused for David Blunkett?
The overwhelming resentment of English students, who still have to pay £1,025 in upfront fees, has prompted the education and employment secretary to lower the means-tested threshold. This will now exempt a further 50,000 students from paying the fees.

webTitle: Crisis-hit Mugabe has luck of the draw

fields.headline: Crisis-hit Mugabe has luck of the draw
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe government online
Amnesty International: Zimbabwe
Arms Trade Resource Centre
fields.trailText: The president of Zimbabwe, Robert Mugabe, has won Z$100,000 (about £1,600) in a promotional draw carried out by a local bank for its clients, the institution said yesterday.
fields.body:
The president of Zimbabwe, Robert Mugabe, has won Z$100,000 (about £1,600) in a promotional draw carried out by a local bank for its clients, the institution said yesterday.

Zimbabwe Banking Corporation said Mr Mugabe's name had emerged from the promotional draw on Wednesday out of thousands of qualifying account holders who participated in the promotion.

"Master of ceremonies Fallot Chawawa could hardly believe his eyes when the ticket drawn for the Z$100,000 prize was handed to him and he saw 'His Excellency RG Mugabe' written on it," the bank said in a statement.

Mr Mugabe, 75, who has been in power since independence from Britain in 1980, awarded himself and his cabinet salary hikes of up to 200% last year.

However, he denies accusations that government mismanagement has plunged the economy into its worst crisis in decades, with crippling petrol and power shortages.

Racism is pernicious in all its forms

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: It should never have taken so long. But at last, ministers have agreed that indirect discrimination - one of the most widespread forms of institutional racism - should be banned from all public as well as private services.

It should never have taken so long. But at last, ministers have agreed that indirect discrimination - one of the most widespread forms of institutional racism - should be banned from all public as well as private services. Unbelievably, almost until the moment when the race relations (amendment) bill arrived in the Lords, the government was still trying to exclude crucial national services - police, prisons, probation, health, inland revenue, social security benefits - from the legislation. While the private sector and local services like schools and housing were all being required to tackle indirect discrimination, Whitehall was looking after its own. And this despite the fact that 25 years ago the white paper which led to the 1976 act unequivocally declared: "It is insufficient for the law to deal only with overt discrimination. It should also prohibit practices which are fair in a formal sense but discriminatory in their operation and effect." Ignoring the Lawrence inquiry, which found no evidence of direct racism but profoundly disturbing indirect discrimination, home office ministers continued to defend the indefensible.

Of the three different forms of discrimination - overt and intentional, disguised but deliberate, and unintentional but adverse - the third creates the most difficulties. It can involve rules or practices which apply equally to everyone but which have a disproportionate and adverse impact upon a particular racial group. The defence which ministers offered for excluding national services here - that opening them up to scrutiny would lead to a tangle of court cases and prevent targeted policies - was always hollow. For example, targeting special heating allowances to elderly people - even if proportionally, there are fewer elderly people from ethnic minorities - could easily be justified on grounds of public health. But where practices cannot be justified in this way they must not be allowed.

The home secretary's decision to go even further, placing a legal duty on the whole public sector from primary schools to maximum security prisons to promote racial equality, is another important breakthrough. Schools with under-performing pupils from particular ethnic groups could be required to tackle the problem; the police, to set themselves targets for reducing their discriminatory use of stop and search powers; the health service, to devise new ways of helping ethnic communities not being reached at present. But the new legal duty cannot produce results without a proper enforcement procedure. The present act contains a vague requirement to "consider appropriate measures" but nothing which bites. The new duty must be unambiguous and clear; its enforcement mechanism, workable and effective.

Mr Straw's initiative has brought the expected complaints, especially from the police, who fear it will add fresh constraints to those imposed by the MacPherson report. If they need a reminder of the dangers of taking racist behaviour too lightly, they need only to look at the case of the two men found hanged in Telford after the older man had been to the police to say he feared for his life after racist threats. There is no way of knowing so far whether these deaths were suicide or murder, but it seems dismayingly clear that the West Mercia police failed to respond with the urgency which the Met has acquired the hard way in London after the Stephen Lawrence and Menson cases. The defeat of racism demands unflagging vigilance. It is good to see the home secretary, even if belatedly, responding to that.

webTitle: Town denies racism amid media scrutiny of hangings

fields.headline: Town denies racism amid media scrutiny of hangings
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Community leaders in Telford last night said their Shropshire town had been unfairly portrayed as a racist hotbed, following media speculation over the suspicious deaths of two black men.
fields.body:
Community leaders in Telford last night said their Shropshire town had been unfairly portrayed as a racist hotbed, following media speculation over the suspicious deaths of two black men.

The family of Harold McGowan, 32, who died in July, and his nephew, Jason McGowan, 20, found dead on new year's day, believe they were victims of racists who made their murders look like suicide.

Harold McGowan, also known as Erroll, was found hanging by a flex from a door in a friend's house.

Jason McGowan was discovered hanging from railings by the side of a road 100 yards from a pub where he was last seen with friends celebrating.

The family have reported that Harold McGowan had learned he was on a "death list" issued by a neo-Nazi group, Combat 18. They also allege that, following his death, members of the family were warned off trying to establish its cause.

They have accused the police of prematurely ruling out foul play. Their complaints have been picked up by national newspapers and yesterday began to receive television coverage.

West Mercia police said that, despite full investigations, no evidence had been found of third party involvement in the deaths.

On Wednesday a member of the force met the Metropolitan police's racist and violent crime task force. It gave them advice on improving relations with the family, including guidelines established in the wake of the Macpherson report into the death of Stephen Lawrence, and urged more openness with the media.

The West Mercia force has remained cautious, insisting it can divulge little in advance of the inquest into Harold's death due on February 28. The family are urging a delay in the inquest date so that the two deaths can be considered together.

The police have won local support. The Shropshire Star newspaper in Telford, where Jason McGowan once worked and which employs his wife, Sinead McGowan, and mother, Doreen McGowan, yesterday ran a front-page comment criticising national coverage of the deaths.

Under the headline Jason: is the grief distorting the facts?, the paper's editor, Adrian Faber, criticised the Independent newspaper for suggesting the deaths could have been caused by a "racist lynch mob".

"Evidence to support a racist conspiracy theory is scant. We cannot allow rumour to become reality just because it is repeated often enough," Mr Faber wrote.

He told of attending Jason McGowan's "harrowing and heartbreaking" funeral but said: "This gigantic leap from a very personal tragedy that has touched us all, to talk of a murdering conspiracy is terrifying."

Last night Sinead McGowan, employed in the Star's classified ads department, said she was "a bit annoyed" by the paper's article.

"I don't know why they haven't actually asked me to make a comment or anything. They haven't spoken to me since before the funeral."

Dave Davies, leader of Telford and Wrekin council, said yesterday: "The speculation has made people very unhappy, as the picture painted in the national media of Telford is unfair and not one that anyone locally recognises."

Marie Barrow, chair of the Telford and Shropshire race equality council, said: "We have a very good record in Telford and Shropshire.

"As in every other part of the country, racism does happen but the national headlines paint a very negative picture of the local community."

West Mercia police said in a statement: "West Mercia recognised immediately that the death of Harold McGowan was a serious incident and extensive resources were employed from the outset.

"When the second tragedy occurred the likelihood of sinister implication was immediately recognised.

"As a matter of normal practice in a major investigation a review has been carried out of our inquiry into the death of Harold McGowan."

fields.body:
West Mercia police investigating the deaths of two black men, Harold and Jason McGowan, have met members of Scotland Yard's racial and violent crimes task force to receive advice on their handling of the investigation.

A Scotland Yard spokeswoman last night confirmed that members of the racial task force had met on Wednesday with the senior detective appointed to scrutinise the investigation.

"Officers from the task force did meet with detectives from West Mercia on Wednesday in relation to an ongoing investigation as part of a wider process of consultation," she said.

The squad is believed to have advised the detectives of the need to keep an open mind on possible causes of the deaths, as well as to check for possible links with extremist groups and to check with other forces for similar cases.

They are also believed to have suggested that West Mercia should keep the family of the dead men up to date with all developments, and should hold joint press conferences appealing to the community for help.

They should also seek to use programmes such as the BBC's Crimewatch in trying to establish any new lines of inquiry.

webTitle: Beowulf bowls out Harry Potter for second award

fields.headline: Beowulf bowls out Harry Potter for second award
fields.trailText: For the second time in a week the literary giants stood head to head in the same category. It was Heaney v Rowling again yesterday at the annual South Bank Show arts awards, with the chance that the boy wizard Harry Potter might take revenge against the Anglo-Saxon Beowulf for his Whitbread Prize victory two days earlier.
fields.body:
For the second time in a week the literary giants stood head to head in the same category. It was Heaney v Rowling again yesterday at the annual South Bank Show arts awards, with the chance that the boy wizard Harry Potter might take revenge against the Anglo-Saxon Beowulf for his Whitbread Prize victory two days earlier.

JK Rowling was not in evidence due to flu, but it was no matter. Beryl Bainbridge presented the award for the year's best achievement in literature to Seamus Heaney for his "magnificently poetic rendering" of a text she had struggled with when young.

Heaney said he was particularly delighted to accept the award with memories of the late Ted Hughes, to whom Beowulf is dedicated. The ceremony at the Savoy Hotel in London was hosted by Melvyn Bragg

Cherie Blair headed the guest list. She was there to present an outstanding achievement award to her friend Sir Cliff Richard for his 41-year career.

She praised his longevity and his pride in his Christianity. "I sometimes hear criticism of him that he's a nice guy, though why there's any problem in being nice is a mystery to me."

Sir Cliff said the award was "beyond his dreams" and emphasised his belief that no one art form was superior to another.

At 91, Sir John Mills presented the cinema award to John Madden, director of Shakespeare In Love.

fields.headline: Most wanted:  boo.com sale
fields.trailText: There's trouble in e-paradise: much-hyped sportswear site boo.com is cutting staff, with a view to downshifting to a more low-tech site. Yes, our hearts go out to those newly unemployed people, but what we really want to know is: how big is the sale?
fields.body: There's trouble in e-paradise: much-hyped sportswear site boo.com is cutting staff, with a view to downshifting to a more low-tech site. Yes, our hearts go out to those newly unemployed people, but what we really want to know is: how big is the sale? The short answer is MASSIVE. All items are reduced by 40% until February 10, so it's open season on designer sports gear. Highlights include a funky crew-neck dress from Fred Perry, was £35, now £21, which would look fantastic with the Rocket Girl Swoosh Hoodie, reduced from £38 to £22.80. For blokes, burgundy leather sneakers by Jil Sander are reduced from £120 to £72. Bargains galore, so long as you're not paying for the time it takes to navigate this stylish but ultimately snail-like website.

fields.headline: Joining the dots
fields.standfirst: Art. Fashion. Installation. Inspiration. At 71, Yayoi Kusama is still in a creative class of her own .  Tamasin Doe  pays tribute
fields.trailText: Art. Fashion. Installation. Inspiration. At 71, Yayoi Kusama is still in a creative class of her own .
fields.body:
A golden evening bag encrusted with pasta rather than gems; a cotton shirt-waist dress garnished with artificial flowers then dipped in silver paint; a yellow dress spotted with giant black dots so that it disappears into a background of similarly decorated giant inflatable worms. No, not the first collection of an avant-garde Belgian couturier but part of the seductive world of artist Yayoi Kusama, now on show at London's Serpentine Gallery.

Although costume is only one part of Kusama's vision, it spanks the bottom of fashion's self-declared mavericks. The bag and dress both date from the mid-60s and echoes of her work - including the crusty silver paint recently revived by Martin Margiela - are still turning up. "My costumes invariably suggest the path of the new generation," Kusama says.

She was born in Matsumoto City, Japan, in 1929, to a conservative, wealthy family. But at the age of 10, her life changed irrevocably when she saw hallucinatory patterns descend and cloak the world around her. These patterns became an important part of her work, in the form of her signature polka dots and "infinity nets", formed from painstakingly applied painted blobs.

Her fixation with the act of disappearance - and her own fear of vanishing - stem from obsessional neurosis, a mental disorder that has for over 50 years directed Kusama's work, which she calls "art therapy". In a bid to exorcise her obsession with disappearing, Kusama has repeatedly placed herself within her installations wearing co-ordinated outfits. These have included dresses and shoes sewn over with padded phalluses - part fashion, part soft sculpture.

Clothes were an early vehicle for her self-expression. "The history of my costume dates back to my teens," she explains. "Whenever I wore unusual and wild clothes, [people] either ostracised me or spoke ill of me." In the fine tradition of intergenerational angst, Kusama's parents forbade her to leave the house wearing her more avant-garde innovations. But leave she did: in an unusually brave act for a Japanese woman, she travelled to New York in 1958, against her parents' wishes. Having connected with other artists, Kusama showed alongside Claes Oldenburg and Andy Warhol in New York, Yves Klein in Paris.

At the centre of her new world Kusama, who had rejected the traditional trappings of her culture, started to use the kimono as part of her personal branding and to make herself visible. Gilda Williams, commissioning editor of contemporary art at Phaidon, which has published a monograph to coincide with the Serpentine show, explains: "She knew the value of her exoticism in that period. She would use the kimono as her advertisement."

Kusama eventually took that impulse to its logical conclusion and did what New Yorkers do: translated her art into business. She shared with Warhol the knowledge that sensational events designed to hold the interest of the media were an unbeatable way to distribute ideas. Throughout the 60s, she merged art with popular impact, notably in a 1966 photomontage that shows her naked but for a pair of shoes and the inevitable polka dots, lying on a sofa studded with phallic protuberances.

In 1968, Kusama Enterprises Inc was set up to market "films, environments, theatrical presentations, paintings, sculpture, Happenings, events, fashions and body painting". Nicknamed "Dotty" by the press, because of her mental state and her favourite pattern, Kusama presided over naked public performances in which she would decorate her subjects with polka dots and exhort onlookers to strip. For Homosexual Wedding in 1968 - claimed to be the first in the US - Kusama performed the ceremony while the bride and groom wore a "fantastic 'orgy' wedding gown designed for two. Clothes ought to bring people together, not separate them," raved the publicity material.

The Kusama Fashion Institute became equally notorious and invited the world to one of the strangest fashion shows. As a press release promised: "See my 'Peekaboo,' 'See-Through' and 'Open' pants in the cloth and the flesh. There are holes all over - holes that radiate life-giving energy - part of my Holy War against the establishment."

At the age of 71, Kusama still inspires designers. Issey Miyake recently chose her to take part in a fashion performance at France's embassy in Tokyo. Kusama took a can of fluorescent paint to one of his outfits to create the illusion of glow-in-the-dark dots moving independently. Along with Miyake (whom she calls an "avant-garde artist"), Rei Kawakubo and Yohji Yamamoto, Kusama is part of a Japanese tradition that assimilates western fashion customs and sends them back in an improved form. Kusama describes her work within fashion as creating "the costumes to wear thought", meaning that she sews a statement into each seam. She still designs her own clothes, though they now tend to be simpler, less aggressive.

These days, Yayoi Kusama divides her life between her Tokyo studio and an institution at which she stays voluntarily. Regarded as a national treasure, she is also one of the country's most fashionable artists, idolised especially by designers who still have a lot to learn at her knee.

Yayoi Kusama is at the Serpentine Gallery, 0171 298 1515, until March 19. Tamasin Doe is editor of Sceneonline.com
fields.bodyText: A golden evening bag encrusted with pasta rather than gems; a cotton shirt-waist dress garnished with artificial flowers then dipped in silver paint; a yellow dress spotted with giant black dots so that it disappears into a background of similarly decorated giant inflatable worms. No, not the first collection of an avant-garde Belgian couturier but part of the seductive world of artist Yayoi Kusama, now on show at London's Serpentine Gallery. Although costume is only one part of Kusama's vision, it spanks the bottom of fashion's self-declared mavericks. The bag and dress both date from the mid-60s and echoes of her work - including the crusty silver paint recently revived by Martin Margiela - are still turning up. "My costumes invariably suggest the path of the new generation," Kusama says. She was born in Matsumoto City, Japan, in 1929, to a conservative, wealthy family. But at the age of 10, her life changed irrevocably when she saw hallucinatory patterns descend and cloak the world around her. These patterns became an important part of her work, in the form of her signature polka dots and "infinity nets", formed from painstakingly applied painted blobs. Her fixation with the act of disappearance - and her own fear of vanishing - stem from obsessional neurosis, a mental disorder that has for over 50 years directed Kusama's work, which she calls "art therapy". In a bid to exorcise her obsession with disappearing, Kusama has repeatedly placed herself within her installations wearing co-ordinated outfits. These have included dresses and shoes sewn over with padded phalluses - part fashion, part soft sculpture. Clothes were an early vehicle for her self-expression. "The history of my costume dates back to my teens," she explains. "Whenever I wore unusual and wild clothes, [people] either ostracised me or spoke ill of me." In the fine tradition of intergenerational angst, Kusama's parents forbade her to leave the house wearing her more avant-garde innovations. But leave she did: in an unusually brave act for a Japanese woman, she travelled to New York in 1958, against her parents' wishes. Having connected with other artists, Kusama showed alongside Claes Oldenburg and Andy Warhol in New York, Yves Klein in Paris. At the centre of her new world Kusama, who had rejected the traditional trappings of her culture, started to use the kimono as part of her personal branding and to make herself visible. Gilda Williams, commissioning editor of contemporary art at Phaidon, which has published a monograph to coincide with the Serpentine show, explains: "She knew the value of her exoticism in that period. She would use the kimono as her advertisement." Kusama eventually took that impulse to its logical conclusion and did what New Yorkers do: translated her art into business. She shared with Warhol the knowledge that sensational events designed to hold the interest of the media were an unbeatable way to distribute ideas. Throughout the 60s, she merged art with popular impact, notably in a 1966 photomontage that shows her naked but for a pair of shoes and the inevitable polka dots, lying on a sofa studded with phallic protuberances. fields.headline: Most everywhere:  karma beads
fields.trailText: When life sucks, we all require a remedy to lift our spirits and instead of turning to the bottle - or, worse, counselling - fashion bods today are donning karma beads.
fields.body:
When life sucks, we all require a remedy to lift our spirits and instead of turning to the bottle - or, worse, counselling - fashion bods today are donning karma beads. These small, smooth glass beads were first used by Buddhists to bring good karma to particular areas of life, with different coloured beads representing different aspects, for example red=love, black=courage, green=wealth. Everybody knows January is the month in which we all need as much good karma as we can get, which is probably why these beads have been spotted adorning the wrists of fashion's great and good. Normally sane-minded women have, it appears, ditched horoscopes as their destiny determiner of choice and are now piling as many different coloured bracelets on their arm as possible. For sceptics out there who don't believe good luck can be beckoned by a bracelet, wear one anyway - they're perfect for fiddling with as you work and far more modish than last year's stringy bits of leather.

Karma beads are available from £3 from Claire's Accessories, 0121 682 8000.
