fields.headline: Anything goes
fields.standfirst: Want to dress up? Great. Want to dress down? No problem. Black? Perfect. Green? Go for it. The message from the Paris menswear collections is simple: next winter, a man can wear whatever he wants.
fields.trailText: Want to dress up? Great. Want to dress down? No problem. Black? Perfect. Green? Go for it. The message from the Paris menswear collections is simple: next winter, a man can wear whatever he wants.
fields.body:
Milan may be the city where global trends are spawned, but it's Paris you turn to for freedom of choice and individuality. After viewing this week's menswear collections, it's fair to say there isn't exactly one big trend being pushed for autumn/winter. Whether you prefer to dapper up or dress down, experiment with colour or fall back on black, look to luxury or play it low-key, there was something to suit even the fussiest man.

Paul Smith, the British designer who takes pride in offering personalised detailing within an eclectic cultural mix, summed up the mood with a collection that took Anglo tradition and melded it with techniques and influences gathered from Hungary, India and China. Whether it be a single button sewn on to a shirt with mismatched thread, a scarf that has taken one artisan 20 days to embroider by hand, or a shirt constructed entirely from army surplus handkerchiefs, Smith's imagination can only be admired. This was one of the designer's strongest collections for some time and while its presentation was a little long-winded and over-styled, individual items such as a tailored sheepskin jacket, washed harlequin-patterned sweater and plaid plus fours were truly covetable.

Dries Van Noten dispensed with his usual catwalk presentation in favour of showing his collection on a one-to-one basis from his showroom. Two rooms lined with rails of clothes enabled his faithful followers to feel the fabrics and play at dressing up, putting together their own combinations from the never-ending wardrobe of Dries classics. Taking the Bloomsbury era as his inspiration, the Belgian designer came up with one of his best collections to date, including shrunken sweaters in cashmere, repaired with patches or Argyll, tweedy coats worn by time and chunky knit scarves which trailed the floor in blocks of colour.

Designed by Alexander van Slobbe, So moved on from the uniformed minimalist styling of the past few seasons: in its place came felted wool jackets splattered with avant-garde prints by young Dutch artists. Second-hand sports T-shirts were taken apart and restructured under jackets that had a military feel and worn with textured trousers that had a slight kick at the ankle.

Recycling was also the focus for Rei Kawakubo's collection at Comme des Garçons. Jackets and sweaters in shrunken sizes were dismantled and used as two-dimensional appliquéd panels over garments that fitted the body snugly. Pleated tartan trousers were cut away at the back and replaced with the backs of marl jersey jogging bottoms. Kawakubo's playful experiments with colour and mismatched plaids are beginning to look a little tired; her boxy suiting silhouettes are not in tune with the sympathetic lines of the luxury tailoring so prevalent this season.

The Anglo-Saxon teen angst that once gave Raf Simons his unique appeal (think Joy Division mixed with sixth-former school uniform) is the very same inspiration that will eventually be the Belgian designer's downfall. Simons' signature style, with its evocations of early 80s British suburbia, seems to have run its course. He should move on, but instead he stuck to a tried and tested formula, with slim-cut suits in black and ash grey felt, school shirts and sweaters in Oxford blue. More inspiring were corduroy Harrington jackets, kimono-sleeved blousons and a vicar's coat in heavy black cashmere.

Roy Krejberg's first go-it-alone collection for Kenzo looks set to be a commercial success. Using predominantly natural fabrics, it was not a great departure from the signature style established by Kenzo himself (who retired in October last year) but seemed younger and more in tune with current tastes. A lot is planned for the Kenzo label for the near future, including new stores and a sportswear line headed by British designer Jeff Griffin.

Hermès offered its usual brand of luxury dressing, but this time it was more pared down and youthful. Other than the pedigree tailoring we have come to expect from the label, shearling jackets (the fur dyed the signature Hermès orange) and velvet suits in violet, apple green or citrus tones should appeal to a new customer.

Yohji Yamamoto also looked more modern. Suits pieced together from angular patchworks of fabric in primary colours offered a much-needed injection of quirkiness into what was otherwise Yamamoto's most commercial collection for some time.

Three designers from the contingent of young labels showing in Paris really shone. German-based Kostas Murkudis showed an edgy take on androgynous dressing, inspired by Native Americans. Dirk Schonberger, Belgium's latest export, showed military clothing mixed with subtle tailoring checks. And Xavier Delcour, designing under the label Only For Men, staged the second best show of the week, fusing raw-edged deconstruction with polished sophistication. He looks like one of the most exciting young bloods to come out of Europe in quite some time.

The two most eagerly anticipated shows in town proved to be poles apart, style-wise. Marc Jacobs, in his debut menswear catwalk show for Louis Vuitton, and Hedi Slimane at Yves Saint Laurent Rive Gauche were the two primary reasons for coming to Paris. Vuitton, with its overstyling of staid classic bourgeois menswear, was disappointing. Jacobs' collection was described as "for the jetset man who is international" - my advice to this jetset man would be to stay at home. Yves Saint Laurent Rive Gauche, however, was a rare fashion moment. Never has menswear looked so luxurious without being untouchable, sexy without being crass, innovative without paying bland respect to a heritage. Black leather frock coats, belted chemises, patent astro-turf coats and luxurious woollens made this Slimane's finest collection to date. Entitled Black Tie (everything was black except for a finale of gold jeans and mauve silk jersey tops), it was a masterclass in cutting. Menswear does not get much better than this and while speculation may surround Slimane's future now that Gucci has taken control of the label, let's hope that Tom Ford has the sense not to fix what isn't broken.

Adrian Clark is fashion director of Attitude.

fields.headline: Diplomacy for democracy
fields.standfirst: Robin Cook's full speech, part II
fields.trailText: We have done much to promote British values of democracy and freedom.
fields.body:
We have done much to promote British values of democracy and freedom.

We have given a new priority to human rights. We now run projects to give practical support to human rights from developing village democracy in China to fighting sexual exploitation in the Philippines. We have launched a global programme to challenge torture and to help its victims. We have dropped the previous government's refusal to lobby against the use of the death penalty. We now consistently oppose its use. We have turned the UK into a leading advocate for the international criminal court. We have been robust in detaining war criminals in Bosnia, and we give wider support to the war crimes tribunals than any other single nation. We have introduced tough new criteria on arms sales and secured a European Code of Conduct which extends similar standards to our partners, and competitors, in the European Union. We have also introduced a detailed annual report which makes the UK more transparent on arms exports than any other European nation.

But the clearest contrast is between the long years of temporising with Milosevic which marked the response to ethnic cleansing in Bosnia, and our defeat of his attempt to do the same in Kosovo. The Kosovar Albanians may have witnessed many appalling scenes. But at least they were spared the sight of the international community tolerating the oppression which produced the massacre of Srebrenica. And they have been spared the long-term consequences of such temporising: six months after the Kosovo conflict, most Kosovar refugees have returned home; four years after Dayton, the majority of Bosnian refugees still have not.

I am content to leave the last word on our record to Amnesty whose recent report concluded that this government 'has made a genuine and active commitment to human rights'. Not many governments can quote with satisfaction the verdict of Amnesty International.

Promoting human rights

Curiously, it is our pursuit of diplomacy for democracy that has proved the most controversial part of our foreign policy. The proposition that there should be a place for promoting human rights within foreign policy is one that would produce consensus not controversy in North America or most other European countries. There is no need for this to be a matter of partisan politics in Britain either. Let me therefore deal with the two most common lines of attack.

My reply to them is not a fresh invention. I anticipated both of them when I set out our commitment on human rights within a month of taking office.

The first line of attack is that our democratic values and our national interests are doomed to conflict in foreign policy that we must choose between promoting our values or pursuing our interests. Whether that was ever true in the past I leave to historians to debate. But those who advance that view are still living in the past. In the global age it is in Britain's national interest to promote British values of freedom and democracy.

Along with authoritarian government come corruption and arbitrary government. What trade and investment require is competition, transparency and the rule of law. All are more easily built on an open society and accountable government.

governments which respect freedom of expression are more likely to provide the transparency to be secure trading partners. Countries which observe the rule of law at home are more likely to accept their international obligations to fight the drugs trade or halt weapons proliferation.

Promoting our values enhances our prosperity, and reinforces our security.

The second line of attack is even more specious. It claims that, because we cannot put everything right, it is inconsistent to try to put anything right. This is not a maxim which we follow in any other walk of life, else we would be reduced to permanent paralysis. Nor should we let it bring foreign policy to a halt.

I flatly reject the cynical view that, because we cannot make the world perfect, we should give up on trying to make it better. The obligation on us is not to put everything right, but to do what we can to make a difference. We will therefore take every realistic, responsible step to pursue diplomacy for democracy.

The advances we secure may seem modest when set against the global scale of human oppression. But they do not seem negligible to those who gain in freedom as a result. I have heard it argued that, because it is not sensible to intervene in Chechnya, we should not have intervened in Kosovo. I would like to be present if those who argue that counsel of defeatism ever have the courage to advance it to an audience of Kosovar Albanians who know that the net result would have been to leave up to a million of them throughout this winter homeless in Macedonia and Albania. Or to audiences in East Timor who know they would not now be independent without the help of an international coalition of which Britain was a prominent member.

Shopping before Christmas I was approached by a man who said reflectively above the Christmas jingles, "You're doing as good a job as we can hope for in the real world". I am content to accept that judgement as much more balanced and mature than those commentators who demand perfection or nothing.

Interventional

The biggest unresolved question in upholding universal values is when is it right for the international community to intervene and who decides that it is right? The United Nations Charter declares that 'armed force shall not be used, save in the common interest'. But what is the common interest, and who shall define it? We need to establish new rules of the road.

The UK has submitted to the UN secretary-general in response to those questions a set of ideas to help the international community decide when it is right to act.

first, any intervention is by definition a failure of prevention. Force should always be the last resort; second, the immediate responsibility for halting violence rests with the state in which it occurs; but, third, when faced with an overwhelming humanitarian catastrophe and a government that has demonstrated itself unwilling or unable to halt or prevent it, the international community should act; and finally, any use of force in this context should be collective, proportionate, likely to achieve its objective, and carried out in accordance with international law.

Britain will be seeking the broadest possible agreement on these principles to take forward the debate on intervention at the UN Millennium Summit in the autumn.

Stronger in Europe, stronger in the world

critical engagement, enlightened self-interest and diplomacy for democracy provide a foreign policy through which we can best pursue Britain's national interests.

Those national interests girdle the globe. The diplomatic strategy I have outlined is pursued in every continent. But the stronger Britain's standing in our own continent of Europe, the greater the leverage we will have in the other six.

This is such a self-evident proposition that it is surprising it needs to be stated. Yet there are a number of people who seem to believe that the UK can project a foreign policy that goes all the way round the world without passing through Europe.

Any sane foreign policy must start by accepting the facts of geography. Europe is where we belong. We cannot opt by political levitation to belong to another continent. As someone once famously said, there is no alternative. As one of her Foreign Secretaries, Lord Carrington, wrote in his memoirs, "Britain's destiny is Europe".

The most strategic shift that the present government has brought to foreign policy has been to take Britain off the sidelines of Europe and into the front row of the team. The result has been to transform Britain's standing not just in Europe, but around the world.

It used to be argued that a stronger relationship with Europe would weaken our relationship with America. The converse is the truth. This government has built a remarkable partnership with Washington because the Administration know they are now dealing with a British government that can deliver in Europe. We could not have played the role that we did during the Kosovo crisis in promoting the cohesion and resolve of the Alliance on both sides of the Atlantic if we had not first secured respect in Europe.

Nor is it only in Washington that our standing rises with our influence in Europe. In the Middle East last week I was struck by the extent to which Britain is valued because we can now be a leading advocate of the Middle East peace process within the European Union. From Japan we hear repeated messages that they value their economic ties with Britain precisely because it is a gateway to the wider European market.

That market is about to become even wider as a result of European Re-union with the countries of central and eastern Europe. A European Union stretching from Portugal to Poland, and from Estonia to Cyprus, will soon be a reality. Simply to contemplate such an immense partnership of European nations is to recognise the necessity of Britain being part of it.

And not a semi-detached member of it. There is no point being half-in, half-out. A half-hearted Britain would deliver only half our interests in Europe. The best way to secure Britain's national interests in Europe, and to promote those interests around the rest of the world, is for us to be recognised as a leading player in Europe.

The European Union is one of the most successful models yet devised for coping with an age in which nations are more interdependent than they are independent. It has reinforced mutual respect for the borders between nations. But at the same time, it has dismantled borders as barriers between people and between businesses. Only those who have a psychological need for the comfort blanket of protection from the outside world should fear the result as a threat.

To the great mass of the British people the Union has offered new opportunities:

the Single Market gives them a better prospect of a job and prosperity. UK exports to the rest of the European Union as a share of GDP have nearly doubled since we joined; the right to move and work freely is the reason why at any one time a hundred thousand of our citizens earn their living in the continental EU; common standards guarantee our consumers the quality and safety of goods in their shops. Our businesses gain from manufacturing for a single European standard rather than fifteen different national ones; enhanced cooperation between police forces and customs has strengthened the fight against cross border crime. In the past two years joint operations have led to big seizures of drugs on their way to Britain; tougher pollution controls have preserved our environment and improved the quality of life of our people. From greenhouse gases to acid rain, the European Union is an essential forum for ensuring that pollution in one country does not undermine the efforts of its neighbours.

To complain that all these benefits infringe our right to unilateral action is pointless. These gains for our people could not have been secured by unilateral action by us alone.

None of them would have been possible without agreements binding on our partners as well as ourselves. Objectively it is the eurosceptics who are undermining the national interest by opposing constructive engagement with Europe. Constructive engagement is the best strategy to deliver benefits for the British people.

We apply the same approach in formulating our policy on the single currency. We believe that Britain would benefit from joining a successful Euro, provided our five tests were met. It would be justified if it made our economy stronger and more prosperous. It is a policy firmly rooted in the national interest. It is the eurosceptics who ignore that national interest by foreclosing for ever the option of joining the euro, even if it served Britain's real economic needs.

Ironically, it is those who most stridently oppose the process of European integration who most loudly proclaim their support for NATO. The UK has indeed gained half a century of unprecedented security from NATO, an Alliance forged under a Labour government. But, to achieve that gain in security, NATO requires a pooling of sovereignty in the area most sensitive for traditional concepts of national identity. Allies have to commit themselves to collective defence, accept each other's troops on their territory, and place their armies under joint command. Surely, if it is desirable to pool sovereignty to obtain military security, it must also be sensible to pool sovereignty to create jobs, to protect our environment or to defeat cross-border crime.

None of this means the end of the nation state. On the contrary, the age of globalisation has been paralleled by strong assertions of national identity and culture. A healthy democracy needs the social cohesion provided by national identity if its minority are to accept those elected by the majority as their legitimate representatives. That is why Gerhard Schroeder rightly told his party congress last month that the nation state will be the centre of people's hopes and needs. And why Jacques Chirac has said Europe's future is not a United States of Europe but a United Europe of States.

Conclusion

Last year, I heard Kofi Annan making a moving speech in which he told the UN general assembly that:

'As the world has changed in profound ways since the end of the cold war, I believe our conceptions of national interest have failed to follow suit. (We need) a new, more broadly defined definition of national interest.... A global era requires global engagement. Indeed, in a growing number of challenges facing humanity, the collective interest is the national interest.'

I believe Kofi is right. The new forces of globalisation offer immense prospects for progress. Those prospects will be fulfilled only if we take every opportunity to pursue our national interest through a foreign policy that also meets the international interest.

We have introduced tough new criteria on arms sales and secured a European Code of Conduct which extends similar standards to our partners, and competitors, in the European Union. We have also introduced a detailed annual report which makes the UK more transparent on arms exports than any other European nation. But the clearest contrast is between the long years of temporising with Milosevic which marked the response to ethnic cleansing in Bosnia, and our defeat of his attempt to do the same in Kosovo. The Kosovar Albanians may have witnessed many appalling scenes. But at least they were spared the sight of the international community tolerating the oppression which produced the massacre of Srebrenica. And they have been spared the long-term consequences of such temporising: six months after the Kosovo conflict, most Kosovar refugees have returned home; four years after Dayton, the majority of Bosnian refugees still have not. I am content to leave the last word on our record to Amnesty whose recent report concluded that this government 'has made a genuine and active commitment to human rights'. Not many governments can quote with satisfaction the verdict of Amnesty International. Promoting human rights Curiously, it is our pursuit of diplomacy for democracy that has proved the most controversial part of our foreign policy. The proposition that there should be a place for promoting human rights within foreign policy is one that would produce consensus not controversy in North America or most other European countries. There is no need for this to be a matter of partisan politics in Britain either. Let me therefore deal with the two most common lines of attack. My reply to them is not a fresh invention. I anticipated both of them when I set out our commitment on human rights within a month of taking office. The first line of attack is that our democratic values and our national interests are doomed to conflict in foreign policy that we must choose between promoting our values or pursuing our interests. Whether that was ever true in the past I leave to historians to debate. But those who advance that view are still living in the past. In the global age it is in Britain's national interest to promote British values of freedom and democracy. Along with authoritarian government come corruption and arbitrary government. What trade and investment require is competition, transparency and the rule of law. All are more easily built on an open society and accountable government. governments which respect freedom of expression are more likely to provide the transparency to be secure trading partners. Countries which observe the rule of law at home are more likely to accept their international obligations to fight the drugs trade or halt weapons proliferation. Promoting our values enhances our prosperity, and reinforces our security. The second line of attack is even more specious. It claims that, because we cannot put everything right, it is inconsistent to try to put anything right. This is not a maxim which we follow in any other walk of life, else we would be reduced to permanent paralysis. Nor should we let it bring foreign policy to a halt. I flatly reject the cynical view that, because we cannot make the world perfect, we should give up on trying to make it better. The obligation on us is not to put everything right, but to do what we can to make a difference. We will therefore take every realistic, responsible step to pursue diplomacy for democracy. The advances we secure may seem modest when set against the global scale of human oppression. But they do not seem negligible to those who gain in freedom as a result. I have heard it argued that, because it is not sensible to intervene in Chechnya, we should not have intervened in Kosovo. I would like to be present if those who argue that counsel of defeatism ever have the courage to advance it to an audience of Kosovar Albanians who know that the net result would have been to leave up to a million of them throughout this winter homeless in Macedonia and Albania. Or to audiences in East Timor who know they would not now be independent without the help of an international coalition of which Britain was a prominent member. Shopping before Christmas I was approached by a man who said reflectively above the Christmas jingles, "You're doing as good a job as we can hope for in the real world". I am content to accept that judgement as much more balanced and mature than those commentators who demand perfection or nothing. Interventional The biggest unresolved question in upholding universal values is when is it right for the international community to intervene and who decides that it is right? The United Nations Charter declares that 'armed force shall not be used, save in the common interest'. But what is the common interest, and who shall define it? We need to establish new rules of the road. The UK has submitted to the UN secretary-general in response to those questions a set of ideas to help the international community decide when it is right to act. first, any intervention is by definition a failure of prevention. Force should always be the last resort; second, the immediate responsibility for halting violence rests with the state in which it occurs; but, third, when faced with an overwhelming humanitarian catastrophe and a government that has demonstrated itself unwilling or unable to halt or prevent it, the international community should act; and finally, any use of force in this context should be collective, proportionate, likely to achieve its objective, and carried out in accordance with international law. Britain will be seeking the broadest possible agreement on these principles to take forward the debate on intervention at the UN Millennium Summit in the autumn. Stronger in Europe, stronger in the world critical engagement, enlightened self-interest and diplomacy for democracy provide a foreign policy through which we can best pursue Britain's national interests. Those national interests girdle the globe. The diplomatic strategy I have outlined is pursued in every continent. But the stronger Britain's standing in our own continent of Europe, the greater the leverage we will have in the other six. This is such a self-evident proposition that it is surprising it needs to be stated. Yet there are a number of people who seem to believe that the UK can project a foreign policy that goes all the way round the world without passing through Europe. Any sane foreign policy must start by accepting the facts of geography. Europe is where we belong. We cannot opt by political levitation to belong to another continent. As someone once famously said, there is no alternative. As one of her Foreign Secretaries, Lord Carrington, wrote in his memoirs, "Britain's destiny is Europe". The most strategic shift that the present government has brought to foreign policy has been to take Britain off the sidelines of Europe and into the front row of the team. The result has been to transform Britain's standing not just in Europe, but around the world. It used to be argued that a stronger relationship with Europe would weaken our relationship with America. The converse is the truth. This government has built a remarkable partnership with Washington because the Administration know they are now dealing with a British government that can deliver in Europe. We could not have played the role that we did during the Kosovo crisis in promoting the cohesion and resolve of the Alliance on both sides of the Atlantic if we had not first secured respect in Europe. Nor is it only in Washington that our standing rises with our influence in Europe. In the Middle East last week I was struck by the extent to which Britain is valued because we can now be a leading advocate of the Middle East peace process within the European Union. From Japan we hear repeated messages that they value their economic ties with Britain precisely because it is a gateway to the wider European market. That market is about to become even wider as a result of European Re-union with the countries of central and eastern Europe. A European Union stretching from Portugal to Poland, and from Estonia to Cyprus, will soon be a reality. Simply to contemplate such an immense partnership of European nations is to recognise the necessity of Britain being part of it. And not a semi-detached member of it. There is no point being half-in, half-out. A half-hearted Britain would deliver only half our interests in Europe. The best way to secure Britain's national interests in Europe, and to promote those interests around the rest of the world, is for us to be recognised as a leading player in Europe. The European Union is one of the most successful models yet devised for coping with an age in which nations are more interdependent than they are independent. It has reinforced mutual respect for the borders between nations. But at the same time, it has dismantled borders as barriers between people and between businesses. Only those who have a psychological need for the comfort blanket of protection from the outside world should fear the result as a threat. To the great mass of the British people the Union has offered new opportunities: the Single Market gives them a better prospect of a job and prosperity. UK exports to the rest of the European Union as a share of GDP have nearly doubled since we joined; the right to move and work freely is the reason why at any one time a hundred thousand of our citizens earn their living in the continental EU; common standards guarantee our consumers the quality and safety of goods in their shops. Our businesses gain from manufacturing for a single European standard rather than fifteen different national ones; enhanced cooperation between police forces and customs has strengthened the fight against cross border crime. In the past two years joint operations have led to big seizures of drugs on their way to Britain; tougher pollution controls have preserved our environment and improved the quality of life of our people. From greenhouse gases to acid rain, the European Union is an essential forum for ensuring that pollution in one country does not undermine the efforts of its neighbours. To complain that all these benefits infringe our right to unilateral action is pointless. These gains for our people could not have been secured by unilateral action by us alone. None of them would have been possible without agreements binding on our partners as well as ourselves. Objectively it is the eurosceptics who are undermining the national interest by opposing constructive engagement with Europe. Constructive engagement is the best strategy to deliver benefits for the British people. We apply the same approach in formulating our policy on the single currency. We believe that Britain would benefit from joining a successful Euro, provided our five tests were met. It would be justified if it made our economy stronger and more prosperous. It is a policy firmly rooted in the national interest. It is the eurosceptics who ignore that national interest by foreclosing for ever the option of joining the euro, even if it served Britain's real economic needs. Ironically, it is those who most stridently oppose the process of European integration who most loudly proclaim their support for NATO. The UK has indeed gained half a century of unprecedented security from NATO, an Alliance forged under a Labour government. But, to achieve that gain in security, NATO requires a pooling of sovereignty in the area most sensitive for traditional concepts of national identity. Allies have to commit themselves to collective defence, accept each other's troops on their territory, and place their armies under joint command. Surely, if it is desirable to pool sovereignty to obtain military security, it must also be sensible to pool sovereignty to create jobs, to protect our environment or to defeat cross-border crime. None of this means the end of the nation state. On the contrary, the age of globalisation has been paralleled by strong assertions of national identity and culture. A healthy democracy needs the social cohesion provided by national identity if its minority are to accept those elected by the majority as their legitimate representatives. That is why Gerhard Schroeder rightly told his party congress last month that the nation state will be the centre of people's hopes and needs. And why Jacques Chirac has said Europe's future is not a United States of Europe but a United Europe of States. Conclusion Last year, I heard Kofi Annan making a moving speech in which he told the UN general assembly that: 'As the world has changed in profound ways since the end of the cold war, I believe our conceptions of national interest have failed to follow suit. (We need) a new, more broadly defined definition of national interest.... A global era requires global engagement. Indeed, in a growing number of challenges facing humanity, the collective interest is the national interest.' I believe Kofi is right. The new forces of globalisation offer immense prospects for progress. Those prospects will be fulfilled only if we take every opportunity to pursue our national interest through a foreign policy that also meets the international interest.

fields.body:
The global context

We have just celebrated the advent of a new millennium. Some people contend that we celebrated one year early. But in foreign policy, we celebrated the new era ten years too late. Movements in geo-political forces do not arrange themselves around convenient points in the calendar.

In international relations, the new century began in 1989 when the Berlin Wall came down. The cold war had divided much of the world and most of its GDP into two hostile camps. Its sudden end has coincided with a revolution in communications technology which has united many of the same countries in one global economy.

It was fashionable in the past decade to debate whether this century would be America's century, or Japan's century, or maybe even Europe's century. In reality, it is going to be the internationalist century.

Economic growth is dominated by global trade which is expanding at triple the rate of output. The integration of financial markets is such that both investors and workers can find themselves ruined overnight because of upsets in banking systems on the far side of the globe. No national economy is now an island.

The growth curve in communications is ultra-exponential. In the US, the world wide web has attracted 50 million users in four years: to do the same took television 13 years and radio 38. Access to information on the internet expands by a million pages every day.

The extraordinary capacity of the new technology to communicate instantly, and cheaply, around the globe has produced the "death of distance" as the defining barrier between states and continents. It also makes it harder for authoritarian regimes to co-exist with modern economies. Even the most vigilant border guard is unable to challenge the mighty click of a mouse.

It is a curiosity of semantics that the word 'internationalism' produces a favourable reaction, except on the wilder shores of reactionary isolationism. But the word "globalisation" generally provokes a wary, if not hostile, reaction. If you asked me whether I am in favour of globalisation, I would give broadly the same answer as Tom Friedman.

My attitude to globalisation is much the same as my attitude to the dawn. On balance, I think it is a good thing that the sun rises every day. But I also know there is nothing I can do to stop it even if I wanted to. Similarly, the only rational response to globalisation is to pursue strategies that maximise benefits and minimise damage.

Goals and principles

What then is the foreign policy that helps deliver the benefits of globalisation and deflect its damage to Britain?

The purpose of our foreign policy is to pursue our national interests. In broad terms, those national interests are the four objectives I set out in the mission statement for the foreign office in this parliament:


 promoting prosperity through trade and the British economy;
 ensuring the security of the United Kingdom;
 enhancing the quality of life of people through global diplomacy on environment, the drugs trade and cross-border crime; and
 building respect for our values by supporting human rights and freedom

How the foreign office promotes those national interests requires us to understand the modern world, and produce a strategy that relates to the world as it will be in this new century, not as it was in the last.

I propose four guiding principles that can help us shape a foreign policy for the internationalist century:


 globalisation requires more bridges and fewer barriers;
 the global interest is becoming the national interest;
 the global community needs universal values; and
 the stronger Britain's standing in our own continent, the greater the leverage we will have in the other six.

Bridges not barriers

For diplomacy the starting point must be that globalisation requires bridges and removes barriers. A policy of containment is a difficult strategy in the age of the fibre-optic cable, the jumbo jet and the satellite dish. There will always be the exception, such as the murderous regime in Iraq where the only safe strategy is to keep it in the isolation ward until it accepts the norms of international behaviour. Or the military dictatorship in Burma which has persistently failed to respond to dialogue. It takes two to critically engage.

Critical engagement

But as a general rule it is increasingly hard to bar the multiple doors that globalisation forces open. We have therefore adopted a conscious policy of critical engagement - the pursuit of political dialogue wherever it can produce benefits.

This strategy of critical engagement has produced practical gains for British interests. For instance, with Argentina, we hosted a visit of reconciliation by former President Menem. We followed it up with an agreement that puts communications between Argentina and the Falklands on a secure basis.

We are robustly committed to the long-standing policy that the Falkland Islands will be British so long as their residents wish it. But, the more we build confidence between ourselves and Argentina, the greater the security we can offer the islanders.

Critical engagement in other cases may require involvement without illusions about the regimes with which we negotiate.

With Libya, we have secured the handover of the two Lockerbie suspects and compensation for the killing of WPC Fletcher. We have returned a British ambassador to Tripoli after fifteen years, enhancing our capacity to promote British interests there and to register our concerns.

With Iran, we have obtained a commitment from the government that they will not carry out the fatwa nor help others to do so. Once again, we have an ambassador in Tehran. That does not mean we have stopped having concerns about a number of policies of Iran, nor that we have stopped expressing them frankly. But it must be right to respond to the growing popular demands within Iran for modernisation and moderation.

With Cuba, I have had the first formal meeting with a Cuban foreign minister since the Castro revolution forty years ago. We retain deep concerns about human rights in Cuba. But we are more likely to make progress if Cuba is more open to the world, and the world more open to Cuba.

Such dialogues can be uncomfortable to those who believe we best preserve the purity of our commitment to human rights by refusing to talk to the very regimes that need to hear our message. Such a policy may leave us with clean hands. But is unlikely to provide their people with better rights.

Dialogue of civilisations

One strength that Britain brings to the task of bridge-building is that modern Britain is a multi-faith, multi-cultural society. Here in London some 200 different languages are spoken. We must use this rich cultural advantage and experience of tolerance to promote tolerance abroad.

Globalisation foreshortens the landscape of diplomacy. Europe and the Middle East are now near neighbours. Last week in Cairo I called upon the Grand Shaikh of Al-Azhar. He quoted to me the verse in the Koran which provides an injunction to tolerance:

"We created you from a single pair of male and female and made you into nations and tribes, that you may know each other, not that you may despise each other."

It is a fallacy to imagine our two civilisations as separate rather than entwined. In the computer age, we should not forget that we still count in Arabic numerals.

Globalisation throws us into intimate and frequent contact with other civilisations. The ultimate test of diplomacy will be whether we can turn contact with other faiths, cultures, and cuisines, to enriching the lives of our people and whether we can diminish its potential to provoke friction, violence or conflict.

Russia

The biggest question for critical engagement is how we can accommodate post-Soviet Russia into European structures. From Peter the Great and the boyars to Stalin and Trotsky, a dominant theme of Russian politics has been the tension between those who wanted to build a fortress Russia and those who recognised that Russia must engage with the world beyond its borders.

Shorn of its colourful episodes, Yeltsin's Presidency will be respected for burying the cold war and establishing Russia as a fully committed player in international forums such as the G8. Yet there remains in Russia a large audience for the old-fashioned songs of nationalism and isolationism. In part this is because the west has not been as skilful as it might have been in helping replace communism with a market economy and the rule of law.

We have real disagreements with Russia and it is right to discuss them frankly. Their conduct in Chechnya is unacceptable and has produced grave humanitarian suffering. Nor, without a political settlement, will it produce their own stated objective of defeating the terrorists. We must bring that message home to Moscow, as we did on Monday when the EU suspended work on its next programme of financial and technical aid.

But the wider question is how we find the diplomatic strategies that develop Russia as a comfortable, willing partner in the global economy and in global security. Russia has ceased to be an opponent of the West. But that is not enough. We need to work closely with the new Russian leadership, and get across our message to the Russian people that the advantages to Russia of being open to the west, attracting western investment and working together to resolve regional conflicts, vastly outweigh any claimed benefits of a chauvinist isolation.

Global interest and national interest

The second guiding principle which I set out was that our national interest will more and more coincide with the global interest.

This is the one which might appear most strange to the world which Chatham inhabited. In his day foreign policy was a zero sum game, with advantage to one player automatically resulting in disadvantage to another. The balance of power which he pursued expressed the objective of foreign policy as an equilibrium of opposing forces in which the greatest threat to the national interest came from other nations.

Today the more immediate challenges to our national interests are likely to be transnational forces - turmoil in financial markets, spread of the drugs trade, or proliferation of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons. There is no greater national duty than the defence of our shoreline. But the most immediate threat to it today is the encroaching sea, rising as a result of climate change which we can manage only by global action.

Some politicians still take a view of the world as a jungle in which the only guiding star is unilateral self-interest. In reality, diplomacy today meets the national interest by forging tactical alliances and building coalitions to secure joint objectives. That is why this government believes that Britain is best served by a foreign policy of enlightened self-interest.

The labels of unilateralist and multilateralist have become inverted. It is the parties of the Right, still clinging hopelessly and touchingly to an outdated model of the nation state in isolation, who are the modern unilateralists. It is the parties of the Left of Centre, with their preference for collective solutions, who are better fitted to understand and operate in the modern multilateralist world.

Britain has more to gain than any other single state from an orderly international framework for the global economy. We depend for our living on trade. We export more per head than either the US or Japan. In absolute terms, our trade with the wider world is twice as great as at the zenith of Empire. We have a larger portfolio of overseas investment than any other European nation. We have more to lose from instability in the international markets.

It is fortunate therefore that Britain also has a broader representation than any other state on the multilateral bodies that will help shape the global economy. We are the only state which is a member of the G8, the EU, NATO, and the Commonwealth, and is a permanent member of the security council. Britain has a unique opportunity to pursue the national interest through the global interest.

If Russia is the biggest challenge for critical engagement, reform of the security council is the biggest unresolved question for multilateral diplomacy. The size of the security council and its permanent membership still replicates the world as it was in 1945. The world has moved on. The UN itself has more than trebled in numbers. The security council risks losing credibility unless it more fairly represents the world as it is today. A modest increase in the numbers on the Security Council seems a small price to pay for a big gain in the Council's authority. That would enhance, not dilute, Britain's position as a permanent member.

Universal values

But even the strongest global institution will sound an uncertain note if it is not clear as to the values which it is meant to promote - which brings me to my third guiding principle, the need for universal values in an age of universal trade and global communications.

The Cold War fostered client states whose repressive behaviour was often condoned in return for their loyalty to one or other camp. This was a particular paradox for the West. All too often it found itself in the pursuit of a proclaimed crusade for freedom shoring up regimes for whom freedom was not on the agenda.

By contrast, the age of globalisation is creating more progressive pressures. Regimes which govern their citizens by fear and repression cannot expect the same people to display the creativity and innovation in the workplace which are essential for a knowledge-based economy. Respect for human rights is not a luxury of growth, but the condition of that growth.

So it is not surprising that democracy has made major gains in the past decade. In Europe the countries of the former Warsaw Pact have chosen democracy. There are no military juntas left in Latin America. In 1975 only three heads of state in Africa were chosen by elections. In 1999, there were 32. The military coup in Pakistan has been so universally condemned precisely because it is out of joint with the times.

We support human rights and democracy for other people because these are values we demand for ourselves. That is why the third theme of our foreign policy for the modern age is diplomacy for democracy.

We have a larger portfolio of overseas investment than any other European nation. We have more to lose from instability in the international markets. It is fortunate therefore that Britain also has a broader representation than any other state on the multilateral bodies that will help shape the global economy. We are the only state which is a member of the G8, the EU, NATO, and the Commonwealth, and is a permanent member of the security council. Britain has a unique opportunity to pursue the national interest through the global interest. If Russia is the biggest challenge for critical engagement, reform of the security council is the biggest unresolved question for multilateral diplomacy. The size of the security council and its permanent membership still replicates the world as it was in 1945. The world has moved on. The UN itself has more than trebled in numbers. The security council risks losing credibility unless it more fairly represents the world as it is today. A modest increase in the numbers on the Security Council seems a small price to pay for a big gain in the Council's authority. That would enhance, not dilute, Britain's position as a permanent member. Universal values But even the strongest global institution will sound an uncertain note if it is not clear as to the values which it is meant to promote - which brings me to my third guiding principle, the need for universal values in an age of universal trade and global communications. The Cold War fostered client states whose repressive behaviour was often condoned in return for their loyalty to one or other camp. This was a particular paradox for the West. All too often it found itself in the pursuit of a proclaimed crusade for freedom shoring up regimes for whom freedom was not on the agenda. By contrast, the age of globalisation is creating more progressive pressures. Regimes which govern their citizens by fear and repression cannot expect the same people to display the creativity and innovation in the workplace which are essential for a knowledge-based economy. Respect for human rights is not a luxury of growth, but the condition of that growth. So it is not surprising that democracy has made major gains in the past decade. In Europe the countries of the former Warsaw Pact have chosen democracy. There are no military juntas left in Latin America. In 1975 only three heads of state in Africa were chosen by elections. In 1999, there were 32. The military coup in Pakistan has been so universally condemned precisely because it is out of joint with the times. We support human rights and democracy for other people because these are values we demand for ourselves. That is why the third theme of our foreign policy for the modern age is diplomacy for democracy. Click here for the rest of the speech.

fields.headline: Animal magic
fields.standfirst: All about the birds and the UFBs
fields.trailText:
Duck and cover
Animals have, of late, been both helping and hindering traffic on Britain's roads. In Warwickshire motorists on the M40 were forced to take evasive action to avoid a pony that was cantering up the middle lane. "It obviously knew the Highway Code," said one eye-witness, "Because when I came up behind it and beeped, it moved over to let me pass." In Nottinghamshire, meanwhile, a parish council has come up with a novel way of discouraging speeding on its roads - ducks.

Duck and cover
Animals have, of late, been both helping and hindering traffic on Britain's roads. In Warwickshire motorists on the M40 were forced to take evasive action to avoid a pony that was cantering up the middle lane. "It obviously knew the Highway Code," said one eye-witness, "Because when I came up behind it and beeped, it moved over to let me pass." In Nottinghamshire, meanwhile, a parish council has come up with a novel way of discouraging speeding on its roads - ducks.

After exploring a variety of methods of slowing traffic as it passes through the village of Linby, the local council eventually decided the best course of action would be to install a new duck pond, the idea being that motorists would see the "Slow - Ducks Crossing" signs and duly reduce their speed for fear of harming the birds. Although the scheme has been condemned by the RSPCA, council chairman Bob Brothwell insists the ducks will be safe: "The pond will be fenced off," he explained, "and the ducks escorted to and from it each morning and evening, so hopefully they won't come to any harm."

Sadly, however, not everyone is quite so concerned about the birds' well-being. "I despise ducks," said one local man. "Far from cutting my speed, I'll actually be increasing it in the hope of squashing a few of them."
Leamington Spa Courier and Hucknall & Bulwell Dispatch

Danger - UFB
Once you only ever heard about them in Bodmin and Dartmoor. Now, however, UFBs - Unidentified Feline Beasts - seem to be cropping up everywhere. A recent hotline at the Peterborough Evening Telegraph, for instance, was deluged with calls from people claiming to have seen The Beast of Castor, a large, cat-like creature that has been terrorising the local countryside. "I believe there are actually two beasts," said big-cat hunter Ian Wilkinson, who has been tracking the creature in a specially-adapted Volkswagen Camper Van. "A puma and a panther. They're a disaster waiting to happen."

Milton Keynes, too, seems to have acquired it's very own monster cat. There have been a number of sightings in and around the Bedfordshire new town, including one terrifying incident in which two children were confronted whilst playing in a local park. "I heard a growling noise," recalled 12-year old Tony Yearsley, "And then this massive black cat ran out of the bushes." Experts are divided as to precisely what the creature is, although one local resident is convinced it's only passing through. "Milton Keynes is that sort of place," he opined. "Even monsters don't stay here any longer than they have to."
The Peterborough Evening Telegraph and Milton Keynes Citizen

Boom time for Bernie
Like the Government, Britain's pets have not had an especially good week. In Nottingham a distressed hamster-owner dialled 999 to ask for help after his beloved rodent fell down the lavatory. Precisely what it was doing anywhere near the lavatory in the first place is unclear, but the emergency services duly arrived and the unfortunate creature was returned to its cage, wet but wiser. Equally distressing have been events in Daventry, where dogs on a local estate have been so traumatised by explosions from a nearby reservoir their owners have been forced to give them tranquillisers to calm their nerves.

The explosions apparently come from gas rockets let off by British Waterways to keep cormorants away from the reservoir's fish. "It's affecting our quality of life," complained local resident Mr Ramon Caira, whose wife and Yorkshire Terrier have both been prescribed homeopathic sedatives because of the noise. "Some days it's like the Battle of the Somme." Daventry District Council are investigating the problem, but so far the noise shows no signs of abating. "Every time there's a bang my Bernie does a woopsie," said another distressed resident. "It's all very well for the bream, but what about my carpets?"
Daventry Express

Reservoir fogs
More problems with reservoirs in Derbyshire, where residents near Carsington Reservoir are convinced that it's ruining the local weather. The property of Severn Trent Water, Carsington was constructed eight years ago, since when, according to farmer Ashley Hedges, there's been a marked and unwanted increase in the amount of rain falling on the area. Local fields are perpetually wet and muddy, even when they're dry only a few miles down the road, whilst there has been an upsurge in gales and thunderstorms. "Because it's a moisture source a reservoir can create more morning fog in an area," admitted a Met Office spokesman, "Although I'd be surprised if it completely altered the local climate."

The Met Office's scepticism is shared by at least one local resident, who believes the reservoir has nothing to do with the recent weather changes. "It's the spaceships that are causing it," insists the woman, who wishes to remain anonymous. "They're here to collect people for sex experiments, and use the bad weather as a cloaking device."
The Matlock Mercury

Loos change
As if the fabulous scenery and fresh, crisp air weren't enough of a reason to visit Argyll and Bute, the Scottish region now has something else to recommend it - the finest public conveniences in the whole of Britain. In the recent Cannon Hygiene Loo of the Year Competition - the Oscars of the toilet world - not one but four of Argyll's public lavatories received awards. "This is a tremendous honour," said one council insider, "and I for one believe we should pass an early day motion to thank all our hard-working toilet attendants."

Particularly admired by judges was the chalet-style lochside lavatory at Ardentinny, run by Gladys Alcorn, whose loo has been highly commended every year since 1994. "Gladys is a legend in the public convenience world," said one colleague. "Her name is synonymous with cleanliness, hygiene and good service. If you use one of her loos you know you're going to have a good time." Ms Alcorn herself is modest about her achievements. "It's nice to receive an award like this," she said, "But at the end of the day it's just a job." Customers, however, are effusive in their praise of her efforts. "It's so good I've stopped using my own toilet," said one satisfied user. "In the maelstrom of life her loo is a little haven of peace and calm."
The Dunoon Observer

Get a WI-ful
It seems that last years erotic calendar featuring members of their Rylstone and District branch has sparked something of an exhibitionist craze within the Women's Institute. Last week we reported on the activities of the Flackwell Heath Branch, where cake-making has given way to belly dancing. Now members of Highly Women's Institute, in Shropshire, are planning their own naked calendar. The women have already had a dry run, posing topless behind their new branch banner. "We were all at one house making the banner when we decided to take a picture of it," explained spokeswoman Joyce Taylor Wilson. "Then, on the spur of the moment, we all decided to take our tops off. It was a great laugh."

Now they are putting together an entire calendar of revealing shots, with no shortage of volunteers coming forward to appear, including several members in their eighties. It has been suggested that such activities represent a quantum shift in the underlying character of the WI, away from sponge and towards sensuousness, although it's probably too early to tell. Rumours that their AGM is to be held in the Raymond Review Bar are as yet wholly unsubstantiated.
The Shropshire Star

Can't see the woods for the woods
If you go down to the woods today... you may well find trees sprouting prophylactics and packs of spermicidal jelly. Or at least you will if you go to Banstead Common in Surrey, where an unholy row has broken out over the local council's decision to install special safe-sex packs for gay men cruising in the area. The packs are part of an anti-AIDS initiative by East Surrey Health Authority's Outreach Team. They have not, however, been universally welcomed by locals. "At first I thought they were new leaves," said one man. "With global warming spring seems to be coming earlier and earlier these days. Then I realised it was actually Liquid Silk Sexual Lubricating Jelly. I was mortified."

The Vicar of Banstead, Reverend David Chance, has condemned the packs, as has local MP Peter Ainsworth. Not everyone, however, is quite so outraged by the scheme. "My grandchildrern love them," said one local resident. "They think they're pixie sleeping bags, and like to see how many they can count when we go up there for a walk."
Epsom and Banstead Herald

Letter of the Week
"I do wish people would grow out of the stupid fashion of leaving bunches of flowers on the spot where a person has died. They don't even put the flowers in a jar of water, but leave them to wither and die. It seems an insult to the deceased. There was a mountain of withered flowers when Princess Diana died. Surely she would have preferred all that money to be donated to one of her charities?

I was driving along a main road recently and saw a collection of flowers where there had been a fatal accident. Looking at them took my attention off the road for valuable seconds, and there could have been another accident in exactly the same spot!"
BM Lea Worcestershire Evening News

fields.headline: Austria's Freedom Party
fields.trailText:
Who is Joerg Haider?
He leads Austria's far-right Freedom party and there is every prospect of him joining the Austrian government run by the moderate right People's Party. That possibility has caused dismay in capitals around the world because of his pro-Nazi remarks in the past, although he has issued apologies in recent months. Be that as it may, Belgium has written to the EU's Portuguese presidency to demand a special meeting of EU foreign ministers to discuss the prospect of the Freedom Party joining the Austrian government. Israel has also threaten to withdraw its ambassador if Mr Haider is part of a new Austrian government.
fields.body:
Who is Joerg Haider?
He leads Austria's far-right Freedom party and there is every prospect of him joining the Austrian government run by the moderate right People's Party. That possibility has caused dismay in capitals around the world because of his pro-Nazi remarks in the past, although he has issued apologies in recent months. Be that as it may, Belgium has written to the EU's Portuguese presidency to demand a special meeting of EU foreign ministers to discuss the prospect of the Freedom Party joining the Austrian government. Israel has also threaten to withdraw its ambassador if Mr Haider is part of a new Austrian government.

What is his background?
Born in the upper Austrian town of Bad Goisern in 1950, Mr Haider studied law in Vienna. He became Freedom Party leader in 1986, when the party was barely securing 5% at the polls, and provincial governor of his native Carinthia in 1989. In 1991, Mr Haider was forced to resign after praising the employment policies of Nazi Germany.

What did he say?
He is reported to have used "penal camps" to describe a concentration camp. He actually said the Romany people in Austria were being marginalised, and asked people to remember that they were almost exterminated in the penal camps of National Socialism. He also said the SS was "a part of the German army which should be honoured". In a TV debate last year he compared the deportation of Jews by the Nazis to the expulsion of Sudeten Germans from Czechoslovakia after the second world war. But he has described the Third Reich as a heinous criminal regime. More pointedly, he has said that Austria was as responsible as Germany for the seven terrible years of the war.

What is Austria's political situation?
Austria has been without a proper government for four months since the inconclusive election in which the Freedom Party surged into second place behind the Social Democrats, who hold 65 seats in the Austrian parliament. The Freedom Party has 52 as does the People's Party. Mr Haider's success sounded the death-knell of the so-called grand coalition, the political partnership between the Social Democrats and the People's Party, which governed Austria for the last 13 years.

What was Mr Haider's platform?
He ran a campaign of stopping immigration in a country that has virtually no immigration and he ran a tough-on-crime campaign in a country that has just about the lowest crime rate in the world. Mr Haider also struck a chord with his anti-European stance. In the past he led Austria's anti-EMU campaign and fought vainly to stop Austria joining the EU in 1995. Last year, he failed to force a referendum on the single currency. Not surprisingly, he is also against EU enlargement. During Austria's six-month presidency of the EU he said: "It is ... a declaration of war against all working and upstanding people." Hence the EU's unease about Mr Haider joining the Austrian government.

Why was he so successful in the last election?
Although Austria is one of Europe's richest countries and its unemployment levels lower than ever, Austrians were fed up with the fractious coalition parties, their high taxes, austerity budget and two-party patronage system. Mr Haider promised to change the stagnant political climate and to create what he calls an Austria for Austrians free of immigrants feeding off the country's generous welfare state.

fields.headline: Cook expounds policy of 'enlightened self-interest'
fields.standfirst:
Foreign secretary avoids 'ethical' in keynote speech
Read Cook's May 1997 'ethical foreign policy speech'
fields.trailText: Britain's international relations must be guided by a policy of "enlightened self-interest", foreign secretary Robin Cook said today, in a keynote speech that carefully avoided any mention of an "ethical dimension" to foreign policy.
fields.body:
Britain's international relations must be guided by a policy of "enlightened self-interest", foreign secretary Robin Cook said today, in a keynote speech that carefully avoided any mention of an "ethical dimension" to foreign policy.

While the government retained its commitment to human rights, that did not mean that there should be no contact at all with repressive regimes, Mr Cook said.

Pointedly, there was no reference to the ethical foreign policy that Mr Cook infamously announced less than a fortnight after the 1997 general election.

Instead he said that in an age of increasing globalisation, it was more than ever in the interest of the UK to advance "British values" of freedom and democracy in the rest of the world.

"Critical engagement" with Iran and Libya had produced the ending of Tehran's support for the fatwa against author Salman Rushdie, compensation for the killing of WPC Yvonne Fletcher and the handover of the Lockerbie suspects for trial, he said. "Such dialogues can be uncomfortable to those who believe we best preserve the purity of our commitment to human rights by refusing to talk to the very regimes that need to hear our message," he said.

"Such a policy may leave us with clean hands. But it is unlikely to provide their people with better rights."

On Europe, Mr Cook said that as the British national interest coincided more and more with the global interest there was a need to develop "universal values".

"Any sane foreign policy must start by accepting the facts of geography. Europe is where we belong. We cannot opt by political levitation to belong to another continent," he said.

"Some politicians still take the view of the world as a jungle in which the only guiding star is unilateral self-interest. In reality, diplomacy today meets the national interest by forging tactical alliances and building coalitions to secure joint objectives."

Amnesty International director Mark Latimer said the government had a good record on human rights "in many respects", for example by helping establish an international court of human rights and demanding the abolition of the death penalty.

But he said its record was being marred by arms sales to regimes with poor human rights.

"They are being sadly let down by the DTI and the MoD who insist on doing what they regard as promoting trade in a way which includes selling arms to countries around the world where there is a grave danger they are used to violate human rights," he said. "People are being killed around the world because of it."

Meanwhile, the Conservative former foreign secretary Sir Malcolm Rifkind claimed Mr Cook's speech amounted to a "retreat" from his ethical foreign policy.

"Basically, what it does is try to draw back from the previous rather dramatic assertions that the government was going to pursue an ethical foreign policy," Mr Rifkind said. "Now what the foreign secretary is saying is: 'Well, when it's in our national interest we will pursue a policy based on ethical considerations but when it is not practical no-one should expect us to'."

Meanwhile, the Conservative former foreign secretary Sir Malcolm Rifkind claimed Mr Cook's speech amounted to a "retreat" from his ethical foreign policy. "Basically, what it does is try to draw back from the previous rather dramatic assertions that the government was going to pursue an ethical foreign policy," Mr Rifkind said. "Now what the foreign secretary is saying is: 'Well, when it's in our national interest we will pursue a policy based on ethical considerations but when it is not practical no-one should expect us to'."

webTitle: Tobacco industry faces the might of Dad's Army

fields.headline: Tobacco industry faces the might of Dad's Army
fields.trailText: Several of the most senior executives in the tobacco industry were summoned yesterday to be burnt alive by the House of Commons health committee.
fields.body:
Several of the most senior executives in the tobacco industry were summoned yesterday to be burnt alive by the House of Commons health committee.

It must have been a terrifying ordeal: as this country's leading merchants of death, they were to face our elected representatives. It would make the Nuremburg trials look like a magistrates' court handling parking offences.

Except it was not like that. Not at all. Not remotely. The five merchants of death trooped sombrely in and adopted the courteous "we're only here to help, your worship" manner favoured by sane corridor-wise people when hauled in front of the house.

In return, the MPs were amazingly, horribly, polite. Oh, they sounded a tiny bit peevish, even once or twice faintly incredulous, but you knew that was only because it was expected of them. The merchants of death must have felt like the Wehrmacht invading Kent, finding themselves face to face with Captain Mainwaring and the rest of Dad's Army.

(On Wednesday I went to see the comedian Al Murray do his famous Pub Landlord act. He picked on a member of the audience who admitted that his job involved marketing cigarettes. "Marketing cigarettes?" Murray asked with an aggressiveness the health committee might try to emulate. "They're in the shops, they're addictive, and kids think they're cool. What do you do all day?")

The MPs kicked off with a few whinges about the difficulty of getting access to the tobacco companies' papers. Eileen Gordon thought that BAT's papers in Guildford were hard to find. "They're between two stations," she said plaintively, "it's a very inconvenient place."

Oh, come on, I thought, of all the things these people have done, failing to store their papers near Guildford station is not exactly the worst.

John Gunnell rambled on and on about something or other. He was incomprehensible. He is the committee's Private Godfrey, played by Arthur Ridley. The merchants of death quickly realised he was pointing his pitchfork the wrong way round and was no danger.

Ms Gordon resumed her assault. "To access your papers you have to get on a train and come down. I mean, would you change your system?"

The committee tried to get cross. They had a secret document of the type which up them, to quote Clive Dunn, executives do not like. It implied that the cigarette manufacturer Gallaher needed to target the fastest-growing market: smugglers.

"A ridiculous document," said Peter Wilson of Gallaher, "part of a brainstorming session in our agency. Many of the suggestions were inappropriate and just plain wrong.

"Clearly we can no longer export tobacco to France and Belgium, since we would be horrified if it were used for large-scale smuggling." (I fear I may have made that quote up.)

A very Germanic looking German, Axel Gietz of RJ Reynolds, explained that the ban on tobacco advertising would harm public health, since it would prevent the companies explaining how some brands were actually safe to smoke. The committee members did not seem troubled by this bizarre suggestion, or by Dr Gietz's reminder that the suffragettes had smoked in order to demonstrate their emancipation. But then chaining yourself to railings did not usually bring about a painful, lingering death.

The merchants resorted to jargon. Why no pack shots in the ads? David Davies of Philip Morris replied: "It is not an objective of product attribution communication."

The only answer to that is "speak English, you fool" - but of course the members of the committee did no such thing, and left to resume fire watches, selling black-market nylons, or whatever they do in real life.

fields.headline: Stores within stores at M&S
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer is building "stores within stores" as a sales platform for its new own-brand designer collections.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer is building "stores within stores" as a sales platform for its new own-brand designer collections.

The ranges, which will go into the top 13 UK stores and three in Europe at the end of February, will be promoted separately from the spring and summer fashion collections launched yesterday.

Designers Julian MacDonald, Katherine Hamnett and Betty Jackson - who has advised M&S for many years - have put together three of the collections as the ailing retailer strives to change its frumpy image.

Two younger designers also produced ranges but refused to let their names be used.

A spokesman for M&S said the designers insisted their names remain confidential. "It is what they want, what they think is best for their image."

The stores within stores, which will have their own shopfittings and specially-trained staff, are a radical departure for M&S.

The group - the worst performer on the high street over the Christmas season with a 9% collapse on 1998 sales compared to rival Next's 8% improvement - desperately needs new attractions to win back disillusioned customers.

The spring and summer fashion ranges were widely acclaimed by fashion writers, and the shares rose 10.75p to 286p. The designer ranges, which will be previewed in Vogue magazine on February 14, are aimed at demonstrating M&S's style credentials.

The Betty Jackson collection focuses on classic pieces, Julian MacDonald has produced a selection of trademark knitwear and crochet, and Katherine Hamnett concentrates on sports and casual wear.

Some of the M&S group's problems have arisen from having been stuck in a fashion no-man's land as shoppers have become either warehouse bargain-hunters or label-conscious brand buyers.
