 I hope Marcia Saunders won't mind if I deal with the letter she sent for publication. This splendid chair of Hornsey and Wood Green Labour party writes about the item in which we pointed that one Lorraine Marshall, herself the author of a published anti-Ken Livingstone letter, is constituency secretary to Barbara Roche MP, one of Dobbo's cheerleaders. "Lorraine Marshall is not constituency secretary for Barbara Roche," insists Marcia. When we ring to check, some chap puts the phone down - so perhaps Marcia would explain why Lorraine is named in a BBC parliamentary directory as Ms Roche's "constituency contact", why she answered the phone there on Wednesday, and why she preferred not to challenge the statement that she was the constituency secretary. Not that there is any question about Lorraine's independence of mind. The newly discovered (by us) fact that she has for several years lived with Adrian McMenamin, Dobbo's spokesman when the campaign began, is neither here nor there.

 In her letter, Marcia also attacks Ken for saying he'd put Glenda Jackson at the head of the GLA candidates top-up list, thus demoting Trevor Phillips to second place. In truth her words have a faint echo of Trevor's own quote yesterday, in which he suggests Ken is a racist determined to deprive black people of GLA representation. Don't be angry with Trev over these sub-McCarthyite smear tactics - the poor fellow doesn't know whether he's Arthur or Martha. When Ken asked him to be his deputy, he said "he liked and admired" Ken, but was unlikely to accept. Months later, he declared Ken had been guilty of racism to offer him the number two position. A few weeks after that, he took the number two position with Dobbo. Not good.

 For the record, Labour's share of the vote would need to hit an unimaginable all-time low for the second-placed candidate not to be elected. Almost no one else contests this, and it may well be a mark of Trevor's increasingly disturbing bafflement that he seems not to understand the system at all.

 Is there too much in the Guardian about the mayoral race, or has the controversy it has provoked about New Labour's attitude to democracy made it a national issue? It's an important question, and a Diary focus group will meet in Rotherham this week under the joint chairmanship of Phillip Gould and my colleague Richard Adams to discuss it. The findings will appear soon.

 Thanks for your replies to a request for information about the Californian 1970s film and magazine star King Dong. One reader suggests that Mr Dong's real name was John Holmes, and that he died of Aids in 1986, but detailed research (and what is this column about if not that?) suggests that the two men were separate entities. Another reader calls to say he knows where Mr Dong is. Yes, we say, all excited? "He's Conservative candidate for mayor of London." You're very kind, but this is a serious matter. No timewasters, if you please.

 Fascinating to see the Sun devoting a leader for the second successive day to ranting about the evils of abolishing section 28. It's barely a year since the paper declared that it had grown out of picking on homosexuals. And now this. If only its editor David Yelland would take or return our calls, he could assuage any fears about wild inconsistency founded on cluelessness. David, come to the phone when we call on Monday. Don't make us come to your doorstep.

 Despite her ferociously hands-on role as Independent on Sunday editor, my old friend Janet Street-Porter still contributes richly to youth culture. A rhyming slang website reports that people seeking just over seven grams of cannabis now routinely say to dealers: "Oi, guv'nor, gissa Janet Street-Porter."

webTitle: Putin to double Russian arms spending

fields.headline: Putin to double Russian arms spending
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Vladimir Putin, Russia's acting president and prime minister, yesterday built on his pledges to restore Russian military might and superpower status by announcing plans to almost double arms spending this year.
fields.body:
Vladimir Putin, Russia's acting president and prime minister, yesterday built on his pledges to restore Russian military might and superpower status by announcing plans to almost double arms spending this year.

Mr Putin, whose whirlwind political ascent has coincided with his prosecution of the war in Chechnya, insisted the increase in spending this year was not related to the north Caucasus campaign, and he argued that the extra funds were essential to reverse years of Russian military decline.

"The army has been underfinanced for several years, entailing negative consequences for the nation's defence potential," Mr Putin said. "It has raised doubts about the very possibility for Russia to have a modern army equipped with state-of-the art weapons."

He said spending on military procurement would increase by 50% this year.

The deputy prime minister responsible for the defence industry, Ilya Klebanov, said spending on arms purchases would go up by 80%, as would funding for military research and development.

As Kofi Annan, the United Nations secretary general, arrived in Moscow to press Mr Putin to begin negotiations in Chechnya, the Council of Europe gave Russia three months to show progress towards peace or face suspension.

But the council's parliamentary assembly in Strasbourg rejected a proposal for an immediate expulsion of 36 Russian legislators. Earlier Russia's foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, told the parliamentary assembly that Russian troops in Chechnya were defending Europe's common borders against "a barbarian invasion of international terrorism".

Boosting Russian military might has rapidly become a central theme of the new Putin era in Russia.

Since being appointed prime minister last August, Mr Putin, has spearheaded the Chechnya war, courted the military lobby, released extra funds for the campaign in the Caucasus and promised to expand the defence budget by 57%.

Since succeeding Boris Yeltsin as president on New Year's Eve, Mr Putin has emphasised the need to stop the rot in the Russian military and also signalled that he sees the defence sector as a key to economic regeneration in Russia.

"The defence industries account for a considerable part of the whole of the national economy. These are high-technology industries that should be a motive force for development," he said yesterday.

Last month he promised naval commanders that he would resume production this year of the RSM-54 sea-launched ballistic missile programme. Last week in Moscow he met the Chinese defence minister for three days of talks about military cooperation deals and arms contracts. China is Russia's biggest weapons purchaser, taking 40% of Russian arms exports.

Russia's new national security strategy, signed into effect earlier this month by Mr Putin, deplores the "impermissible drop in equipping the forces with modern arms and military and special hardware. This leads to a weakening of the military security of the Russian Federation as a whole".

Last year's defence budget was about £3bn. Yesterday's decision means spending purely on military procurement will rise this year to £1.5bn.

It is not clear where the money is coming from. Mr Klebanov admitted that half the bills for defence contracts with the state last year went unpaid and the government is still in arrears for contracts from three years ago. All the debt, the government insisted, would be cleared by April.

While the government emphasised that yesterday's moves were unrelated to Chechnya, the military is exploiting the Chechnya campaign to underline the need for greater defence spending.

"The uncontrolled collapse of the entire system of ensuring the state's military security has gone too far," said Sergei Sokut, a defence analyst. "The worst thing is that the nadir of the crisis has not yet been reached. Some destructive processes in the military-industry complex have become irreversible."

Mr Sokut believes the moment of truth for Mr Putin arrived last year when the need for victories in Chechnya became apparent. "The government realised the potential of the army and began to exploit that, while the army became aware of its value," he added.

webTitle: Half-brother named as sacked executive's net accuser

fields.headline: Half-brother named as sacked executive's net accuser
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
www.yahoo.com
www.aol.com
fields.trailText: Dimitri Papadakos, ousted as chief executive of a US leasing company after anonymous claims against him were posted on the internet, claims the web allowed him to identify their source as his half-brother.
fields.body:
Dimitri Papadakos, ousted as chief executive of a US leasing company after anonymous claims against him were posted on the internet, claims the web allowed him to identify their source as his half-brother.

Mr Papadakos is seeking $20m (£12.2m) damages from Gyrodyne, founded by his father, for defamation.

In court papers filed in New York, Mr Papadakos alleges that his half-brother Peter, a former fellow director, used web aliases to make derogatory statements about him on an internet message board.

Dimitri Papadakos was sacked last May after the company began investigating the claims that he misused company assets for his own ends.

Jacob Zamansky, his lawyer, said he identified the source by issuing subpoenas to the service providers, Yahoo and America Online, forcing them to hand over the client's name and address.

"This case is significant because it sends notice to anonymous message-posters that their identity will be discovered," Mr Samansky said.

Yahoo was unable to identify users of its message boards but did provide an AOL email account number. Another subpoena forced AOL to identify the account owner as Peter Papadakos.

US law, which allows internet businesses to be subpoened information, has mainly been used to track down illegal sharetippers or fraudsters.

Mr Zamansky said yesterday: "This is a fascinating new area of the law." As well as ending the cover of anonymity the case reflected the fact that a "company is responsible for the acts of its directors".

Robert Holtzman, Gyrodyne's lawyer, declined to comment, citing "ongoing litigation".

Peter Papadakos, father of the warring half-brothers, founded the company in 1946 after inventing a dual-blade helicopter. The company stopped manufacturing helicopters in 1975 and its main business is now development of commercial land in Long Island and Florida.

fields.headline: Misys brushes off Y2K pinch
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Misys, the UK's biggest software company, has announced half-year pre-tax profits which slumped 18% to £48.3m.
fields.body:
Misys, the UK's biggest software company, has announced half-year pre-tax profits which slumped 18% to £48.3m.

The firm, which develops software for the financial services and healthcare industries, said the decision by banks and stockbroking houses to defer software purchases until the beginning of 2000, saw revenue decline from £287.9m to £280.6m in the six months to November 30.

However, Misys chairman Kevin Lomax, said orders in the current six months had rebounded and "we are very confident of returning to our long-term growth rates of about 20%.

Stockbroker Dresdner Kleinwort Benson reined in its full year profit forecasts from £139m to £131m but Misys shares improved 81p to 872p on the news of an improving order book. In Misys banking and securities division, orders for the initial licensing of software were £38m in the half-year compared with £32m in the same previous period.

Misys may consider floating off its internet arm, which includes Screentrade and other personal financial services, to realise its value.

Mr Lomax said the market was valuing pure internet players higher than those companies which incorparated the internet as a business division. He did not indicate a time frame for any such demerger. Misys intends to invest £50m in the next three years developing its internet services.

Howard Evans, finance director, said Misys growth would be focused on e-commerce principally in the financial services market. Banks and other financial services houses are expected to spend up to $9bn by 2002 on software for e-commerce activities globally. The interim dividend was increased 15% to 1.39p a share.

fields.headline: Vivendi ponders rescue for Mannesmann
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The board of Vivendi, the French media and utilities group, meets in Paris today amid speculation that it could seal an alliance with Mannesmann, rescuing the German telecoms group from the clutches of Vodafone.
fields.body:
The board of Vivendi, the French media and utilities group, meets in Paris today amid speculation that it could seal an alliance with Mannesmann, rescuing the German telecoms group from the clutches of Vodafone.

With 10 days to the closing date of Vodafone's £95bn hostile bid for Mannesmann, the French group is said to be considering offering a stake to its German partner in Cég&~233;tel, the French mobile phones firm.

Mannesmann owns 15% of Cégétel, in which Vivendi owns 44%, and is rumoured to be ready to sell Orange, the mobile phone operator it bought for £20bn last autumn, to the French group.

The reawakening of interest in Vivendi as a potential white knight for Mannesmann prompted a dismissive response from Vodafone - itself cited in the French media as a potential Vivendi partner.

Mannesmann yesterday also sought to underline its independent future by unveiling a deal with the French software group Cap Gemini to bundle together their e-commerce and internet-related activities.

The deal involves a series of joint ventures, including one to promote "web-hosting" which is said to promise sales in the business-to-business segment worth £625m a year within four years.

Mannesmann said it remained confident of winning majority backing for its defence against Vodafone's bid, claiming almost total backing among German retail investors, who own 10% of its equity.

Hutchison-Whampoa, the Hong Kong group which sold it Orange, has pledged its 10% stake and the German group expects substantial support from German and other Euroland institutions, which command 30%.

It concedes that Vodafone is ahead among US and UK investors.

fields.headline: 'Flying doctors' investigate kidney blunder
fields.standfirst:
Royal College of Surgeons sends rapid response team to Wales in damage limitation exercise established after tragedy at Bristol

Special report: The future of the NHS
The National Kidney Research Fund
Royal College of Surgeons
fields.trailText: Within an hour of the Royal College of Surgeons receiving the call for help from Carmarthenshire NHS Trust, two of the top urological surgeons in the country were speeding towards Wales.
fields.body:
Within an hour of the Royal College of Surgeons receiving the call for help from Carmarthenshire NHS Trust, two of the top urological surgeons in the country were speeding towards Wales.

Ever since the scandal at Bristol Royal Infirmary which did so much to undermine public confidence in hospital doctors, the college has been ready to put together rapid response teams. The Bristol tragedy - the high death rates among babies undergoing heart surgery at the hands of two surgeons - was hugely damaging and the college has been determined to prevent anything similar happening again.

Surgeon John Roberts removed the wrong kidney of his patient Graham Reeves at the Prince Philip Hospital in Llanelli on Monday. The trust called the college and the college called the top people in the field.

Fletcher Deane, based in Glasgow, is the president of the British Association of Urological Surgeons. Keith Parsons is a consultant urologist and chief executive of the Royal Liverpool and Broad green University Hospital NHS trust. They dropped everything, because each time a scandal breaks, the leaders of the profession know there is potential for yet more damage to its standing. Self-regulation has been on the line since Bristol and the government's proposed reforms are already set to undermine doctors' traditional independence.

The college launched its rapid response procedures just ahead of the government's announcement of an inspectorate called the commission for health improvement. If the reforms go through, it will be the commission, not the profession, that sends in the trouble-shooters. The inquiry by Mr Deane and Mr Parsons is tinvestigating the surgeon, Mr Roberts, and examining the case notes. The trust has also set in train an internal inquiry which will examine the role of the team in the operation.

None of this should take long. The removal of a diseased kidney is straightforward. Mike Jones, the trust's chief executive, said: "We are not talking about the skills of the surgical team, but something which has gone terribly wrong with the procedures, which are well tried and tested, and it's very difficult to explain it at face value." The position of the kidney to be removed should be well documented in the case notes, and is marked in ink on the patient's body before the operation begins.

Neither inquiry is supposed to be investigating the earlier operation by Mr Roberts to remove an oversized prostate gland, after which the patient died from complications. All surgeons sometimes lose patients and this one, according to Peter Thomas, medical director of the trust, was "very high risk". Mr Roberts was reprimanded. "I did have cause to speak to him and tell him to be careful... We have reason to believe he is a responsible surgeon," said Dr Thomas.

Mr Roberts's suspension from the Ysbyty Gwynedd general hospital in Bangor, where he previously worked, "may have been personal difficulties with management but nothing from a clinical point of view," said Dr Thomas.

But although these matters are not under direct scrutiny, they will be considered as part of the broad picture once the inquiries have reported. If these find serious fault with the surgeon, various disciplinary measures could be taken. The trust could terminate his contract and the college could remove him from his fellowship which would prevent him working as a surgeon in the NHS. He could also be reported to the General Medical Council, which could remove him from the medical register.

 The Royal College of Surgeons yesterday warned that the transplant service is in crisis, with thousands of people waiting for transplants and too few organ donors.

Doctors called on the government to announce urgent action to establish a national transplant service and for a public awareness campaign to increase organ donation.

The trust has also set in train an internal inquiry which will examine the role of the team in the operation. None of this should take long. The removal of a diseased kidney is straightforward. Mike Jones, the trust's chief executive, said: "We are not talking about the skills of the surgical team, but something which has gone terribly wrong with the procedures, which are well tried and tested, and it's very difficult to explain it at face value." The position of the kidney to be removed should be well documented in the case notes, and is marked in ink on the patient's body before the operation begins. Neither inquiry is supposed to be investigating the earlier operation by Mr Roberts to remove an oversized prostate gland, after which the patient died from complications. All surgeons sometimes lose patients and this one, according to Peter Thomas, medical director of the trust, was "very high risk". Mr Roberts was reprimanded. "I did have cause to speak to him and tell him to be careful... We have reason to believe he is a responsible surgeon," said Dr Thomas. Mr Roberts's suspension from the Ysbyty Gwynedd general hospital in Bangor, where he previously worked, "may have been personal difficulties with management but nothing from a clinical point of view," said Dr Thomas. But although these matters are not under direct scrutiny, they will be considered as part of the broad picture once the inquiries have reported. If these find serious fault with the surgeon, various disciplinary measures could be taken. The trust could terminate his contract and the college could remove him from his fellowship which would prevent him working as a surgeon in the NHS. He could also be reported to the General Medical Council, which could remove him from the medical register.  The Royal College of Surgeons yesterday warned that the transplant service is in crisis, with thousands of people waiting for transplants and too few organ donors. Doctors called on the government to announce urgent action to establish a national transplant service and for a public awareness campaign to increase organ donation.

webTitle: Dome chiefs to plead for £60m loan as attendances plummet

fields.headline: Dome chiefs to plead for £60m loan as attendances plummet
fields.trailText: A multimillion pound plan to rescue the Millennium Dome after its disastrous launch will be presented to the government today amid growing fears over the project's viability.
fields.body:
A multimillion pound plan to rescue the Millennium Dome after its disastrous launch will be presented to the government today amid growing fears over the project's viability.

After a dramatic fall in attendance figures, organisers of the dome at Greenwich, south-east London, are to ask the culture secretary Chris Smith for a loan of up to £60m in lottery money to cover their losses.

Takings at the dome, which is said to attract barely 5,000 visitors a day, are so low that the organisers are barely able to cover their running costs. The dome needs 20,000 visitors a day to break even.

The New Millennium Experience Company, which runs the dome, said last night that it had not submitted a formal application for extra funding.

But it is understood that a rescue package will be on the table when the Millennium Commission meets in London today under the chairmanship of the culture secretary.

The dome desperately needs an injection of cash because the few visitors who do travel to Greenwich are not buying their tickets far in advance.

Instead, they are buying them at lottery outlets a few days before visiting the dome, depriving the organisers of much-needed cash.

Speculation about a rescue package was fuelled when Lord Falconer, the minister in charge of the dome, conceded at the weekend that a loan might be needed.

Lord Falconer knows that he must do all in his power to protect the dome if Labour is to avoid a huge embarrassment.

Peter Ainsworth, the shadow culture secretary, yesterday accused ministers of refusing to answer his questions about the dome's finances.

Gordon Brown, the chancellor, has made it clear that he will not bail out the project with taxpayers' money.

fields.headline: Woman's 26-year wait for op
fields.standfirst: Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: An NHS trust was last night investigating the case of an elderly patient who has been waiting 26 years for a routine operation.
fields.body:
An NHS trust was last night investigating the case of an elderly patient who has been waiting 26 years for a routine operation.

North East Wales hospital trust launched the inquiry after learning that Mary Edwards, 84, of Wrexham, has been waiting for an operation for varicose veins since 1973. Miss Edwards now suffers from Alzheimer's disease and is cared for by her brother, who says it is too late for her to risk the operation.

Miss Edwards was referred for the operation at the Maelor hospital in Wrexham on the advice of her GP and a specialist. Her brother, Jack Lloyd Edwards, 79, said he raised his sister's case to demonstrate that recent problems with the NHS are the result of years of mismanagement.

"In February 1976 we had a letter from the hospital to say she was still on the list, and apologising for the delay," he said. "In 1979 Mary checked to see if she was still on the list. The hospital asked if she still wanted the operation, and she said she did. Since then we've heard nothing."

A hospital spokesman said they had no record of Miss Edwards's outstanding operation and were seeking to establish why.

"The problem is not that she has been on a list for 26 years but that she seems to have disappeared from our list."

fields.headline: The general digs in
fields.standfirst:
The bleak aftermath of the Pakistan coup

Pakistan coup: special report
fields.trailText: If anybody can force General Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's recalcitrant coup-leader, to change tack, it is the United States government. But the crisis in relations between the US and its long-time regional client and aid recipient grows starker by the day.
fields.body:
If anybody can force General Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's recalcitrant coup-leader, to change tack, it is the United States government. But the crisis in relations between the US and its long-time regional client and aid recipient grows starker by the day. Gen Musharraf's stubborn refusal to heed US-led calls to schedule elections, nearly four months after he overthrew Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, is the most galling aspect of a broader failure. Instead, Pakistan's new, soft-focus Zia puts Mr Sharif on trial for his life and indulges in further constitutional vandalism, compromising the judiciary's independence and forcing the resignation of the chief justice.

Gen Musharraf is also proving obstructive on terrorism, a top administration priority. A senior US official visiting Islamabad last week failed to convince Pakistan to proscribe the Harkat ul-Mojahedin organisation, the men behind last Christmas's hijacking of an Indian airliner. To US dismay, Pakistan persists with its support for this and other violent Kashmiri separatist groups, and with its close links to Afghanistan's Taliban, the pariah protectors of America's arch-foe, Osama bin Laden. The regime's refusal to discuss nuclear weapons curbs, its current military and diplomatic stand-off with Delhi, and its failure to launch credible reforms all endanger US and western interests in South Asia.

The idea, under active discussion at the White House, that President Clinton should try to win over the general with a personal visit, tacked on to his expected March tour of India and Bangladesh, is a bad one. If Pakistan's leader agrees to give ground, especially on a return to democracy, before Mr Clinton travels to the region, then the legitimising reward of a face-to-face meeting might be justified. But not otherwise. Quiet persuasion has not worked. Washington must be ready to take a tougher line. For the general's coup has brought only trouble for Pakistan. He has rejected the advice of his friends, including Britain. He seems incapable of giving a clear lead. He is digging himself into an ever bigger hole. And as time passes, his incompetence begs a more basic question: who is really calling the shots in Pakistan? Is it the intelligence services? Is it army hardliners? Is it the Islamic fundamentalist parties and their armed surrogates? Nobody, including Pakistan's US patrons, knows for sure - which is what happens when a general trashes a democracy.

webTitle: Toll tax: Bad news for British motorists

fields.headline: Toll tax: Bad news for British motorists
fields.standfirst: More about transport
fields.trailText: Motorists using major road bridges and tunnel crossings in Britain are set to face hefty increases in charges after a European ruling yesterday.
fields.body:
Motorists using major road bridges and tunnel crossings in Britain are set to face hefty increases in charges after a European ruling yesterday.

The government has fought against the levying of a 17.5% VAT charge being imposed by the European commission, but the European court of justice's advocate general has now said no country should be exempt from charging a tax on tolls.

Siegbert Alber, one of the court's eight advocates-general, said Britain is in breach of a 1977 directive requiring member states to charge the 17.5% tax.

A final ruling will be made this summer but it is unlikely motorists using the likes of the Skye bridge and the Dartford tunnel, will escape the charges.

Legal experts said last night that in 80% of cases a final decision follows the court advocates opinion.

The revelation sparked anger from motoring groups. Paul Watters, head of road and transport policy at the AA, said: "This is a further imposition on motorists who pay enough tax as it is."

A department of transport spokesman said: "These bridges and tunnels provide a public service and the UK government felt VAT should not be levied on the tolls."

Tory shadow transport secretary Bernard Jenkin said: "The government have been shirking on this issue. The court's judgment was inevitable."

The court also said Britain owes millions for late payment of the tax as well as the costs of the long-running case, brought by the European commission.

Member states are bound by treaty to pay a proportion of their VAT revenue to the EU's central budget.

France is also expected to be badly hitby the ruling.

The court of justice is the final arbiter in disagreements arising from EU treaties or legislation.

 Rail fares will be allowed to rise by as much as 5% under plans being drawn up to share out new rail franchises, the shadow Strategic Rail Authority confirmed yesterday.

fields.headline: Throw away your crutches
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: King's Cross, Thursday, 2.30 pm.
fields.body:
King's Cross, Thursday, 2.30 pm.

The old lady's face lights up. Years of toil and stress disappear in an instant. Ethel's face is etched in sunshine.

"He touched me!" she says. She's been a Labour voter all her life, but this is the first time she's been touched by Ken Livingstone and it's a day she will never forget. "'Ere, love" says her husband Jack, who used to work down the Kensington coal mines before they were grassed over to make way for Kensington Gardens, "'ere, love - throw away those crutches."

With one courageous shove, Ethel throws her crutches to the ground. Then she places one leg in front of the other. And walks. First one step. Then another. And another. Then another. Around her, even the most hard-bitten commuters stop and cheer, tears welling in their eyes. "Say what you like about Ken Livingstone," says a pinstriped businessman, normally a diehard Conservative, "but the man works miracles".

A very special day for Ethel, then - but one much like any other for "Red" Ken Livingstone. He tends to play down his miraculous powers of healing, though in private he does mention that the operators of the London Eye ferris wheel have been begging him for some time to place his hands on it. "But there are more important things to do," he says, bravely, "like arranging halfway decent buffet cars on the Tube, with free Cokes and French fries for the kiddies, and getting everyone at present in a London hospital up and about again as right as rain."

The Angel, Islington, Thursday 3.00pm.

Steve, 39, shakes Ken by the hand. "Good luck, mate," he says. Ken smiles. "I'm going to need it mate!" he quips, and we all rock with laughter. Steve is concerned about the threat posed by foxhunters. Ken assures him that when he is mayor, there will be no foxhunting in the Greater London Area. "At the moment, there's a lot of secret foxhunting going on round Marble Arch. Residents are kept awake at night by the crunch of the hooves and the blaring of the horns," he confides to Steve. "It's an intolerable situation and one I fully intend to halt, mate."

Privately, Ken confides that he donated his old moustache to the Campaign Against Cruel Sports in a joint venture to show you could gain just as much pleasure without recourse to killing. They tied the moustache to a length of string and ran around with it while others chased them on foot. They were going to spray it with fox's urine he says proudly, but they found it didn't need it.

Southwark Bridge, Thursday, 4.30pm.

A middle-aged man comes up and recalls Ken's GLC - a time when London buses were as clean as a bright new pin and decorated with fresh flowers every day and when the cheery drivers would let you don their caps, sit on their laps and have a go at driving the bus yourself. "And we were all 20 years younger then, and it was only 14 years since we'd won the World Cup, and we all had full heads of hair and golden futures in front of us! And Ken," he continues, his voice choking with emotion, "you're the only candidate who can bring those days back for us. Good luck, mate, good luck!" And with that, he stuffs a £20 note into Ken's campaign bucket. It's the savings he was going to put towards food for the next 10 days, but he says he'll do without. It's not every day, he says, that England can regain the World Cup.

Waterloo, Thursday, 5.15pm

Ken Livingstone walks through the station concourse with a wholly natural air, first one foot, then the other. It's one of the most genuine walks I've ever witnessed. He's been walking this way all his life, he confides. "I began walking shortly after my first birthday, and I've never lost the knack. It's a highly convenient mode of personal propulsion, particularly in and around the home," he says, "though no substitute, of course, for a fully integrated public transport system". He has these facts at his fingertips, and it's his high level of knowhow that impresses even his opponents. A bowler-hatted stockbroker comes up, shakes his hand, and reminisces about the golden days of his GLC. "All the main pavements were carpeted then, of course - and at no extra cost to the ratepayer," he recalls. "And we all buckled down and did the hoovering, singing old Gracie Field numbers to keep us going, while passersby fed us with nutritious stews they had brought along specially."

A man approaches Ken and says he comes from East Croydon. Ken says he once went shopping in East Croydon, back in 1989. He's made the man's day. Without prompting, one hundred commuters lift him on to their shoulders and carry him in a triumphant procession through the station concourse. Small wonder Frank Dobson is scared.

fields.trailText: Your piece on detailed aerial photography (Top secret photos for £17.50, January 27) ended with the statement by David Baker, editor of Jane's Space Directory, that the technology would develop in ways that would mean "someone in a tent in the Middle East can now plan how to drop a missile down a lavatory in Whitehall". He of all people should know that Middle Eastern toilets are much more likely targets.

fields.headline: Dangerous trends
fields.trailText: The EU's new freedom of information rules (Read Romano Prodi's mail. Or not, January 26) are far more restrictive than you suggest. There are a couple of positive reforms but these are overshadowed by substantial new restrictions on access to EU documents. These amount to a charter for secret, unaccountable and illegitimate EU decision-making.
fields.body:
The EU's new freedom of information rules (Read Romano Prodi's mail. Or not, January 26) are far more restrictive than you suggest. There are a couple of positive reforms but these are overshadowed by substantial new restrictions on access to EU documents. These amount to a charter for secret, unaccountable and illegitimate EU decision-making.

"Internal documents" (broadly defined), including email, will be excluded altogether. All documents affecting the EU institutions' discussions must be refused in all cases.

The new rules also allow the EU to refuse to reply to "repetitive" requests, meaning repeated requests by the same person for "different" documents. This is an attempt to overturn rulings by the EU ombudsman in favour of investigative journalism and research. Meanwhile, the preamble suggests that each member state will have to obey EU rules when handing out documents. This will affect liberal access rules in many EU states and possibly even the supply of documents to national parliaments.

The new EU proposal is more subtle than Jack Straw's national proposals, but deserves as much opposition.

Steve Peers
Human Rights Centre
University of Essex
speers@essex.ac.uk

 Charlotte Denny (Out of the Red, January 26) suggests that the government's new "resource accounting" and its proposal to measure the outputs or results of public spending were invented in New Zealand in the 1980s. In 1969 I, and a consultancy colleague, proposed such an accounting system to the Procedure Select Committee, but the treasury turned it down. Output or programme budgeting was developed in the US in 1961 and applied throughout the Federal government in 1965. Our treasury thought it impractical.

John Garrett
(former Labour treasury spokesperson) Norwich, Norfolk

 I read Francis Beckett's article (The real extremists, January 26) with amusement. Far from ever having been "a rigid ideological socialist", my principal interest was in Labour party democracy.

Safe seats for life is old Labour. A contract renewable once in every parliament is New Labour. One might say I was New Labour before it was fashionable. As to why Tony Blair has included me in his government, it certainly was not because I sucked up to the establishment - as an examination of my 12 years in parliament will show.

Chris Mullin MP

fields.headline: Holocaust day works
fields.trailText: Geoffrey Wheatcroft (Holocaust chic, January 27) believes that history has a "shelf life" and that the Holocaust has outlived its sell-by-date. It is all very well saying that this whole catastrophe should now be laid to rest; there have been many attempts but it simply refuses to lie down - and there are good reasons for this.
fields.body:
Geoffrey Wheatcroft (Holocaust chic, January 27) believes that history has a "shelf life" and that the Holocaust has outlived its sell-by-date. It is all very well saying that this whole catastrophe should now be laid to rest; there have been many attempts but it simply refuses to lie down - and there are good reasons for this.

There is of course no real "Shoah business", as if those museums and educational organisations concerned with the events of the Holocaust were making money - quite the reverse. The impetus for commemoration and study comes from the genuine historical imperative to record eye-witness accounts of any event; this is now a race against time.

The government's proposed memorial day would provide an opportunity for citizens of Europe to focus on historical European events which involve universal issues affecting every nation and society. Under the proposals, schools, communities and institutions will be invited to consider the effects of casual discrimination, blind obedience to authority and the creation of tyranny. In the light of a great many of the articles elsewhere in yesterday's Guardian, it is wrong to suggest that we do not need help to ensure these lessons are learned - at least until people feel it is okay to forget.

Jane Clements
Council of Christians and Jews
CCJUK@aol.com

 The problem of why the Holocaust looms so large 50 years on, which Geoffrey Wheatcroft sees as "curious", yields easily to a small amount of consideration. Many survivor accounts date from recent years, because people were unable to relive the memory until they had built some kind of normality and put a generation of work and family between themselves and the experience of living daily with death. Some who tried to confront their memories in the three decades following the war, such as the writers Primo Levi, Paul Celan and Jerzy Kosinski, found themselves trapped in a mental anguish which led to suicide. Society at large has taken its time to digest the realities. What is now happening is that the Holocaust is taking its rightful place in history.

In the meantime, I don't think Geoffrey Wheatcroft and others understandably embarrassed by the excesses of the Holocaust industry are going through too much pain.

Gil Elliot
London

 Would it not be more appropriate for the day to be called national Holocaust and slavery day? The 2.6m African slaves that British shipowners transported to the Americas not so long ago, and the continual worldwide dangers of human abuse and exploitation, might then also be remembered and acknowledged.

Prof Robin Wilson
Puerto Madryn, Argentina
ccbpat@infovia.com.ar

 No decent person would deny Jews proper commemoration for the Holocaust. What opponents object to is its use as a symbol of Jewish victimhood and thus as a justification for Israeli aggression and oppression.

If Jews and Israelis want to heal the wounds of their past let them strive to properly commemorate the 1948 massacre at the Palestinian village of Deir Yassin which, along with other coercions, signalled the dispossession and exile of the Palestinian people.

Paul Eisen
London
dyr@eisen.demon.co.uk

 Am I alone in thinking that the announcement of Holocaust day sits somewhat uneasily next to the row about letting in "too many" refugees, many of whom have been persecuted in their homelands?

Noel Longhurst
Sheffield

fields.headline: Drifting towards calamity
fields.trailText: George Monbiot does a fine job of explaining the crucial role of ocean circulation in moderating climate (The seas rise, the glaciers disappear, January 27). Indeed, thanks to the North Atlantic Drift, an extension of the powerful Gulf Stream, western Europe actually receives "free" heat equivalent to the output of one million power stations.
fields.body:
George Monbiot does a fine job of explaining the crucial role of ocean circulation in moderating climate (The seas rise, the glaciers disappear, January 27). Indeed, thanks to the North Atlantic Drift, an extension of the powerful Gulf Stream, western Europe actually receives "free" heat equivalent to the output of one million power stations.

But this fortuitous set-up could change in a warming world in the space of two decades. I suspect we don't know yet just how probable such a climate flip is. But surely society should be ensuring against this calamity?

Dr David Cromwell
Southampton Oceanography Centre

 George Monbiot argues for 90% reduction in fossil-fuel use within 10 years, and makes fundamental reform of the global market system a pre-condition of achieving it. Since there is no chance of that happening in time, he might as well have said there is nothing we can do about global warming, which is certainly not the case.

A realistic target would be for renewable energy sources to take over by mid-century. Achieving that requires decisions about housing, transport, industry and agriculture to be guided by a vision of a feasible fossil-fuel-free world.

John Stringer
Ewhurst Green, E Sussex
js@energy21.freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: Come clean on racism
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw's decision (Straw extends race bill, January 27) is most welcome. Indirect - or institutional - racism can be just as damaging as direct discrimination. Legislation alone is not enough, however. Real change will also require genuine motivation and honest self-criticism by public authorities. The conduct of nine London local authorities is not therefore encouraging.
fields.body:
Jack Straw's decision (Straw extends race bill, January 27) is most welcome. Indirect - or institutional - racism can be just as damaging as direct discrimination. Legislation alone is not enough, however. Real change will also require genuine motivation and honest self-criticism by public authorities. The conduct of nine London local authorities is not therefore encouraging.

The authorities - including Lambeth council - commissioned research from the Institute of Employment Studies following evidence that black employees were far more likely to face formal disciplinary action from managers than their white colleagues.

The research took years to complete and has been finished for some months. Officers of the authorities, co-ordinated by the Greater London Employers Association (GLEA), have thus far delayed publication of a summary report and have no current intention of releasing the full detailed findings.

Preliminary research findings, which are in the public domain, are very worrying. They suggest managers often base their decision on whether or not to invoke a formal disciplinary procedure solely on the fact that the employee is of different ethnic origin.

In the spirit of the home secretary's decision to give local authorities a new duty to promote race equality, perhaps the GLEA will now encourage the authorities to come clean and publish these important research findings in full so that a properly informed debate can take place.

Jon Rogers
Lambeth Unison

fields.headline: Trailblazer
fields.trailText: Michael White trailed a speech by David Blunkett to be given later that day (Blunkett beats drum for party's achievements, January 26). The following day I could see no report of the speech. The only information about the event we have is a piece relying on a Labour party handout - and Radio 4 used the same one. We were given what the spin doctors wanted us to read, without the critical appraisal and comments that come after the delivery.

fields.headline: Don't give peace the push
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: You do not have to be a unionist to realise that unless David Trimble receives support his days, and those of pro-peace process unionism, are numbered (Leader, January 27). Decommissioning was supposed to be a prerequisite for meetings between British ministers and Sinn Fein representatives. That was dropped.
fields.body:
You do not have to be a unionist to realise that unless David Trimble receives support his days, and those of pro-peace process unionism, are numbered (Leader, January 27). Decommissioning was supposed to be a prerequisite for meetings between British ministers and Sinn Fein representatives. That was dropped.

Decommissioning was supposed to be a prerequisite for all-party talks. That was dropped. The original Mitchell report in 1996 favoured some decommissioning in parallel with all-party talks. That was dropped. Tony Blair led unionists to believe that decommissioning would take place before republicans entered government. That was dropped.

David Trimble took a leap and entered government on the understanding that the IRA would make a start on decommissioning. This was probably the only way he could have won the support of his party for entering government. If the Labour government fails to support Trimble they will destroy his leadership and the prospects of a cross-community settlement.

Attempts to coerce an apparently defeated unionism failed during the first peace process of 1973/74 and the Anglo-Irish agreement of 1985. On both occasions English politicians under-estimated unionist resistance. You don't have to be a unionist to realise that there are limits to how far you can push unionism.

Paul Dixon
University of Ulster

fields.headline: Last of the Birtists
fields.standfirst:
Will the director general's legacy survive?

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Reports that John Birt is going to write a "how to" guide for managers of struggling organisations have been greeted by some with the enthusiasm that might have attended King Herod's becoming director of the south Judea child care department. Our reaction is surprise that he thinks the wonderful idiosyncrasy of his tenure as director-general affords any generalisations. Can theories of "management" be extracted from the utterly, gloriously anomalous BBC? The more its structure and values resemble those of a commercial organisation, the less likely it is to serve the public interest.
fields.body:
Reports that John Birt is going to write a "how to" guide for managers of struggling organisations have been greeted by some with the enthusiasm that might have attended King Herod's becoming director of the south Judea child care department. Our reaction is surprise that he thinks the wonderful idiosyncrasy of his tenure as director-general affords any generalisations. Can theories of "management" be extracted from the utterly, gloriously anomalous BBC? The more its structure and values resemble those of a commercial organisation, the less likely it is to serve the public interest.

Birt, ennobled but so far not gazetted, today leaves a BBC every bit as peculiar (and peculiarly managed) as the organisation he took over from Sir Michael Checkland in 1992. Long may it remain so. Odd in its governance, in its relationship with the state, in its weight in cultural life and journalism, it has to remain gloriously odd in its people. Without them there would not be programmes worth watching or listening to, nor would it be worth checking out the BBC's widely-admired nest of websites. As it is, there are still abundant reasons for tuning in: a broadcaster which can get people talking avidly about a "steamy shower scene" between two fully-clothed actors standing in a distinctly unerotic BBC studio cannot have lost its magic.

But Birt and his legions of consultants and super-editors do not produce The Archers. It is an unresolved question whether the changes associated with his tenure (the separation of production and commissioning, say) did much for final output. Perhaps, if he is not suffocated by partisan embrace in the Lords, he may find some new organisation to remould. But the world can live without another leaden tome pretending to teach executives wisdom. In any case, directing the BBC is, primarily, a political and strategic, not a management, job; just how political, Rupert Murdoch's minions remind the new DG, Greg Dyke, every day.

webTitle: Police inquiry into Barak party fundraising

fields.headline: Police inquiry into Barak party fundraising
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: A criminal investigation has been ordered into allegations that the One Israel alliance led by the prime minister, Ehud Barak, broke fundraising laws during last year's election.
fields.body:
A criminal investigation has been ordered into allegations that the One Israel alliance led by the prime minister, Ehud Barak, broke fundraising laws during last year's election.

The Israeli state comptroller, Eliezer Goldberg, presented parliament yesterday with a report accusing Mr Barak's alliance, made up of his Labour party and two other political factions, of having violated fundraising laws during the general election last May.

Mr Goldberg then handed the case over to the attorney general, Eliyakim Rubinstein. Charges of fraud and breach of trust against One Israel and several other political parties accused of similar financing irregularities could follow.

It is only the latest development in a series of scandals in which some of the most senior figures in the Israeli political establishment - including President Ezer Weizman and the former prime minister Binyamin Netanyahu - have been accused of abusing their office for financial gain or skirting party financing laws.

One Israel is accused of setting up non-profit organisations (NPOs) to fund Mr Barak's campaign as a way to dodge strict state controls on campaign financing.

Mr Goldberg said in his report that Mr Barak should have known his election team was using such tactics and slapped a 13.7m shekel fine (about £2.1m) on One Israel, adding that he was "being lenient" about the transgression.

"I expressed in [my] report a critical view of the prime minister's behaviour," he said. "I determined clearly that the law was broken. This blatantly tramples the law."

Officials close to Mr Barak portrayed the fundraising tactics as taking advantage of loopholes in the campaign financing laws rather than any illegal manoeuvre.

Mr Barak has said he will cooperate fully with the investigation but has maintained he has done nothing wrong. He also said that during the busy election campaign it was impossible for him to keep close watch over all fundraising.

Political opponents, however, dismissed his response as inadequate. "How can he not have known what was going on under his nose?" asked Limor Livnat of the rightwing Likud party. "I would say that the answer of the prime minister is really pathetic."

The report comes at a time when Israel's official head of state, Mr Weizman, is under criminal investigation for allegedly accepting cash gifts from a French textile magnate, Edouard Saroussi, possibly in exchange for political influence. Police are looking into whether Mr Saroussi had business interests in Israel.

Israelis, while losing trust in political institutions, are becoming more accustomed to seeing their leaders in hot water, according to Yohanan Peres, a sociologist at Tel Aviv university. But he added that Israeli voters were far more interested in the peace process and the state of the economy.

"The public wants to see good candidates, and they don't care how they're elected or how much money they spend to get there," he said.

However, there was a danger that Mr Barak's opposition could capitalise on public dismay over continuous sleaze scandals.

"I would not like them to use this as an opportunity to open a campaign against Barak. I am afraid that this little corruption issue might overshadow the bigger, more important issue of peace," Dr Peres said.

fields.headline: Funding row threatens poor regions
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: Billions of pounds in special European aid earmarked for Britain's poorest regions is being theatened by confusion and delays in Whitehall over how much cash the government should provide in so-called matching funds.
fields.body:
Billions of pounds in special European aid earmarked for Britain's poorest regions is being theatened by confusion and delays in Whitehall over how much cash the government should provide in so-called matching funds.

Although the European Commission has promised more than £3bn for West Wales and the valleys, South Yorkshire, Cornwall and Merseyside, fears are growing that much of the aid will not come unless the government follows Brussels protocol by pledging a similar amount for the six year programmes.

So far, there is no indication if -or how - the government plans to provide the additional £3bn.

The aim is to pull the regions, among the poorest in western Europe, up the EU wealth league with a range of industrial support, business creation and regeneration schemes. Areas with the "objective one" label qualify because GDP per head is at least 25% below the European average.

Over the past few weeks, ministers have been criticised by Labour MPs and councillors in theold industrial heartlands who fear that tens of millions of pounds will have to be handed back to Brussels.

Opposition members of the Welsh assembly are also threatening to bring down Alun Michael's minority administration in Cardiff over the issue.

After a meeting in Cardiff, Liberal Democrats from the four areas have written to the chancellor, Gordon Brown, demanding an unqualified guarantee that matching funds will be available.

They warn in a letter that while the European Commission requires additional public funds to match the European grants pound for pound, there is a shortfall from the government "which means that millions of pounds of EU funds are at risk."

The issue has now forced itself onto the agenda of the forthcoming Ceredigion byelection, where a Welsh language newspaper has put up a candidate under the "match funding now" banner.

Opposition parties in Cardiff have said they will table a no confidence motion in Mr Michael next month unless they are satisfied that the treasury is prepared to find matching funding to trigger off a £1.2m package from Europe.

Concern is also growing in Cornwall, the poorest county in England. It is earmarked for £314m from Europe. Councillors have written to Tony Blair asking for an urgent meeting "to clarify the situation".

Officials in South Yorkshire - promised almost £800m - and on Merseyside - seeking £844m from Europe - have expressed their concern about the cash returning to Brussels.

fields.headline: Upbeat Clinton pleads for forgiveness
fields.standfirst: More about the state of the union address
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton used his final state of the union speech last night to plunge himself back into the heart of the US election year political debate, but failed to distance himself from the humiliating spectre of Monica Lewinsky.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton used his final state of the union speech last night to plunge himself back into the heart of the US election year political debate, but failed to distance himself from the humiliating spectre of Monica Lewinsky.

As he prepared for last night's speech, Mr Clinton could not help but reflect on the two-year scandal and its aftermath which have done so much to diminish the president's personal reputation.

"First of all I made one mistake. I apologised for it. I paid a high price for it and I've done my best to atone for it by being a good president," Mr Clinton told PBS television interviewer Jim Lehrer. The still incomplete six-year investigation into the Clintons' involvement in the notorious Whitewater property deal was "a bunch of bull", he claimed, adding that Republicans in congress knew that early on.

"But I do regret the fact that I wasn't straight with the American people [about Lewinsky]," Mr Clinton admitted. "It was something I was ashamed of and pained about, and I regret that."

After two years in which his annual address to congress - traditionally the most important date in the American domestic political calendar - was completely dominated first by the Lewinsky affair and the impeachment crisis, Mr Clinton was returning to Capitol Hill for the eighth and last time in defiant mood, celebrating his own "American revolution" of economic prosperity and social reform.

webTitle: 'VAT on fat' idea to avert heart deaths

fields.headline: 'VAT on fat' idea to avert heart deaths
fields.trailText: Putting VAT on fatty foods such as butter, whole milk and cheese could prevent up to 1,000 premature deaths from heart disease every year, a scientist claims today.
fields.body:
Putting VAT on fatty foods such as butter, whole milk and cheese could prevent up to 1,000 premature deaths from heart disease every year, a scientist claims today.

In an article for the British Medical Journal, Tom Marshall from the department of public health and epidemiology at Birmingham university proposes a radical way to persuade people to change their diet and preserve their health.

Bad diet is a significant cause of rising rates of heart disease, which is most common in the least affluent people. They often buy foods high in saturated or polyunsaturated fats, such as biscuits, because they are filling and relatively cheap.

Most food is VAT-free. He proposes the 17.5% tax should be added to high-fat foods, while foods such as orange juice and low-fat frozen yoghurt should be exempt.

The result, he hopes, would be substitution of low-fat for high-fat foods.

He calculates that death rates from heart disease would fall by between 900 and 1,000 among the under-75 age group. But he accepts that the strategy would leave the poorest worse off.

"Most consumers will end up by spending more on food and this will disproportionately affect the poor." He suggests that welfare benefits should be increased.

Nutritionists thought it a good idea that would be difficult to put into practice.

"Great idea - what fun the lawyers will have deciding which foods are fatty and which aren't," said Tim Lobstein, co-director of the consumer watchdog body, the Food Commission.

"At present manufacturers try to sell us lower fat products at a premium. This would reverse that."

webTitle: Hunt starts for man missing with his sons

fields.headline: Hunt starts for man missing with his sons
fields.trailText: A nationwide hunt was launched yesterday for a father and his two children who vanished last week, two months after police began to probe the mysterious disappearance of their mother.
fields.body:
A nationwide hunt was launched yesterday for a father and his two children who vanished last week, two months after police began to probe the mysterious disappearance of their mother.

Gary Malone, 44, took his sons Adam, four, and Robert, two, from their home in Potters Bar, Hertfordshire, last Friday in a van he had hired for the weekend.

He has written three letters to relatives and friends since then in which he has described the pressure he has been under since the disappearance last November of his second wife, Sharon, 28.

In one he admitted he was finding it difficult to cope.

Detective Chief Inspector Lewis Benjamin, who is leading the investigation, stressed yesterday that his overriding concern was the safe return of the boys.

Their grandfather, Harry Clinch, 60, who is Sharon's father, pleaded yesterday for Mr Malone to get in touch. He said that both boys were desperately missing their mother and needed constant love and reassurance.

Four months ago Mr Clinch's wife Elizabeth died of cancer. "I can't explain how it feels to lose all your family in one go," he said yesterday. I have gone to the end of my emotions. At night I sit by the door just hoping that someone will open it. I feel completely and utterly gutted."

Mr Benjamin said Mrs Malone went missing on Sunday November 28, having apparently said she was driving to see an unnamed friend. She did not return home and Mr Malone reported her missing the following day.

Her blue Ford Escort was found abandoned a month later near her home. It was locked and contained her mobile phone.

Police said yesterday that Mrs Malone, who was studying to be a teacher at Hertfordshire university, had not drawn any money from her bank accounts.

Last month Mr Malone appealed for her to return and hoped that she might get in touch at Christmas to speak to the children.

Mr Clinch said yesterday that the couple, who met at karate classes, had been under a lot of pressure because Gary had lost his job at a water delivery company.

The police do not believe, however, that Mr Malone, a psychology graduate who used to work for a jeweller, was short of money.

Detectives believe that he has substantial funds but are unsure where they came from. "He is not involved in any criminal activity as far as we know," said a police source. "We are conducting urgent inquiries into his finances."

Officers want to discuss with him the disappearance of his wife, but reiterated that the priority was the return of Adam and Robert.

In one of the letters to his father-in-law Mr Malone said that he would come back when his wife returned.

"The pressure of the circumstances surrounding Sharon's disappearance has got to him," said Mr Benjamin.

"We don't know why he's disappeared, where he's gone and we don't know why last Friday is significant. Gary is likely to be in a highly emotional and stressed state and we are concerned for his welfare and for the safety of Adam and Robert."

Mr Malone is 5ft 10in, of medium build, with short dark hair. He occasionally wears dark-rimmed glasses.

fields.headline: Caution for head over forgery
fields.trailText: A headmistress was given a formal caution by police in Gloucestershire after she forged a signature on a reference which disparaged her former secretary, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
A headmistress was given a formal caution by police in Gloucestershire after she forged a signature on a reference which disparaged her former secretary, it emerged last night.

Janice McBride, head of St Mary's Primary School in Broadway, Worcestershire, admitted she forged the signature of a school governor.

Mrs McBride, 46, sent a reference to Moreton-in-Marsh hospital under the signature of Patricia Conroy outlining her misgivings about the former school secretary. But it emerged that Mrs Conroy had already provided the hospital with her own reference.

The headmistress wrote again when she heard that the former secretary had got the job, in which she would handle sensitive patient records. Mrs McBride, from Broadway, who has been head of the school for five years, refused to comment yesterday. But the school's chair of governors, Father Malchay Steenson, said: "This is a matter for the governors to discuss when they next meet."

The matter will also be investigated by Worcestershire county council and the Roman Catholic diocesan school commission.

Gloucestershire police confirmed that Mrs McBride was cautioned on January 20 and that police bail following her arrest had been cancelled.

webTitle: Fans' fury at Subbuteo send-off keeps game in toyshop league

fields.headline: Fans' fury at Subbuteo send-off keeps game in toyshop league
fields.trailText: It worked for salad cream, and if the outcry that followed the announcement that Subbuteo was to be shown the red card is anything to go by, it should work for the table football game too.
fields.body:
It worked for salad cream, and if the outcry that followed the announcement that Subbuteo was to be shown the red card is anything to go by, it should work for the table football game too.

Hasbro, the toymakers, humbly gave in to fans' pressure yesterday and granted a reprieve, after admitting having underestimated the game's popularity. Others were more cynical, suggesting that Hasbro had mounted a classic marketing ploy to rescue a troubled former top-seller.

Whatever the explanation, the game is to play on into the next season with an improved range and a tougher marketing strategy to support it.

Mike McCulloch, Hasbro's sales and marketing director, said: "We were overwhelmed by the response we had from customers. We have to hold our hands up and say we underestimated the support the game has in the marketplace."

He admitted that the reprieve showed up the inadequacies of the company's market research, and denied that the announcement last week that Hasbro would cease manufacturing the game was part of a strategy to ratchet up sales. "We are not in the business of treating our customers in that way. It would be a very cynical approach to take."

When Heinz announced last year that it was reviewing the future of its salad cream sales rocketed and the product was saved. However, David McCormack, news editor of PR Week magazine, warned other companies to think carefully before trying the same stunt. "If this is a cynical marketing ploy, it can't be used often. The public are fairly media savvy."

Since its launch in 1947 Sub buteo has been a favourite among football fans who want to recreate their top-flight teams' contests in their homes. It is sold in more than 50 countries, but last week its makers said it could no longer compete with hi-tech games. Football games for PCs and consoles such as the Sony Playstation - featuring 3D graphics, action replays and commentaries - have drawn younger competitors away from flick football.

But Mr McCulloch, himself a keen player, said thousands of passionate fans had saved the game, and Hasbro was keen to breathe new energy into Subbuteo teams. "We are looking at potentially increasing the number of teams out there and extending to division one and including Ireland in our international sides," he said.

The former owners, Waddingtons, who sold the rights to Hasbro in 1994, frequently sold more than 300,000 sets annually worldwide, and top-level games were televised. Now sales are at about 50,000.

The Toys R Us chain is teaming up with Hasbro to promote the game and the full range will be sold in all 63 UK stores this year.

fields.headline: Gay sailor breaks silence
fields.trailText: A rating on a destroyer became Britain's first openly gay serviceman when he told his shipmates he was homosexual, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
A rating on a destroyer became Britain's first openly gay serviceman when he told his shipmates he was homosexual, it emerged yesterday.

The sailor, who does not want to be named, said that on January 11, when the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, announced the lifting of the ban on homosexuals serving in the armed forces, he visited a gay nightclub to celebrate. He then told four mess mates on HMS Newcastle based in Portsmouth that he was gay. "I was just fed up lying to people. I was living separate lives," he said. "I have been in the navy for eight years but I didn't know I was gay when I joined."

The government lifted the ban after a European court of human rights ruling last September in favour of four gay ex-servicemen. Among them was former lieutenant commander Duncan Lustig-Prean, who also served on HMS Newcastle before being discharged over his sexuality.

Simon Langley, vice chairman of Rank Outsiders, the support group for lesbian, gay and bisexual armed forces personnel, applauded the sailor's decision but added: "I personally wouldn't have done it. I still think it is early days."

webTitle: Watchman who got drunk is jailed

fields.headline: Watchman who got drunk is jailed
fields.trailText: A Polish sailor was jailed for six months yesterday for getting drunk on watch and falling asleep, leaving his ship to run aground on the Scottish coast.
fields.body:
A Polish sailor was jailed for six months yesterday for getting drunk on watch and falling asleep, leaving his ship to run aground on the Scottish coast.

At Newcastle crown court, Judge Denis Orde told Jerzy Pawluk, 42, chief officer of the 900-tonne MV Roustel, it was an "act of God" that none of the six crew had perished.

The ship, empty of cargo but with 16,000 litres of diesel fuel on board, had been heading from Scotland to Teesside last December when Pawluk, a former Polish navy lieutenant with 20 years at sea, left the bridge for his bunk after swigging whisky. He had put the ship on auto-pilot but turned off an alarm which should have sounded every 10 minutes to ensure someone was there.

The 200ft vessel steamed through the night before running aground in heavy seas near Montrose, with the crew in their bunks. Pawluk was arrested in Tyneside when the vessel was taken into dry dock for repairs costing £100,000. He pleaded guilty to conduct endangering ships, structures or individuals under shipping law, charges brought by the maritime and coastguard agency.

The judge told Pawluk: "You drank yourself into oblivion that night... [Your vessel] became, in effect, a ghost ship travelling at full speed through the night.

"Had it struck rocks or collided with another vessel there could have been wholesale slaughter. It was an act of God you ran aground on shingle."

Paul Caulfield, defending, told the court it had been a tragedy for Pawluk. Though he was the breadwinner for his mother and fiancée, his career was finished.

fields.headline: 'Criminal' boys face resort ban
fields.trailText: A council is seeking to exclude two young brothers from the centre of Weston-super-Mare in an attempt to halt the boys' crime wave.
fields.body:
A council is seeking to exclude two young brothers from the centre of Weston-super-Mare in an attempt to halt the boys' crime wave.

One is 12, and it is thought he would be the youngest person in England and Wales to be made the subject of an anti-social behaviour order, introduced in April last year under the 1998 crime and disorder act. It is thought about a dozen orders have been imposed to date.

The boy and his 15-year-old brother are said to have been involved in almost 70 incidents in the Somerset resort over the past three months, ranging from criminal damage to shoplifting and threatening and abusive behaviour.

A summons was served two days before Christmas, but court hearings were adjourned again this week when the shaven-headed 12-year-old complained of toothache and was taken to hospital by his mother.

The boys, who cannot be named for legal reasons, are due to return to court in Weston-super-Mare on February 16.

Shopkeepers say the boys' behaviour has disrupted trade. The brothers, both excluded from school, live with their mother on Weston's largest council estate.

North Somerset became the first authority in England and Wales to use the orders when it secured one against a 27-year-old man who had caused damage at an area housing office on the estate where the boys live.

Eileen Means, North Somerset's director of housing and social services, said the council had decided to seek the latest order following "a lot of complaints" from local people and retailers.

fields.headline: Drink-drive killer gets seven years
fields.trailText: A convicted drink-driver, who drank all day then led police on a car chase before running down and killing an A-level student, was jailed yesterday for seven-and-a-half years.
fields.body:
A convicted drink-driver, who drank all day then led police on a car chase before running down and killing an A-level student, was jailed yesterday for seven-and-a-half years.

Raymond Albert, 28, was serving a two-year ban when he caused the death of Lydia Morgan, 16, last September, Merthyr Tydfil crown court, in south Wales, was told.

Albert, unemployed, had driven to a garage in the town to buy cigarettes when police saw his vehicle nearly hit another car.

Richard Twomlow, prosecuting, said: "The officers shouted for him to stop, which he did. As one officer got out of his car, Albert looked directly at him, took a drag on his cigarette and drove off at speed." As police followed, he rammed two cars and forced some women to run out of his path.

He lost control of his vehicle and hit a parked taxi and a bus shelter before ploughing into Miss Morgan on the pavement. She died of head injuries.

Albert was found to have 118 micrograms of alcohol per 100 millilitres of breath. The legal limit is 35 micrograms.

He admitted causing death by dangerous driving, driving while disqualified, driving with excess alcohol and driving without insurance.

Judge John Curran said: "No comment or sentence can ever put right the permanent feelings of loss, grieving and devastation which are suffered by the victims' families."

As one officer got out of his car, Albert looked directly at him, took a drag on his cigarette and drove off at speed." As police followed, he rammed two cars and forced some women to run out of his path. He lost control of his vehicle and hit a parked taxi and a bus shelter before ploughing into Miss Morgan on the pavement. She died of head injuries. Albert was found to have 118 micrograms of alcohol per 100 millilitres of breath. The legal limit is 35 micrograms. He admitted causing death by dangerous driving, driving while disqualified, driving with excess alcohol and driving without insurance. Judge John Curran said: "No comment or sentence can ever put right the permanent feelings of loss, grieving and devastation which are suffered by the victims' families."

fields.headline: Pinochet ruling on Monday
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: A judge will rule on Monday whether the Belgian government and human rights groups can go ahead with a last-ditch legal challenge to Jack Straw's plans to allow Augusto Pinochet to return to Chile on medical grounds.
fields.body:
A judge will rule on Monday whether the Belgian government and human rights groups can go ahead with a last-ditch legal challenge to Jack Straw's plans to allow Augusto Pinochet to return to Chile on medical grounds.

The Belgian authorities and six human rights groups applied to Mr Justice Maurice Kay for leave to seek judicial review. They argued it would be against the public interest if they were denied access to the medical reasons behind the home secretary's announcement that he is minded to halt extradition proceedings against the former Chilean dictator.

If the judge turns down the application the general could board a Chilean air force jet, waiting in Bermuda for Mr Straw's final decision, and return to Chile as early as next Tuesday. If Mr Justice Kay agrees the judicial review should go forward, it will be heard before three judges. The home office has said Mr Straw would reserve any decision until proceedings have been completed.

At the high court yesterday Presiley Baxendale QC rejected claims from lawyers for the home secretary that Belgium was not entitled to seek judicial review. The request was legally justified as Belgium - along with Spain, Switzerland and France - was actively seeking Pinochet's extradition.

webTitle: Refuse service will help Lundy to clean up its act

fields.headline: Refuse service will help Lundy to clean up its act
fields.trailText: It is one of Britain's most precious isles, an area of outstanding beauty and with wildlife to match. But Lundy Island only had one way to get rid of the tons of rubbish it generated every year - lob it into the sea.
fields.body:
It is one of Britain's most precious isles, an area of outstanding beauty and with wildlife to match. But Lundy Island only had one way to get rid of the tons of rubbish it generated every year - lob it into the sea.

Now the island, which rises steeply out of the Bristol Channel 23 miles west of Ilfracombe, Devon, is finally to get a refuse collection service.

Lundy has 18 residents but the population swells to more than 150 with summer visitors attracted by grey seals and sea birds, including breeding puffins. It is an area of outstanding natural beauty and a site of special scientific interest and has been recommended for special conservation status under the European habitats directive.

But for as long as anyone can remember people have been burning rubbish and sending the remnants, including unmelted cans and bottles, down a natural chute on the south-west of the island into the sea.

Torridge district council's environmental and leisure committee has now agreed that the council should issue the island with three 1,100 litre wheeled bins for domestic rubbish and nine barrels for tin and glass recyclables.

Its waste will be brought to the mainland for collection at Bideford by the island's ship, the MS Oldenburg.

Lundy's general manager, Paul Roberts, said he had been determined to secure a recycling system because it fitted in better with the island's strong environmental spirit.

But he said a study by English Nature had proved the old disposal method had not had an effect on local waters, which were "the cleanest in the UK".
