fields.headline: Getting the goat
fields.standfirst: Extinction augurs ill for other EU species
fields.trailText: The new millennium has started woefully for Capra pyrenaica pyrenaica, a species of Pyrenean mountain goat. Despite money from Europe, new international laws, regional aid and the best efforts of conservationists, the last of a   long-horned, short-haired line stretching back into antiquity died on January 6 after a tree fell on it.
fields.body:
The new millennium has started woefully for Capra pyrenaica pyrenaica, a species of Pyrenean mountain goat. Despite money from Europe, new international laws, regional aid and the best efforts of conservationists, the last of a long-horned, short-haired line stretching back into antiquity died on January 6 after a tree fell on it.

It is a snaphot of what may happen in the next few decades to at least 10 more European species.

The World Wide Fund for Nature yesterday declared that the Iberian lynx, brown bear, harbour porpoise, monk seal, loggerhead sea turtle, a freshwater mussel, Atlantic salmon, marsh fritillary butterfly, lady's slipper orchid and corncrake are in serious decline in EU countries.

Falling trees aside, the constant erosion of animal and plant habitats is blamed for the decline of these and other European species. The WWF says this is the last chance to save them.

Several species found in the UK are under severe pressure. The corncrake and marsh fritillary have been the victims of intensive agriculture as ploughing and pesticides destroy habitat and insects. The harbour porpoise is vulnerable to drowning in fishing nets. Research suggests there are fewer than 650 Iberian lynx left in the wild. Monk seal numbers are put at 500.

The WWF is calling on the British and other governments to implement the EU habitats and species directive, which would give further protection to endangered species. Stuart White of the WWF said yesterday: "European governments have had an excellent conservation law available to them since 1992 to prevent these declines. But they have failed to meet every deadline for putting the law into practice."

The directive was supposed to become national law in all EU countries in 1994 but is not fully on the statute book in any country. Sites for protection under it were to be proposed by the countries by June 5, 1995. All failed to meet that deadline and have been asked by the European commission to propose more sites.

As a result not one country has met the directive's requirements.

The commission has started legal action against Britain for its failure to designate enough sites.

webTitle: Homes of the past feature in minister's vision of future

fields.headline: Homes of the past feature in minister's vision of future
fields.trailText: Folk singer Pete Seeger once called them tacky little boxes all looking the same. The rock star Morrisey launched a 1980s musical tirade against "ugly new houses" painting a vulgar picture.
fields.body:
Folk singer Pete Seeger once called them tacky little boxes all looking the same. The rock star Morrisey launched a 1980s musical tirade against "ugly new houses" painting a vulgar picture.

After years of controversy, the government yesterday finally signalled the end of the modern, off-the-shelf house - colloquially known as the "spec semi" - by promising tough planning guidelines to force through new standards.

Housing minister Nick Raynsford told housebuilders at a London conference that he was determined to drive through a new architectural era, where a strong premium would be placed on good quality design "and far less profli gate use of land". Amid growing concern about proposals for up to 1m new homes in the south-east by 2016, he forecast that discerning buyers would soon reject standardised buildings in favour of more adventurous houses.

"They will not be prepared to put up with the indifferent collection of boxes that have passed for development in the past," he thundered. "Too often, they are mechanistic, unimaginative... produced according to standard layouts which actually waste a lot of space."

What's more, they would not stand the test of time. In a back-to-the-future vision, he said enduring properties in Victorian and Georgian London offered the best example of good design - whereas many modern homes would simply become rundown. "I can't see any of the unimaginative, poor quality developments of the last 50 years being attractive houses people want to buy in the future."

He told the builders: "We are not going to beat about the bush. When applying for planning permission, housebuilders will have to demonstrate [to local councils] how they have taken the need for good design into account." With most regions - particularly the south-east, south-west and East Anglia - facing the threat of thousands of acres being carpeted with concrete and bricks, the government says it is determined to curb urban sprawl.

The minister said developers had to address reality, rather than build speculatively.

"Seventy per cent of future housing requirement is going to be for one person households and yet the vast majority of the houses we have built over the last 30 years or so have been three bedroom."

His main grouse is that developers have failed to learn lessons from the past.

"If the density standards that currently apply had been used in the 18th century none of Georgian London would have been developed... some of the most popular (London) homes were built at four to eight times the number of homes that would typically be built on the same space today," he said.

The Council for the Protection of Rural England has calculated that rebuilding London at the density of current housing would mean filling the entire area within the M25 - 1,000 square miles in all.

It says that around England 8m people could be housed on urban derelict land if it was developed as traditional London streets and squares.

Significantly, the government's urban task force, chaired by the architect Lord Rogers of Riverside, yesterday entered the debate with another strong attack on speculative house building, particularly in the south-east.

webTitle: School sex and drugs survey row

fields.headline: School sex and drugs survey row
fields.trailText: Children as young as 11 have been asked in a school questionnaire how many times they have been "stoned" on illegal drugs, it was disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
Children as young as 11 have been asked in a school questionnaire how many times they have been "stoned" on illegal drugs, it was disclosed yesterday.

The survey, handed out to 6,000 pupils at six schools in Scarborough and Ryedale, North Yorkshire, prompted outrage after it emerged that many of its questions were about drugs and sex.

The four-page questionnaire, issued by North Yorkshire county council, contained more than 100 questions about homework, religion, smoking, drinking, the National Lottery and pocket money.

But more than half dealt with drug abuse, and 26 questions were about sex.

Nick Seaton, chairman of the Campaign for Real Education, said that he was shocked by the number of questions about drugs and sex.

Margaret Morrissey, spokeswoman for the National Confederation of Parent Teacher Associations, said: "I think that it is sad that local authorities are teaching children in this way. I am sure if parents had been consulted about it they would not have been happy."

One teacher at a secondary school said staff were unaware of the survey's contents. "A number of us went to express some concern to the head, particularly those teaching at the younger end of the school," said the teacher.

"It is not something which we should be exposing children to without any overtones of whether it was right or wrong."

David Uffindall, coordinating tutor for health education at North Yorkshire county council, said that it was a sensitive survey.

"We had to take that risk," he said. "Children are going to have to deal with these sort of things in real life. This survey could help save some people's lives or improve people's lives.

"We have to ask sensitive questions to deal with sensitive issues. We want a clear picture of what is happening in our schools."

Mr Uffindall said that the youngsters did not have to answer every question and were given guidance by teachers if they did not understand them.

The results of the survey will now be studied and will help to form the sex and drug education curriculum at the schools which took part.

webTitle: More heterosexuals than gays falling victim to HIV

fields.headline: More heterosexuals than gays falling victim to HIV
fields.trailText: The number of people who contracted HIV through heterosexual sex was higher than those infected through homosexual activity for the first time last year.
fields.body:
The number of people who contracted HIV through heterosexual sex was higher than those infected through homosexual activity for the first time last year.

Figures released by the Public Health Laboratory Service (PHLS) have revealed that new diagnoses of the Aids virus in 1999 were the highest for a decade.

Of 2,457 people diagnosed with HIV last year, 1,070 were infected through heterosexual sex and 989 through homosexual sex.

The remainder were mainly infected as a result of injecting drugs and sharing needles. The 1999 figures are not yet complete and the toll is expected to be the highest in 10 years.

Angus Nicoll, head of the service's HIV and sexually transmitted diseases division, said: "Much of this increase is the result of initiatives to encourage people to get tested, such as the government's new policy of offering universal ante-natal screening to women.

"The majority of those heterosexually-acquired infections affect people who are from or who have spent time in countries with a high prevalence of HIV, in particular, sub-Saharan Africa."

Dr Nicoll called for better access to prevention and treatment information for ethnic minority groups, particularly those from sub-Saharan Africa.

Around 30,000 people are living with HIV in the UK, of whom a third do not know they have the virus.

Last year 361 died in the UK as a result of Aids, compared with 357 the previous year.

Among heterosexuals with HIV, around half are estimated to be unaware of their condition

A spokesman for the Health Education Authority said: "The most recent research we have done among the heterosexual community shows that people sometimes do not appreciate that there is a very real risk of HIV transmission.

"These figures show that there is a very real risk and that there is a need to practise safe sex and to use a condom."

The steady decline in deaths among people with HIV and Aids is also levelling off, causing experts more alarm.

New combination drug therapies introduced in the mid-90s helped improve survival rates and reduce death rates to a third of what they were before 1995.

But there is concern that the tough regime of the drug therapies and their unpleasant side effects are making it difficult for people to take them.

And scientists are also worried that HIV sufferers may be developing resistance to the drugs.

Dr Nicoll said: "We are not yet entirely sure what this levelling out indicates.

"It may be that many of these deaths occur in people who are only diagnosed at the time they become sick with Aids, when it can be too late for them to benefit from the new drug therapies. "Alternatively it may represent cases in which the drugs are not effective, perhaps because of the development of resistance. Further work is needed to explain this trend."

A spokesman for the National Aids Trust said: "These infection figures are extremely worrying. We are concerned that the UK is losing its way in HIV prevention and more needs to be done to increase awareness."

He added: "The drug therapies are extremely tough regimes which many people find difficult to stick to, and often have very unpleasant side effects.

"We have to give people who are taking these therapies a lot more support, and also look at new, more effective and less unpleasant treatments."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Gatwick casts e-net for thefts
Police in Sussex are turning to email in their war against crime in a pioneering scheme being tested at Gatwick. From spring, victims will be able to report incidents, in particular minor offences such as theft, via the Gatwick online database (Gold) and police will download details on to criminal intelligence records.
fields.body:
Gatwick casts e-net for thefts
Police in Sussex are turning to email in their war against crime in a pioneering scheme being tested at Gatwick. From spring, victims will be able to report incidents, in particular minor offences such as theft, via the Gatwick online database (Gold) and police will download details on to criminal intelligence records.

Thefts account for a third of all crime committed at Gatwick, the UK's second busiest passenger airport, yet many offences go unreported if they are only discovered after travellers reach their destination. With the new email system, people will be able to report crime from anywhere in the world.

Misdiagnosis killed youth, 17
Alex Reed, 17, of Long Eaton, Derbyshire, was killed by the medical treatment he received in hospital, a Nottingham coroner said yesterday.

Staff at Queen's medical centre in Nottingham, where he was admitted with suspected tonsillitis, failed to diagnose glandular fever and a ruptured spleen and gave him so much fluid that they flooded his lungs, triggering a heart attack which cut the oxygen supply to his brain. A verdict of accidental death was recorded. The hospital admitted liability, has apologised to the parents, and agreed to pay £7,500 compensation.

UK yard in race for superliner
A UK shipyard is in the running to build Cunard's £370m new superliner, which is expected to be called the Queen Mary 2. Cunard is considering a deal in which Harland and Wolff in Belfast build the hull and superstructure and Germany's Lloyd Werft yard the rest. The company initially said that no British yard was capable of building the 2,500-passenger QM2 which is expected to go into service in 2002.

Chiefs from Cunard's US parent company recently visited Belfast. A decision on the contract and whether the vessel will fly the British flag is expected within six weeks.

Homes in toxic waste scare
Eleven families are being advised to leave their homes in the Weston area of Runcorn, Cheshire, after traces of a toxic waste product which causes cancer in rats were detected.

Tests began after small traces of the chemical, a waste product believed to have been dumped by ICI between 1920 and the 1970s, were detected deep in the rocks of neighbouring quarries. The company offered residents air monitoring tests. So far 11 privately owned terraced homes and a scout hut have shown some presence of the chemical hexachlorobutadiene (HCBD).

North Cheshire health authority advised those residents to leave and four families are being temporarily accommodated in hotels.

fields.headline: Heads warn of school funds 'scandal'
fields.standfirst: Visit our education site at www.educationunlimited.co.uk
fields.trailText: Millions of pupils are being short-changed by "scandalous" disparities in public funding for education across different parts of the country, headteachers warn today.
fields.body:
Millions of pupils are being short-changed by "scandalous" disparities in public funding for education across different parts of the country, headteachers warn today.

In an appeal for the government to fund state schools directly from Whitehall instead of through local authorities the Secondary Heads Association said every school should have a "national funding entitlement". This would mean delivering common education standards that were being dictated in detail from Whitehall.

John Dunford, the SHA general secretary, said variations in funding for schools with a similar intake of pupils were unacceptably wide.

For example, Melbourn Village College, a comprehensive with a Hertfordshire postal address, fell three miles inside the Cambridgeshire education authority boundary. If the school was funded at the Hertfordshire rate, it would get an extra £359,000 a year. After allowing for extra costs in Hertfordshire where teachers are paid an outer London weighting, the difference was worth £570 per pupil.

"There is no logic in this. For intelligent people (in government) to be aware of it and do nothing is scandalous," said Peter Downes, the association's former president and author of its funding proposals.

webTitle: Few prisoners broke curfew in first year of tagging

fields.headline: Few prisoners broke curfew in first year of tagging
fields.trailText: Only 460 of the 16,000 tagged offenders released early from prison in the first year of the home detention scheme have been sent back to jail for breaching their curfews, according to home office research published last night.
fields.body:
Only 460 of the 16,000 tagged offenders released early from prison in the first year of the home detention scheme have been sent back to jail for breaching their curfews, according to home office research published last night.

But the study suggests that the scheme's success lies in the fact that prison authorities were far too cautious in deciding who should take part in it. Some 30,000 inmates qualified for early release but only 16,000 were granted it.

Most of those sent back to jail had been away from home during curfew hours, had threatened monitoring staff or had damaged the equipment.

Only seven were recalled on grounds of representing a risk of serious harm to the public, and police said less than 1% - about 140 - had been charged with a further offence while under curfew. The home secretary, Jack Straw, said the results showed the scheme had been a great success, with 95% of those tagged complying with the conditions of their early release.

Offenders wear an electronic tag which sends an alarm signal if they leave home at night. The most famous tag-bearer is the former Tory cabinet minister Jonathan Aitken.

 The chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, will today attack the activities of the Prison Officers' Association at Dorchester prison as among the worst in the UK.

In his report on the overcrowded Dorset jail, he alleges that the union kept 25 cells empty for more than two years as part of an industrial dispute, and that medical treatment was withheld from some patients in the hospital wing after complaints from POA officials about the number of inmates on medication.

webTitle: Bungling contract killer jailed for life

fields.headline: Bungling contract killer jailed for life
fields.standfirst: Wife gets three years after plotting with friend on shopping trip to hire ex-murderer for 'fantasy world' attack on husband
fields.trailText: A man who took on a contract killing and bungled it was jailed for life yesterday at Stafford crown court.
fields.body:
A man who took on a contract killing and bungled it was jailed for life yesterday at Stafford crown court.

Matthew Lee, 53, agreed on a price of £5,500 to murder Clifford Jones, 35, when approached by Mr Jones's wife, Sandra, 38, and her best friend, Julie Harvey, 34.

The women, old school friends described by the judge as living in a fantasy world, decided on the plot after bumping into each other while shopping, the court had heard.

It failed when Lee, who had been given a key, sneaked into the semi in Uttoxeter where Mr Jones was asleep in bed and hit him over the head with a crowbar - but failed to kill him. Cut and bruised but alive, the husband fought with Lee in the bedroom and struggled with him down into the front garden, where Lee fled.

Detectives were not convinced it was a burglar who had attacked Mr Jones, and within days Sandra Jones had confessed, the court was told.

Lee denied conspiring to murder but was found guilty at the end of a two-week trial. After the verdict the court was told he had been convicted of murder in 1981 and served 17 years. Sentencing him, Judge Justice Kay said he was wicked and dangerous. "You savagely attacked Clifford Jones. It is only fortunate that he lived. I have no doubt your only motive was money."

Jones, 38, who claimed her husband was violent, pleaded guilty to the same charge, and was jailed for three years. "Whatever the problems you had, nothing can have justified the action you took. I accept you were deeply unhappy," the judge told her.

Harvey, 34, of Uttoxeter, was jailed for 18 months after admitting conspiracy. The judge said she was "totally misguided" to encourage her friend to hire a hitman.

Mr Justice Kay said the women seemed to be in a "fantasy world" and described the plot as "astonishing". The pair, former schoolfriends, hatched the plot after bumping into each other while shopping. Jones said she was extremely unhappy and claimed her husband was violent, the court heard. She stood to gain £96,000 in life insurance if her husband died, but police did not believe money was her primary motive.

One attempt by Jones and Harvey to find someone to "do Cliff over" came to nothing, but they persisted and approached Lee, a cleaner in a Uttoxeter pub, knowing he had been convicted of murder and had settled in the town to start a new life. At first he thought they were joking but eventually agreed when Jones took out a £6,000 loan to pay him.

Bernard Thorogood, prosecuting, said: "The trio decided they would make the murder look like a burglary. Mr Lee was given a key and they carefully hatched a plan which involved him entering the house after Sandra Jones left in the morning. Clifford Jones would have been asleep after his factory night shift."

Lee bought a crowbar from a hardware shop and last February he attacked Mr Jones. Sandra Jones had taken their daughter, 13, and son, eight, to school, expecting to find her husband dead when she returned. Instead, he was giving a statement to the police, nursing cuts and bruises from several blows to his head.

Staffordshire police did not believe it was burglary because there was no forced entry. Within days they discovered Jones had been plotting with Lee.

DCI Peter Hall said: "Sandra was arrested in front of Clifford in the kitchen. We wanted to speak to them separately, she wanted them to stay together. Clifford was virtually speechless." Mr Hall added: "He said they had a turbulent marriage, but he never thought things were that bad. He had absolutely no suspicion his wife had anything to do with the attack."

Mr Jones denies ever assaulting his wife, including allegations he hit her with bowling balls, and the police say there is no evidence to support the claims.

He said last night he had written to the judge to ask him to be lenient. "I find it hard to be bitter, with the children involved. They have already seen their mum taken away once when she was on remand, and now I have got to go home and explain all this again.

"I have no real feeling for Lee; he had to go down as he is a danger to the public. But as far as Sandra goes, it should never have got this far."

webTitle: Why we can't afford to make a crisis out of a drama

fields.headline: Why we can't afford to make a crisis out of a drama
fields.standfirst: Comment
fields.trailText: "Give us the tools and we will finish the job," said Churchill in 1941. And that seems to be the bottom line of Peter Boyden's report into regional theatre. We cannot, in short, expect our theatres to go on being play-producers, arts centres, educational resources and much else besides on the current meagre subsidies. I well remember Stuart Burge, when director of Nottingham Playhouse in the early 1970s, telling me he felt like an industrial welfare officer for the east Midlands. But theatres cannot be asked to be carry so many social burdens without the funding to match.
fields.body:
"Give us the tools and we will finish the job," said Churchill in 1941. And that seems to be the bottom line of Peter Boyden's report into regional theatre. We cannot, in short, expect our theatres to go on being play-producers, arts centres, educational resources and much else besides on the current meagre subsidies. I well remember Stuart Burge, when director of Nottingham Playhouse in the early 1970s, telling me he felt like an industrial welfare officer for the east Midlands. But theatres cannot be asked to be carry so many social burdens without the funding to match.

What, however, is the case for sustaining a network of producing theatres across the country? For decades the debate has gone on as to whether we should have "equal misery for all" or commit our limited resources to a few regional centres of excellence. In other words, focus on the big-city theatres in Manchester, Birmingham, Leeds, Sheffield, Nottingham and elsewhere and axe the playhouses in the smaller towns and cities.

In a way it is similar to the debate raging about county cricket in which some, including Mike Atherton, advocate dropping the present system and concentrating on a few elite regional teams. In theatrical terms, however, it would be a tragic mistake.

For a start each regional theatre is an expression of its community. The clearest example I had recently was at the Bolton Octagon, threatened last year with being turned into another bland receiving house. As you walked into the theatre, you were asked to sign a petition protesting at the plans and urging that the theatre stay a producing house. Even more strikingly, at the end of the evening - the premiere of Charlotte Jones's Martha, Josie and the Chinese Elvis - the audience stood and cheered in solidarity. Bolton had seen and Bolton had spoken.

Regional theatres are also part of a national network that not only sustains the theatre but the whole entertainment industry. Jude Kelly, director of West Yorkshire Playhouse, says she hates the word "training-ground". I see her point but the fact is that regional theatre is a huge nourisher of talent. Anthony Hopkins honed his craft in Leicester in the early 1960s, Antony Sher and Jonathan Pryce were products of the Liverpool Everyman and Janet McTeer, who this week picked up a Golden Globe best actress award, emerged from Manchester's Royal Exchange. The list is endless. Every time we close a regional theatre we are not only killing a vital piece of community life but aiming a blow at the artistic industry.

Can we afford to sustain our regional theatres? We can't afford not to. Audiences and artists need the diversity the network of regional theatres affords. Chop off a few and the whole system will soon crumble, leaving us with a denuded artistic life and even more civic centres that, in the evening, become ghastly echoing ghost towns.

webTitle: Oasis star 'over the moon' after birth of baby Anais

fields.headline: Oasis star 'over the moon' after birth of baby Anais
fields.trailText: As celebrity baby names go, the new born daughter of Oasis star Noel Gallagher and his wife, Meg Matthews, got off lightly yesterday when her parents chose to name her Anais - after Ms Matthews' favourite author Anais Nin.
fields.body:
As celebrity baby names go, the new born daughter of Oasis star Noel Gallagher and his wife, Meg Matthews, got off lightly yesterday when her parents chose to name her Anais - after Ms Matthews' favourite author Anais Nin.

The latest addition to the Gallagher clan was born two weeks early weighing 7lb 6oz at lunchtime on Thursday at the Portland Hospital, in central London.

Anais, meaning fruitful in Greek, was said to be "doing well". Last night Gallagher, 32, described the experience as "the best thing ever", adding that he was "over the moon" at the birth which he attended despite his earlier fears that it would resemble "Exorcist material".

While Ms Matthews, 33, celebrated with champagne accompanied by her mother, Chris, and her mother-in-law Peggy, the new father chose to wet the baby's head with a pint or five of Guiness in a nearby pub.

Meg, whom he met in 1994 while she was working at the band's former record company Creation and married three years later, was "feeling great" after an easy labour, he said.

"It's just like she's been shopping," he added. "She looks amazing, she doesn't even look like she's had a baby.

Gallagher insisted that the birth would not change him "too much" and it would bring out his "feminine side".

Baby Anais's literary namesake was born in the Parisian suburb of Neuilly-sur-Seine on February 21, 1903, living and working in Paris, New York and Los Angeles until her death in 1977. After studying psychoanalysis under Otto Rank, she went on to publish her first work, The House of Incest in 1936, followed by a series of avant garde novels, including Delta of Venus, A Spy in the House of Love, and a book of short stories, Under a Glass Bell.

Gallagher was due to stay overnight in the hospital, after a celebratory drink with his brother.

fields.headline: Curtains for debt-laden theatres?
fields.standfirst: Chronic underfunding strangles creativity and plunges regional venues into financial crisis, report warns
fields.trailText: Most of the country's best regional theatres are technically insolvent after 20 years of chronic underfunding, and the constant fear of going under is undermining their work, a new report claims.
fields.body:
Most of the country's best regional theatres are technically insolvent after 20 years of chronic underfunding, and the constant fear of going under is undermining their work, a new report claims.

The Arts Council-commissioned Boyden report - which is likely to form the basis of the most radical shake-up in decades - blames theatres' woes not on waste or mismanagement but on being continually starved of cash.

The findings are a clear challenge to government thinking that further sacrifices will have to be made and more theatres closed before the long-running policy of "misery for all" can be ended.

When the review was first announced last year, the culture secretary, Chris Smith, called for "unsentimental hard decisions" and warned that "simply because funding support has always been in place [it should not be assumed] that it must continue to be the case for ever more".

But management consultants Peter Boyden and Associates, who found that more than half the "producing" theatres they surveyed were in the red, said a failure to take risks for fear of further losses was cramping creativity.

Their preliminary report claims that without help, loss-making theatres which clung on through the Thatcher years "have little chance of trading their way out of trouble. The debilitating artistic impact of fragile balance sheets is a major constraint for producing theatres," it added. "Boards feel exposed to personal liability, programmes tended to conservative and innovation discouraged."

Crucially, it confirms long-held fears within the industry that over-reliance on populist playwrights like John Gobder and Alan Ayckbourn is turning some regional reps into "museums". Forced to run the same bankable old reliables, they risked alienating the young and forcing the next generation of writers to look to television and film.

Too much emphasis on balancing budgets was affecting the quality of new work, it warned. "There is also the complex question of the artistic cost of a trading surplus. It seems reasonable that if the funding exists to support quality work then the idea of an 'artistic' deficit is as unacceptable as a trading loss."

The lottery millions had been a mixed blessing, "de-stabilising the trading environment" by favouring the bigger city theatres over those in smaller towns, while the increased costs of running new buildings put a further strain on already straitened budgets.

Theatres were also being asked to do educational work and projects to counter social exclusion, without sufficient cash. The report praised regional houses for the work they already do in these areas and said "the cost of failing to build on the excellence of much current practice is potentially high".

"Many theatres lack the resources they need to fulfil their potential and deliver this full range of benefits," it adds. "Some of them have become fragile vessels in which to place such wide-ranging responsibilities."

Nevertheless, the report detects positive signs in Whitehall and Chris Smith's victory in wresting more money from the treasury for the arts last year - the first increase in 20 years - "holds out the prospect of change".

The findings were widely welcomed by regional theatres. Maggie Saxon, of the West Yorkshire Playhouse, which - despite huge West End success with Spend, Spend, Spend and big audiences in Leeds - is in the red, said theatres had been set up to fail. "The case for more money is irrefutable at this stage. The report is an accurate appraisal of the current situation - it is just foolhardy not to invest in these theatres."

Ludo Keston of the New Victoria in Newcastle under Lyme near Stoke, which is also running a deficit, said the report could not have been clearer that the fundamental issue was lack of money. "It is up to the government now. Theatre has got to a crunch point. This cannot go on any longer."

Even theatres which are cited by the government as paragons of virtue, such as the Theatre Royal, Plymouth, which is to launch two shows into the West End in the next few months, argue that extra funding can be put off no longer. Artistic director Simon Stokes said regional theatre was full of "scavengers who had learned to survive on next to nothing. I challenge anyone to find more financially savvy people anywhere."

But there were limits to scrimping. "There is no room for emotion in the subsidised sector, and there never will be. We budget down to zero. We give very, very good value for money. The jury is now out on the government."

Ted Craig of the Croydon Warehouse, whose very existence is threatened by property developers, said it all boiled down to more money. "We never have seen any realistic increases in funding. Over 20 years this builds up. It's a now or never situation, I'm afraid."

Behind the scenes: the fight for survival

Croydon Warehouse (Breaking even)
Artistic director Ted Craig: 'We're on the edge. Since our lottery application to build a new theatre was turned down, we could be closed down at any time by the property developer who owns the area. We will keep hammering on.' Despite their troubles, 'people are being turned away' from the theatre's second Dick Barton-based hit, The Pharaoh's Tomb, which will soon go on national tour

West Yorkshire Playhouse, Leeds (In debt)
Chief executive Maggie Saxon: 'You have to be stubborn and stand up to people who want to put you in a box.' A regional powerhouse, the Playhouse scored huge West End success with Spend, Spend, Spend, its musical based on pools winner Viv Nicholson. Also hopes to transfer its current hit, Singing in the Rain, to London

Wolsey Theatre, Ipswich (Closed)
The last proper rep in East Anglia went dark last year. A strong local campaign has been launched to resurrect it

Theatre Royal, Plymouth (Not in debt)
Artistic director Simon Stokes: 'We've pioneered a way of surviving with co- productions that others are following.' Lautrec, a musical based on the French painter, opens soon and will transfer to the West End. Adventures in Motion Pictures will open its follow-up to Swan Lake there in March

New Victoria Theatre, Stoke (In debt)
Manager Ludo Keston: 'There's a danger we'll all turn into museums. We want to be able to put on the best of now not the best of what was.' Mr Keston has reduced debts from £200,000 to £60,000

The Gate, Notting Hill (In debt)
Artistic director Mick Gordon: 'This is a passion machine. We need £30,000 by March. It's mad and it's always the same every year. The whole situation is crazy.' Mr Gordon earns £7,000 for running a fringe theatre with an international reputation

Palace Theatre, Watford (Not in debt)
Artistic director Lawrence Till:'You have no idea what has been lost because of lack of money. It doesn't bear thinking.' The Palace produced the West End hit Elton John's Glasses. The Late Middle Classes, which it commissioned, was voted play of the year last year

But management consultants Peter Boyden and Associates, who found that more than half the "producing" theatres they surveyed were in the red, said a failure to take risks for fear of further losses was cramping creativity. Their preliminary report claims that without help, loss-making theatres which clung on through the Thatcher years "have little chance of trading their way out of trouble. The debilitating artistic impact of fragile balance sheets is a major constraint for producing theatres," it added. "Boards feel exposed to personal liability, programmes tended to conservative and innovation discouraged." Crucially, it confirms long-held fears within the industry that over-reliance on populist playwrights like John Gobder and Alan Ayckbourn is turning some regional reps into "museums". Forced to run the same bankable old reliables, they risked alienating the young and forcing the next generation of writers to look to television and film. Too much emphasis on balancing budgets was affecting the quality of new work, it warned. "There is also the complex question of the artistic cost of a trading surplus. It seems reasonable that if the funding exists to support quality work then the idea of an 'artistic' deficit is as unacceptable as a trading loss." The lottery millions had been a mixed blessing, "de-stabilising the trading environment" by favouring the bigger city theatres over those in smaller towns, while the increased costs of running new buildings put a further strain on already straitened budgets. Theatres were also being asked to do educational work and projects to counter social exclusion, without sufficient cash. The report praised regional houses for the work they already do in these areas and said "the cost of failing to build on the excellence of much current practice is potentially high". "Many theatres lack the resources they need to fulfil their potential and deliver this full range of benefits," it adds. "Some of them have become fragile vessels in which to place such wide-ranging responsibilities." Nevertheless, the report detects positive signs in Whitehall and Chris Smith's victory in wresting more money from the treasury for the arts last year - the first increase in 20 years - "holds out the prospect of change". The findings were widely welcomed by regional theatres. Maggie Saxon, of the West Yorkshire Playhouse, which - despite huge West End success with Spend, Spend, Spend and big audiences in Leeds - is in the red, said theatres had been set up to fail. "The case for more money is irrefutable at this stage. The report is an accurate appraisal of the current situation - it is just foolhardy not to invest in these theatres." Ludo Keston of the New Victoria in Newcastle under Lyme near Stoke, which is also running a deficit, said the report could not have been clearer that the fundamental issue was lack of money. "It is up to the government now. Theatre has got to a crunch point. This cannot go on any longer." Even theatres which are cited by the government as paragons of virtue, such as the Theatre Royal, Plymouth, which is to launch two shows into the West End in the next few months, argue that extra funding can be put off no longer. Artistic director Simon Stokes said regional theatre was full of "scavengers who had learned to survive on next to nothing. I challenge anyone to find more financially savvy people anywhere." But there were limits to scrimping. "There is no room for emotion in the subsidised sector, and there never will be. We budget down to zero. We give very, very good value for money. The jury is now out on the government." Ted Craig of the Croydon Warehouse, whose very existence is threatened by property developers, said it all boiled down to more money. "We never have seen any realistic increases in funding. Over 20 years this builds up. It's a now or never situation, I'm afraid." Behind the scenes: the fight for survival Croydon Warehouse (Breaking even) Artistic director Ted Craig: 'We're on the edge. Since our lottery application to build a new theatre was turned down, we could be closed down at any time by the property developer who owns the area. We will keep hammering on.' Despite their troubles, 'people are being turned away' from the theatre's second Dick Barton-based hit, The Pharaoh's Tomb, which will soon go on national tour West Yorkshire Playhouse, Leeds (In debt) Chief executive Maggie Saxon: 'You have to be stubborn and stand up to people who want to put you in a box.' A regional powerhouse, the Playhouse scored huge West End success with Spend, Spend, Spend, its musical based on pools winner Viv Nicholson. Also hopes to transfer its current hit, Singing in the Rain, to London Wolsey Theatre, Ipswich (Closed) The last proper rep in East Anglia went dark last year. A strong local campaign has been launched to resurrect it Theatre Royal, Plymouth (Not in debt) Artistic director Simon Stokes: 'We've pioneered a way of surviving with co- productions that others are following.' Lautrec, a musical based on the French painter, opens soon and will transfer to the West End. Adventures in Motion Pictures will open its follow-up to Swan Lake there in March New Victoria Theatre, Stoke (In debt) Manager Ludo Keston: 'There's a danger we'll all turn into museums. We want to be able to put on the best of now not the best of what was.' Mr Keston has reduced debts from £200,000 to £60,000 The Gate, Notting Hill (In debt) Artistic director Mick Gordon: 'This is a passion machine. We need £30,000 by March. It's mad and it's always the same every year. The whole situation is crazy.' Mr Gordon earns £7,000 for running a fringe theatre with an international reputation Palace Theatre, Watford (Not in debt) Artistic director Lawrence Till:'You have no idea what has been lost because of lack of money. It doesn't bear thinking.' The Palace produced the West End hit Elton John's Glasses. The Late Middle Classes, which it commissioned, was voted play of the year last year

fields.headline: IRA need more time - Adams
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president, raised the stakes over the future of Northern Ireland's fledgling government last night, warning that Unionist "tactical manoeuvring" over IRA arms decommissioning could finally scupper the fragile peace process.
fields.body:
Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president, raised the stakes over the future of Northern Ireland's fledgling government last night, warning that Unionist "tactical manoeuvring" over IRA arms decommissioning could finally scupper the fragile peace process.

Mr Adams made it clear that republicans would view seriously any move next week by Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, to suspend the new power-sharing executive and cross-border bodies. Emergency legislation would then signal a return to direct rule.

His hardline speech was aimed at deflecting criticism back on to Ulster Unionists as Irish government sources and the SDLP showed signs of losing patience with Sinn Fein. The nationalist Irish News published a rare front-page editorial, demanding an IRA gesture.

General John de Chastelain, chairman of the international commission on decommissioning, will issue his latest report on Monday. He will be unable to announce that IRA decommissioning is under way, sparking crisis after a two-month honeymoon period.

David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionist party, agreed in November to join the executive with Sinn Fein after telling his ruling council that he would resign as first minister if there were no start to IRA decommissioning by February 12. The 860-strong council is due to reconvene then to assess the situation.

After General de Chastelain's reports, Mr Mandelson will consider putting the new institutions into cold storage pending a second review of the Good Friday agreement. To allow Mr Trimble and his three Ulster Unionist ministers to resign would create enormous difficulties even if the review succeeded.

Mr Adams said the only reason to do that would be if there had been default on decommissioning. There had been none. He warned Mr Mandelson that he would be acting outside the 21-month agreement to do that. The government has so far been fastidious in ensuring it fulfill its obligations.

Mr Adams insisted that there was no secret deal during ex-US senator Goerge Mitchell's review last year that there would be a start to decommissioning by January. Ulster Unionists sources claim they had expected it to begin in the week after Christmas.

Mr Adams, opening new party offices in Newry, Co Down, said: "The reality is that a collapse or even soft landing or another review phase would recreate a political vacuum, reinforce and encourage negative Unionists, put the entire process into jeopardy and make decommissioning even more difficult that it has been so far."

Mr Adams said he remained committed to decommissioning, and would continue to try to bring it about. But that had been set back because Sinn Fein's opponents had used the issue as a political football.

He said: "Sinn Fein succeeded in persuading the IRA to meet General de Chastelain because the UUP leadership gave commitments to enter the institutions. There was no question of this being for a conditional period. Will collapsing the institutions or resigning leadership positions or going into another review settle this matter of decommissioning? Of course not. Will it make it more or less likely? It will serve only to advance the interests of the no men of unionism."

webTitle: Kidney blunder surgeon was warned before

fields.headline: Kidney blunder surgeon was warned before
fields.standfirst:
The National Kidney Research Fund
Prince Philip Hospital
fields.trailText: The consultant urologist in charge of the bungled operation in which a pensioner's one healthy kidney was removed had previously been warned by hospital officials to take more care after the death of a high-risk prostate patient on whom he had operated, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
The consultant urologist in charge of the bungled operation in which a pensioner's one healthy kidney was removed had previously been warned by hospital officials to take more care after the death of a high-risk prostate patient on whom he had operated, it emerged last night.

The surgeon, John Roberts, 58, has been sent home on leave from Prince Philip hospital, Llanelli, south Wales, while experts investigate how the kidney blunder occurred.

Graham Reeves, 69, a former soldier and power station worker, remained in a critical condition last night, three days after what should have been a routine operation to remove a diseased kidney.

Carmarthenshire NHS trust has asked the Royal College of Surgeons to carry out an independent inquiry into Mr Roberts' surgery in addition to an internal inquiry into the operation, whose preliminary results are expected to made known today. The trust is also to carry out an audit of 400 recent operations at the hospital. It said Mr Roberts was a very senior and experienced surgeon and it had had no reason to raise questions about his ability. But the medical director, Peter Thomas, said executives had talked to the surgeon after the post-operative death of a high-risk prostate patient at the hospital.

Mr Thomas said he had asked Mr Roberts to be more careful. "It was a very difficult, high-risk case. There was a complication and the patient died. It is not clear whether he died as a result of the operation."

Mr Thomas also revealed that Mr Roberts had been suspended from a previous post at Ysbyty Gwynedd general hospital in Bangor, where he worked between 1983 and 1997, after a disagreement with the management.

A Gwynedd hospital spokesman confirmed he had been reprimanded over his personal conduct, but said the incident did not involve a patient or patient care.

Monday's blunder was not discovered until after the operation had been completed when the removed kidney was sent for examination. Laboratory staff discovered the tissue was healthy.

Mr Reeves, who fought in the Korean war, is on a dialysis machine at Morriston hospital, Swansea, to which he was moved after the mistake was discovered.

Hopes that a close relative might be found to donate a kidney for transplant to replace the diseased organ the surgical team should have removed received a setback yesterday when it emerged that Mr Reeves had no brothers, sisters or children.

Friends and neighbours of Mr Reeves in Burry Port, west Wales, said they were horrified by the blunder. Lorraine Ashford, a close friend, said: "He really needed this operation. He was told he would feel much better afterwards and he was looking forward to getting his health back."

The Welsh health secretary, Jane Hutt, said she was deeply disturbed that such an error could have been made. In a statement to the national assembly's health and social services committee, she said the NHS in Wales would explore all options available for fur ther treatment of Mr Reeves.

The trust disclosed that Mr Roberts, who was in charge of the case, had carried out the operation with an unnamed surgical registrar and others.

It said the surgical team, who were "very distressed" by what had happened, had been relieved of their responsibilities until further notice. It had been decided that Mr Roberts should take leave but he would be available for both inquiries into the incident.

webTitle: Woman 'frozen' in lake brought back to life

fields.headline: Woman 'frozen' in lake brought back to life
fields.trailText: A young doctor who was clinically dead for three hours was brought back to life after she became trapped under ice and her body temperature dropped to a record low of 13.7C.
fields.body:
A young doctor who was clinically dead for three hours was brought back to life after she became trapped under ice and her body temperature dropped to a record low of 13.7C.

Anna Bagenholm, 29, a trainee surgeon, was skiing off-piste, near Narvik, in northern Norway, when she fell through a frozen river and became trapped under the ice for 40 minutes.

As colleagues struggled to rescue her from beneath the ice, her body temperature gradually dropped and her vital organs shut down.

Her temperature had fallen more than 23 degrees below normal. No one is known to have lived after becoming so cold before. The previous survival record was held by a child whose temperature fell to 14.4C.

Ms Bagenholm was resuscitated and given oxygen on her way to hospital by air ambulance.

On her arrival at hospital she was not breathing, her blood circulation had stopped, and her pupils did not respond to light.

However doctors re-warmed her while her circulation was maintained with a heart-lung machine until her heart started to beat again.

She spent 60 days in intensive care, including 35 days receiving ventilator treatment.

Five months after the accident she returned to work and she has since resumed hiking and skiing.

The case was described in the Lancet medical journal. Mads Gilbert, of the Tromso university hospital, Norway, said the key to surviving such hypothermia included "a spirit not to give up".

fields.headline: TV ban boy found hanged
fields.trailText: A 12-year-old boy hanged himself after his parents said he could not watch TV as punishment for being given a school detention, an inquest heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A 12-year-old boy hanged himself after his parents said he could not watch TV as punishment for being given a school detention, an inquest heard yesterday.

But the North Durham coroner, Andrew Tweddle, said there was no evidence Daniel Quinn had intended to take his own life.

Daniel was found hanged by one of his belts, which was attached to the wall of his bedroom at his home in Chester-le-Street, Co Durham, on January 21.

Daniel's father Michael, a driver, told the hearing in Durham that his son seemed to be his normal self when he came in from school.

Mr Quinn told the court that Daniel, a pupil at Pelton Roseberry comprehensive school, went upstairs to his room after being given the punishment.

When a friend rang, his parents called up for him to answer. But when no answer came they thought he was sulking, the inquest heard.

Mr Quinn said: "When I entered the room Daniel was sitting on the floor but with his back in a position against the wall." Daniel never regained consciousness, the court heard.

Detective Sergeant Eric Malcolm confirmed that there were no suspicious circumstances.

He added that after two searches of the room no suicide note had been found.

webTitle: Abuse suspect killed by Spanish police

fields.headline: Abuse suspect killed by Spanish police
fields.trailText: A British man shot dead by Spanish police in the holiday resort of Torremolinos yesterday was wanted in connection with a series of sexual assaults on an 11-year-old girl, Spanish authorities said.
fields.body:
A British man shot dead by Spanish police in the holiday resort of Torremolinos yesterday was wanted in connection with a series of sexual assaults on an 11-year-old girl, Spanish authorities said.

The man, identified by Spanish police as Michael Lindgen-Hornett, 49, was killed after a car chase from Malaga airport, where British police officers had gone to try to arrest him.

British authorities last night refused to confirm his identity.

A Scotland Yard spokesman confirmed that two officers from the Metropolitan police had flown to Spain to arrest a man in connection with indecency charges.

Spanish police said that Mr Lindgen-Hornett had driven his British-registered car on the wrong side of the road for almost 20 miles as he tried to escape police.

After crashing in a dead end street he is then said to have attempted to reverse his car over a Spanish police officer.

Spanish police opened fire and shot him once in the chest.

A foreign office spokesman said: "We believe that a man shot and killed by Spanish police in Torremolinos on January 27 may have been a British national."

A Scotland Yard spokesman said the two Met officers had travelled to Spain on Wednesday after a man failed to answer to police bail.

"They travelled to Spain in connection with the proposed arrest of a man wanted for questioning by the Met in relation to alleged indecency offences," he said.

The spokesman added: "I cannot confirm the whereabouts of the Met officers at the time of the shooting, but it is a Spanish police matter."

He added that the man they were looking to interview was arrested in Britain last year and released on police bail in November.

fields.headline: Tories toughen asylum line
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Asylum seekers from "safe countries" should be locked up automatically on entering Britain and have their cases fast-tracked in 14 days, the Tories insisted yesterday in their harshest response yet to the rise in asylum applications.
fields.body:
Asylum seekers from "safe countries" should be locked up automatically on entering Britain and have their cases fast-tracked in 14 days, the Tories insisted yesterday in their harshest response yet to the rise in asylum applications.

The shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, said that Labour's decision to scrap the "white list" of countries judged to have no persecution, introduced by Michael Howard in 1995, meant the UK was seen as a "soft touch" for bogus claims.

Up to 8,000 people would be detained under the Tory crack down, Miss Widdecombe said. "We need to so something more to toughen up the message which goes out, and that is that you would automatically detain anyone who's applying for asylum who was on that list.

"The message would be 'if you come to Britain with a bogus claim from a safe country we will lock you up and we will turn your case around quickly and we will return you to your country'."

The proposal will prompt outrage among refugee campaigners, who welcomed the abolition by home secretary Jack Straw of the white list. The six "safe countries" were India, Ghana, Bulgaria, Cyprus, Poland and Romania. The government dismissed the Tory proposals, but a rise in asylum applications from 29,000 in the Tories' last full year to 71,000 last year has put the government firmly on the back foot over the issue. New figures also revealed that local authorities can find places around the country for no more than a fifth of the 20,000 refugees awaiting asylum decisions.

Miss Widdecombe yesterday insisted the proposed crackdown would not harm genuine asylum seekers.

"It's designed to make life very hard for the chap who is abusing the system. Imagine someone leaving England and saying 'I'm persecuted'."

webTitle: Cook bounces back as cheerleader for euro

fields.headline: Cook bounces back as cheerleader for euro
fields.standfirst:
Last year he was beset by troubles and tipped to lose his job. Now the foreign secretary and former Eurosceptic has rebuilt his reputation
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, will today deliver a speech billed as his most important since his ethical mission statement soon after the general election. He will cover everything from the rules of intervention through to Britain's membership of the United Nations security council, but most interest will surround what he has to say about the euro.
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, will today deliver a speech billed as his most important since his ethical mission statement soon after the general election. He will cover everything from the rules of intervention through to Britain's membership of the United Nations security council, but most interest will surround what he has to say about the euro.

This former euro-sceptic has transformed himself into the cabinet's main cheerleader for a speedy entry into the single currency. While the chancellor, Gordon Brown, once the leading spirit in the charge towards Europe, has gone quiet on the subject of late, Mr Cook has become increasingly vocal.

In today's speech at Chatham House in London, Mr Cook will stick rigidly to the agreed formula on the single currency but his language, as with his other recent speeches, will be enthusiastically pro-European. The transformation in his position on the euro is not the only one he has accomplished. Mr Cook's lowest point came almost exactly a year ago as he awaited publication of his ex-wife's book. "He was psychologically wounded," one of his few close friends said this week. No wonder: she branded him a penny-pinching drunk and womaniser.

His register office marriage to mistress Gaynor Regan also saw him ridiculed with newspaper claims that he sneaked out of the foreign office's country retreat wearing a car coat for the private ceremony.

Things were not much better at work. There had been the disastrous trip to India with the Queen, the Sierre Leone affair and accusations of hypocrisy in his ethical foreign policy. The murmuring at Westminster was becoming louder. He had failed to fulfill the promise he had shown in opposition and had disappointed those who believed him to be the great hope of the left. He was a prime case for being dropped at the next reshuffle.

"He never showed it and he would not thank me for saying it, but of course he was hurt. Robin is very sensitive," said a Labour insider. "You could see him wince when he read some of the stuff."

But, unusually for such an unforgiving profession, he has succeeded in rebuilding his career. Tony Blair praised him lavishly at the end of the Kosovo conflict for his skill in keeping the Western alliance together. As he goes out jogging, to shed those pounds from embassy lunches and dinners, he can look back with some satisfaction on a remarkable political recovery. A foreign office insider said that January last year "was not only his low point but his turning point".

He now looks secure, at least until the general election. The one problem is the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, who longs to be foreign secretary. When Mr Cook does move, a job that might appeal would be constitutional overlord with responsibility for Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

Nothing infuriated Mr Cook more during his difficulties in 1998 than being dubbed "Mr A4" by opponents who claimed he was lazy and demanded all reports be boiled down to a single sheet of paper. Downing Street concurs with the view that one of his strengths is his workrate. One source said he was obsessive about detail, especially at EU summits, where he could reel off the negotiating position of each person round the table.

With confidence returning after the Kosovo conflict, Mr Cook burst back into the political scene in September with the most pro-single currency speech yet from a cabinet minister. He had had a reputation as a leading Eurosceptic and his sudden enthusiasm for the euro appeared to be a contradiction. He squares it by saying he had opposed it, though not as much as the media suggests, but once it had become a reality, it would be foolish to be outside. The foreign office view is that Britain is in danger of losing influence by being excluded from key European meetings and, in the longer term, risks losing foreign investment.

Mr Cook's thinking is in line with Mr Blair's, though the prime minister is less vocal about it. The government has said it is committed to the single currency in principle and that there will be a referendum on it soon after the general election.

The relationship between the foreign office and the treasury is poor, though Mr Cook hates it being suggested that this has anything to do with his long-running feud with the chancellor, Gordon Brown. The permanent secretary at the foreign office, Sir John Kerr, is an unabashed advocate of joining the euro, whereas at least one key treasury official has hinted entry might even have to be delayed until the parliament after next.

The extent of the ill-feeling that exists is illustrated by an incident last week when foreign office ministers and officials discussed who had leaked details of a Zimbabwe arms deal to the Guardian. One of those present suggested it might have been treasury-inspired, to damage the foreign secretary.

In spite of his improved standing within government, Mr Cook is still not loved by many of the civil servants at the foreign office, who have accused him of being more concerned with presentation than with substance, and who find him personally difficult to work with. But he has in recent months being trying to make amends.

At a private party hosted by Mr Cook and Gaynor for staff and their partners in the drawing room of his Carlton House Terrace residence, he said in an emotional speech: "I just want to say thank you to all of you because I know if ever I get any credit for anything it's also down to you. I've invited partners because I know that you all work long hours." After that little speech he went up to Gaynor and showed how he can still be ill at ease by asking: "Was that all right? Did I say the right things?"

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: WR: Mysteries Of The Organism
fields.body:
WR: Mysteries Of The Organism

(Dusan Makavejev, 1971)

11.45pm, FilmFour

Still a cult and festival favourite, this bizarre and original Yugoslavian film generated plenty of controversy at its release (and has been misconstrued as a porn film ever since) thanks to its subject matter and the fact that its title was often misread as Mysteries Of The Orgasm. Instead, it's an intelligent satire based on the theories of Wilhelm Reich, associate of Freud and inventor of the "Orgone Accumulator", who equated communism with sexual repression.

Hobson's Choice

(David Lean, 1954)

5pm, Carlton Cinema

Delightful screen version of Harold Brighouse's stage comedy, filmed in the authentic industrial-Lancashire atmosphere of Salford. It's beautifully played, with Charles Laughton as the boozy bootmaker who's tied up in knots by his eldest daughter Brenda de Banzie and her dim husband, John Mills. Funny, and warm as a ferret up a trouser leg.

A Fistful Of Dollars

(Sergio Leone, 1964)

10pm, FilmFour

It's pretty raw compared to Leone's masterly Once Upon A Time In The West, but as the spaghetti western that made Clint Eastwood the Man With No Name, A Fistful Of Dollars breathed new life into a fading genre. The plot is freely borrowed from Kurosawa's Yojimbo, with Clint's laconic, ponchoed gunman playing off two warring factions against each other in a dusty Tex/Mex border town.

Smilla's Feeling For Snow

(Bille August, 1997)

1am, Sky Premier

Interesting if ultimately disappointing adaptation of Peter Hoeg's bestseller. Julia Ormond is Miss Smilla, an alienated woman who starts to find herself while investigating the death of her one friend, a 12-year-old Inuit boy; and with its chilly snowscapes it's always watchable, but the story drifts between romance, thriller and Bergmanesque soul searching.

fields.headline: At home with Tony
fields.standfirst: It could be as explosive as the Princess of Wales on Panorama: an intimate portrait of Tony Blair that could cast him in a new light.  Michael White  talks to Michael Cockerell, the reporter who has been given unprecedented access to our leader
fields.trailText: Michael Cockerell is one of life's smoothies. It is as easy to imagine the BBC's veteran biographer sweet-talking girlfriends, wives and children down the years as he has so successfully done with politicians. He's done it again, this time with Tony Blair (What Makes Tony Tick?, BBC2, Sunday, 8pm).
fields.body:
Michael Cockerell is one of life's smoothies. It is as easy to imagine the BBC's veteran biographer sweet-talking girlfriends, wives and children down the years as he has so successfully done with politicians. He's done it again, this time with Tony Blair (What Makes Tony Tick?, BBC2, Sunday, 8pm).

For over 10 years now, the bedrock of the Cockerell family mortgage in Notting Hill has been television political portraits, all the way from Enoch Powell and Alan Clark on the Tory right through to lefties like Barbara Castle and Michael Foot.

There have been plenty of centrists in between, the Callaghans, Healeys and Ken Clarkes. In fact, Clarke was a first: perceptively profiled while still chancellor. His little brother, a cheerful Midlands car salesman, said Ken had never acknowledged their mother's alcoholism. The poignant interview with Clarke seemed to bear out that claim.

But on Sunday night Cockerell tackles the centrist's centrist: Blair gives what his interrogator calls the most intimate and frank answers to personal questions ever provided by an incumbent prime minister.

"People will see him in a way they have never seen him before," predicts Cockerell. It is enough to persuade Tunbridge Wells colonels to stay by the telly with their shotguns. There are shirt-sleeved Blair opinions on the death of Princess Diana, on charges that he is a control freak or the Napoleon of Downing St - a claim first made by an aide who meant it as a moderniser's compliment. As with several of Cockerell's recent films - How To Be A Foreign Secretary or Westminster's Secret Service - this is as much the portrait of an institution as an individual.

Cockerell, a manipulative expert at pre-publicity, was cagey for this article. He dribbles out titbits around Fleet St before transmission day and knows that tomorrow's tabloids will love what he has learned about Di, and about Blair and Cherie's courtship (and recent baby).

We usually forgive Cockerell his tricks because he delivers what he promises, Roy Jenkins's love life, for instance. Tastefully done, natch. Alan Clark's slightly less tastefully. While the TV crew was waiting for the diarist to arrive home at Saltwood Castle, his formidable wife, Jane, spilled the beans on camera while feeding the peacocks.

Cockerell the telly spin-doctor sees this as a turning point for the boy premier - that the film will do for him what Martin Bashir's interview did for the doomed princess ("there were three of us in the marriage"). But serious students of the Cockerell oeuvre may find their interest focused on that perennially fascinating topic which holds up the government: the Blair-Brown relationship. Throw in "Bobby" Mandelson and indeed it is the nearest thing New Labour has to a marital threesome.

Everyone knows the story, Cockerell conceded yesterday. How Tony and Gordon were inseparable, how they both assumed Gordon was the senior partner until the dreadful day of John Smith's sudden death in 1994. How Blair, backed by Mandelson, rapidly emerged as the heir and Brown gave up his claim - for now.

"Those few weeks were the most difficult days in my entire life. There was a lot of sorting out to do with Gordon," Blair tells Cockerell. But the film, some of it not previously seen, tells the story better. The two young MPs are seen chatting and joking in the 80s and early 90s - the body language is relaxed and intimate. Cut to the Blair-Brown meeting last week to back Frank Dobson's bid for London mayor. Blair praises his chancellor with evident admiration. But Mr Brown is seen scarcely to smile, let alone laugh at his friend's jokes.

Lord Irvine, Blair's legal pupil master, now his Lord Chancellor, is seen to say: "Tony was the right man at the right time in the right place and luck plays a crucial part in the career of every politician." Blair stresses how close they remain, but it is a different relationship, one with a big unresolved question at its heart.

Labour's former general secretary, now chairman of the Notting Hill Housing Trust, Lord Tom Sawyer, gives viewers a flavour of it all.

"I think obviously there's lots of public comment about his relationship with Gordon. I observed them both closely at many, many meetings between '94 and '98, and I would say it was a very strong professional relationship," he reports. "But you must never underestimate the tensions at the top in politics. Doors do slam, telephones do get slammed down, and people drift for a few days and don't speak. But this happens in families, never mind in politics."

Doors slammed, sulks and silences, it is the stuff of cabinet government since the cabinet itself first evolved in that jerry-built terraced house in the 18th century. But now it is on film for all to see - Cockerell has caught the cabinet filing in with their bone china cups of tea alongside Lucy, David Blunkett's blind dog.

Blair uses the opportunity to tell the cabinet - and the Cockerell cameras - about the need to build a clear set of arguments and alliances for the euro. That in itself should alert us to the fact that fly-on-the-wall cameras do not always tell the unvarnished truth even if they like to give the impression that they do. Mike Cockerell may be an old smoothie, but Tony Blair is a young one.

Still, it is not a badly matched contest. More self-effacing than Paxman, less emollient than Frost, Cockerell may be the insider's interviewer. But he remains a craftsman at his work.

webTitle: Behind the screen: Janine Gibson's TV gossip

fields.headline: Behind the screen: Janine Gibson's TV gossip
fields.trailText: A moment of silence - pray - for the demise of two of the Fox network's most enduring hits, Beverly Hills 90210 and Party Of Five, both on the brink of extinction, we understand.
fields.body:
A moment of silence - pray - for the demise of two of the Fox network's most enduring hits, Beverly Hills 90210 and Party Of Five, both on the brink of extinction, we understand.

Aaron Spelling's tale of high school angst in LA has followed the trials of Brandon, Kelly, Steve, David and Donna for ten years, clocking up what's alleged to be the highest number of episodes of any show still on television. But all good things must come to an end, and sinking ratings combined with the loss of key cast members mean that we must bid farewell to the oldest high school kids in town, who by now must surely have graduated from college and got proper jobs.

Still, the fans have taken it hard, and are rallying via the medium of Fox's website. Petitions are being gathered, and appeals are out to boost the ratings. "Go round to your grandmother's house and set the TV to 90210" appeals one die-hard.

There is a precedent. Fan pester-power succeeded in saving Party Of Five from its first axing threat in 1995. After a shockingly slow start, the series which brought us the pouting twosome, Neve Campbell and Jennifer Love Hewitt, was all set for the chop until rescued at the insistence of vociferous fans. Fox gave in but issued the dire warning "well, you'd better watch it then", a tactic which unaccountably worked for six seasons, though not without the threat of extinction at the end of each. Now Campbell and Hewitt (or is it Love Hewitt? Hard to tell) are busy being film stars, the unfeasibly traumatised five orphans have run out of 12-step programmes to join, and seem set to split for good. Which, we can only assume, means no more of the fabulous PO5 drinking game: drink when alcoholic Bailey drinks; two sips when miserable Claudia whines and down in one if the rarely spotted baby Owen appears. Shame.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Out with his family five years ago, television producer Christopher Morris found some mud-stained sheets of paper in a hedge. They turned out to be pages from a diary. Once Morris had deciphered the sentence "Rommel went through Cannes last night" he determined to discover more. Fragments In Time (11.0am, Radio 4) tells the story of his eventually successful hunt for the author, and of the time she spent nursing elderly British patients who had found themselves trapped in Nazi-occupied France.
fields.body:
Out with his family five years ago, television producer Christopher Morris found some mud-stained sheets of paper in a hedge. They turned out to be pages from a diary. Once Morris had deciphered the sentence "Rommel went through Cannes last night" he determined to discover more. Fragments In Time (11.0am, Radio 4) tells the story of his eventually successful hunt for the author, and of the time she spent nursing elderly British patients who had found themselves trapped in Nazi-occupied France.

In Routes Of English (4.0pm, Radio 4) Melvyn Bragg discusses with Professor Richard Hoggart and others why spoken English should carry so many underlying social messages. Is there any other tongue which transports such a load of cultural baggage? It can take no more than one brief sentence to telegraph someone's whole background, however hard they may try to disguise it.

webTitle: Who are you? What the Land Rover ad says about you

fields.headline: Who are you? What the Land Rover ad says about you
fields.trailText: The ad: This intelligent spoof of Born Free cleverly casts the Land Rover Freelander in the wild outdoors instead of its more usual habitat of the North London school run. It features a group of game wardens driving across Africa to release an unseen animal. "It's all wrong. The city is no place for them", says the Zulu warden, his words subtitled in English. Eventually they tease the "animal" out of the truck and it turns out to be a Freelander, which zooms off across the savannahs.
fields.body:
The ad: This intelligent spoof of Born Free cleverly casts the Land Rover Freelander in the wild outdoors instead of its more usual habitat of the North London school run. It features a group of game wardens driving across Africa to release an unseen animal. "It's all wrong. The city is no place for them", says the Zulu warden, his words subtitled in English. Eventually they tease the "animal" out of the truck and it turns out to be a Freelander, which zooms off across the savannahs.

The jargon: This ad is aimed at reconfirming its credentials as a genuine off-roader. "It's about mental freedom, not actual freedom", says agency WCRS.

Personality: The ad uses its humour to hook in a more youthful consumer, so you are likely to be at the younger end of the jeep market, ie 26-35. You are also likely to be living somewhere urban, particularly in or around London.

Financial status: A Freelander is comparable in price to a good Ford or a top-end VW Golf - it costs between £16,000 and £22,000.

Telling lifestyle detail: You are very sociable and active, into going away at the weekends and getting muddy. Basically you've got better things to do on Sunday mornings than worry about washing your car.

Other relevant data: It was shot in Namibia and the savannahs of South Africa using native actors. The star is the renowned Patrick Ndlovu who speaks throughout in a genuine Zulu dialect.
