fields.trailText: Columbus discovered the clitoris in the sixteenth century.
fields.body:
Columbus discovered the clitoris in the sixteenth century.

Trust me. I have an honest face.

This Columbus was an Italian anatomist, who spotted the clitoris in the course of a day's routine rummaging. As Donne put it "Oh my America! my new-found-land."

Channel 4 are not familiar with the meaning of the word private, which is why the lift running up the side of their offices is made of glass and why they are showing a series called Private Parts . You have to behave very circumspectly in the lift. This is not true of the series.

Next week, the penis. This week the clitoris. An hour is a long time in television, but I must say it grew on me. In every sense, I suppose.

The catch about being a critic is that, while television puts out such programmes at night, the review is read in the morning. Parts of the film were plainly pornographic in a perfectly well intentioned way. A faithful account would tend to put you off your Cheerios.

Those who persevered to the end encountered an endearing duo, Del and Svar, artists who specialise in genitalia. Rather like Steve, who makes plaster casts of the vulva for drawer handles. You put your hand in and pull, if you follow me. Del and Svar were women, but decided against it. By dint of determined doses of male hormones, they achieved something between a clitoris and a penis. There was clearly room for improvement, so Del demonstrated a sort of vacuum pump. The result can be unpredictable. "Oh! No! Ow!' he cried. "It's stuck!"

This minor malfunction was cut out of the final edit, which seems a pity. Pure farce is a familiar and disinfecting factor in sex.

Del and Svar, like many contributors, were American. Frankness comes with the territory. There were certified sexologists (not necessarily insane), some explicit footage from Masters and Johnson ("The physiological changes in the sexually stimulated female), and the dreadfully nosey Betty ("The grandmother of sex education.") An Australian surgeon, Helen O'Connell, who discovered in 1998 that the clitoris, like an iceberg, was largely hidden and much bigger than believed, was refreshingly discreet.

The man in the street was represented by a cheerfully rowdy bunch of traders from Covent Garden flower market. They pointed out how blatantly anatomical anthuriums are and recoiled like salted snails from the director's bunched fist. Presumably proferred so they could point out the position of the clitoris.

There were also some deeply dubious statistics about the frequency of female orgasms ("The average woman has five orgasms a week.") As Bertie Wooster said when assured there is no love without trust, "Who told you that?"

One charm of Dinnerladies (BBC 1) is that we now know the characters so well that we can predict how they would react to this intimate stuff.

Dolly (Thelma Barlow) would hate Private Parts and look forward confidently to a scathing piece in today's Daily Mail. Petula (Julie Waters) would not only love it, she would be in it. Possibly as an explicit drawer handle. In this last programme she videoed a message to her daughter from her death bed ("No, I'm not in shot! I can tell. Lower! That summer with Ken Russell wasn't wasted.") You are never positive with Petula that there is not a pinch of truth in her rich fantasy life.

The old-fashioned canteen has been phased out in favour of a sandwich bar and the little solar system of dinnerladies has shot off at various tangents, rather the way Bren thinks. So we know it is all over. Jet propelled by a final, mighty fart, Petula dies of, well, everything really. ("They had to write really small to get it all on the certificate.") There is a certain bounce, wouldn't you say, in dying of everything?

I am glad I didn't know that, in our darkest hour, British secret agents were confidently working on an exploding rat. Churchill's Secret Army (Channel 4), or the SOE, were completely new to sabotage. They were, therefore, ingenious, inventive and particularly fond of gadgets. Booby-trapped wine bottles, exploding coal and a corrosive paste for engraving rude things about Hitler on glass windows, which was cunningly packaged in toothpaste tubes and inadvertently sent out to agents without instructions. And, of course, the exploding rat. There was a diagram of this unfortunate animal. It seemed ("Pay attention 007!") to have a time fuse up its backside.

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.trailText:
Good day
Michael Fabricant. The beautifully coiffeured Tory MP for Lichfield made a heartfelt plea that many would empathise with. He complained about being swamped with "useless junk faxes" and demanded consumer protection "for the poor guy who owns a fax machine and ends up having to pay for the paper, the toner and everything else".

Bad day
London's millennium celebrations after it was revealed that the cost of clearing up after revellers was estimated at £500,000. Junior environment minister Keith Hill said that the Millennium Commission contributed £180,000 towards the cost.

Today
Second readings of two private member's bills, on prevention of euthanasia, and protection of animals .

fields.headline: Dobson attacks Millbank 'mess'
fields.standfirst:
Party HQ damaged me, says Downing St's favourite
The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Frank Dobson yesterday made a last-ditch attempt to assert his independence from the Labour leadership in the London mayoral contest, as Tony Blair hailed him as "an unspun, unspoilt candidate" and party officials claimed the former health secretary has been gaining ground against Ken Livingstone.
fields.body:
Frank Dobson yesterday made a last-ditch attempt to assert his independence from the Labour leadership in the London mayoral contest, as Tony Blair hailed him as "an unspun, unspoilt candidate" and party officials claimed the former health secretary has been gaining ground against Ken Livingstone.

Labour's Millbank machine had "messed things up from start to finish", Mr Dobson said, in an attack clearly intended to convince party members that, despite being Downing Street's candidate, he will not be a puppet of the hierarchy.

Referring to the prime minister as "his nibs", Mr Dobson said in an interview with the New Statesman magazine that he had suffered "more harm than anybody else" and lost considerable support as a result of the leadership's intervention on his behalf.

But as ballot papers for the Labour nomination are delivered to almost 50,000 party members in the capital, the prime minister once more endorsed him in a final push before voting begins. "He is someone I can trust," Mr Blair said, adding: "You take him as he is."

The final stages of the nomination battle were again marked with bitter accusations and controversy. Mr Dobson and his running mate Trevor Phillips turned renewed fire on Mr Livingstone, claiming the frontrunner's decision to offer the deputy mayor's job to Glenda Jackson instead of Mr Phillips would leave Afro-Caribbean voters without representation in London.

Mr Dobson said: "He will have alienated a lot of Afro-Carribean Labour supporters", adding that "people will not be very happy at this casual opportunism by Ken".

Last year Mr Phillips rejected the former Greater London council leader's offer of the deputyship, arguing it was patronising that as a black candidate he should be expected to run for the deputy's job.

Yesterday Mr Livingstone said: "I approached Trevor Phillips and he said I would be a disaster for London, so I have gone for Glenda."

Ms Jackson meanwhile called for a Labour party inquiry into Millbank's conduct of the mayoral nomination campaign and said the attacks on her and Mr Livingstone had "if anything, boosted our support and been counter-productive".

Mr Dobson said he had found the whole process "embarrassing and deeply angering".

He added that he would "remain convinced until the day I die that I would have won in a ballot on the basis of one member one vote", rather than the electoral college that is being used.

fields.headline: A man of straw
fields.standfirst:
This political and not medical decision was taken last June

Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: In principle, I rather detest articles or items that begin or end with the words, "You heard it here first". Nonetheless, this is what I told readers of the Nation on December 28 1998, in rounding off a whole series of uncannily, nay eerily, exact predictions about the Pinochet case: "I also know Jack Straw, and I think he'll contrive a 'humane' way to let Pinochet go home. Everything Straw does is modelled on Clinton, from 'zero tolerance' for dope to school uniforms and curfews for teenagers. People who preach 'law 'n' order' for the weak are invariably soft on crime when it comes to the strong."
fields.body:
In principle, I rather detest articles or items that begin or end with the words, "You heard it here first". Nonetheless, this is what I told readers of the Nation on December 28 1998, in rounding off a whole series of uncannily, nay eerily, exact predictions about the Pinochet case: "I also know Jack Straw, and I think he'll contrive a 'humane' way to let Pinochet go home. Everything Straw does is modelled on Clinton, from 'zero tolerance' for dope to school uniforms and curfews for teenagers. People who preach 'law 'n' order' for the weak are invariably soft on crime when it comes to the strong."

In the intervening period, Straw used his tenure as home secretary to make the asylum laws as inelastic as possible for impoverished and desperate refugees, while allowing the defendant in the world's landmark torture and kidnapping case to sit in a country house and receive regular teatime visits from Baroness Thatcher. The baroness never noticed or reported any signs of mental deterioration in her old pal and kept on about his courage and fighting spirit, but now we are asked to believe that the general is in such a state of decrepitude that he wouldn't or couldn't even understand the charges against him.

This is what I intended to convey by putting the word humane in inverted commas. The coalition of anti-Pinochet forces with which Jack Straw has to deal - that coalition that favours international human rights law - is not in favour of dragging terrified or disabled people before tribunals that are conducted in a language unknown to the defendant, as happens all the time to deportees from British shores. Nor does it favour keeping people in suspense for long periods about their fate, as has been routine for refugees from dictatorships armed by British weapons manufacturers. So it was quite witty and clever, all things considered, for a Labour minister to discover that common decency and the quality of mercy could and should be applied this one exceptional time.

Usually, the politicised inhumanity of the British home office is justified by reference to the strict letter of the law. This time, the politicised lenience is directly related to the most lax interpretation of the relevant statutes. In this instance, a Spanish request for extradition has been met by an abrupt British statement that the accused is unfit to stand trial - and none of the supposed medical evidence has been made available to the plaintiffs or to the jurisdiction that represents them. "Somewhat absurd," as the Spanish judicial reply so politely understates the case.

That's disgraceful enough on its own. More outrageous still is the distinct possibility that Straw has overstated the findings of his four-person medical team. Sir John Grimley Evans, who admittedly sounds like a Conan Doyle character and who is nonetheless professor of clinical gerontology at Oxford University, has given discrepant interviews about the relationship between Pinochet's medical state and his fitness for the dock. This may be a false issue, in any case, since Pinochet always refused to meet doctors appointed by the Spanish judge, Baltasar Garzón.

Straw counters both Spanish and British demands for an evaluation of the medical records by saying - and here again one doffs the hat in salute to a true pseudo-humanitarian - that these cannot be examined without Pinochet's permission! Quite apart from the fact that confidential medical material is presented in court every day, how can a man supposedly suffering from dementia be expected to make such a call, let alone be the judge in his own case?

The pro-Pinochet Sunday Telegraph revealed what has long been common knowledge in a certain area of the left, namely that this political and not medical decision was actually taken in June of last year. The British and Spanish foreign ministers met then at the Rio summit and decided that such a highly toxic defendant could not be allowed to expire on British or Spanish soil. All that remained was the confection of an excuse that would sound good to good people.

It was criminal in the highest degree to ignore an essential submission made by the Spanish court as far back as October 19 1998. This was a request that testimony be taken from Pinochet, whether this testimony would eventuate in a trial or not. Many thousands of Chileans and dozens of other nationals want to know what happened to their relatives, in circumstances too awful to recapitulate. Pinochet can shed light on this, in cases where he is not the defendant. Or he could have.

In January Judge Garzón renewed this forlorn appeal for a Comisión Rogatoria, simply to take evidence from the prime source. I doubt it will weigh much. The Blair and Clinton administrations didn't just dislike the idea of Pinochet as a defendant. They rejected the possibility of his even being a witness. And this is part of the measure of their own complicity, which is why we ought to hope that one day, they get justice too.

 Reprinted from the current issue of The Nation, New York

fields.headline: Sex education plan 'same as section 28'
fields.standfirst:
Stonewall
Section 28 explained
fields.trailText: The government moved to appease opponents of its plan to repeal section 28 yesterday, by promising to place marriage and family life at the heart of strengthened sex education guidelines.
fields.body:
The government moved to appease opponents of its plan to repeal section 28 yesterday, by promising to place marriage and family life at the heart of strengthened sex education guidelines.

Though mainstream gay campaigners were unwilling to condemn the move publicly, privately critics fear it would amount to a reintroduction of section 28 through the back door.

A commitment by the socially conservative education and employment secretary, David Blunkett, to issue new guidance follows pressure from religious leaders protesting at the planned change to the law banning the "promotion" of homosexuality.

In a phrase which will infuriate gay campaigners, department for education sources yesterday indicated that the advice on sex and relationships education would effectively give guidance "along the same lines" as section 28.

Although the department yesterday stressed there was "no intention for the new guidance to be a vehicle for the deliberate promotion of any sexual orientation", it also said the circular would cover "the importance and nature of marriage and family life in bringing up children".

Mr Blunkett told the cabinet yesterday: "What people do not want is proselytising" in favour of gay lifestyles. He promised to talk to church leaders.

Tony Blair argued that repeal is vital because section 28 is a "badly drafted, discriminatory piece of legislation".

The commitment to consult widely on the guidelines is a clear attempt by ministers to defuse the row over section 28, amid attacks on the repeal plans by high profile bishops and, on Wednesday, by the chief rabbi Dr Jonathan Sacks. The move has also been criticised by the right-wing media.

However, the government has also made - somewhat clumsy - attempts to keep its own backbenchers on board, finally issuing a firm commitment yesterday that Labour MPs would be ordered to vote in favour of repeal of the clause, introduced under the 1988 local government act.

Backbenchers had earlier expressed outrage at Downing Street suggestions that MPs - a handful of whom are opposed to the change - could be given a free vote on the issue.

The planned new guidance for schools will relate to sex and relationships education, taught as part of personal, social and health education. The guidelines, last issued in 1994, are due to be updated following recommendations in a government report on teenage pregnancies before Christmas.

Mr Blunkett, a supporter of the traditional family who opposes the reduction of the gay age of consent to 16, also wants to bring the guidance in line with the priorities underpinning new citizenship lessons, which will also stress the importance of marriage and stable families.

The sex education guidelines will also remind schools that policy should be decided by the governing body, in consultation with parents. Downing Street hopes that, too, will reassure opponents of section 28 repeal.

A DfEE source said: "The guidance will be strong in guiding schools and authorities. It will promote marriage and tradition family life."

Asked whether the circular would, in effect, reinforce the section 28 bar on the promotion of homosexuality, the source said: "In so far as it will give guidance on that, yes, the document will guide on the same lines."

The department's statement said the guidelines would "ensure that teachers are in a position to offer information and support to all young people and to address incidents of homophobic bullying".

The lesbian and gay pressure group Stonewall, while accepting the current guidelines' support for stable families and marriage, last night said it sought further measures enabling teachers to address homophobic discrimination.

fields.headline: Donald Budge
fields.standfirst: One of tennis's all-time greats, he was the first player ever to achieve the grand slam
fields.trailText: In 1938, Donald Budge, who has died aged 84 of a heart attack, became the first person to achieve the tennis grand slam - winning the United States, French, Australian and Wimbledon championships in the same year. It would be more than 25 years before another man, the Australian Rod Laver, equalled that feat, and in the 60-odd years since Budge's triumph, no other American male player has managed it.
fields.body:
In 1938, Donald Budge, who has died aged 84 of a heart attack, became the first person to achieve the tennis grand slam - winning the United States, French, Australian and Wimbledon championships in the same year. It would be more than 25 years before another man, the Australian Rod Laver, equalled that feat, and in the 60-odd years since Budge's triumph, no other American male player has managed it.

In that year Budge had surpassed himself. He not only won the men's doubles, mixed doubles and singles at Wimbledon - all for the second year running - but also became the first player ever to win Wimbledon without the loss of a set. In the final, against Britain's Bunny Austin, he lost only four games. "Donald was unstoppable that afternoon, almost unplayable at times," Austin remembered. "He was a true great. Painfully thin, red-headed, with a prominent nose, protruding ears and eyes close together, he appeared more pasty-faced Glaswegian than Californian golden boy. In 1934, he retained his California state championship and, with Mako, won the Pacific Coast. On his way east he beat Frank Parker in the semi-finals of the national clay court championship in Chicago, at a time when Parker was thought invincible on clay.

He effectively clinched this triumph with what is often described as the greatest match in the history of tennis, the third-day singles match in the interzone finals at Wimbledon against the German champion von Cramm. Budge lost the first two sets and, having equalised, was 2-5 down in the fifth set - but, in a match of transcendent virtuosity, he eventually triumphed 6-8, 5-7, 6-4, 6-2, 8-6.

This match was filmed, so it is still possible to witness Budge's unique talent at its height. His victory, restoring the Davis Cup to the US after its loss to France a decade earlier, was an immediate stimulus to American tennis and inspired thousands to adopt his aggressive style.

At this point, Budge had also just become Wimbledon champion. He had reached the semi-finals at his first attempt, unseeded, in 1935, overcoming Bunny Austin in an extraordinarily lengthy quarter-finals match, before losing to von Cramm. The following year, seeded fifth, he did equally well, losing to Fred Perry, while becoming, with Mako, US doubles champion.

In the 1937 Wimbledon clash, Budge lost only one set, and beat von Cramm 6-3, 6-4, 6-2 in the finals. With Mako, he also won the men's doubles and, with Alice Marble, the mixed doubles. He was also that year's US champion, and for the third year running won the Mercedes Benz Cup. At the New York World's Fair, Babe Ruth presented him with the Sullivan Award as outstanding national athlete in any sport, the first time a tennis player had won this trophy.

Budge's style was innovatively aggressive, with good weight of shot all round. His backhand, even stronger than his forehand, made devastating use of a heavy, 15-ounce racquet, and he developed a rolled shot that was consistently accurate and awesomely authoritative. He said that Ellsworth Vines was "the best player in the world on his day", while watching Fred Perry taught him the importance of commanding the net. "I patterned my game after Vines and Perry; then I turned it up a notch" he said. He never smoked, nor drank during his years as a player. Asked what made a champion, he replied: "Discipline. You have to have discipline to go to bed early."

The power of his strokes and his determination to win were combined with an unshakably sportsmanlike demeanour. As Laurie Pignon put it, "he never questioned a call or raised a ginger eyebrow."

Between 1933 and 1938, Budge had survived in the amateur game on tournament expense money. He always denied having been paid under the table, though he conceded that "expenses" could be generous. When the Australian Tennis Association paid for him and Mako to sail to Australia, for instance, the journey took three weeks each way. On the other hand, his Wimbledon prize was a Mappin & Webb voucher for £5.

It couldn't go on, and after his grand slam win, Budge announced that he would turn pro at the beginning of 1939. He had turned down an offer of $50,000 the previous year; now he accepted it.

Some 16,000 people turned out to Madison Square Garden for Budge's pro debut against his old idol, Ellsworth Vines, on the night of January 3 1939. He won. In March, he beat Fred Perry. In his first year as a pro, he recalled in the 1980s, he "made $148,000 and paid $2,080 in taxes. Gasoline was 10 cents a gallon... and a good room was $6 a night. So I was able to invest a lot of that money."

The second world war interrupted his play. A soldier in the Army Air Corps, he served in the Pacific, but injured his shoulder while training. He competed and gave exhibitions after the war, but could not recover his previous unbeatable form.

His book, Budge On Tennis, first pubished in 1939, was reprinted in the 1950s, and in 1969 came Don Budge; A Tennis Memoir. He and his first wife, with whom he had two sons, drifted apart, and in 1974 Budge married his second wife, Loriel. He sold the Don Budge tennis camp, Baltimore, in 1983 but remained on the board of advisers of Prince Racquets, and on the committee to pick the world's champion each year.

A lifelong jazz fan, Budge was a friend of Pablo Casals, among others. He grew in dignity and gravitas as he aged, and though he left no stock of witticisms, he could quote Einstein and the poet Heinrich Heine, on God and religion, and George Bernard Shaw on war and peace.

In the world of tennis, Budge set out to be the world's best. He succeeded, and in the process, he designed the modern game.

webTitle: 10 dead as bomb destroys Sri Lankan post office

fields.headline: 10 dead as bomb destroys Sri Lankan post office
fields.trailText: A powerful bomb blast yesterday ripped through the main post office in the northern Sri Lankan town of Vavuniya, killing at least 10 people, including three soldiers.
fields.body:
A powerful bomb blast yesterday ripped through the main post office in the northern Sri Lankan town of Vavuniya, killing at least 10 people, including three soldiers.

The bomb, which was left on a counter inside the building, appeared to be aimed at security personnel, who made regular visits there.

"It was payday on Wednesday, and everyone knows that the next day the army and police go to the post office to send money orders back to their families in the south," said P Manikavasagam, a local journalist.

The late-morning explosion injured more than 70 people, mostly civilians, with eight soldiers and eight policemen among the casualties.

"It seems that those responsible were targeting the army, but unfortunately the public was also killed," the army spokesman Brigadier Palitha Fernando said.

The security forces have blamed the attack on the rebel Tamil Tigers who have been fighting a 17-year battle for a separate Tamil homeland in the country's north and east.

The separatists attacked police and army convoys, killing nine soldiers in a mine attack just south of Vavuniya two weeks ago. A Tamil town controlled by the government, Vavuniya is an obvious target, as it lies less than 13 miles from the front lines.

The Tigers have also been blamed for three recent suicide bombings in which more than 50 people have died. The Sri Lankan president, Chandrika Kumaratunga, sustained serious eye injuries during one attack on her final election rally in Colombo in December, and earlier this month another suicide bomber blew herself up outside the office of Ms Kumaratunga's mother, the prime minister, Sirimavo Bandaranaike.

In October the Tigers overran several army camps just north of Vavuniya, and there were fears that the town would be attacked.

At one point, the Tigers ordered everyone to leave and residents, expecting artillery attacks, fled to nearby villages and towns until the Tigers relaxed the order.

The government has stepped up its efforts to track down the Tigers. The police and army have carried out cordon and search operations in Tamil areas of Colombo, where thousands of people have been photographed and questioned. Hooded informants have been used to point out suspects.

The blast followed a visit this week by a high-level delegation from Norway, which raised speculation about peace moves. The Norwegian secretary for development, co-operation and human rights, Leiv Lunde, met representatives of the Tamil parties, ministers and civil groups.

Norwegian officials and a Tamil Tiger representative are also reported to have met in London. The government, which previously rejected any idea of a third-party mediator in the conflict, now appears to support it.

"The Norweigans wouldn't say anything because whatever they are doing is very sensitive," said R Sampanthan of the Tamil United Liberation Front, who met Mr Lunde. "But they are very interested in the prospects of peace and the need for a consensus."

The government has already drawn up a timetable for peace. Ms Kumaratunga's hopes are pinned on a proposal to devolve power to the regions to satisfy Tamil demands for more autonomy.

The government says it will negotiate with the Tigers after discussing its proposals with the other political parties. But the bomb blast in Vavuniya suggests the Tigers are not immediately giving up their armed struggle.

"On the surface, there is some positive movement and we should support that," said Jehan Perera of the National Peace Council. "But the fact that the Tigers blasted this bomb probably gives out a message as well."

General elections are due within the next seven months, and political parties are likely to wait until afterwards before committing themselves to peace plans which may end in failure.

webTitle: Murdered exile's grave located at Paris mosque

fields.headline: Murdered exile's grave located at Paris mosque
fields.standfirst: £60m religious site linked to international plot to kill opponent of Moroccan king 35 years ago
fields.trailText: Thirty-five years after the Moroccan opposition leader Mehdi Ben Barka disappeared after being kidnapped in Paris, his secret burial site has been located south of the capital.
fields.body:
Thirty-five years after the Moroccan opposition leader Mehdi Ben Barka disappeared after being kidnapped in Paris, his secret burial site has been located south of the capital.

His body was buried under Europe's biggest mosque, built by his bitter foe, the late King Hassan II of Morocco.

The operation to silence Ben Barka, the king's former mathematics teacher who died aged 45, involved the Moroccan defence chief, General Mohammed Oufkir, the French secret service and leading gangland figures linked to the Gaullist party.

The discovery of his grave follows a decision by King Mohammed VI, enthroned last year after Hassan's death, to allow Ben Barka's widow and four children to return to Morocco.

The French prime minister, Lionel Jospin, has also lifted a secrecy ban on most of the archives documenting the affair.

It appears that Hassan had known of the circumstances of Ben Barka's murder when he financed the building of the £60m mosque over the secret grave. The building of the mosque, at Courcouronnes near Orly airport, started in October 1984, 19 years after Ben Barka was bundled into a car as he went to the Lipp brasserie in Saint-Germain-des-Prés for lunch.

He had flown to Paris from Geneva, where he was living in exile, supposedly to discuss a film on oppression in Morocco, where he faced arrest for leading a democracy movement.

The invitation was a set-up, according to evidence given in several criminal trials that arose from the kidnapping.

After being stopped by two plainclothes French policemen on the Boulevard Saint-Germain, Ben Barka was handed over to Frenchmen with long criminal records at a house at Fontenay-le-Vicomte, south of Paris, to await a meeting with Oufkir.

After being seriously injured in a fight with his captors, the opposition leader was bound and gagged, then transferred to a house at nearby Ormoy, where he died in a cellar on October 30 1965.

What happened to his body has now been revealed to Paris Match by a former secret serviceman, Antoine Lopez, known as "Don Pedro".

Mr Lopez, now 75, said he had seen Ben Barka being tortured in the cellar and then helped put his body, wrapped in an army blanket, in the boot of a Mercedes. The car was driven six miles to a field, where his kidnappers dug a grave in a small copse known as the Bois de la Mare à la Besace.

Oufkir was convicted of Ben Barka's abduction and murder and sentenced to life imprisonment in his absence by a French court. He died in 1972 after leading an abortive coup against King Hassan.

A French policeman and an intelligence agent were jailed for the abduction.

Several senior French intelligence personnel were sacked but many details of the case remain unclear because their involvement resulted in many documents being classified.

It is believed that archives may reveal that France's president at the time of Ben Barka's murder, Charles de Gaulle, knew of the burial site and had informed Hassan before the area was submerged by a building programme for the new town. Three years after Ben Barka's burial, French authorities compulsorily acquired the land and in 1977 ceded it to a Moroccan cultural association.

Guided by Mr Lopez, investigators have located the site under the car park in front of the mosque, but have ruled out exhumation because it is under several feet of concrete.

According to Paris Match, Mr Lopez, the last surviving member of the kidnap team living in France, traded his information against an eventual meeting with Hassan.

The king was invited to the Bastille Day celebrations last year, but died 10 days later, before a meeting could be arranged.

Revelations concerning the burial site have not quashed rumours that Ben Barka's head was sent to Hassan in a diplomatic bag and buried in a desert tomb.

Nor has there been any progress in finding four gangsters linked to the abduction who were given refuge by Hassan after fleeing France.

webTitle: Italian women queue to join up

fields.headline: Italian women queue to join up
fields.trailText: The opening of Italy's armed forces to women has unleashed a tidal wave of applications which is forcing the authorities to intensify the feminisation of what was Nato's last male-only bastion.
fields.body:
The opening of Italy's armed forces to women has unleashed a tidal wave of applications which is forcing the authorities to intensify the feminisation of what was Nato's last male-only bastion.

The government is expected today to raise the planned 20% quota of female cadets after half the applicants for military academies turned out to be women.

Plans to phase in female fighter pilots, tank drivers and ship gunners have been exposed as insufficiently radical in light of the pent-up desire of Italian women to join up. The government is also considering bringing forward to this year the date for allowing women to become junior officers.

A decree last September abolishing the ban on women in the ranks, hailed as a milestone in sexual equality, has obliged the military to hastily amend barracks organisation, uniforms, language and rules.

A total of 1,004 men and 917 women have applied for the 700 places on Italy's two-year officer training courses. Most of the applicants for the army academy at Modena and the naval academy at Livorno were women, although men remain in the majority in applying for the air force academy at Pozzuoli.

The women must be between 17 and 25, with secondary school diplomas, childless and single or divorced. They will undergo a two-month selection. Those over 25 with suitable degrees may apply for direct entry at officer level.

The decree does not prohibit women from combat.

"We were expecting a boom of requests, but not of this size," said Valdo Spini, chairman of the lower parliament's defence committee. "If, as is likely, the number of women who make it as cadets will be above 20%, they will have to arrange things differently."

The parallel move away from conscription to an entirely professional military will reduce its strength from 280,000 to 50,000.

Feminists hailed the applications as vindication of a long campaign to open the armed forces. Debora Corbi, who founded the National Association of Aspiring Women Soldiers, said: "We knew it would happen. We were the last Nato country to pass the norm."

Much attention has been paid to uniform design. The navy's offering was condemned by fashion experts as boxy and, because it was designed by officers' wives, deliberately dowdy.

The uniform for the carabinieri, a paramilitary police force, received better reviews after the professional designer Rocco Barocco unveiled hip-hugging holsters, tight blue shirts and capes. However, the top brass said the 5cm heels would have to be reduced.

Much attention has been paid to uniform design. The navy's offering was condemned by fashion experts as boxy and, because it was designed by officers' wives, deliberately dowdy. The uniform for the carabinieri, a paramilitary police force, received better reviews after the professional designer Rocco Barocco unveiled hip-hugging holsters, tight blue shirts and capes. However, the top brass said the 5cm heels would have to be reduced.

fields.headline: Underground treasures
fields.standfirst: Metro system opens in Athens
fields.trailText: Athens is about to be transformed by an underground railway system that aims to entice passengers through a combination of modern trains and ancient treasures.
fields.body:
Athens is about to be transformed by an underground railway system that aims to entice passengers through a combination of modern trains and ancient treasures.

The £1.2bn network, which will be formally opened today, has been hailed as the answer to the congestion and pollution choking the city.

The new 11-mile system connects 21 stations, the first 14 of which will be opened today. It expands a single-line railtrack built in the late 1800s to connect the northern suburbs with the port of Piraeus. Two lines will be opened initially, with another due to be ready by 2002.

"Athenians have waited years for this," said the environment minister, Costas Laliotis. "Nothing will improve the quality of life in Athens and the Attica region more than the metro."

Few events have stirred such public enthusiasm. For the past week Athenians have been singing and dancing outside the network's white marble stations. Many have expressed disbelief that the metro - originally scheduled to open in 1996 - has arrived.

"This is the sort of thing that can change a person's life," said Katerina Evangelopoulou, an office clerk. "I'm going to save about 40 minutes getting to work in the city centre."

It is estimated that some 250,000 cars will be removed from the streets daily once the system be comes fully operational in 2002. That, say experts, is equivalent to reducing toxic vehicular emissions by 35%.

Car ownership has risen from 36,000 to nearly 2m in 30 years, and the inauguration of the network comes days after the government launched a programme to link up the city's ancient sites in a traffic-free zone.

The metro also gave archaeologists their dream dig. Most of the system's stations fall within the shadow of the Acropolis, and excavation work conducted over 69,000 square metres threw up ancient artefacts that have done more to explain the development of Athens than any dig so far. Roman baths, ancient roads, metal working shops, cisterns, drains and cemeteries were revealed during the eight years of construction, often delaying work in the process.

With more than 30,000 ancient Greek and Roman finds, officials say just travelling the metro will be an art connoisseur's delight. Passengers are to be given a rare insight into the "city beneath the city", with many of the discoveries remaining in place or being put on display.

"We have sought to highlight the finds by, in essence, turning the main stations into small museums," said Mr Laliotis.

"Treasures dating from the 6th century BC to about AD 1000 will be put on show in bullet-proof cases. From now on, travel is going to be fun."

webTitle: Iran's female students protest at segregation

fields.headline: Iran's female students protest at segregation
fields.standfirst:
Medical school sit-ins reflect growing demands for sexual equality

More about Iran
fields.trailText: In a daring challenge to the Islamic system, female medical students in Iran are refusing to attend classes and are staging sit-ins in protest at their segregation from men in universities.
fields.body:
In a daring challenge to the Islamic system, female medical students in Iran are refusing to attend classes and are staging sit-ins in protest at their segregation from men in universities.

The students believe they receive an inferior medical education to their male peers.

One medical school in the holy Shi'ite city of Qom is for women only, and in Tehran's universities men and women must attend classes in separate rooms or sit on opposite sides of the classroom.

"We suffer because we have little interaction with our male classmates. We rarely have an exchange of ideas. There is a wall between us," said Homa, 24, a student at Tehran university's medical school.

"Many classes are for women only, and the best professors and facilities go to the men. We get the leftovers," she said.

This week a group of female medical students called upon President Mohammad Khatami and the country's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, to reverse what they believe is sex discrimination. They have also complained to the health ministry.

Such action may not guarantee immediate change. But their public dissent adds a significant voice to a growing demand for sexual equality.

Even some reformist theologians now say that the clerical establishment has misinterpreted the Islamic texts taken as the basis for Iranian laws.

Ayatollah Yusef Sanei, a reformist cleric, ruled two months ago that women were free to run for president of the republic, and to be given more rights in cases of spousal abuse and divorce.

There is growing opposition to the inequality between the sexes that continues despite the significant gains women have made since the 1979 Islamic revolution.

Today, there are more women than men in higher education, and women are increasingly seen in important positions of authority.

Women were encouraged to attend medical school after the revolution so they could treat female patients, in line with conservative readings of Islamic teachings. But these opportunities no longer satisfy women in modern Iran.

"In theory, our government says women are equal. But in practice and in our culture this is not the case," said one woman, a 25-year-old medical student, who wished to remain unidentified.

"I know when I begin practising medicine, male doctors will always have more authority over me. It doesn't matter if I am smarter than they are or if I am a better physician."

One medical professor said sex discrimination had led to her resignation from the women-only Fatimieh medical school in Qom.

"In Islam, male doctors are allowed to treat female patients. So why should the state separate men from women in medical schools?" she asked.

"When I went to medical school 23 years ago under the shah, men and women studied together and we had no problems. To enter medical school, you have to be at the top of your class, and students are there to learn, not to flirt."

Parliament passed a law in 1998 to segregate health services to reflect conservative MPs' interpretation of Islam.

Under a pilot programme prompted by the legislation, the Fatimieh medical school in Qom, the intellectual centre for the Shi'ite Muslim clergy, dismissed all its male staff.

But experts say the quality of medical education has suffered as a result, with women students deprived of the wide range of patients and teachers they need to complete their education.

Taha Hashemi, a cleric and MP who sits on the school's board of trustees, told the daily Aftab-e Emrouz he had proposed hiring older male staff to bolster student training. "I and several other members have stopped attending board meetings in protest of the existing situation," he said.

webTitle: Taxi drivers terrorise South African streets

fields.headline: Taxi drivers terrorise South African streets
fields.standfirst: New regulations to curb lawless industry spark menacing revolt
fields.trailText: Hundreds of South Africa's widely loathed minibus taxi drivers brought parts of Johannesburg to a standstill yesterday as they terrorised motorists with guns and clubs in protest against government plans to control the notoriously violent industry.
fields.body:
Hundreds of South Africa's widely loathed minibus taxi drivers brought parts of Johannesburg to a standstill yesterday as they terrorised motorists with guns and clubs in protest against government plans to control the notoriously violent industry.

The drivers, who mainly carry township residents on routes not served by council buses, object to new regulations replacing the 126,000 minibuses on South African roads with 85,000 larger vehicles that can be electronically monitored for speed and regular maintenance.

The taxi union says it will cost more than half the drivers their jobs because they do not have special licences to operate the new buses. The government is keen for all drivers to take tests because it suspects many paid bribes to obtain their original licences.

About 400 minibuses created chaos as they drove from the centre of Johannesburg along a motorway to an exhibition centre north of the city where the new buses were being launched. Some minibus taxis which did not join the protest and continued plying for trade were stopped, their passengers ordered out and their drivers beaten.

Many of the protesters appeared to be drunk. They waved an array of weaponry from sticks and machetes to guns, which were pointed menacingly at the traffic police and taxi drivers who broke the strike. They threatened to burn any of the new buses put into service.

"This country will be ungovernable if this plan goes on," said one driver, Joseph Liza.

When the drivers reached the exhibition centre, they assaulted the exhibitors of the new buses. The army and police sealed off the area to prevent the protest spreading. Some of the drivers confronted them with weapons but eventually backed away.

The regional transport minister for Johannesburg and Pretoria, Khabisi Mosunkutu, said the protest was illegal. "Peaceful motorists have been threatened on several occasions, putting lives in danger. Those people have no respect for the law of the land and they must be dealt with accordingly," he said.

The government has introduced the new vehicles and greater control of the taxi industry in response to growing public anger at the behaviour of minibus drivers, who are blamed by many people for the appalling death rate on South African roads.

About 10,000 people a year die in accidents, and many crashes are blamed on minibuses with worn tyres, poor brakes or exhausted drivers.

Taxi owners have also been upset by a lowered speed limit of 100km per hour (62mph) for public transport after a series of high profile accidents - most notably the bus crash in Lydenburg last year in which 26 British tourists and their guide were killed.

The government also wants to break organised crime's grip on the taxi industry which has led to regular killings in the competition for passengers. More than once, lines of people waiting at bus stop used by one company have been attacked and killed by gunmen from a rival firm.

This week, a government inquiry into the industry accused sections of the police of feeding the violence. Mr Mosunkutu said there was "overwhelming evidence of police complicity in taxi violence".

Yesterday the taxi union submitted a memorandum to the government giving it 14 days to scrap the new regulations or face escalating protests. The drivers ended their demonstration by driving chaotically back down the motorway to Johannesburg city centre.

 A judge in Johannesburg sentenced six men to a total of more than 1,000 years in jail yesterday for a series of gang rapes including that of a 13-year-old girl.

The men, aged 16 to 24, were convicted on 24 counts including gang-raping eight women, one of them pregnant, in a 1998 reign of terror which included housebreaking, assault and armed robbery. The victims had known the accused all their lives, growing up with them in Thembisa township, north of Johannesburg.

Three of the men received four life terms and 165 years each and the other three were given sentences totalling 251 years each. They will serve between 20 and 25 years each.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: UN tribunal jails Rwandan
fields.body:
UN tribunal jails Rwandan

The international criminal tribunal for Rwanda yesterday sentenced the former tea factory boss Alfred Musema to life imprisonment after finding him guilty of genocide and crimes against humanity.

The UN court, established in northern Tanzania to try those accused of fomenting the 1994 Rwandan genocide, found Musema guilty on three of nine charges brought against him. Reuters, Arusha, Tanzania

Burmese rebels replace leader

The leader of the ethnic Karen rebels fighting Burma's military regime, Bo Mya, has been replaced by the dissident group after 24 years at its helm, the group announced yesterday.

The Karen resistance is in crisis, after a disastrous terrorist raid this week on a Thai hospital ended when the Thai military shot all 10 hostage takers. Bo Mya will be replaced by Saw Ba Thin, a Karen National Union veteran. AP, Mae Sot, Thailand

Anti-corruption politician shot

Unidentified assailants yesterday shot and injured a leftwing politician known for speaking out against corruption in Istanbul's local administration.

Dursun Catli of Turkey's Republican People's party, who had been outspoken about government corruption in the central Sisli neighbourhood of Istanbul, was shot in the leg at his office near the city's centre. AP, Istanbul

Rival herders in massacre

At least 100 Pokot herders from western Kenya, who had gone to graze their cattle in neighbouring Uganda, have been killed and 40 injured by rival Karamojong herders, according to Kenyan police.

Yerer Lokorihada, a survivor, said at least 700 heavily armed Karamojongs gunned down the unarmed Pokots on Monday as they attempted to flee the Moriat hills region, 220 miles north-east of the capital, Kampala. AP, Kitale, Kenya

Thailand holds Indian guerrilla

Thai police have arrested a separatist guerrilla leader from India's northern Nagaland, according to an elected official from the state yesterday.

Thuingaleng Muivah, 66, a founder of the guerrilla group the National Socialist Council of Nagaland which has been fighting for a separate homeland for 50 years at a cost of 15,000 lives, was arrested on January 19 in Bangkok on a charge of travelling under a fake South Korean passport. AP, Gauhati, India

Troops repel Kabila offensive

Congolese rebels yesterday said they had staved off an offensive by President Laurent Kabila's army in Mobambo, north-western Congo, despite continuous aerial and ground attacks near the Ubangui river near Uganda. AP Kigali

fields.headline: Jefferson 'did father slave's children'
fields.standfirst: Investigators lay to rest 200-year-old mystery that has split descendants of America's third president
fields.trailText: A mystery that became a symbol of America's confused racial past appeared to have been settled at last yesterday after the keepers of Thomas Jefferson's legacy confirmed that the nation's third president probably fathered the children of his slave, Sally Hemings.
fields.body:
A mystery that became a symbol of America's confused racial past appeared to have been settled at last yesterday after the keepers of Thomas Jefferson's legacy confirmed that the nation's third president probably fathered the children of his slave, Sally Hemings.

The findings represent a severe blow for traditionalists for whom Jefferson, the author of the Declaration of Independence, is an icon of American liberty. But for many black Americans he was a hypocrite who fought for freedom for whites while keeping African slaves on his estate, Monticello, in Virginia.

The Thomas Jefferson Memorial Foundation broke two centuries of silence to announce that its investigations indicated "a high probability that Thomas Jefferson fathered Eston Hemings, and that he most likely was the father of all six of Sally Hemings's children appearing in Jefferson's records". According to the records, Hemings gave birth to six children, including two who died in infancy.

The confirmation of a direct link between one of the country's founding fathers and generations of black claimants to his name symbolically affirms the central role of African-Americans in the making of the modern nation.

"It's about time that someone is validating what oral history has confirmed for years," said Shay Banks-Young, a Hemings descendant.

Daniel Jordan, the foundation's president said that although the results were not 100% conclusive, "the evidence is compelling and we think the evidence is persuasive... whether it was love or lust, rape or romance no one knows and it's unlikely that anyone will ever know".

The foundation, which owns and operates Monticello, and maintains the country's most extensive archive on Jefferson, spent almost a decade on its investigation, examining DNA evidence and appraising oral histories, plantation documents and artefacts.

A study in the scientific journal Nature in 1998 found DNA links between Jefferson's white family and Hemings's descendants, but sceptics argued that Sally Hemings may have had a relationship with Jefferson's brother, Randolph.

The foundation's study, however, looked through Jefferson's journal in which he recorded where he spent each day of his adult life, and found that he was in the same place as Sally Hemings, who was 30 years his junior, each time the six children were conceived.

"How likely is it that this could have occurred by chance if Jefferson was not the father? Not very?" said Fraser Neiman, Monticello's director of archaeology. He ran the probabilities through four mathematical models and found there was only a 1% chance that Jefferson's presence at the time of each conception was a coincidence.

There was no evidence that Jefferson's brother was in Monticello in the relevant periods, but Herbert Barger, who is married to one of Jefferson's descendants, called the report inconclusive and argued: "Nobody keeps an accurate record every time they invite their brother up for a visit." Mr Barger, however, is one of a dwindling number of sceptics.

The Monticello Association, a group of Jefferson's acknowledged white descendants, is due to meet in May to discuss the evidence and to consider whether Sally Hemings's descendants should be buried in the family graveyard at Monticello.

Lucian Truscott, an association member pressing for the graveyard to be opened, said: "This is like the civil rights act for the Hemings family. It's what I believe and it's what the Hemings have known for 200 years."

webTitle: Arrest 'links Bin Laden with millennial bomb plot'

fields.headline: Arrest 'links Bin Laden with millennial bomb plot'
fields.standfirst: Osama Bin Laden
fields.trailText: Prosecutors believe that the Saudi extremist Osama Bin Laden had links with a group of Algerians charged with plotting a millennium bomb attack in the United States, a US newspaper reported yesterday.
fields.body:
Prosecutors believe that the Saudi extremist Osama Bin Laden had links with a group of Algerians charged with plotting a millennium bomb attack in the United States, a US newspaper reported yesterday.

According to the New York Times, the Senegalese authorities have detained a Mauritanian national, Mohambedou Ould Slahi, who US investigators believe directed the Algerian plot.

Mr Slahi, who is a brother-in-law of one of Mr Bin Laden's aides, travelled to Montreal from Germany last year and is believed to have spent time with Mokhtar Haouri, one of the Algerians charged over his alleged involvement in the plot.

The alleged conspiracy fell apart on December 14, when another Algerian, Ahmed Ressam, was arrested crossing into the US from Canada with explosives hidden in his car. Immediately after the arrest, Mr Slahi is reported to have fled to a Montreal mosque and then left the country.

Dan Lambert, a spokesman for the Canadian Security In telligence Service, said yesterday that Mr Slahi had been under constant surveillance while in the country, but he had been allowed to leave because "at that stage, there was no evidence available to justify his arrest".

"We were aware he was going to be travelling," Mr Lambert said. "It was in relation to the heat he was feeling from the Canadian investigation."

The New York Times said federal agents had flown to Senegal to question Mr Slahi, but the Senegalese government and police sources were quoted yesterday as saying they knew nothing about his detention.

Mr Slahi is believed to be related by marriage to one of Mr Bin Laden's closest associates, known only as "the Mauritanian". US investigators claim he was involved in the 1998 bombings of US embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, which Mr Bin Laden is suspected of masterminding.

Mr Slahi is also said to have maintained "constant communications" with a construction company run by Mr Bin Laden in Khartoum, Sudan.

US investigators believe there may be a second link between the Saudi fugitive and the Algerian conspiracy. The link involves Hamid Aich, an Algerian who lived for three years just outside Vancouver and shared a flat with Abdel Majid Dahoumane, who later shared a room with Ressam in a Vancouver hotel. However, the New York Times reported that the US and Irish authorities now believe they may have missed a chance to find out more about the Algerian network.

Analysis of documents and a computer seized in the raids suggested Mr Aich may have had ties to Mr Ressam and the Egyptian Islamic Jihad. He has since disappeared.

fields.headline: Albright wiped floor with men
fields.trailText: Her face is instantly recognised across the globe and she is one of the few people with the power to summon Bill Clinton to the phone.
fields.body:
Her face is instantly recognised across the globe and she is one of the few people with the power to summon Bill Clinton to the phone.

So the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, could be forgiven for exploding with rage when she was mistaken for a cleaning lady during last year's abortive peace negotiations on Kosovo.

Mrs Albright's brief taste of how if feels to be treated as a lowly cleaner came when she made the mistake of interrupting the Albanian delegation in the deeper recesses of the Rambouillet chateau, outside Paris.

Dugagjin Gorani, a member of the Albanian delegation, recalls his colleagues' astonishment when the formidable Mrs Albright stormed into their room as they sweated over the Rambouillet peace deal into the early hours of February 23 last year.

"She just showed herself [at] the door," Mr Gorani says. "One member of the delegation, who didn't realise who she was, and probably thinking she was some cleaning lady because it was after midnight, simply said to her, 'Give us five minutes and please go away'."

Mrs Albright, a fearsome operator even by Washington standards, erupted at the Albanian's impertinence. "Mrs Albright started using explicit language which the translators never could translate into Albanian," Veton Surroi, another member of the Albanian delegation, told a Channel 4 programme on the Kosovo conflict to be screened on Sunday night

Despite her ferocious outburst, the Albanians resisted the pressure from Mrs Albright to sign up immediately to the Rambouillet deal.

The Kosovo Liberation Army leader, Hashim Thaci, who led the Albanian delegation, headed back to Kosovo to sell the deal to the KLA, eventually agreeing to sign the agreement in Paris two weeks later. The Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, refused to sign, precipitating the Nato bombing campaign.

Members of the Albanian delegation recall that they were so suspicious of the Americans at Rambouillet that they ended up holding discussions in an unusual meeting place. "We were [often] in the toilet because we realised that was the safest place to discuss," Mr Gorani, the editor of Kosovo's English-language KD Times, tells the programme.

The disclosure that Mrs Albright was mistaken for a cleaner will delight her many enemies in Washington, who have dubbed her Madeleine Not-so-bright.

War in Europe will be screened on Channel 4 on Sunday night.

fields.headline: Monsanto's name radically modified
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: The Monsanto company name, which has become synonymous with the genetically modified food business, is to be ditched, the company revealed last night.
fields.body:
The Monsanto company name, which has become synonymous with the genetically modified food business, is to be ditched, the company revealed last night.

The beleaguered American biotech company is merging with the US-Swiss drugs group Pharmacia & Upjohn and the $50bn corporation will in future be known as Pharmacia.

"We have chosen a name with power and global relevance," said Robert Shapiro, chairman of Monsanto, who will lead the new company. "This name and logo will create a strong new identity for our 60,000 employees and will build value with our existing customers worldwide."

Mr Shapiro, who championed GM food, was once regarded as a visionary who would mix nutrition, biotechnology, crop protection and medicine in one commercial venture. But the Monsanto name became tainted last year as the consumer backlash against GM food spread from Europe to the US.

In addition to food safety and environmental fears there were concerns that farmers in developing countries would never be able to afford the new Monsanto seeds.

Last month a shareholder campaign in the US unveiled a plan to target 24 companies, including Monsanto, demanding a moratorium on the use of GM food until independent testing had been completed. The campaign is being coordinated by 275 religious and other groups which claim to control $100bn of shares in US companies.

Monsanto, which had been a high-flying pharmaceutical stock and darling of Wall Street, fell swiftly from grace when its crop technology business, which little over a year ago was regarded as a world beater, turned into an albatross. Shareholders watched as their investments lost a third of their value.

The newly merged Pharmacia Corporation will use the names Searle, Pharmacia and Upjohn for its three sales divisions. Only an autonomous agricultural subsidiary will continue to use the Monsanto name.

webTitle: Time for a '21st century American revolution', says Clinton

fields.headline: Time for a '21st century American revolution', says Clinton
fields.standfirst: More about the state of the union address
fields.trailText: President Bill Clinton declared in his state of the union speech on Thursday night that it is time for a "21st century American revolution" shaped with billions of dollars in new government spending.
fields.body:
President Bill Clinton declared in his state of the union speech on Thursday night that it is time for a "21st century American revolution" shaped with billions of dollars in new government spending.

"We must be, as we were in the beginning, a new nation," Clinton said in remarks prepared for delivery in his 9pm EST (0155 GMT) address to a joint session of Congress and millions of Americans watching on television.

At a time when Democrats and Republicans are debating what to do with surging government surpluses spawned by a booming economy, Clinton proposed a $350bn tax cut aimed at the middle class, and big increases for health care, education, the environment and fighting crime.

"Never before have we had such a blessed opportunity - and therefore such a profound obligation - to build the more perfect union of our founders' dreams," said Clinton, borrowing language from the preamble of the US constitution.

In his eighth and last state of the union speech - unless he gives one in the waning days of his presidency next January - Clinton also planned to propose a handgun licensing programme, aides said.

It was a turnabout from his previous stance that he would only push for gun-control measures he believed he could get through the Republican-controlled Congress. It was likely to generate a storm of protests from the gun lobby.

Providing a powerful symbol in support of his proposal, however, was Tom Mauser, whose son Daniel was killed in the April 1999 shooting spree by two students at Columbine High School in Littleton, Colorado. He was seated with first lady Hillary Rodham Clinton.

The set piece event in the chamber of the House of Representatives gave a prominent role to Clinton's understudy, vice-president Al Gore, before millions of Americans watching on television who are starting to focus on the presidential election campaign. Gore sat behind Clinton's right shoulder and led the applause.

For Clinton, it was an ambitious attempt to set the Democratic agenda for the legislative year despite his status as a lame-duck president. It was likely to get a sceptical response from the Republican-controlled Congress in an election year.

And it provided Clinton a chance to bask on the big stage unencumbered by personal baggage. The two last such speeches were given at a time when he and the country were preoccupied with the Monica Lewinsky scandal.

Taking a shot at the Republicans, Clinton said they for too long have been "standing still on some of our most pressing national priorities" - such as campaign finance reform.

He said America now has the "confidence to dream big dreams". "We will be judged by the dreams and deeds we pass on to our children. And on that score, we will be held to a high standard, indeed - because our chance to do good is so great," he said.

Senate budget committee chairman Pete Domenici, a New Mexico Republican, said Clinton has proposed $225bn in new government spending in the past 31 days and, coupled with a $118bn prescription drug benefit for seniors on Medicare, adds up to $343bn in new government spending.

"If President Clinton speaks tonight for 90 minutes, he will be spending almost $4bn a minute," Domenici said.

Some of Clinton's agenda was warmed over from last year, including $350bn in tax breaks targeted at the middle class over 10 years.

It would be offset by about $100bn in savings from closing corporate tax loopholes, for net tax breaks of $250bn.

It was roughly the same as last year and an attempt to answer Republicans who say Americans deserve broad tax cuts because of the surpluses.

A big-ticket tax break item was his proposal for retirement savings accounts, first offered last year. It would give an estimated 76m Americans the opportunity to save for their retirement through a progressive tax cut. It would cost $54bn over 10 years.

Clinton proposed spending $110bn over 10 years to make health insurance cheaper and easier to get, expanding coverage to some 5m Americans who are now uninsured, and $28bn over 10 years to offer a $3,000 tax credit for people who need long-term health care.

On education, he asked for about $5bn to expand after-school and summer school programs; give more money to Head Start, the early child development program; hire more teachers to reduce class size; offer bonuses to states that improve school performance; improve the quality of teachers, and build new schools and repair old ones.

And he requested $30bn over 10 years to offer up to $2,800 in tax relief for college students or their families.

fields.headline: No: 1566 Teddy St Aubyn
fields.body:
Age: 40.

Would like to be known as: Godfather to Earl Spencer's youngest child, Louis; a novelist.

Is known as: Jerry Hall's latest squeeze.

Jerry and a toff? That's not very rock'n'roll. Like, hello? She does have a mind, you know. Teddy was the perfect accessory for Tuesday night's Whitbread Award ceremony, which Jerry attended as one of the judges.

Oh. He wasn't up for a prize then. No. The two books of his listed on the bookseller website Amazon are out of print, and his latest novel, The Edge, is set in a Californian new age community.

Might give it a miss. Your loss. The Daily Mail has called him "one of the foremost satirists of the upper classes".

I bet that's a fiercely contested title. Easy. Teddy can be thin skinned about his efforts. Word is, he's an intellectual snob.

Does he have claim? Some. Like all good minor aristos, he graduated in coke snorting from Oxford to chisel out some constipated prose about his rough childhood and now hangs about on the literary fringes in Noël Coward dress and Noel Edmonds' ego.

Ouch. Any other sore points? Well, don't mention his ex-wife Nicola Shulman.

Nicola Shulman. OK, smart arse. The couple divorced and Shulman is now sitting pretty, several leagues above him, as the Marchioness of Normanby.

Any other ex-girlfriends? An old flame called Ana, who Teddy's friends nicknamed Earner on account of his posh accent.

But Jerry isn't using him for social advancement, is she. No. And she really liked Beowulf.

Do say: "Sir, your inclusion in Passnotes is entirely down to your status as the foremost satirist of the upper classes."

Don't say: "There's a Teddy someone on the line for you, Countess Jerry."

Not to be confused with: Mick Jagger, Teddy Kennedy, Evelyn Waugh.

webTitle: Who's your daddy? Well, you know our friend David with the funny moustache...

fields.headline: Who's your daddy? Well, you know our friend David with the funny moustache...
fields.standfirst: He is the hairy, hard-living super-hippy from 70s rock giants Crosby, Stills, Nash and Young. And now it turns out that David Crosby donated sperm to rocker Melissa Etheridge and her female lover.  Jancee Dunn  reports while, below,  Adam Sweeting  wonders how the children will turn out
fields.trailText: He is the hairy, hard-living super-hippy from 70s rock giants Crosby, Stills, Nash and Young. And now it turns out that David Crosby donated sperm to rocker Melissa Etheridge and her female lover.
fields.body:
It was beginning to get ridiculous: the speculation . . . the rumours . . . the jokes. For three long years, Melissa Etheridge and her partner, film-maker Julie Cypher, were asked the same question over and over: Who is the biological father of your two children? Once, the couple found it amusing. Then, with the release of Etheridge's album Breakdown, the famous US rock singer's first in more than three years, the badgering intensified.

On a recent Late Show appearance, David Letterman had a go. "Now, I'm no geneticist, but in some regard there must have been Daddy somewhere," he said, leaning forward. "Who's Daddy?"

"Well, you were on the short list for a minute," Etheridge hedged.

Letterman pressed on. "Just tell me, who's Daddy? Who's Daddy?"

Etheridge threw up her hands in mock exasperation. "All right," she said, "it's Dan Quayle."

Rumours flew on the internet. Was it Brad Pitt? He's a friend of theirs. Bruce Springsteen? Etheridge jumped onstage with him at a New Jersey show. Maybe he's the dad! How about Tom Hanks?

Cut to a Time magazine interview. "Did Brad Pitt father your children?" columnist Joel Stein wanted to know. "It is a man, right? . . . And he's famous?" Yes, she said. "So it's Brad Pitt . . . Come on, it's better if it's Brad Pitt. It's good for his career, for your career." "We just got so tired of this secret," says Etheridge, who didn't even tell the rest of her family the father's name until the couple's first child, Bailey, was a year old. "It wears you out. And keeping this big secret goes against how we are choosing to live our lives: very openly." There was also the consideration that Bailey, now three, will attend school soon: "I didn't want my kids to ever be in a position where someone could come up to them and know something they don't."

"Because Bailey was starting to ask," adds Cypher. "And you know what else? It was becoming a joke, more than it should have been." Thus, after much discussion, the two have decided to reveal the identity of their two children's biological father. It is a man whose name, it is safe to say, has never come up on a shortlist of candidates. It is, of all people, David Crosby, founding member of The Byrds and Crosby, Stills, Nash and Young, a rock'n'roll bad boy with a four-decade-long career, a wife of 12 years and a 35-year-old son.

Etheridge and Cypher live in a spacious 1926 Tudor home filled with sunlight, honey-coloured wood and antiques in Los Angeles. It is a very different home from the one that the pair lived in four years ago, with its careful display of antique match strikers and its Louvre-size collection of dog photos. Now, the effluvia of children are everywhere: half-drunk glasses of juice in plastic cups, Elmo in various permutations, milk and bananas on the grocery list. The match strikers have been relegated to a glass case. As for the dog photos: "Bruce Springsteen once gave me the best parenting advice," says Cypher. "He said, 'You know, all of a sudden, your dogs are just gonna be dogs.'"

Cypher and Etheridge give a tour of their house, pointing out a black baby grand piano in the sitting room before moving on to the toy-strewn family room. "This is the room we live in," says Cypher. Against one wall is a row of seats from the community theatre in Etheridge's hometown of Leavenworth, Kansas, that the establishment gave to her after she made a donation to help restore it. The two point out a Maori school desk they found in New Zealand. "We love, love, love to antique-shop," says Cypher.

Bailey races into the room. "Look at me!" she cries, hurling herself onto a beanbag chair. "I'm just a laughing frog!" One-year-old Beckett, meanwhile, is being fed by a nanny. The children, whose faces are sweet and apple-cheeked, could be lifted out of a Victorian postcard. "Beckett looks just like David, doesn't he?" says Etheridge, looking on happily, a rock-chick mom in a blue corduroy jacket with silver studs. She produces Crosby's autobiography, which contains a baby photo from back in the day. The resemblance is eerie.

It all began in Hawaii, they say, where the two were vacationing. They dropped by to visit David Crosby and his missus, Jan, whom they had met a while back at a show. "We'd see them every now and then at a party, stuff like that," says Etheridge. As the group chatted, the subject of children came up, and Etheridge and Cypher mentioned their dilemma. Eggs they had. Sperm was another matter.

"And Jan said, 'What about David?'" says Etheridge. "It came from her, which was the best, most perfect way." They thought it over for a year before they made the call. "For one, he's musical, which means a lot to me, you know, and I admire his work," continues Etheridge. "And he has his own life, has his own family."

A few questions:

What do the kids call you?

"I am Mama, Julie is Mamo," says Etheridge.

Not to put too fine a point on it, but how did the fertilisation occur?

"It was artificial insemination, done privately," says Cypher.

"We did not use a turkey baster," adds Etheridge.

"No kitchen implements were involved," says Cypher.

It was decided that she should carry the babies because of Etheridge's work. "I was more the homebody, so to speak," Cypher says. "And I'm a health nut, a fanatic, so I was really good at making babies."

Are the Crosbys godparents?

"No, that would be our dearest friends," she says, pointing to a picture of a smiling man and woman. "Beckett's role model," she says, pointing to the man.

"For people who are worried about the male role model," says Etheridge. "So many people are worried about that male role model."

"Sometimes they have a hard time wrapping their head around the fact that this can work," says Cypher.

Kate Capshaw - who, with her husband Steven Spielberg, has hung out with the couple for the past two years - says she thought that the news was fantastic. Then she said: "Who's David Crosby?" She laughs uproariously. "The name rang a bell! Oh, God. As they sat there with their expectant faces, right? I'm like, 'I know he was part of a big group that did well.'" She laughs again. "I was listening to Claudine Longet back then, let's be honest."

Does Crosby share parental duties? "It's not a parental thing for David," says Etheridge. "David and Jan totally understood that we are the parents."

"So we see them every once in a while," says Cypher.

"Julie is adopted," says Etheridge. Coming from that place - wanting to know who her real parents were - she felt it was important that her children know where they came from.

"Four or five months ago, when she was two and a half, Bailey said, 'Do I have a daddy?' I said, 'Well, yes, you do.' Pause. 'Well, who is he?' I said, 'You know our friend David, with the funny moustache?'"

Satisfied, Bailey moved on to the next subject. Relieved, so did Cypher.

Was there a concern about the father's well-known past, which includes prodigious drug use?

Cypher and Etheridge did their homework on this matter and were convinced there was no danger to their children. New York urologist Mark Stein says: "Sperm are made all the time, and they take three months to mature. So the sperm that's coming out today was made three months ago. Once, the couple found it amusing. Then, with the release of Etheridge's album Breakdown, the famous US rock singer's first in more than three years, the badgering intensified. "Well, you were on the short list for a minute," Etheridge hedged. Letterman pressed on. "Just tell me, who's Daddy? Who's Daddy?" Etheridge threw up her hands in mock exasperation. "All right," she said, "it's Dan Quayle." Rumours flew on the internet. Was it Brad Pitt? He's a friend of theirs. Bruce Springsteen? Etheridge jumped onstage with him at a New Jersey show. Maybe he's the dad! How about Tom Hanks? Cut to a Time magazine interview. "Did Brad Pitt father your children?" columnist Joel Stein wanted to know. "It is a man, right? . . . And he's famous?" Yes, she said. "So it's Brad Pitt . . . Come on, it's better if it's Brad Pitt. It's good for his career, for your career." "We just got so tired of this secret," says Etheridge, who didn't even tell the rest of her family the father's name until the couple's first child, Bailey, was a year old. "It wears you out. "Because Bailey was starting to ask," adds Cypher. "And you know what else? It was becoming a joke, more than it should have been." It is, of all people, David Crosby, founding member of The Byrds and Crosby, Stills, Nash and Young, a rock'n'roll bad boy with a four-decade-long career, a wife of 12 years and a 35-year-old son. "He said, 'You know, all of a sudden, your dogs are just gonna be dogs.'"
