webTitle: Should I tell my ex-husband his daughter has dropped out of university?

fields.headline: Should I tell my ex-husband his daughter has dropped out of university?
fields.trailText: I have recently divorced my husband and have custody of our two teenage daughters. They make their own contact with their father but I still talk with him about their progress and well-being. One daughter has a successful career, the other has recently had to leave university and is afraid to tell her father. He is a successful academic and has high expectations of his children, and thinks she is doing well. I would feel disloyal if I had to tell him otherwise, but I feel dishonest not telling him the truth. She says she couldn't cope with his anger and disappointment on top of the other problems. I am caught in the middle of a "no win" situation and don't know what to do.
fields.body:
I have recently divorced my husband and have custody of our two teenage daughters. They make their own contact with their father but I still talk with him about their progress and well-being. One daughter has a successful career, the other has recently had to leave university and is afraid to tell her father. He is a successful academic and has high expectations of his children, and thinks she is doing well. I would feel disloyal if I had to tell him otherwise, but I feel dishonest not telling him the truth. She says she couldn't cope with his anger and disappointment on top of the other problems. I am caught in the middle of a "no win" situation and don't know what to do.

Put your daughter first

Your dilemma seems to boil down to whose rights and feelings are more important to you - your daughter's or your husband's.

Your relationship with your ex-husband is officially over and you lead separate lives. Your relationship with your daughter is for ever, and you are still the parent who is taking responsibility for her. Your daughter is a young adult whose wishes - and right to privacy - should be treated with respect.

So why would you consider betraying your daughter's trust merely to avoid the disapproval of a man whose life you no longer share?

If you tell him, just to keep the moral high ground, no one wins. She will be hurt and he will be disappointed. I am sure that she will explain the situation to him when she feels the time is right, or when the matter has resolved itself.
Lynne Jones
West Norwood, London

Do not betray her trust

You must not under any circumstances inform your ex-husband of the situation. By telling her father, you will be irrevocably betraying your daughter's trust, and may alter any relationship that yourself and your daughter have. Living up to your parents expectations is one of the hardest trials in life. Academic pressure from the family can effect the very foundations of one's confidence - and here I speak from personal experience. Your daughter, as an adult, has made a decision and it is she who has to live with that, not you. Therefore, you are not in a position to tell her father, it is something that she will have to do in her own time.

At the end of the day, a parent will always be sad if their children don't continue with their education, if they themselves are graduates, but your ex-husband will come round in the end. A parent's role is to guide and support their children, not dictate their lives.

Your daughter, I am sure, is coming to terms with her new career path, and it will not help if you alter her plans. It is understandable that you feel as if you are being compromised, but you must let your daughter know this. Encourage her to let her father down, gently. Sooner, is obviously better than later, as she is deceiving her father, thus creating a barrier in their relationship. Encourage her to confide in her father, and let her know that you will help to deal with any potential fury that may arise. The sooner he knows, the sooner he can deal with it. Either that or rent a couple of hundred people, a hall and a graduation certificate in a few years time.
Name and address supplied

Readers are also welcome to propose other problems, of around 300 words. webTitle: Things that make you go yum

fields.headline: Things that make you go yum
fields.standfirst: Scientists have just unravelled the secret of the 'fifth taste' - umami.  Oliver Burkeman  learns why there are some foods we just can't resist
fields.trailText: You know there's something funny about a taste when even those who spend their professional lives preparing, sampling and talking about food struggle to describe it.
fields.body:
You know there's something funny about a taste when even those who spend their professional lives preparing, sampling and talking about food struggle to describe it. "Unctuous is probably quite a good description, but there's a sweetness, too, and a mouthfeel," ventures Heston Blumenthal, chef at the Fat Duck at Bray. "It's a richness, a rounding," is how Dr Peter Barham, a reader in physics at Bristol university who writes about the science of taste, puts it. Talk to a food technologist and words such as "savoury", "full-bodied" and "brothy" will crop up frequently. Even Kikunae Ikeda, the Tokyo scientist who first isolated the source of the taste, could only think to christen it "umami" which - exotic though it sounds to the untrained ear - means something close to "yummy" in Japanese.

Umami is the mysterious "fifth taste" - a flavour that has never seemed to fit into the existing categories of sweet, sour, salty and bitter. South-east Asian chefs have exploited it throughout history - it's an essential part of the taste of seaweed, among other things - and Ikeda identified it as long ago as 1908, demonstrating that the food substance usually responsible for stimulating the taste was glutamic acid; parmesan cheese, tomatoes, mushrooms and peas are loaded with it. And yet, until last week, scientists' attempts to develop Ikeda's insights - and, crucially, to find out whether or not umami really is a distinct taste - had progressed at an excruciatingly slow pace.

"We can't even be sure that we're having the same experience when we taste it," says Barham. "We all know what 'sweet' means, because we're used to tasting sugar, and we all know what 'bitter' means if we drink gin and tonic. But there's no one thing you can put in your mouth and say 'that's umami'. Parmesan certainly has a different effect to cheddar when you put it on your pasta, but it's a combination effect - and it's virtually indescribable." The debate over umami has raged within the tiny global community of taste scientists for years, and, says Barham, goes to the heart of the question of what taste itself really is. He characterises the disagreements thus: "What defines a taste? What makes something discrete and different, and what defines a taste receptor on the tongue? Does umami have a discrete receptor or not?"

Now, though, it seems that much of the mystery may have been solved. Writing in next month's edition of the journal Nature Neuroscience, biophysicist Dr Nirupa Chaudhari and her colleagues at the University of Miami announce a breakthrough: elaborating on their earlier investigations into the taste buds of rats, the researchers have isolated a protein molecule present on the tongue which, uniquely, enables us to taste umami foods - and thus to savour a vintage parmesan or a ripe tomato. Known as taste-mGluR4, it's a version of a protein also found in the human brain. On the tongue, though, it is truncated - which explains why glutamic acid must be present in relatively high concentrations before umami can be detected.

In the kitchens of the Fat Duck at Bray, umami is viewed with a mixture of enthusiasm and suspicion. "From a restaurant point of view, we're seeing something of an umami explosion - people finding all the things that have umami and chucking them all into a dish together," says Blumenthal. The taste is evoked more subtly in his own dishes, but reaches its fullest expression in the Fat Duck's roast scallop and caramelised cauliflower with marinated cep and jelly of Oloroso sherry. "Caramelising the cabbage enhances the umami taste, and scallops taste of it too, but then the sherry jelly counterbalances it and brings the whole dish together."

Perhaps unfortunately, though, Britain is best acquainted with umami via the ubiquitous gloopiness of monosodium glutamate (MSG), the powdered flavour enhancer on which your local Chinese takeaway almost certainly relies. It gives a concentrated umami hit, but it's a controversial additive - several studies have claimed that up to 30% of the population react adversely to it, displaying symptoms including migraines, hives, asthma attacks and cardiac irregulaties. Britain's Institute for Food Research insists that it's safe, but many of the smarter Chinese restaurants now spurn it, looking to natural sources of the same flavouring instead. Christine Yau, of the Ming restaurant on Greek Street in central London, runs a school for professional Chinese chefs at which MSG is a dirty word.

"A lot of cooks have misused it, and so our students are not allowed to," says Yau. "MSG is not something that you need in cooking; it enhances and brings out the flavours of good foods, but if you use it with bad materials it just makes things taste worse. We do use it occasionally at Ming, for dishes such as chicken and cashew nuts, which might otherwise be a bit bland. But the same taste occurs naturally in some kinds of vegetables, such as pak-choi cabbage and green leaves. It's a unique taste; there's a hint of sweetness there, but it's not just sweet."

There is certainly something strangely potent about the taste. Snack manufacturers have long been criticised for adding MSG to their products, at least partly because it seems to have the curious power to encourage further consumption, almost against the purchaser's will. It is being used experimentally to administer food to people suffering from cancer who lose their appetites entirely; Japanese studies of babies' facial expressions show marked signs of exceptional pleasure when they taste it.

Mysterious and exotic as umami seems, though, it is actually one of the tastes about which we know a relatively large amount: the taste receptors for sweetness and bitterness are still unknown. "It's in the west, alone, that umami has only been taken seriously in the past two or three years," says Barham. "The entire eastern world has known about it for centuries."

"It's in the west, alone, that umami has only been taken seriously in the past two or three years," says Barham. "The entire eastern world has known about it for centuries."

fields.headline: On the menu: cherimoya
fields.standfirst: Food on the net
fields.trailText: What is it?
fields.body:
What is it?

In actual fact, it's our new friend, the custard apple, although there is some scholarly debate on the subject.

Cut to the chase. What does it taste like?

The flesh, so they say, is white, wobbly in texture, like custard, and slightly acid, with notes of pineapple and banana.

How will I recognise your new friend?

It's round, with a pale jade-green skin which looks as if it were modelled by an apprentice potter.

And where do I find it?

In Peru or any self-respecting supermarket.

Anything else I should know?

It has lots of pips.

SpiceNet

Part of the huge MarketNet portal, which offers e-shoppers everything from fresh fruit to holidays, the SpiceNet site scales down the options. Three gift baskets crammed with spices are excellent value, particularly the oddly-named "Lovers" selection at around £1 per spice.

Pros: Baskets come with a booklet of hints on how to use your spices. Cheaper than a supermarket, with a few names you won't recognise.

Cons: Labelling on individual spices could be clearer; some of us need a hand telling our garam masala from our colombo.

Delivery: By post, within a week.

Charges: All included in the price.

fields.headline: David Everitt-Matthias
fields.body:
Age: 39.

Nationality: English.

Restaurant: Le Champignon Sauvage, 24-26 Suffolk Road, Cheltenham, GL50. Tel: 01242 573449.

Past form: "I started at the Inn on the Park (now the Four Seasons), then went to Steamers, which specialised in fish, and to Fingal's in Fulham. I've worked with Edouard Hari and Pierre Koffmann. My wife Helen and I set up Le Champignon Sauvage 13 years ago this July.

Style of cooking: French terroir - food of the earth, but with modern spicing.

Signature dishes: Roasted scallops and baby squid with pumpkin purée and squid ink; Wiltshire pork with homemade black pudding and chou farci; feuillantine of mango and Thai-spiced cream.

Bookshelf: Pierre Koffmann's Memories of Gascony is an insight into what makes, in my opinion, the best chef in Great Britain. Michel Guerard's Cuisine Gourmande is as relevant today as it was when it came out in 1978. Other favourites are Lindsey Bareham's In Praise of the Potato, and Nigella Lawson's How to Eat. If I can learn one new technique from a book, I'm very satisfied.

Favourite restaurant (other than own): In London, Tante Claire, Gordon Ramsay's, and anywhere that Bruno Loubet or Eric Crouillière-Chavot (currently at The Capital) are cooking.

Favourite food: When eating out, foie gras, scallops, sweetbreads. Eating in, it's roast chicken or liver and bacon.

What's in your fridge? The bare essentials - milk, butter, margarine. We prefer to prepare what we've bought when it's as fresh as possible, so there's no point in stocking up.

What did you have for breakfast? Porridge, black coffee, juice, a poached egg and roast chicken.

Top tip: Cook what you like to eat, and you'll have more confidence.

Biggest culinary disaster: In the Chef of the Year competition, my mixer fell off, with my egg whites for the dessert. But I still won in the end. These little things happen.

Career high: Opening the restaurant, and, most recently, getting the second Michelin star.

Interview by Claire Phipps

fields.headline: Gisele, the fashion fantasy
fields.trailText: First there was Cindy, then there was Kate, now there's Gisele. Gisele Bundchen, Brazilian model of the moment. Not just Vogue and American Vogue and Harper's Bazaar and W, all of whom featured her on their January covers, but every kind of publication has taken to Gisele like a Carlsberg in the desert.
fields.body:
First there was Cindy, then there was Kate, now there's Gisele. Gisele Bundchen, Brazilian model of the moment. Not just Vogue and American Vogue and Harper's Bazaar and W, all of whom featured her on their January covers, but every kind of publication has taken to Gisele like a Carlsberg in the desert. This girl is gorgeous in the true, mouth-watering sense of the word. She makes Kate Moss look like a runt. She makes Sophie Marceau look a bit tired. She's got pistons for legs and gold leaf for skin. Style sections have heralded the "Rise of a Sex Goddess". It's like Donny mania all over again.

But this is so much more than mere glamour worship. This, we are told, is about the return of the real woman, with real breasts and curves and warm blood coursing through her veins. After the best part of a decade during which the epitome of fashionable looks was a flat chested, ashen-skinned, paper-thin adolescent, Gisele is being feted not just as the face of the new millennium, but as a symbol of a new, wholesome, womanly mood in fashion.

It's only a matter of time before Tony sees fit to comment on this positive development. "For too long our women have been forced to deny their natural forms and aspire to a teenage ideal" might be a good way to kick off. "We have Gisele and our own British standard bearers, Catherine Zeta Jones and Elizabeth Hurley to thank for leading us back to the female form as God intended it." Free at last, oh thank you fashion industry.

Hello! Wakey wakey. Some of us have seen Gisele on the catwalk and, guess what? She may have a 36in chest but those hips aren't an inch over 34, that waist is a clear 23, and of the 5ft 10in Amazonian frame, two thirds is beach volleyball-honed, nutcracker leg. Gisele is as fit as a butcher's dog and a lot leaner. The 36 inches of her anatomy that has generated all this fanfare about the vogue for bigger statistics, are totally self-supporting and four inches higher than you would normally expect to find them.

And, concentrate - here comes the science bit. Gisele is nineteen years old. In our rush to line the streets, scattering roses in the path of the liberator who has come to rid us of little Kate Moss with her bow legs and bee-sting breasts, gawky Erin with her hawk nose and big eyebrows, Karen Elson with her red hair, hump back and Quasimodo walk, we seem to have missed something.

The thing is, you can aspire to looking like Kate Moss (shorter than the average model and pushing 30, well, 26). You can see a picture of Karen Elson and imagine yourself wearing the clothes she's modelling (she has that "go on, if I can do it anyone can" appeal). But for those of us who are borderline fashion victims and have no trouble blurring the lines between real life and a Mario Testino shoot, looking at Gisele in the sea-green Versace number, and then imagining yourself in the sea-green Versace number, is really testing the powers of fantasy to the limit.

Poring over her pictures in the glossies has a similar effect to going shopping with the-girl-who-looks-great-in-everything, spending a poolside holiday with same, or learning that your boyfriend is about to make a film with Catherine Zeta Jones. It doesn't put you where you want to be. And it doesn't help at all with the suspension of reality that is essential to enjoying fashion. There's always a choice - that looks like an air hostess's uniform/that looks like something Catherine Deneuve would have worn.

What us girls really need when we get into that changing room and draw the curtain behind us is an image we can just about aspire to. Not Racquel Welch in the fur bikini in One Million Years BC, not Brigitte Bardot in And God Created Woman, not Gisele in micro Dolce & Gabanna but something vaguely attainable. Just so we can get going. I've often been Kate, particularly in the Burberry ads (well why else would you try on a trench?); I've been Carolyn Murphy and, when the chips are down, I've even been Jade Jagger. This, you understand, is just for those few moments between getting a glancing impression in the mirror of someone quite like your mother, realising it doesn't quite fit, and deciding to buy it. It helps to slightly narrow your eyes and go to that other place where the beautiful people live.

But Gisele is a babe too far. Let her into the changing rooms at Prada and Gucci and they're not going to shift a single pussy bow blouse or snakeskin-print dress . Bring back the bone bags. At least they look like the same species.

fields.headline: Star of Sundance
fields.standfirst: Gurinder Chadha, director of the film that opened Redford's festival, on her night of glory
fields.trailText: Gurinder Chadha, director of the film that opened Redford's festival, on her night of glory
fields.body:
Exactly three years ago I attended the Sundance film festival, in the ski resort of Park City, Utah, fresh off a week-long intensive stint at Robert Redford's Sundance Institute's screenwriters' lab. It was the first time a British writer-director had been invited to the lab. This year I'm returning with the same script - What's Cooking? - now finished and given the honour of opening this year's festival.

Sitting in the audience on opening night in 1997, I would never have guessed I'd be up there on that podium introducing my film. I was numb from the lab, where my script had been heavily scrutinised by an illustrious group of Hollywood writers with often parochial comments. My co-writer and husband, Paul Mayeda Berges, and I were frustrated by the feedback we'd received. The writers at the lab wanted us to push our script in a direction I knew wasn't right for my vision of "Americanness".

What's Cooking? interweaves four diverse Los Angeles families - African-American, Latino, Vietnamese, and Jewish - as they come together to celebrate Thanksgiving: Americana through British Asian eyes. I had the idea for the film while I was in LA promoting my first film, Bhaji on the Beach. The film was well received and scripts from the studios started to come in, but as I read them I kept thinking, Los Angeles is such an exciting city and what I was seeing wasn't reflected in the scripts. If you've only experienced LA through films and TV, you'd have no sense of the richness and diversity of the city: 70% of LA schools are Latino and over 200 languages are spoken. LA is the great American experiment realised.

After the Screenwriter's Lab, we spent the next two years trying to get the film made. Most film companies loved the script, but no one knew how they would sell it. There had never been a film made with all these communities together that wasn't about "problems" between them. They knew the film would appeal to all these audiences, but they weren't sure how to market it to the different ethnic groups represented.

Approaching actors was a different story. We gave the script, a video of Bhaji On the Beach and a great letter of support for the project from Robert Redford to Alfre Woodard, Julianna Margulies, Mercedes Ruehl, Joan Chen and Kyra Sedgwick. They all said the same thing: I want to be a part of it. With a great cast attached, we finally raised private equity finance and made it as a truly independent film. For my first film in America, I had a privilege most other directors never get - no editorial interference.

We shot the film in May 1999 on location in LA over 25 days - pretty tight on a film with 42 speaking parts eating their way through 32 turkeys. I was knocked out by the generosity and professionalism of the US cast and crew. Not one person said, "Oh no love, you don't want to do that..."

We completed the film in November and submitted it to Sundance. I hoped they would like it, but I was completely over the moon when they selected it to open the festival. When we flew into Salt Lake City for the film's world premiere, none of the actors, the public or anyone from the industry had seen it. As I saw industry people milling around baggage claim I began to get nervous: 2,000 people, what if they don't get it...

We got to the hotel and there were five make-up people waiting to do Alfre Woodard and Julianna Margulies, but both of them decided to do their own make-up so they spent the next three hours working on me. Meanwhile there were 10 people in my room - someone trying to pluck my eyebrows, a woman waiting to blow-dry my hair, Paul and his friends breaking open champagne - and I still hadn't decided what to wear. Should I dress traditional Indian "elegant" or western "power-dressy"? The hair and make-up team voted Indian hands down.

We were taken to a pre-opening night party for the governor. All the actors were there and everyone was nervous but excited to finally see the film. I grabbed a drink and some food before we were led in front of a huge line of cameras, photographers and press outside the hall. I had Alfre on one side and Julianna on the other as all the cameras clicked furiously. I saw Paul glaring at me from the side. He pointed to my tooth - blimey, I had some broccoli wedged in there. We had to hover backstage because we were on "Bob time" - that's 20 minutes late for the screening because we're waiting for Robert Redford to show up.

On stage the festival director introduced me. I told the audience that when I was a young girl in London I thought "Salt Lake City" and "Utah" were very exotic places. They looked surprised. I confessed it was because my bedroom walls were covered with posters of Donny Osmond. Of course the local crowd warmed to this. Later I learnt that Donny's best friend was in the audience and Donny really wanted to come but couldn't get a ticket! Paul said this is the only town where I would be applauded for my Donny Osmond infatuation.

The film began and I felt the buzz from the audience. Their laughter echoed throughout the enormous opera hall, sometimes over the next several lines of dialogue. I felt proud that we were able to make the film exactly as we wanted, even if it did take us five years to finish it.

At the party everyone was beaming. A woman asked me when it's coming to Albuquerque so she can take her family to see it. Robert Redford said he loved the film but was freaking out - we actually filmed on the LA street that he grew up on. He remembered all the houses because his dad was a milkman and delivered there.

Festival co-director Geoff Gilmore said it was the best opening night they'd ever had. He introduced me to the president of a major festival's sponsor, who told me he could arrange for me to meet Donny Osmond. I realised that no matter how well the film was received that night, it was the end of my street cred forever.

fields.headline: The talented Ms Highsmith
fields.standfirst: Her heroes are deviants and genial psychopaths. No wonder film-makers from Alfred Hitchcock to Anthony Minghella have adapted her novels. Robert Shore on the enduring appeal of Patricia Highsmith
fields.trailText: Her heroes are deviants and genial psychopaths. No wonder film-makers from Alfred Hitchcock to Anthony Minghella have adapted her novels. Robert Shore on the enduring appeal of Patricia Highsmith
fields.body:
In life the novelist Patricia Highsmith habitually drew strong reactions from those around her. Like Brigitte Bardot, she appears to have reserved most of her affection for animals: when she died, in 1995, she left behind 22 novels, mostly studies of everyday psychopathy, and a lifetime's worth of sketches of cats. Her sometime publisher Otto Penzler described her as a "mean, cruel, hard, unlovable, unloving human being" - and he was a fan.

Nor is Highsmith likely to find immortality as a feminist icon: her early books are notable for their negative portrayal of female characters. When questioned about her preference for male heroes, the author would reply: "Women are tied to the home... Men can do more, jump over fences."

But, as we all know, a bad character has never been a bar to creating good art, and Highsmith's claustrophobic studies of commonplace deviancy have been entertaining and appalling readers for a half-century now. In particular, they have found a receptive audience among film-makers. When Anthony Minghella's The Talented Mr Ripley opens across the UK next month, it will be almost exactly 50 years since Highsmith was first adapted for the big screen.

That initial cinematic translation was in 1951, with Strangers on a Train by Alfred Hitchcock, and it made Highsmith famous - not to say well-off - overnight. In the intervening period, many others have felt drawn to the author's gallery of literary sociopaths: Claude-Autant Lara (Le Meutrier, 1963), Claude Miller (Dites-lui que je l'aime, 1977), Michel Deville (Eaux Profondes, 1981) and Claude Chabrol (Le Cri du Hibou, 1987) have all made films based on her work.

In addition there have been two previous attempts to adapt Highsmith's most celebrated creation, the genial psychopath Tom Ripley: René Clément filmed The Talented Mr Ripley as Plein Soleil, starring a very young Alain Delon, in 1960 (reissued in 1997 by Miramax, the company behind Minghella's version), while a later volume in Highsmith's Ripley series, Ripley's Game, was the basis for Wim Wenders's 1977 The American Friend.

But just as the foregoing list attests to Highsmith's popularity with film-makers (particularly ones called Claude), it also shows a marked bias for her work among European cinéastes. There is no real mystery about Hollywood's shyness where Highsmith is concerned, for the author - though an American - was positively opposed to the key film industry tenet that the good should be rewarded and the wicked punished. As she once said, "I find the public passion for justice quite boring and artificial, for neither life nor nature cares if justice is ever done or not."

No one who knows Highsmith only through American screen adaptations will therefore have much of a sense of the novels' characteristic moral climate. Hitchcock's version of Strangers on a Train has little in common with its source material beyond a general misogyny and an opening proposition - two men, one a psychopath, one not, meet on a train and discuss their difficulties with their respective families. Suddenly the psychopath slams his palms together and cries out euphorically: "Hey! Cheeses. What an idea! We murder for each other, see? I kill your wife and you kill my father! We meet on a train, see, and nobody knows we know each other! Perfect alibis! Catch?"

Thereafter film and novel diverge significantly. In the cinema version the good guy is never allowed even to contemplate going through with his side of the bargain - at worst he risks being thought guilty by other people. In the novel, on the other hand, the honest citizen actually carries out the killing and becomes possessed by guilt; such is Highsmith's skill that the process by which he comes to commit the murder seems entirely logical, and all the more terrible for that. As Susannah Clapp observed in a recent issue of the New Yorker: "In Highsmith, the corruption of good intentions is so insidious that it comes to seem a perfectly natural process." Conventional notions of justice - legal, divine, poetic - have no force in Highsmith's world.

Highsmith does not appear to have invited discussion of her personal life, but the established biographical facts are none the less worth rehearsing. Her parents separated five months before she was born, in Fort Worth, Texas in 1921, and she was raised initially by her grandmother.

This happy period was cut short when she was summoned to join her mother in New York, where the two women appear to have formed a lethal partnership worthy of Whatever Happened to Baby Jane?; mother taunting daughter by relating how she had tried to abort her foetus during pregnancy. "She really tried to get rid of it - she told me - I didn't mind," Highsmith later remembered. "She said, 'It's funny you adore the smell of turpentine, Pat'. It is an extraordinary story, not least for the way in which Highsmith tells it, managing to make a monstrous revelation seem entirely ordinary, an effect that Highsmith achieves again and again in her fiction. In the circumstances it is perhaps understandable that Highsmith hated her mother and blamed her for her own later inability to live with others.

As a young adult, the novelist toyed with various careers, briefly pursuing writing for comic books: interested readers can still find the children's title Miranda the Panda is On the Veranda in the collection of the British Library. She almost became a painter, too. It will come as no surprise to learn that she was particularly drawn to the work of Francis Bacon: humanity vomiting into a toilet bowl struck a chord.

But recognition as a writer was not long withheld from her. In 1945 her first short story, The Heroine, was published in Harper's Bazaar. Soon after, on a recommendation from Truman Capote, she went to stay at the Yaddo writers' colony, redrafted Strangers on a Train, found a publisher in Harper & Sons and achieved international success - though, mirroring the tastes of film-makers, her books have traditionally had a larger audience in Europe than in the US. The novelist herself moved to Britain and France in the 1960s before finally settling in Switzerland.

When it was first published in 1950, Strangers on a Train was advertised by its publishers as "A Harper Novel of Suspense". If you go in search of a copy today, you will discover that the label has stuck, for her works are usually kept in the specialist crime or thriller sections of bookstores rather than among general fiction.

Although Highsmith is still thought of as a genre writer, her most obvious literary relations are rather grander than the classification would suggest. In the first place there is Henry James, another European-American puritan obsessed with the isolated consciousness and the destructive powers of the imagination: a James tale such as Maud-Evelyn shares many of the preoccupations of Highsmith's This Sweet Sickness. James's influence is hinted at explicitly in The Talented Mr Ripley when Mr Green leaf asks Tom if he has ever read The Ambassadors - in fact the plot of Ripley, in which an American is sent to Europe to try to persuade a fellow countryman to return home, is borrowed directly from James, albeit with an important twist.

However, the literary movement that most obviously marks Highsmith's work is European existentialism, from her beloved Dostoevsky and Gide through to Camus and Sartre - it is one of the constant lessons of these tales of individuals destroying one another that hell is other people.

Viewed in his proper postwar context, Tom Ripley is at once a psychopath and an existentialist hero. The series of books that Highsmith devoted to him - The Talented Mr Ripley (1955), Ripley Underground (1970), Ripley's Game (1974), The Boy Who Followed Ripley (1980) and Ripley Under Water (1990) - are a classic, if rather perverse, existentialist statement of the freedom of the individual to recreate him- or herself. Moreover, Ripley's murder of Dickie Greenleaf in the perfect tranquillity of San Remo is not without an echo in another seaside murder, that committed by Meursault in Camus's The Outsider.

In the existentialist tradition, the irrationality of human behaviour is an abiding theme. As Graham Greene wrote of Highsmith: "Her characters are irrational and they leap to life in the very lack of reason; suddenly we realise how unbelievably rational most fictional characters are."

One of the principal experiences of reading the novels is frustration: the reader's terrible sense of entrapment that comes with having to follow the mental processes of a character who consistently refuses to act in his own best interests. When, in A Suspension of Mercy, the writer Sydney Bartleby sets out to behave in a way that makes him seem guilty of his wife's murder, the reader is left to despair at the terrible lucidity of a consciousness ensnaring itself in absurdist Kafkaesque traps of its own devising.

Isolation, absurdity, irrationality: the philosophical essence of Highsmith's fiction is not obviously cinematic. As Russell Harrison points out in his monograph on the writer, it is the absence or displacement of many of the staples of realistic fiction that gives the novels their compelling, unique oddness. Politics, social observation, sex - these are all simply missing from most of Highsmith's earliest and best work.

Sex, or the lack of it, in Highsmith is particularly intriguing. Highsmith presents a world in which her characters are cut adrift, determined neither by family nor work duties. The consequences of removing all such moral and professional props can be spectacularly disorientating.

When Ripley is about to kill Richard Greenleaf, we are told: "He could have hit Dickie, sprung on him, or kissed him, or thrown him overboard." That there is a homoerotic element in the relationships drawn by Highsmith between her male characters has not passed unremarked by critics, nor by Minghella in his screen adaptation of The Talented Mr Ripley. However, in the novels, faced with the choice between killing or kissing, Highsmith's creations will almost invariably choose the former. There is one notable exception, however, for in an early work Highsmith did experiment with allowing her characters more explicit sexual existences and a conventional "happy ending".

The novel in question is The Price of Salt, which was first published in 1952 under the pseudonym Claire Morgan and which rapidly became an underground lesbian classic, selling nearly a million copies. When Highsmith finally owned up to the work in 1990, her explanation for the upbeat treatment of the gay lovers had a familiarly perverse ring, although here her insistence on going against the grain will strike most readers as more humane in its motivation: she had, she said, allowed the couple to find happiness in their relationship because "homosexuals male and female in American novels have had to pay for their deviation by cutting their wrists, drowning themselves in a swimming pool, or by switching to heterosexuality."

Ironically, The Price of Salt is one of the rare occasions when Highsmith's fiction indulges the desire for poetic justice so beloved of Hollywood producers - but, given its explicit subject matter and its leading female roles, it is probably the least likely of Highsmith's novels to be adapted for big-screen presentation.

fields.headline: 'This is the anti-Hollywood'
fields.standfirst: Brian Pendreigh reports from Palm Springs, America's premier showcase for foreign-language cinema
fields.trailText: Brian Pendreigh reports from Palm Springs, America's premier showcase for foreign-language cinema
fields.body:
Cary Grant and Randolph Scott pioneered the idea of Palm Springs as Hollywood's favoured weekend retreat in the 30s when they donned posed for pictures at the Racquet Club. Before long just about every film star had a home in the sheltered desert town 125 miles from Hollywood.

Residents included Clark Gable, Elizabeth Taylor, Elvis Presley, Ronald Reagan, Steve McQueen and Frank Sinatra. But the collapse of the studio system, rising salaries and ease of travel, mean that stars are now more likely to head for a ranch in Montana than a bungalow in the Colorado desert.

Asked if there are any film stars left, the best that one local resident can do is Loretta Young. However as one link with the film world dies, another is born. The stars of old Hollywood have been replaced by a new breed of film celebrity led by Pedro Almodóvar, Zhang Yimou and Catherine Deneuve. Once a Hollywood colony, Palm Springs is now promoting itself as the home of the US's premier international film festival.

So here we have an offshoot of Hollywood staging a film festival without major studio films. And, since it overlaps with Sundance, it loses out on the best American independent films too. The January time-slot does have one big advantage: it comes during the run-up to the Oscars. Of the record 47 national nominees for best foreign-language Oscar, two-thirds were shown at the festival, which concluded this week. It provides a valuable platform in a town whose residents include almost 300 voting members of the Academy.

All About My Mother, Rosetta and Three Seasons will be familiar titles for British audiences, though others proved genuine discoveries. All My Loved Ones, the true story of an Englishman rescuing children from the Holocaust, sounded like a Slovakian attempt to remake Schindler's List, but was skilfully constructed and prompted floods of tears and a long standing ovation.

Sonny Bono envisaged the festival as a US version of Cannes and developed the idea when he was mayor in the late 80s. This year's festival was the biggest ever and the trade paper Variety covered it in detail for the first time, which helped attract buyers. "I would like to say it was because of great insight, but that's not the truth," says festival director Craig Prater. "It was originally created to encourage tourism in Palm Springs in the winter. But it has taken on a life of its own."

The festival halved the number of US films this year to concentrate even more on overseas films. But a team-sheet that includes Almodóvar, Zhang Yimou and Hector Babenco suggests Palm Springs has not only become the anti-Hollywood, but a candidate for investigation by the Un-American Activities Committee.

Almodóvar attended a screening of All About My Mother. The film won a Golden Globe for best foreign film in Hollywood on Monday but its director was understandably bitter when Sony insisted the film be shown here in a cinema with no more than 200 seats because it is already on commercial release. People who could not get in were angry too, though it screened with some standing and sitting in the aisle.

Zhang Yimou does not have a film in contention for the foreign-language Oscar - the Chinese committee preferred the dreadful Lover's Grief Over the Yellow River, a second world war "epic" whose portrayal of the Japanese makes Birth of a Nation's view of African-Americans seem enlightened. He came anyway with Not One Less, billed as a world premiere, even though it screened at Venice and won the golden lion. The festival included three new Catherine Deneuve films - Belle Maman, Place Vendôme and East-West.

Palm Springs has come out of the closet since Cary and Randolph played together. Go out on a Saturday night and it seems everyone is gay. It is now one of the US's leading gay resorts and there was a significant gay strand in the festival. But go out during the week and you will be be lucky to see anyone under 70. Add into the equation that almost 20% of the 45,000 residents are reputedly millionaires and you have a very atypical American town, and a very affluent one.

Other festivals use students as volunteers; the gofers at Palm Springs are often retired professionals. Significantly the festival opened with the world premiere of Walking Across Egypt, in which Ellen Burstyn plays a feisty old southern lady. It conjures up memories of Driving Miss Daisy.

But the biggest star in town was Kirk Douglas, a former resident who moved to LA to be closer to his grandchildren. In Diamonds, Douglas, who suffered a stroke a few years ago, plays a man who suffered a stroke a few years ago. He was in fine form, both in person and on film. Although it may aspire to the status of America's Cannes, Palm Springs has not severed its ties with Old Hollywood completely.

fields.headline: The Shane gang
fields.standfirst: Shane Meadows tells Fiachra Gibbons about Clint Eastwood, air rifles, the midlands' first homegrown cockney and his new film
fields.trailText: Shane Meadows tells Fiachra Gibbons about Clint Eastwood, air rifles, the midlands' first homegrown cockney and his new film
fields.body:
Mary Whitehouse was right. Screen violence does corrupt the young. Not even film-makers themselves are immune. Take the sorry story of Shane Meadows, one of our most ebullient directors. One summer afternoon - his mind filled with God knows what horrors after watching a TV matinee of Clint Eastwood's The Outlaw Josey Wales - Meadows grabbed a rifle and went out on to the streets of one of Uttoxeter's better council estates to take terrible revenge on Paul Fraser for not playing badminton with him. Fraze, his next-door neighbour and best friend since birth, was shot down like a dog. OK, so they were 11 at the time, and it was only an air rifle, but the hurt and the guilt linger.

Meadows, a man as acquainted with shame as he is with the grooming habits of the lesser lemurs of the Outer Comores, still blushes at the memory. "I was aiming at the wall. Honest, I was." Fraser pulls up his T-shirt to show where the wound was. "It was the biggest pea-sized bruise you have ever seen... My mum always said I should stay away from you."

Janet Fraser took a dim view of Shane. She knew trouble when she saw it (Meadows would later appear in court for the theft of a breast pump. We'll not mention the dodgy second-hand chopper business he ran from his back garden). Janet also had the fastest smack in the West Midlands, and vengeance was swift. "I'd rather have faced Ali," says Meadows.

It was the beginning of the end of their boyhood together. That and a bit of horseplay on a swing, which Shane got blamed for and which aggravated an injury to Fraser's back. Fraser, a quiet lad, spent nearly two years recovering in bed, living in his own head, learning magic tricks and collecting Pepsi cans. "I don't know why, but when you're 12 you do these things." Janet first kept chubby, chatty Shane away, but he soon stopped calling anyway. He was getting his teenage kicks early, piggybacking on the older boys who fancied his big sister to gain entry into worlds "no child should have been near".

It doesn't sound like much, but it was from such childish things that his new film came. A Room For Romeo Brass is the story of Fraser and Meadows's lifelong friendship and how their loyalty to one another was tested in that odd, dangerous and peculiarly unexplored period before the claxon bells of puberty start ringing in your pants. It neatly brings to a close Meadow's "Nottingham trilogy", on which Fraser also worked, the low-budget Small Time and the feature TwentyFourSeven, yet far surpasses both in scope and subtlety.

Edinburgh in August is a city of strange sights. But even among nude Azerbijani chicken jugglers and Phill Jupitus in shorts, Shane Meadows's Midland posse turned heads on the way to the film festival awards. All dressed in flared white suits, with shaven-headed Shane giving it at that up front, it looked for all the world that Blaxpoitation had been born in Burton-on-Trent and not Burbank. You wouldn't expect less from a man who made 30 short films, and an international reputation, with a video camera borrowed from Nottingham DSS.

Andrew Shim, the child actor who plays Romeo Brass is a ringer for Meadows both on and off screen - first to the microphone and last to leave the table. There is only one slight difference. Andrew is black. Ben Marshall, who plays the Fraser role "Knock Knocks", is just as fair and hangs back just like Fraze. Vicky McClure (Romeo's gobby sister Ladine) stares at her shoes, and covers her shyness by looking dead bored in that way teenagers do. The following week's Variety, the Hollywood bible, will fawn over her performance.

Meanwhile Paddy Considine, who plays Morell, the weird estate idiot who comes between the friends, is cracking jokes in the cinema foyer. Paddy's a very good photographer. You may have seen his studies of bare-knuckle fighters. He's also funny, very funny. There are impersonations, mad, frighteningly fast improvisations, sudden dazzling changes of pace. It begins to go quiet. The room is watching him. He is better than anything I've seen in three weeks of fringe comedy. Steve Coogan couldn't live with this man. Paddy will be back on the dole in Burton come Monday.

Back in an Edinburgh hotel too snooty to serve Irn-Bru, Fraser and Meadows are confessing their childhood crimes against a kid called Squirrel. "He was the kid they tested things on," says Meadows. "We couldn't wait to be one of the big lads, to be able to spit and play football properly. You would do anything to hang around with them.

"I remember them getting this big piece of ice from a pond once - it was so thick they were fish still in it - and making us lie round in the circle so they could drop it on our heads. They smashed it on poor Squirrel. He was not a well boy. When he came to, they promised to give him some of their Chinese if he put a couple of coats on and ran round a bit so they could use him for target practice for their air rifles... Later when the big lads were blooding me into their gang, they held Squirrel down so I could give him a kicking. That was the kind of things we did."

It was their realisation that such cruelties were not confined to Westland Road, Uttoxeter, and prompting from Meadows's dying grandfather, that persuaded them to sit down together and write about their friendship. "After TwentyFourSeven, I thought we should do a genre film or something. We were sitting in Stratford thinking about this Welsh western," says Meadows. "But my grandfather reminded me about Fraser. When you think about it, how many guys brought up on either side of a semi-detached council house in Uttoxeter go on to make film in their mid-20s?

"Fraser's creative edge was always apparent. I remember him winning this big writing competition. When he was sick I got in with these pretty dodgy older blokes. You think they are great, they've got cars and all, and you don't see the dangers. I saw things a child shouldn't see. I saw a kid get a kicking from a guy who just wanted to impress me. He was stamping on his head and everything. That's when I realised I had to get out of this. I tried to be a tough guy, but when I was exposed to real violence it did my head in."

After neglecting his sick mate for 18 months - several lifetimes when you're 11 - Meadows eventually skulked back up the stairs to see him. "To be forgiven by someone when you have done nothing for them except be a pain in the arse was a big thing for me," he said. "He had been cooped up in that box room going through puberty on his own, and I hadn't been there for him. I had changed a lot too, and in ways I hated Fraser because he hadn't seen what I had. I felt kind of dirty."

Those were not the only things that had altered in those two years. When Fraser did emerge from his bed he had a cockney accent as well - "I saw this cockney bloke get off with a girl at the pool; I thought it was cool," he said. "I remember coming up to Shane in the corridor of the high school and saying 'Watcha mate!' Everyone was thinking 'Who is this kid?' Shane had a bit of a reputation and I think he was embarrassed by this snotty little arse." "Too right," says Meadows, "my credibility was at stake."

"One day he told me I had to belt this guy to prove myself," says Fraser. "So I went up to this kid and whacked him, but he didn't go down. He didn't even move. Shane was behind me saying, 'Whack him again, Fraze.' I did, but he still wouldn't fight. I looked a twat and I got detention for it as well."

His career as a goon over before it started, blond, blue-eyed Fraser became the second-form heart-throb instead. "It was only later when sensitive Fraze pulled this really great girlfriend that I realised that my big masculine thing had gone right out of fashion," says Meadows. "So I got wacky fast and joined the school play to get near the girls. But we still played up to the older lads. We'd do these little comedy routines for them in the arch down the town centre - nativity plays outside pubs even. They thought we were just these mad kids, but they accepted us."

It is this gift for play that may explain why the pair have got so much out of their young actors. Apart from Bob Hoskins, Frank Harper and Ladene Hall, who have all been round the block, the guts of the cast was drawn from the Central Junior TV Workshop in Nottingham. They rehearsed and workshopped the script for three months.

Meadows was determined that after TwentyFourSeven, which won prizes, was liked by critics, but wasn't seen by a huge public, he wanted to make a truly populist film. "I would hate to make a festival circuit film about two lads... that's not what I'm about." What Meadows will no doubt shortly be about is big-budget films. He wants do a few TV things, and a couple of smaller DVD projects with Fraser, but it's clear he's knows a call from a studio is not far away. "It was good to do it while I still could," he said. Fraser pulls up his T-shirt to show where the wound was. "It was the biggest pea-sized bruise you have ever seen... My mum always said I should stay away from you." Janet Fraser took a dim view of Shane. She knew trouble when she saw it (Meadows would later appear in court for the theft of a breast pump. "I'd rather have faced Ali," says Meadows. It was the beginning of the end of their boyhood together. fields.headline: Jane Leeves
fields.trailText: Jane Leeves
fields.body:
What was the first film you saw?

A double bill of James Bonds at the local fleapit in East Grinstead: they were Diamonds are Forever and Thunderball.

What's your favourite film?

Lawrence of Arabia. It's a perfect film - David Lean always uses the screen like a canvas. I saw it on the telly when I was little and that's what inspired me to become an actor.

What was the last film you walked out of?

The Thomas Crown Affair. I hear it got better at the end, but I thought the sex scenes were childish, staged and strained.

What was the most erotic movie moment?

The scene between Jack Nicholson and Jessica Lange when he takes her on the kitchen table in The Postman Always Rings Twice. It's just so raw and yet there's no nudity.

What's the most annoying habit in a cinema?

People who natter incessantly, vocalising every reaction and repeating the dialogue. It's a product of the TV generation.

What's your favourite snatch of dialogue?

In The Sound of Music where the mother superior says: "Go back to the von Trapps" and Maria says, "I can't face it". Then the Mother Superior says, "What is it you can't face, Maria?". It sounds incredibly like she's saying something rude. Or Marlon Brando in Mutiny on the Bounty where he says, "I feel the cheese may be tainted." Or in Breakfast at Tiffany's where she gets the plans mixed up for her knitting and says, "I think I may be knitting a ranch house."

When did you last snog in the cinema?

I don't think I've really snogged anyone, but I went to the movies with my husband recently and we had a little smooch and snuggle before Being John Malkovich started.

Which actor would you most like to be?

Peter O'Toole. He's so fearless as an actor. You never know what you're going to get with him but it's always out there.

Which actress?

Meryl Streep. I'd say that doubly now I've worked with her. There's nothing she can't do. I hate her!

What was the last time you hid under your seat?

In Silence of the Lambs. You never knew what was around the corner. It was gory when she went into that warehouse. I'd read the book and knew she was going to find that head in a jar.

Last time you cried?

I cry when I watch myself because I just think "yikes". And I bawled my eyes out watching Music of the Heart because it's such an inspiring little movie.

Do Niles and Daphne ever get it together?

Yes. We've just done a couple of episodes where Daphne has found out that Niles has had a crush on her for years and years. She's engaged but is developing feelings for Niles. It all gets incredibly complicated and lovely.

 Jane Leeves is in Music of the Heart on general release.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: The Mummy | Le Dner de Cons | The Hi-Lo Country
fields.trailText: The Mummy | Le Dner de Cons | The Hi-Lo Country
fields.body:
The Mummy
Rental, retail and DVD £19.99
Universal Pictures Cert 12
***

Loosely hung on the bones of the old Boris Karloff films started by the same studio in 1932, The Mummy is conceived much more as Indiana Jones meets the Ungrateful Dead. It chucks lots of top-of-the-range FX at the screen, often at the expense of narrative coherence. The film's plagues, for example - locusts, rats, beetles and a sort of human sandstorm - are highly impressive but come from a different story altogether. "It's Egypt already, let's do plagues," seems to be the thinking here.

The plague of ancient racial stereotyping rears its head too - don't expect to see any noble, incorruptible or even clean locals. It's set in 1926, but I don't think that's an excuse. The actors are inevitably secondary, but Brendan Fraser and Rachel Weisz are appealing in stock roles. Fraser, already adept at goofy comedy and the subtle drama of Gods and Monsters, is also a natural for an action hero. He's got the physique and moves well enough without quite being in Banderas's league. Weisz has the best comedy scene when she brings an entire library down through the domino effect and an enjoyable drunk scene: "I am proud of what I am. I am a librarian." (This is actually the only line I can remember from writer-director Stephen Sommers's script).

At times Fraser and the initially prissy Weisz play it as if they're doing The African Queen with sand for water. Everything here seems to come from other movies. John Hannah as Weisz's brother doesn't get much to work on. He's not quite comic relief and no one seems to have worked out what he's there for. All in all, an archetypal Hollywood film - both dazzling and hugely unoriginal with many cliches surviving intact: have you ever seen someone whose glasses get stepped on not come to a terrible fate within the next three minutes?

Le Dîner de Cons
Retail £15.99
Fox Pathé Cert 15
***

Even a glance at the sleeve lets you guess that the inevitable Hollywood re-make of this French hit will star Danny DeVito. The small, balding Jacques Villeret, who is the best thing about this farce already adapted from a long-running stage hit, is a dead ringer for Hollywood's poison dwarf.

Villeret plays Pignon, a "walking disaster area", and enthusiastic but well-meaning bore who can't resist showing photos of his collection of matchstick models to the stranger (Thierry Lhermitte) he meets. This is roughly the role John Candy had in Planes, Trains and Automobiles, but with one big difference: Lhermitte is delighted to meet a perfect exhibit for the "dinner of idiots" he holds with a friend. It's a good set-up but there's a problem with filmed stage farce - a lot of the fun is in seeing a tricky manoeuvre pulled off live. A complicated plot involving mistresses, cuckolds and taxmen robs us of the promised dinner. It's neither as witty nor as physical as might be hoped for.

The Hi-Lo Country
Rental Universal Pictures Cert 15
**

Stephen Frears, man of many genres, tackles his first western with a 1961 novel that was once a Peckinpah project. It's a big, sprawling family drama, roughly in the style of The Big Country but can't help coming over like a film out of its time with its fighting cowboys, hoedowns and women compared to horses.

Billy Crudup is our hero staying firm friends with best buddy Woody Harrelson although he's having an affair with the girl of Crudup's dreams (Patricia Arquette). There's the inevitable good woman a-waitin' too. The film seems to think Harrelson's an admirable maverick but his character seemed to me boorish and hardly worth the limpet-like friendship (a gay subtext looms but never emerges). A big, overstretched disappointment from the director of The Grifters and The Snapper.

fields.headline: Divided we fall
fields.standfirst:
Increasing differences between Westminster, Edinburgh and Cardiff are a taste of confusion to come

Devolution in Wales: special report
Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: Increasing differences between Westminster, Edinburgh and Cardiff are a taste of confusion to come.
fields.body:
Today tuition fees, tomorrow transport policy, health, agriculture and fishing. Who knows? The limits to which an acquisitive Scottish parliament can challenge Westminster are limitless.

Then there's that other troublesome lot west of Offa's Dyke with fewer powers than the Scots, unable to frame legislation, yet chaffing at the bit and already complaining that Westminster is doing them down over Euro aid. And don't forget the soon-to-be elected mayor, and assembly in Greater London preparing for battle with the real government just down the Thames, complaining their powers are too limited - and (watch this space) confronting the Edinburgh parliament with claims that London's multi-billion pound "subsidy" to the nations and regions of Britain has to stop. "We want our money back," they are already screaming.

The UK, in short, is anything but united these days. And those who warned that unilateral devolution would lead Britain into a constitutional minefield - from Labour's Tam Dalyell to the former Foreign Secretary, Malcolm Rifkind - are being proved right. Few western democracies can have such a hotch-potch system of government and voting mechanisms - a form of proportional representation here, first-past-the-post there - and such an uneven pattern of local government. People in some areas are served by two local councils in a two-tier system; in others, a single unitary authority undertakes all functions.

Devolution, of course, was bound to throw up all sorts of anomalies, cross-border disputes and much hand-wringing at Westminster - particularly when partial-PR almost guarantees that no party will have an overall majority in Scotland's 129-member parliament. But so soon?

Of course, Labour's climb-down over tuition fees in Edinburgh is a direct result of coalition government. Lib-Dem partners in the ruling administration had always said the fees should be scrapped - hence the compromise of a scheme under which students will have to pay back £2,000 (for the standard four-year course in Scotland) when they start earning £10,000 a year. But if Scottish parents earn less than £23,000 annually, they'll be eligible for grants of £2,000. Tough luck, of course, for the parents of English students studying in Scotland.

It's this anomaly - a taste of things to come? - which brought the Exeter MP, Ben Bradshaw, to his feet in the Commons this week at Scottish question time. He hoped that his constituents wouldn't have to fund the £50m cost of implementing the scheme (actually, it should be met from Scotland's generous £14bn-plus annual grant from Whitehall). In the event, it caused such a panic at Westminster that the education secretary, David Blunkett, rushed forward a £68m scheme to help poorer English and Welsh students. The tartan tail is already wagging the Westminster dog and panicking ministers into action.

Bradshaw's intervention was significant. Scotland, and the constitution at large, will assuredly become a much bigger issue as the (British) general election approaches. Labour MPs in middle England are restless. Understandably, some of their supporters are seething, particularly if they have offspring studying in Scotland.

Southern anger about privileged Scottish students can soon develop into a wider question about a Westminster funding formula which gives Scots a level of government spending per head 20% higher than in England.

In Tory central office, this apparent anomaly will no doubt be dusted down and presented as a big issue when Tony Blair decides to go to the country. But by then, other little idiosyncrasies - and, doubtless, other policy divergences - will have blown another hole in cross-border unity. Cardinal Thomas Winning would like Scottish control of abortion policy. This is a confusing area, because the Edinburgh parliament oversees other health matters.

Others north of the border would like to assume responsibility for immigration policy to give asylum seekers a better deal. It's another confusing area because, while Jack Straw is in charge of immigration, Edinburgh (through the local councils it funds) has a duty to house and feed refugees.

Then there's transport. Sure, the rail regulator regulates rail services in Scotland - but then Edinburgh oversees other aspects of public transport and, of course, funds all roads. Agriculture and fishing? Yes, devolved too - except that Westminster leads discussions in Brussels. Confused? So are most Scots.

Westminster MPs, particularly Labour members in Scotland, are a more angry. Scotland's new government has been getting some awful publicity, invariably over the would be spin-doctors and advisers surrounding First Minister Donald Dewar. In Wales, First Secretary Alun Michael, leading a minority administration, faces other survival problems. With a British general election possibly a little over a year away - mid-term, as it happens, in Westminster and Cardiff - some MPs understandably feel threatened by events outside their control.

In England, meanwhile, the next cross-border dispute is waiting to happen. Comprehensive Spending Review later this year, perhaps? How much to dish out around the UK - for the English regions are getting restless? Maybe we ain't seen nothing yet.

But if Scottish parents earn less than £23,000 annually, they'll be eligible for grants of £2,000. Tough luck, of course, for the parents of English students studying in Scotland. It's this anomaly - a taste of things to come? - which brought the Exeter MP, Ben Bradshaw, to his feet in the Commons this week at Scottish question time. He hoped that his constituents wouldn't have to fund the £50m cost of implementing the scheme (actually, it should be met from Scotland's generous £14bn-plus annual grant from Whitehall). In the event, it caused such a panic at Westminster that the education secretary, David Blunkett, rushed forward a £68m scheme to help poorer English and Welsh students. The tartan tail is already wagging the Westminster dog and panicking ministers into action. Bradshaw's intervention was significant. Scotland, and the constitution at large, will assuredly become a much bigger issue as the (British) general election approaches. Labour MPs in middle England are restless. Understandably, some of their supporters are seething, particularly if they have offspring studying in Scotland. Southern anger about privileged Scottish students can soon develop into a wider question about a Westminster funding formula which gives Scots a level of government spending per head 20% higher than in England. In Tory central office, this apparent anomaly will no doubt be dusted down and presented as a big issue when Tony Blair decides to go to the country. But by then, other little idiosyncrasies - and, doubtless, other policy divergences - will have blown another hole in cross-border unity. Cardinal Thomas Winning would like Scottish control of abortion policy. This is a confusing area, because the Edinburgh parliament oversees other health matters. Others north of the border would like to assume responsibility for immigration policy to give asylum seekers a better deal. It's another confusing area because, while Jack Straw is in charge of immigration, Edinburgh (through the local councils it funds) has a duty to house and feed refugees. Then there's transport. Sure, the rail regulator regulates rail services in Scotland - but then Edinburgh oversees other aspects of public transport and, of course, funds all roads. Agriculture and fishing? Yes, devolved too - except that Westminster leads discussions in Brussels. Confused? So are most Scots. Westminster MPs, particularly Labour members in Scotland, are a more angry. Scotland's new government has been getting some awful publicity, invariably over the would be spin-doctors and advisers surrounding First Minister Donald Dewar. In Wales, First Secretary Alun Michael, leading a minority administration, faces other survival problems. With a British general election possibly a little over a year away - mid-term, as it happens, in Westminster and Cardiff - some MPs understandably feel threatened by events outside their control. In England, meanwhile, the next cross-border dispute is waiting to happen. Comprehensive Spending Review later this year, perhaps? How much to dish out around the UK - for the English regions are getting restless? Maybe we ain't seen nothing yet.

fields.trailText: In our Other people feature about Elspeth Garman, page 16, January 15, we called her in a sub-heading "Inventor of a vaccine to combat flu." In fact, the new anti-flu drug is not a vaccine, and she has never claimed to be the inventor of it. That was a claim we mistakenly thrust upon her. The drug, Relenza, was invented by three scientists in Australia, Dr Peter Colman, Dr Graeme Laver and Dr Mark von Itzstein. The new drug is a treatment not a vaccine (treatments seek to make you better once you are ill; vaccines should stop you falling ill in the first place). Apologies to all concerned.

fields.headline: Coutts client on fraud charge
fields.trailText: Rachamim Anatian, a businessman involved with Coutts, bankers to the Queen, was charged with falsifying business records and fraud in insolvency yesterday.
fields.body:
Rachamim Anatian, a businessman involved with Coutts, bankers to the Queen, was charged with falsifying business records and fraud in insolvency yesterday.

The criminal charges, brought by the district attorney's office in New York, follow an investigation of the bank by the Federal Reserve Bank.

Coutts, the private banking arm of NatWest, has denied all wrongdoing in the case. Last year it closed its New York branch with losses of $50m.

Mr Anatian, a former client, has accused it of questionable practices and filed a civil case against it. The bank, whose client list includes Elton John, has called itself a "victim" of a scandal which has also involved several members of staff.

Mr Anatian is understood to have borrowed money from the bank.

Yesterday he was accused of submitting false promissory notes worth more than $27m (£16.5) in order to stake a claim to the assets of Global Broadcasting Systems, a bankrupt company he once managed.

In a 96-count indictment, the district attorney accused him of tampering with physical evidence, of committing fraud in insolvency and falsifying business records.

webTitle: French battle for Belfast missile maker

fields.headline: French battle for Belfast missile maker
fields.trailText: France's two premier defence groups, Aérospatiale Matra and Thomson-CSF, have begun a bitter spat over ownership of Belfast-based Shorts Missile Systems (SMS).
fields.body:
France's two premier defence groups, Aérospatiale Matra and Thomson-CSF, have begun a bitter spat over ownership of Belfast-based Shorts Missile Systems (SMS).

The row has created uncertainty for SMS's 500 employees in Northern Ireland - and 50 in France - just as Thomson is due to take control on Monday.

Denis Ranque, Thomson's chairman, was savouring his coup in buying Racal for £1.35bn when he received a letter from Philippe Camus, Aérospatiale's chief executive, warning that he would exercise an option to take 49% of SMS's equity.

Mr Ranque, who had bought out the 50% stake in SMS held by Bombardier, Shorts' Canadian owner, retorted that Aérospatiale had no legal basis for claiming that option.

French observers said yesterday that Mr Camus, whose group controls Europe's biggest missile maker, Matra BAe Dynamics (MBD), with BAE Systems, had no intention of allowing its biggest French rival to establish a substantial presence in this sector.

MBD is poised to win a £1bn order from the UK to supply Eurofighter with its "smart" missiles and is seeking to forge a pan-European rival to Raytheon, the American missiles group.

Aérospatiale officials said yesterday that the 49% option over SMS dated from a 1993 agreement between itself and Thomson, and talks continued on the issue. But its French rival, while conceding talks took place in 1993, insisted no such accord existed.

SMS primarily supplies the Starstreak missile fitted on the Alvis Stormer armoured vehicle.

"We are still a joint venture today but on Monday we will be wholly owned by Thomson," a spokeswoman said. "Everything is as normal in Belfast."

webTitle: £6bn work for UK if Boeing wins dogfight

fields.headline: £6bn work for UK if Boeing wins dogfight
fields.standfirst: Test flights in March for 'concept' combat aircraft
fields.trailText: British defence firms stand to win orders worth at least £6bn if Boeing wins the contract to build the Joint Strike Fighter, senior executives of the American planemaker said yesterday.
fields.body:
British defence firms stand to win orders worth at least £6bn if Boeing wins the contract to build the Joint Strike Fighter, senior executives of the American planemaker said yesterday.

The programme could be worth an astonishing $300bn in export orders, guaranteeing tens of thousands of UK jobs, and pits a team built around Boeing against one led by Lockheed Martin, the world's biggest defence contractor.

The multi-role combat aircraft is being developed to replace fighters such as the F-16 and F-22 for the US airforce, navy and marines - and the ageing Harriers of the Royal Navy and RAF, which want 60 and 90 planes respectively.

It could provide the main thrust of the rapid reaction forces being built up by the UK and its European partners, notably on the two new aircraft carriers being planned by the ministry of defence.

But the overall programme could involve up to 5,000 planes, with the USAF alone ordering 1,763 aircraft so far and countries such as Norway, Canada, Israel, Turkey and Singapore joining in.

Announcing plans for Boeing's two "concept demonstrator" aircraft to begin test flights by the end of March, Frank Statkus, vice-president of Boeing's JSF programme, said UK firms would be guaranteed 20% of the eventual value of the contract. The UK government is contributing 10% of the development costs.

Among those in Boeing's team are the avionics division of BAE Systems, once part of GEC-Marconi, Rolls-Royce, which is supplying hardware for the jump-jet version, Messier-Dowty, which is providing landing-gear, and other smaller firms.

But BAE Systems also stands to gain if the rival team headed by Lockheed and embracing Northrop Grumman, makers of the B2 stealth bomber, wins the JSF contract.

The contract is being awarded by the Pentagon and the ministry of defence, and a decision is likely within 18 months. Production of the plane would begin in 2004 and it would enter service in 2012.

Industry sources said the plane was so technologically advanced and the programme so financially weighty that there may be a decision to split it between the rival teams.

They said these two were running neck and neck in terms of controlling costs, with Mr Statkus claiming the programme was a model of affordability and the lowest risk Boeing had ever undertaken.

"This plane will give the free world the technological best of the best - and guarantee that freedom for 40 years," he said, at a London presentation.

The aircraft were rolled out last month at a ceremony in California attended by employees, contractors and US defence officials.

One has conventional take-off and landing capability, the other short take-off and vertical landing abilities for carrier use. Both can be built on the same production line because of common parts.

Boeing applied "lean" concepts, including advanced 3D modelling and minimal tooling, to design and build the X-32 in less time and at lower cost than comparable aircraft.

webTitle: Rhodia close to clinching A&W deal

fields.headline: Rhodia close to clinching A&W deal
fields.trailText: Speciality chemicals group Rhodia is expecting to tie up its €1.2bn (£750m) acquisition of phosphates-maker Albright & Wilson within the next few weeks.
fields.body:
Speciality chemicals group Rhodia is expecting to tie up its €1.2bn (£750m) acquisition of phosphates-maker Albright & Wilson within the next few weeks.

The deal has been held up by negotiations over regulatory clearance in the US, and Rhodia's chairman and chief executive, Jean-Pierre Tirouflet, acknowledged yesterday that, although there had not been any basic disagreements with the federal trade commission, the discussions had taken "a little bit longer than expected".

"We are now close to the endgame," he said.

The acquisition will increase Rhodia's UK workforce because about 40% of Albright & Wilson's 5,000 employees are based at factories in Birmingham, Avonmouth, Widnes and Whitehaven.

Rhodia also plans to expand its pharmaceutical intermediates business, which includes plants in Holmes Chapel and Dagenham, with a series of new products in the pipeline.

Yesterday Rhodia, fully independent since Rhone-Poulenc sold its remaining 67.3% stake last October, reported full-year sales down 0.2% at €5.5bn but operating income up 22.5% at €409m.

Margins have been under pressure with sales volumes picking up 1.9% overall but prices falling 5.6%. There are signs that higher volumes towards the end of the year will help support higher prices, however.

The group remains on the look-out for acquisitions as it seeks to strengthen its position in what it regards as key areas and to reduce its exposure to cyclical fluctuations.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
House price rises slow down
A new year slowdown in housing market activity has resulted in property prices rising by the smallest amount for six months, according to new figures.
fields.body:
House price rises slow down
A new year slowdown in housing market activity has resulted in property prices rising by the smallest amount for six months, according to new figures.

British house prices have risen 0.9% this month, against 1% in December, said Nationwide Building Society. The average price of a home is £75,060 - 13.1% more than a year ago. However, while estate agents reported fewer viewings, there is evidence that, as in the 1980s boom, some homeowners are cashing in on the value of their properties by extending their mortgages to pay for luxury goods.

"There are signs that homeowners may once again be beginning to 'withdraw' equity," said a spokesman. "Our estimates suggest that equity withdrawal amounted to £10bn, or just over 1.5% of disposable income, during 1999." However, this was "a long way below" the levels of the late 1980s, of up to 6%.

Electrolux investigated
German police have been called in to investigate the £18m rogue currency trading losses by an employee of Electrolux, the world's largest consumer appliances group.

More than 1,000 different transactions are being examined in what is expected to be a long-running inquiry. Electrolux disclosed on January 3 that its Siege office in Germany, responsible for currency dealings relating to the group's imports and exports, had been hit by huge amounts of unauthorised trading.

Since confessing in December to nearly a year's worth of such speculation, the employee - a German national who had worked for the firm for 3 years - has been suspended.

Electrolux spokesman Folke Hammarlind said: "[He] has no future in the company", but confirmed the unnamed employee had not been dismissed.

He said an audit squad from KPMG has arrived in Siege to begin a full internal inquiry into the unauthorised currency speculations which are likely to wipe up to 5% off Electrolux's 1999 profits.

Telewest gives merger plans
Cable TV firm Telewest Communications detailed its plan yesterday to merge with Flextech in an agreed offer of 3.78 new Telewest shares for each Flextech share, which will result in Telewest shareholders owning around 80% and Flextech shareholders owning around 20% of the merged group.

Telewest said Cob Stenham will be the merged company's independent non-executive chairman, while Flextech's Adam Singer will be chief executive officer and Tony Illsley will be group managing director. It said it has acceptances for 37% of Flextech from Liberty Media.

Insurer excels under Halifax
Clerical Medical, the insurance arm of Halifax, took in £325m of new business in 1999, a 36% rise and just above the industry average for new business of 30%. Clerical Medical, which sells its products through independent financial advisers, said its worldwide retail business was £2.5bn, more than double the figure it was three years ago when it was taken over by Halifax.
