fields.headline: Merger talk lifts Fiat shares
fields.trailText: Shares in Fiat, the Italian car manufacturer, and DaimlerChrysler, the US-German group, rose yesterday on reports that they planned a merger.
fields.byline: Jane Martinson  in New York  and David Gow
fields.body:
Shares in Fiat, the Italian car manufacturer, and DaimlerChrysler, the US-German group, rose yesterday on reports that they planned a merger.

Fiat, long seen as the next target in the wave of consolidation that has swept the global car industry since Daimler took over Chrysler two years ago, ended up 5%. Daimler closed up 3.8%.

The report in Italian newspaper Il Giornale coincided with a move by Stuttgart-based Daimler to strengthen its control of the combined group when Robert Eaton resigned as co-chairman.

His departure cedes control to Jürgen Schrempp, his co-chairman, and eight fellow German directors on the 13-strong board where the Americans have lost power in what was billed as a merger of equals.

Both companies refused to comment but Wall Street analysts said Mr Schrempp could use a Fiat merger to extend his group's range into smaller cars. "They have been trying to formulate a small car strategy for some time," said one. Another Italian paper, Il Messagero, said there had been some opposition to the rumoured deal from Gianni Agnelli, Fiat's honorary chairman. The founding Agnelli family still owns about 33% of Fiat.

Any takeover is likely to have political ramifications as Fiat contributes almost 5% of Italy's GDP. Its automotive division provides just half its annual sales. Other interests include agricultural and construction equipment, Iveco commercial vehicles and insurance.

webTitle: CGU endowment policy holders win reprieve

fields.headline: CGU endowment policy holders win reprieve
fields.standfirst: Mortgage mis-selling explained
fields.trailText: Holders of failing endowment policies were thrown a lifeline yesterday by insurance group CGU, which said it would plug any shortfall between the value of policies and the mortgage originally targeted by dipping into its £5bn in free reserves.
fields.body:
Holders of failing endowment policies were thrown a lifeline yesterday by insurance group CGU, which said it would plug any shortfall between the value of policies and the mortgage originally targeted by dipping into its £5bn in free reserves.

CGU, the third largest endowment provider in Britain, says it will top up any policy where there is a shortfall between the payout and the mortgage it is attached to, as long as future investment returns do not fall below an average of 6% a year net. However, if returns drop below 6% CGU admits that policyholders will have to cough up extra cash to repay mortgages.

The guarantee means that none of CGU's 700,000 policyholders will be asked to increase endowment premiums in contrast to increases of £25 to £50 per month common at other companies. CGU says it only had a few thousand policies where shortfalls are "serious" but concedes that up to 400,000 policies could have had "very small" shortfalls.

The move will embarrass other insurers which are issuing millions of warning letters on endowments under orders from the financial services authority. Last week Standard Life wrote to 1m policyholders saying that many policies bought in the late 1980s "are likely to give a projected shortfall against the money needed to repay the mortgage". The FSA has now exempted CGU from sending out the letters.

CGU reported bumper new business figures earlier this week, and says its investment portfolio earned a gross return of 19% in 1999. It believes that future returns should comfortably exceed the 6% projection set by regulators, which it regards as too pessimistic.

But it says that even if the guarantee forces it to pay out, the liability will be minimal. fields.headline: French win Global One battle
fields.standfirst:
$4.3bn agreement puts Telecom company's strategy back on track in deal-a-day sector sector

E-finance: special report
www.global-one.net
www.francetelecom.fr
www.dtag.de
www3.sprint.com
fields.trailText: France Télécom was celebrating getting its international expansion strategy back on track yesterday after the announcement that it has reached a $4.35bn deal to buy out its partners in Global One.
fields.body:
France Télécom was celebrating getting its international expansion strategy back on track yesterday after the announcement that it has reached a $4.35bn deal to buy out its partners in Global One.

Shares in the French telecommunications group were up more than 4% in the wake of the deal which was struck late on Wednesday after a complex series of negotiations.

Under the terms of the agreement France Télécom is paying $3.88bn in cash and taking on $464m in debt for the 71% of Global One which it does not already own.

The US group Sprint is getting $1.127bn in cash and the repayment of $276m for its 42% stake while the third partner Deutsche Telekom gets $2.755bn in cash and $188.5m in debt repayment for its 29% holding. Both Deutsche Telekom and France Télécom, which each owns a 10% stake in Sprint, has agreed to back the US group's proposed merger with MCI WorldCom.

Explaining the difference between the prices paid for the two stakes a Deutsche Telekom spokesman said there had been one round of talks over the terms under which Sprint would sell its holding and then the two remaining partners had bid for which would take control. "France Télécom was the acquirer," he said. He declined to comment on how much Deutsche Telekom had offered.

The French group said the deal "significantly strengthens one of the three core elements of France Télécom's international strategy; providing world class services to multinationals and carriers."

The future ownership of Global One had been uncertain for some time ahead of Wednesday night's deal. The two European partners had been close allies but fell out last year after Deutsche Telekom tried to buy Telecom Italia. Regulatory pressures on Sprint to sell its stake to smooth the way for its merger with MCI WorldCom made the ownership issue increasingly urgent.

The deal values loss-making Global One, which provides voice and data telecommunications services to corporate customers in 65 countries, at around five times 1999 revenues.

Analysts broadly welcomed the deal. "Strategically it allows France Télécom to strengthen its position on the international stage, a factor which has become essential since its failure to acquire [German mobile phone group] E-Plus," said one analyst.

"This is a good transaction because it allows France Télécom to participate in the data market at an international level," according to Stefan Sater at Société Générale.

However there were divisions of opinion about which of the partners had got the best of the deal in terms of the price which France Télécom was paying.

The move is bound to spark speculation about further consolidation in what is fast becoming a deal-a-day industry

Deutsche Telekom, which earlier this week announced plans to sell a 10% stake in its T-Online internet business in April and which is also planning to float its mobile phone operation towards the end of the year, has said it will use the funds from the Global One sale to fund its international ambitions.

Outright ownership of Global One is clearly not the full extent of France Télécom's international ambitions and its financial firepower will be strengthened over the next two years as it sells off non-core businesses.

"Our non-strategic assets have a market value of Fr130bn (£11.8bn). We expect to sell them by the end of 2001," chairman Michel Bon said yesterday.

fields.headline: Disc drive inventor wins £28m payout
fields.trailText: It was a Pyrrhic victory for the UK's computer disc drive pioneer, Rodime, yesterday after it reached an out-of-court settlement with Seagate Technology, the manufacturer it sued seven years ago for patent infringement.
fields.body:
It was a Pyrrhic victory for the UK's computer disc drive pioneer, Rodime, yesterday after it reached an out-of-court settlement with Seagate Technology, the manufacturer it sued seven years ago for patent infringement.

Seagate, which is the world's biggest disc drive manufacturer, has agreed to pay $45m (£28m) to Rodime which made the world's first 3-inch disc drive in 1983. Rodime claimed that Seagate had infringed its patent.

However, the settlement leaves Rodime with only £7m in cash to pursue the development of is digital servo patents, after it repays debts to Bank of Scotland. Seagate continued to deny Rodime's allegations despite the settlement.

Stephen Luczo, Seagate's chief executive, said: "We maintain Seagate had meritorious defences to Rodime's claim. However, given the uncertainty associated with leaving such a technically complex matter in the hands of a jury, Seagate has compromised."

Rodime became almost a shell company, employing four staff, and living off its intellectual property while it battled with Seagate.

Its shares rose 5p to 15p on the settlement yesterday.

David Mathewson, non-executive director of Rodime, said: "These patents have been in the freezer but we've now taken them out and are having a good look at them."

fields.headline: Marks' fortunes still trending downward
fields.standfirst: Big problems for Vandevelde
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer is learning. Six months ago it unveiled its winter ranges in the grim surroundings of its Baker Street Lubianka. This week, unveiling its spring and summer collections, it has been occupying prime territory in the South Molton Street parade ground of the UK's fashionistas.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer is learning. Six months ago it unveiled its winter ranges in the grim surroundings of its Baker Street Lubianka. This week, unveiling its spring and summer collections, it has been occupying prime territory in the South Molton Street parade ground of the UK's fashionistas.

The verdict: simply stunning, darling. Mwah, Mwah. The shares celebrated with a 4% rise to close at 286p.

But let us hold on a minute before we all get carried away by M&S's "pared down cropped tailoring" and "this season's essential feminine detailing".

The merchandise is only half M&S's problem, and the reaction of the fashion press does not automatically set the tills ringing.

Take last autumn. The group's winter collections were greeted with widespread enthusiasm by the nation's style writers. The shares climbed by getting on for £1 to some 440p in anticipation of customers flooding in to buy those £300-a-go white leather coats and £20-a-throw pastel woollies. Shoppers voted with their feet and headed for Next.

Similarly, the new Paisley print dresses and pink lizardskin mules cannot return M&S to its former prestigious position, no matter how hot they are.

Trading remains abysmal. The 9% like-for-like decline in Christmas clothing sales was bad, but as a result of the unique way M&S calculates its underlying sales the reality was probably far worse.

The shares are trading at a level which can be justified only by takeover speculation. But bid fever has faded in the last couple of weeks and investment bank Salomon Smith Barney has a target price of just 200p.

M&S's stores are depressingly old-fashioned and it has too much trading space. But there would be few takers for its huge stores and because M&S is so often the anchor store in a shopping development its very presence dictates the rent that can be commanded.

There is also the sad but true fact that Marks & Spencer has become a naff brand. No one boasts about their M&S buys anymore. For the young and trendy St Michael is seriously uncool. The chain has consultants and a new marketing manager working on a revamp, but it will be an uphill task.

Longer term, the food business, now one of the most aggressive markets, is almost bound to run into problems. Then there is a new chairman, Luc Vandevelde, grappling with an old fashioned company culture and huge changes to the supply chain.

M&S has big problems, and they will not be solved with a bit of good gear.

Empty banks

There is something about this government that business has to get used to: it likes aggressive headlines, it likes big promises - and it tends to deliver rather less than expected.

This time the issue is Don Cruickshank's review of the banking sector. After a thorough and theoretical analysis of the way banks make money, Mr Cruickshank is telling his targets privately that he has actually found they are competing with one another after all. While there is a risk that he is simply softening the sector up for a real body blow, the banks do not appear to be concerned by recommendations which make it easier for customers to move their accounts - dubbed "portability" - or come up with other ideas which might make life easier for customers.

The banks believe that Mr Cruickshank, not adverse to publicity himself, knows he will not be able to provide the government with the headlines it wants when his report is published in March. No big attacks or reprimands, but just some useful (and perhaps rather boring) suggestions for financial firms.

Mr Cruickshank might be concerned that he will find himself a victim of a government that enjoys rhetoric it cannot back up with substance.

A good example is the mortgage industry, which in a rare situation, wanted to be regulated. Instead of strengthening protection, the government has caused more confusion for consumers.

When it comes to tackling social exclusion - a worthy aim to make it easier for all sectors of the community to have access to financial services - the government has also fallen short, failing to back its policies with hard cash. Plans to encourage credit unions are unlikely to get anywhere without money to back the initiative.

The industry argues that progress has been made in eradicating some of the least desirable financial products in recent months - for instance mortgages with lengthy lock-ins. It can be argued (and the authorities probably will) that the real reason for the sudden appearance of more "customer-friendly" products is that the banking industry read the threat of legislation seriously and took pre-emptive action.

But reviews such as Mr Cruickshank's are heavy-handed tools - and they are having a diminishing impact.

fields.headline: Hitting ITV pause button
fields.trailText: With AOL and Time Warner having tipped the global media business on its ear, and then Time Warner and EMI having got together to redefine the meaning of "takeover" with the outrageously convoluted pooling of their music assets, it is easy to forget that a media battle is still being fought with real ferocity within these shores.
fields.body:
With AOL and Time Warner having tipped the global media business on its ear, and then Time Warner and EMI having got together to redefine the meaning of "takeover" with the outrageously convoluted pooling of their music assets, it is easy to forget that a media battle is still being fought with real ferocity within these shores.

Behind the scenes, Granada, Carlton Communications and United News & Media are still trading insults as the fight to be the top dog of ITV continues. Almost nine weeks have passed since news of the proposed nil-premium merger between Carlton and United broke. Three weeks ago, Granada - sly as ever - said it was seeking regulatory guidance on whether it might launch a spoiling bid for one or other of the two merger partners. The move allowed Granada to sidestep the question of whether it will actually bid and at the same time increased the likelihood that the whole affair will be packed off to the competition commission.

There are suggestions - flatly refuted by the Carlton/United camp - that some institutional shareholders feel they are being strong-armed into giving an early indication as to how they might vote on the merger.

It is certainly the case that if the Carlton/United version of the deal were a hostile affair, advisers would now be flying around the City as Day 60 approaches in the takeover code timetable (February 8). But Granada is the predator and it has not yet made a formal move. So shareholders should simply expect the Carlton/United proposals to be rolled-forward once again at the next closing date (February 3).

The office of fair trading, meanwhile, might take until the middle of next month to arrive at its advice as to whether the merger should go to the competition com mission - and trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers might then take another week or so deciding whether or not to follow the OFT's advice. Setting aside all the political traps associated with any sort of decision on media regulations, he is a busy fellow, as everyone knows.

In the meantime, the OFT also has to come up with some sort of answer to Granada's questions - and so Mr Byers might even decide he wants to wait until he sees those before reaching a decision on Carlton/Granada. On top of this, there is also the BSkyB review to take into account.

All the while, close followers of this saga are just about 100% convinced that the whole shooting match will go to the commission. The real action will not begin until June at the earliest and everyone knows it would be unreasonable to ask shareholders to make a decision on which particular media horse they are minded to back before the regulatory position becomes decidedly clearer.

Shares in all three companies have proved to be pretty volatile over recent weeks. Now and again stories go round the Square Mile suggesting one or other European media player might be about to come in and upset this delicate applecart. But few who really know the sector reckon there is much chance of this happening.

The whole show is on "pause". Investors who already own stock in any of the three might as well just sit back and relax. Speculators, on the other hand, should look for excitement elsewhere.

webTitle: Non-EU trade deficit at record high

fields.headline: Non-EU trade deficit at record high
fields.standfirst: Markets surprised by widening gap between imports and exports
fields.trailText: Britain's trade deficit with non-European Union countries soared to record levels in December, revealing the damage the strong pound is inflicting on industry.
fields.body:
Britain's trade deficit with non-European Union countries soared to record levels in December, revealing the damage the strong pound is inflicting on industry.

Imports outstripped exports to countries outside the EU by £2.3bn last month, according to the office for national statistics - the widest gap since records began in 1988 and much more than the market had expected. Exports fell by 4.2% over the month and imports rose by 0.4%.

The less up to date figures for Britain's trade gap with the rest of the world also disappointed the markets. The whole world deficit for November stood at £2.5bn, the largest gap for six months.

Analysts said yesterday's numbers suggested that the pound was starting to do real damage. "The current levels of sterling are only sustainable in the short run," said Michael Hume, UK economist with Lehman Brothers.

The pound was 7.5% higher last month than a year ago against the currencies of Britain's trading partners.

Business surveys had suggested that export order books were filling up despite the pound's appreciation, but the new data will give the Bank of England's monetary policy committee cause for concern.

"The UK trade data imply that the UK economy isn't coping as well with the strong pound as we have been led to believe, and also that the Bank of England should be somewhat cautious in making further repo rate hikes," said Neil Parker, UK economist at the Royal Bank of Scotland.

The deficit for 1999 with countries outside the EU also reached a record high at £20.4bn, a 35% increase on the previous year's £15.2bn shortfall. The ONS said a rapid rise in imports from recovering economies in south-east Asia was partly to blame.

On a volume basis, which strips out price changes, imports from non-EU countries surged by 12% over the year, and exports were up just 2.5%.

Weak demand in the rest of the world is no longer the problem behind Britain's widening trade gap, with Europe, south-east Asia and north America growing steadily.

"Sterling's recent appreciation makes it difficult for UK producers to claim a share of this burgeoning global demand," said John O'Sullivan at Greenwich NatWest markets.

"At current exchange rates, Euro-11 producers enjoy a significant price advantage over their UK counterparts, both within the EU and outside it."

Despite the disappointing headline figures the ONS said the trend suggested the world trade deficit was narrowing. Over the last three months exports have risen 1%, while imports have stayed stable.

The ONS also published figures from customs and excise, showing regional trade breakdown for the first time.

The south-east is the largest source of exports and the largest consumer of imports, which statisticians said was unsurprising given the number of firms and population density. London and the south-east together account for 45% of imports and 34% of exports.

The whole world deficit for November stood at £2.5bn, the largest gap for six months. Analysts said yesterday's numbers suggested that the pound was starting to do real damage. "The current levels of sterling are only sustainable in the short run," said Michael Hume, UK economist with Lehman Brothers. The pound was 7.5% higher last month than a year ago against the currencies of Britain's trading partners. Business surveys had suggested that export order books were filling up despite the pound's appreciation, but the new data will give the Bank of England's monetary policy committee cause for concern. "The UK trade data imply that the UK economy isn't coping as well with the strong pound as we have been led to believe, and also that the Bank of England should be somewhat cautious in making further repo rate hikes," said Neil Parker, UK economist at the Royal Bank of Scotland. The deficit for 1999 with countries outside the EU also reached a record high at £20.4bn, a 35% increase on the previous year's £15.2bn shortfall. The ONS said a rapid rise in imports from recovering economies in south-east Asia was partly to blame. On a volume basis, which strips out price changes, imports from non-EU countries surged by 12% over the year, and exports were up just 2.5%. Weak demand in the rest of the world is no longer the problem behind Britain's widening trade gap, with Europe, south-east Asia and north America growing steadily. "Sterling's recent appreciation makes it difficult for UK producers to claim a share of this burgeoning global demand," said John O'Sullivan at Greenwich NatWest markets. "At current exchange rates, Euro-11 producers enjoy a significant price advantage over their UK counterparts, both within the EU and outside it." Despite the disappointing headline figures the ONS said the trend suggested the world trade deficit was narrowing. Over the last three months exports have risen 1%, while imports have stayed stable. The ONS also published figures from customs and excise, showing regional trade breakdown for the first time. The south-east is the largest source of exports and the largest consumer of imports, which statisticians said was unsurprising given the number of firms and population density. London and the south-east together account for 45% of imports and 34% of exports.

fields.headline: Double Jeopardy
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Whatever credibility this film has is ruined by the fact that the villain's name is... Nicholas Parsons
fields.body:
Double Jeopardy is a thriller which, to convey its full flavour, should sport the Channel 5 logo on the top left-hand corner of the screen. Ashley Judd plays Libby, a sexy, youngish soccer mom who is sent to the joint when her evil husband fakes his own disappearance at sea, framing her for murder. Once she's banged up, he gets a new name and identity, and runs off with their little boy, who was the technical beneficiary of his life assurance payout. Devilishly clever plan! Heh, heh, heh, heh! But suspecting the truth, Ashley pertly busts out of her parole hostel with murder in her heart, because the "double jeopardy" rules mean she can't be tried a second time for topping him. Oooo-er.

Her parole officer is Tommy Lee Jones, the king of masculine cragginess, who seems to have no work to do other than tracking her down. Whatever credibility this film has is ruined by the fact that the villain's name is... Nicholas Parsons. Tough police chiefs keep saying things like: "Who the hell is this Nicholas Parsons?" This turkey is directed by Bruce Beresford, who presumably has plans for a film about a sex fiend serial killer called Derek Nimmo.

fields.headline: Strong Language
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: The whole thing has got pace, and an elegant and disturbing clinch at the end. Rumley is a film-maker to watch
fields.body:
An intelligent attempt at a film about a dark, edgy London zeitgeist is Strong Language, a first feature from Simon Rumley, shot on video in 1997, and only now getting a release. It's a series of faux vox-pop confessionals straight to camera from a cast of young Londoners who riff on various themes - music, Aids, debt, clubbing, sex - sparked off by the central story told by a well-heeled young criminal barrister whose life has been ruined in one terrible night of violence.

Rumley's film has got problems. A lot of the self-admiring Cool Britannia stuff, like the earnest disquisitions on the subject of Damon from Blur, look excruciatingly naff and dated three years on: the product of Mrs Virginia Bottomley's culture and media administration. And the performances are variable to say the least. Some of them have a loose, likeable, improvisational fluency. Some are full-on Rada audition pieces. But the whole thing has got pace, and an elegant and disturbing clinch at the end. Rumley is a film-maker to watch.

fields.headline: Julian Po
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: 83 screen minutes of anaemic small-town quirkiness slide pointlessly past. Why anyone should want to make, or watch such a film beats me. It's a flatliner
fields.body:
Julian Po is a dull, faintly puzzling nullity of a movie. Christian Slater plays the curiously-named Julian Po, a 30-year-old guy who one day walks into a small American town - his car having broken down - on his way to realise a lifetime's heartfelt ambition: to see the ocean. What on earth has stopped the stupid jerk doing this before now is one of many uninteresting mysteries in this uninteresting film. The suspicious, aggressive locals demand to know Mr Po's business, and he stammers that he's here to kill himself.

Why precisely he should broadcast this untruth is another boring mystery. Anyway, the locals decide they respect his courage (why?) and he becomes a hero. Nothing in this film is sufficiently explained or motivated, and 83 screen minutes of anaemic small-town quirkiness slide pointlessly past. Why anyone should want to make, or watch such a film beats me. It's a flatliner.

fields.headline: Simpatico
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A heavy, indigestible meal, with Nolte and Bridges competing to see who can be the more sweaty, testosteroney and unshaven
fields.body:
A debut from a talented British theatre director this week: Simpatico is directed and co-written by Matthew Warchus, from the play by Sam Shepard, about two men Lyle (Jeff Bridges) and Vinny (Nick Nolte), for whom a horseracing scam they perpetrated 20 years before reaches out to destroy their lives. This picture is a heavy, indigestible meal, with Nolte and Bridges competing to see who can be the more sweaty, testosteroney and unshaven. Your heart will sink at Sharon Stone's appearance, about 40 minutes in, as a dyed blonde honey with smeared mascara, for whom only the whiskey bottle's siren song will induce her to stagger out of bed of a morning.

There aren't many thrills, neither is there much in the way of really plausible drama or emotional tension between the two principals; but Warchus puts it together with great craftsmanship and gets a sturdy, self-possessed performance from Albert Finney as a disgraced racing official who has found a serenity that utterly eludes Bridges and Nolte, the men who ruined him.

fields.headline: Fast Food
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: quickly degenerates into just another load of old pseudo-American gangster cliches
fields.body:
I sat down to Fast Food with high hopes. It promised inspiration from new Asian cinema, and boasted Douglas Henshall as the lead - always a very attractive, watchable performer even when, as here, he is let down by the script. Fast Food quickly degenerates into just another load of old pseudo-American gangster cliches: transparent, larcenous borrowings from GoodFellas and Reservoir Dogs. (Writer-director Stewart Sugg even uses a gag about Walker's cheese and onion crisps coming in a blue packet that was invented long ago by Channel 4's Adam and Joe.)

The lead characters are supposed to have grown up together in Woolwich in south-east London, yet their accents are Manc, Belfast, cockney, Glaswegian. The violence is ugly and unconvincing. And why do so many British film-makers want to do callow, show-off thrillers with guns, an idiom for which they clearly have no aptitude or knowledge whatever?

fields.headline: The Wood
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A very watchable, sweet-natured movie... and some very nice, unassuming performances
fields.body:
The Wood is a kind of upscale version of the Hood. It is the middle-class district of Inglewood, California, where three black American guys - Mike, Slim and Taye - grew up together in the 80s, with Run-DMC on their mental soundtrack. They've returned for Roland's wedding, but he's succumbed to prenuptial nerves and his two friends have to bring him back, stopping by their old haunts in the process, and this brings back teen memories.

This is a very watchable, sweet-natured movie, with a feel of DJ Jazzy Jeff and Fresh Prince enlarged for the big screen, and some very nice, unassuming performances, particularly Sean Nelson as the shy, younger Mike, and Malinda Williams as his girlfriend Alicia. They bring off a difficult and long scene showing their first sexual experience with humour and tact. The Wood shows that the coming-of-age teen comedy is not a whites-only preserve.

webTitle: Taking a rain check with Ron

fields.headline: Taking a rain check with Ron
fields.trailText: They say it never rains in southern California, but it's a dirty rotten lie. I'm looking out of my window right this minute and it's coming down like stair rods. Two hours ago, nothing. Then hard rain, solid water - the city was an aquarium in seconds. This being America, there's none of your tame old cats-and-dogs style precipitation levels either. Today it' s been hippos and elephants from the get-go.
fields.body:
They say it never rains in southern California, but it's a dirty rotten lie. I'm looking out of my window right this minute and it's coming down like stair rods. Two hours ago, nothing. Then hard rain, solid water - the city was an aquarium in seconds. This being America, there's none of your tame old cats-and-dogs style precipitation levels either. Today it' s been hippos and elephants from the get-go.

Rainy days are rare in Los Angeles and when they come along I like to grab a brolly, and trek the five blocks from my house to the famous, man-made LA river, which flanks one side of my neighbourhood. It' s a fantastically ugly, pale yellow concrete channel that has - at the section near me, at least - managed to acquire a weird, accidental kind of bucolic beauty and calm.

Thousands of birds - herons and Canada geese - gather there almost year round. This is also where the giant atomic ants in Them! were trapped and toasted back in 1954.

When a real storm hits, the river can rise 20 feet in a day. Then I like to stand in the middle of the bow-shaped wooden footbridge that crosses the river and watch the terrifying turbulence now only 15 feet below my feet, hoping to glimpse anything bizarre that' s been swept down-river - household pets, Buicks, Jimmy Hoffa, entire three-piece suites, small children. There's always something.

And when the rain clears LA is at its most beautiful. You can stand on the top of Mount Hollywood in Griffith park and see a priceless 360-degree view - from the Pacific Ocean in the west to the snow-covered peak of Mount Baldy 60 miles inland - a view that' s hidden by smog for much of the year. It' s as if Travis Bickle's apocalyptic "real rain" has finally come down and "swept all the scum off the streets".

Actually what' s really swept all the scum off the streets is the Sundance film festival. Oh, to be in Hollywood, when all of Hollywood' s in Park City, Utah. No wonder the air feels so crisp and clear and bracing. All the agents and producers are out of town. There's no one left in Los Angeles to shout at the waitresses.

I was asked to go at the very last minute, but after a few calls I gladly declined. One LA film writer I know, someone who, to quote the sheriff of Malibu in The Big Lebowski, "draws a lot of water in this town", told me that she'd reserved her accommodations in Park City a year ago, and had made two dinner reservations last October - with a $60 minimum tab per person, food only, booze extra.

Who needs that kind of gouging? The people you' ll be fighting with over Z-list tickets, vomit-flecked crash-pads, and scraps of overpriced food will be trust-funded film school grads who can't distinguish Satyajit Ray from Nicholas Ray or even Rudy Ray Moore. And they're all fighting for the attention of Hollywood's transplanted managerial class, who can't distinguish their cocaine from the snowdrift they just dropped it into.

That song about the rain may be a lie, but it definitely never snows in southern California, so I gladly stayed home and went to the movies.

There were only two minor roll-outs this weekend, the romantic comedy Down to You, and Ron Shelton's new boxing flick Play It to the Bone. One was rubbish, one wasn' t. Guess which one scored at the box office?

That would be Down to You, one of those puppy-love movies that make you feel like you' re drowning slowly as you watch it. As each rottenly written scene grimly outstayed its welcome, my hand kept reaching out for the fast- forward button on an imaginary TV remote.

It' s the story of how Al (Freddie Prinze Jr) and Imogen (Julia Stiles) meet cute, fall in love cute, fall out of love cute and fall back in cute. Writer-director Kris Isacsson defames and traduces both his job titles in fine style. His one-draft screenplay seems to have been written straight through without stopping or looking backwards.

Of the two wan leads, Prinze has a certain charm but he' s cast adrift by Isacsson, and Julia Stiles meanwhile exercises both her facial expressions (brow furrowed, brow unfurrowed) to create a yawning hole of boredom where a performance should be. It made $7.6m and reached number two, but it was a smash-and-grab job. By next weekend the word of mouth will have killed it dead.

Then there was Bone, starring Woody Harrelson and Antonio Banderas as two washed-up boxers, best friends, given a last shot at the big time - in a fight against each other. I love Shelton' s movies. Most of his male characters are buttheaded fools determined to throw away their talent, and his women are no-bullshit smokers and brawlers straight out of Howard Hawks, equally determined to save their men from themselves.

The formula varies a little each time out, but the main attraction is Shelton' s exceptionally literate and witty dialogue, which has drawn comparisons with that of Preston Sturges and is usually salted with one or two unattributed lines from Walt Whitman and Keats.

Even his longtime editor, Paul Seydor, just happens to be the best living writer on Sam Peckinpah' s movies, and Shelton himself also wrote the uncommonly sophisticated political drama Under Fire. Despite his track record - which includes Bull Durham and White Men Can' t Jump - Shelton was so sick of the studio film-making process that he made Bone independently, selling the script on a take-it-or-leave-it basis and filming in six weeks, with his stars taking salary cuts and Shelton' s fiance, the two-fisted Lolita Davidovich, as the female lead. And all this despite the massive success of his last movie Tin Cup - a studio production. His reward? Play It to the Bone only scraped to number nine, with $3.4m.

In an ideal world, it whould have been the other way round. But this is Hollywood, where the scum - like Down to You - always rises fastest, no matter how hard the rain may try to wash it away.

fields.headline: American Beauty review
fields.standfirst: It’s won Golden Globes. It’s poised for Oscar success. And despite a few flaws, Sam Mendes’s film debut is exhilaratingly intelligent
fields.trailText: It’s won Golden Globes. It’s poised for Oscar success. And despite a few flaws, Sam Mendes’s film debut is exhilaratingly intelligent
fields.body:
The reputation of American Beauty, the cinematic debut of the young British stage director Sam Mendes, has compounded at an extraordinary, exponential rate since its US release. Initially regarded as a witty, literate ensemble piece to be cautiously compared to Ang Lee's Ice Storm, it has become a gigantic screen achievement, now arriving here hailed as the first bang-up classic of the new decade, garlanded with Golden Globes and soon (bet your shirt on it) Oscars.

I felt it made a stunning impact at the London film festival in November and although it does not quite withstand the scrutiny of a second viewing, containing as it does elements of redundancy and naivety, it is certainly a film of incredible flair and formal, compositional brilliance. Mendes has assembled his actors like an extremely classy theatrical cast, and, with the help of Alan Ball's terrific screenplay, conjured from them superbly modulated complementary performances, crowned by Kevin Spacey and Annette Bening as the unhappiest middle-aged couple in all suburbia.

Spacey plays Lester Burnham, a middle-aged ad executive who hates his job and hates his life, whose wife and daughter loathe him, and for whom jerking off in the shower is the only pleasurable experience of the day. (At night, this indulgence is covertly extended to the matrimonial bed next to his sleeping wife.)

His daughter Jane (Thora Birch) is moody, mopey, grungey and secretly saving up for breast augmentation surgery, of which she has no obvious need, as Mendes later reveals in a scene in which Jane removes her top for the benefit of Ricky, the boy next door who is obsessed with filming her with his Sony DV camera. It is one of many erotic ironies in this picture, through which voyeurism is wilfully confused with rapture.

But the real head-case is Carolyn, a failing real-estate saleswoman and Lester's uptight wife. This is an outstanding study in unhappiness from Annette Bening, who gives her best performance since The Grifters. Bening's bright, chipper keeping-up-appearances smile causes her crow's feet to crinkle and clench almost audibly. It is a mask of dysfunction and despair; and there is a compelling scene in which she fails to sell a tatty family home because of its inadequately tropical "lagoon-style" pool. After the contemptuous would-be buyers have left, she bursts into hysterical, self-loathing tears, while slapping herself across the face: "Shut up! Shut up! You're weak!"

They all are. Peeping, wanking, sobbing and yearning, Mendes's characters and their weirdo neighbours drift through a bright suburban moonscape. This is the arena for their hidden lives, and secret, unacknowledged longings - erotic and otherwise - which manifest themselves outwardly in little jolts of disorientation and inattention, the suburban moment when, as Nabokov put it in Lolita, one accidentally sweeps the refrigerator and defrosts the driveway.

But all this creepy serenity is blown away when Lester uproariously flowers into a liberating mid-life crisis. He quits his job; he smokes premium-quality dope bought from Ricky and conceives an obsession with Angela (Mena Suvari), Jane's unbearably blonde and sexy best friend.

All this is managed with magnificent confidence by Mendes, who shows an awe-inspiringly precocious mastery of technique, in part due to canny reliance on his veteran cinematographer Conrad L Hall. Opinion will divide on the dream-setpieces in American Beauty which - a bit artificially - amplify the roses of Carolyn's immaculate garden into the film's central poetic motif. As visionary enactments of erotic languour, they are stagey, pedantic, and a bit soft-core, but certainly entertaining and ingenious.

American Beauty has its limits, and its flaws. As a journey into the troubled heart of American suburbia, it has nothing like the power and conviction of, say, Todd Solondz's Happiness or Alexander Payne's Election. Actually, there is a faint trace of saccharine here. When Ricky shows us an 11-minute video he has made of a plastic bag blowing in the wind, we are apparently invited to endorse his glassy-eyed assessment of it as a wonderful epiphany of natural beauty. So much beauty in the world, he says, that his heart almost collapses.

Yet Ricky is, after all, supposed to be a drug dealer, who invites Jane to run away with him to New York City, where they will live on his earnings. This film makes that sound a sweetly romantic, almost bucolic existence. (I was reminded of a line in Doug Liman's underrated Go: "Yeah, right, he's the good drug dealer...") Moreover, there is a structural problem in the fact that a scene has been cut from the end, without which neither the pre-credit sequence, nor the denouement, really make satisfactory sense.

But flaws and all, this is intelligent, exhilarating, effervescent film-making, and a remarkable debut from Sam Mendes for whom an Academy Award - along with prizes for Spacey and Bening - would now appear to be in order.
fields.bodyText: The reputation of American Beauty, the cinematic debut of the young British stage director Sam Mendes, has compounded at an extraordinary, exponential rate since its US release. Initially regarded as a witty, literate ensemble piece to be cautiously compared to Ang Lee's Ice Storm, it has become a gigantic screen achievement, now arriving here hailed as the first bang-up classic of the new decade, garlanded with Golden Globes and soon (bet your shirt on it) Oscars. I felt it made a stunning impact at the London film festival in November and although it does not quite withstand the scrutiny of a second viewing, containing as it does elements of redundancy and naivety, it is certainly a film of incredible flair and formal, compositional brilliance. Mendes has assembled his actors like an extremely classy theatrical cast, and, with the help of Alan Ball's terrific screenplay, conjured from them superbly modulated complementary performances, crowned by Kevin Spacey and Annette Bening as the unhappiest middle-aged couple in all suburbia. Spacey plays Lester Burnham, a middle-aged ad executive who hates his job and hates his life, whose wife and daughter loathe him, and for whom jerking off in the shower is the only pleasurable experience of the day. (At night, this indulgence is covertly extended to the matrimonial bed next to his sleeping wife.) His daughter Jane (Thora Birch) is moody, mopey, grungey and secretly saving up for breast augmentation surgery, of which she has no obvious need, as Mendes later reveals in a scene in which Jane removes her top for the benefit of Ricky, the boy next door who is obsessed with filming her with his Sony DV camera. It is one of many erotic ironies in this picture, through which voyeurism is wilfully confused with rapture. But the real head-case is Carolyn, a failing real-estate saleswoman and Lester's uptight wife. This is an outstanding study in unhappiness from Annette Bening, who gives her best performance since The Grifters. Bening's bright, chipper keeping-up-appearances smile causes her crow's feet to crinkle and clench almost audibly. It is a mask of dysfunction and despair; and there is a compelling scene in which she fails to sell a tatty family home because of its inadequately tropical "lagoon-style" pool. After the contemptuous would-be buyers have left, she bursts into hysterical, self-loathing tears, while slapping herself across the face: "Shut up! Shut up! You're weak!" They all are. Peeping, wanking, sobbing and yearning, Mendes's characters and their weirdo neighbours drift through a bright suburban moonscape. This is the arena for their hidden lives, and secret, unacknowledged longings - erotic and otherwise - which manifest themselves outwardly in little jolts of disorientation and inattention, the suburban moment when, as Nabokov put it in Lolita, one accidentally sweeps the refrigerator and defrosts the driveway. But all this creepy serenity is blown away when Lester uproariously flowers into a liberating mid-life crisis. He quits his job; he smokes premium-quality dope bought from Ricky and conceives an obsession with Angela (Mena Suvari), Jane's unbearably blonde and sexy best friend. All this is managed with magnificent confidence by Mendes, who shows an awe-inspiringly precocious mastery of technique, in part due to canny reliance on his veteran cinematographer Conrad L Hall. Opinion will divide on the dream-setpieces in American Beauty which - a bit artificially - amplify the roses of Carolyn's immaculate garden into the film's central poetic motif. As visionary enactments of erotic languour, they are stagey, pedantic, and a bit soft-core, but certainly entertaining and ingenious. American Beauty has its limits, and its flaws. As a journey into the troubled heart of American suburbia, it has nothing like the power and conviction of, say, Todd Solondz's Happiness or Alexander Payne's Election. Actually, there is a faint trace of saccharine here. When Ricky shows us an 11-minute video he has made of a plastic bag blowing in the wind, we are apparently invited to endorse his glassy-eyed assessment of it as a wonderful epiphany of natural beauty. So much beauty in the world, he says, that his heart almost collapses. Yet Ricky is, after all, supposed to be a drug dealer, who invites Jane to run away with him to New York City, where they will live on his earnings. This film makes that sound a sweetly romantic, almost bucolic existence. (I was reminded of a line in Doug Liman's underrated Go: "Yeah, right, he's the good drug dealer...") Moreover, there is a structural problem in the fact that a scene has been cut from the end, without which neither the pre-credit sequence, nor the denouement, really make satisfactory sense. But flaws and all, this is intelligent, exhilarating, effervescent film-making, and a remarkable debut from Sam Mendes for whom an Academy Award - along with prizes for Spacey and Bening - would now appear to be in order.

fields.headline: White Teeth by Zadie Smith
fields.standfirst: White Teeth by Zadie Smith (Hamish Hamilton, £12.99) digested in the style of the original in 400 words
fields.trailText: Archie Jones is boring. If life is a beach, Archie is a pebble. If it's an ocean or a haystack, he's a raindrop or a needle respectively. But Life says "Yes" to Archie.
fields.body:
Archie Jones is boring. If life is a beach, Archie is a pebble. If it's an ocean or a haystack, he's a raindrop or a needle respectively. But Life says "Yes" to Archie.

"We're not licenced for suicides around here. This place is halal. Kosher, understand?" says Archie's rescuer. Because the grubby north London borough where Archie lives is multicultural. It's a melting pot. It's eclectic. It's besieged with identity crises.

Even boring Archie indulges in a bit of ethnic diversity. Back from the brink, he marries the beautiful and exotic Clara from Lambeth (via Jamaica). He didn't love his first wife, but he loves Clara, who is tall, black and has a bosom that defies gravity. Clara is 30 years Archie's junior and marries him by accident after escaping a Jehovah Witness family and a pile of misplaced copies of the Watchtower .

Archie and Clara spawn Irie who is a nerd and therefore technically marginalised too. The object of Irie's undying love is the dashing Millat Iqbal, who, as an Islamic militant, has also staked out his post-colonial ground. As it turns out, Millat (and twin Magid)'s dad, Samad, is Archie's best mate.

Two families from different sides of the colonial fence whose lives intertwine on a daily basis. Very late 20th century. Very ordinary. Because multiculturalism is ordinary. And in north London boroughs such as this one, shit happens and people get on with their lives.

But Archie and Samad's - a Bengali Muslim and one-armed waiter - friendship goes deeper. They're wartime buddies who, naturally, have a shared secret. They were herded into the same tank and left to bond until peace was declared. And everyone knows wartime friendships are sacred. So when Samad moves to England on the back of the 1970s immigration wave, the two soon re-establish their immutable bond. And anyway, the Bangladeshi Iqbals "aren't those sorts of Indians", Archie reassures Clara.

So the Joneses and the Iqbals live happily in multicultural bliss until the second generation realise that ethnic ecleticism presents some serious issues. "Who are we? Where are we from?" they wonder. Then along come the Chalfens with their good genes and progressive ideas about DNA. The Chalfens are radical, progressive and liberal. They're Chalfenists with Chalfenesque ideas and a cloned mouse called FutureMouse. More shit for the kids to deal with.

Magid is sent off to Bangladesh to become a good Muslim and returns as an atheist, anglophile intellectual, such is the topsy-turvy nature of this strange boundary-less world. He thinks the FutureMouse is cool. Millat confuses the glamour of American gangsters with the darker edge of fundamentalism. Extremism looms. Racism is rife. Then there's gender - Irie is fat and obsessive.

Race. Land. Ownership. Faith. Theft. Blood. Identity. Destiny. New Year's Eve 1992 and the FutureMouse is unveiled. Family and belonging. It's all so confusing. But then it's a wicked lie that "the past is always tense and the future, perfect", ponders Archie.

 And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested The Joneses and the Iqbals are different yet similar. Post-colonial Britain is confusing. Identity, race, gender and genetics are serious issues. But that doesn't make ordinary people serious - they just get on with their lives.

fields.headline: Jilted lovers
fields.standfirst: ... to save you burden of reading them
fields.trailText:
Love is a Four Letter Word, by Claire Calman (Black Swan, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL
fields.body:
Love is a Four Letter Word, by Claire Calman (Black Swan, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Love is indeed a four-letter word, but it is probably not one that Bella wants to hear ever again after being cruelly dumped. Our jilted heroine is so appalled by her experiences that she changes her job, her town, her entire life. But she does not change her mind - love leads only to tears. Her only solace is eating copious amounts of biscuits. Suggested revenge: Keep Hobnobs within arm's reach. Learn to laugh raucously in the face of disaster.

Waiting in the Wings, by Donna Hay (Orion, £16.99)
Buy it at BOL

Dumped for her best friend, actress Annie Mitchell is left with "the self-esteem of the last sandwich in a railway station buffet". In true tabloid fashion, the repentant ex returns, but not before an old flame (yes, he is tall, dark and handsome) has recaptured Annie's heart. So stop sobbing into your pillows, deserted lovers! Suggested revenge: Believe that your Mr Darcy is waiting in the wings. It will make you feel a damn sight better.

Bitter Sweet Symphony, by Shyama Perera (Sceptre, £10)
Buy it at BOL

Forsaken lovers need to learn how to tell the difference between men and women. Women are like "engineers" who "test and service the nuts and bolts" of a relationship. Men, on the other hand, "chuck them on the floor". Just ask Nina - her husband, Buster, deserted her. Women must unite and "pick ourselves off the floor and party". Suggested revenge: Teach yourself "woman power" - drink vodka and forget about men.

Bing Banged My Lula, by Frankie Park (Orion, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Four bitterly disillusioned single mums go on the lookout for "potential shags", but end up forming a band, falling in and out of love in typically disastrous fashion and indulging in some "lesbian-relationship thing" along the way. Men, it seems, are just love-rats - you are right to remain cynical about marriage. Suggested revenge: Pretend that you are "strong and feisty", even if you are really "a weak, love-needy, dope-on-a-rope".

Amanda's Wedding, by Jenny Colgan (Harper Collins, £5.99)
Buy it at BOL

Avoid rebound relationships - they invariably involve "smelly, over-sized accountants with juvenile tendencies". Far better to slander your "selfish ex-boyfriend" and sabotage all intended marriages in your vicinity. This is what the jilted Mel tries to do when she finds out that the social climber Amanda "has got a Scottish aristocrat by the nuptials". Suggested revenge: Rejoice in the company of mad friends and steer clear of accountants.

webTitle: Elian relatives ask congress to act

fields.headline: Elian relatives ask congress to act
fields.standfirst: More about the Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: The warring sides in the political tug-of-war over six-year-old Elian Gonzalez took their respective claims to meetings with members of the congress yesterday, while the US government released details of interviews with the boy's father in support of their recommendation to return him to Cuba.
fields.body:
The warring sides in the political tug-of-war over six-year-old Elian Gonzalez took their respective claims to meetings with members of the congress yesterday, while the US government released details of interviews with the boy's father in support of their recommendation to return him to Cuba.

The day after they met Elian in a private reunion in Miami, the boy's two grandmothers returned to Washington to meet members of congress, where they said they had encountered a changed and emotionally drained child who should be returned to his father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez.

Elian was found clinging to an inflated tyre off the US coast on November 25. His mother drowned when their boat capsized in heavy seas. He is now at the centre of an increasingly bitter custody battle.

In court papers released yesterday, the US justice department urged a Florida judge to dismiss efforts by Elian's Cuban exile relatives to keep him in the US, as this would "ignore accepted international practice in cases involving a sole surviving parent in the US, where we would expect the foreign country to immediately return the child to the surviving American parent".

The justice department also released details yesterday of interviews which US immigration officials conducted with Mr Gonzalez in Cuba on December 13, in which he says Elian is "his life".

"He is my first son. Wherever I went, he went with me, I taught him how to swim, to kayak, he has a parrot here, dogs, a bicycle and all kinds of toys. As a matter of fact I haven't been to the barber because he isn't here, since we always go together."

Meanwhile, the nun who hosted Wednesday's meeting between Elian and his grandmothers said she favoured letting the boy remain in the US. Sister Jeanne O'Laughlin told the Associated Press that before the interview her view was that she would "go with the law that the child should be with the father, but what I saw and felt really frightened me for the child".

In Cuba yesterday the Communist daily newspaper Granma complained that the grandmothers were not allowed to take a mobile phone into the meeting with their grandson, on which the boy was expected to hold his first direct conversation with his father since leaving Cuba.

On Capitol Hill, the Republican leader Senator Trent Lott said yesterday he had "no solid plans" for pursuing legislation to give the boy US citizenship.

However, in an interview broadcast on a Miami-based radio station, Elian reportedly tells an interviewer: "Tomorrow they're going to make me an American citizen."

webTitle: Elian's father claims he was bribed to move to US

fields.headline: Elian's father claims he was bribed to move to US
fields.standfirst:
Miami relatives deny offering Cuban millions to keep his son in Florida

More about the Gonzalez case
fields.trailText: Elian Gonzalez's father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, told US immigration officials that his Miami relatives offered him millions of dollars, a house and a car to join the six-year-old boy in the US, according to court papers filed yesterday.
fields.byline: Martin Kettle  in Washington and AP
fields.body:
Elian Gonzalez's father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, told US immigration officials that his Miami relatives offered him millions of dollars, a house and a car to join the six-year-old boy in the US, according to court papers filed yesterday.

Elian was found clinging to an inflated tyre off the US coast on November 25. His mother drowned when their boat capsized, and he is now at the centre of a bitter custody battle.

"I could go there with all my family and would be taken care of and could have a job if I wanted to work. But with the money offered, I would not need to do so," Mr Gonzalez said. "That's when I hung up the telephone."

But Elian's cousin, Marisleysis Gonzalez, denied the bribery accusations. "Never did we offer him money," she said. "We would never buy our family. We would never buy anybody because we are the type of family that believes money can't buy people."

The US government filed the papers in response to a lawsuit filed by the boy's Miami relatives, who are challenging an order that Elian be sent back to live with his father in Cuba. The warring sides in the political tug-of-war took their respective claims to meetings with members of congress yesterday.

The day after they met Elian in a private reunion in Miami, the boy's two grandmothers told members of congress in Washington they had encountered a changed and emotionally drained child who should be returned to his father.

Meanwhile, the US justice department urged a Florida judge to dismiss efforts by Elian's Cuban exile relatives to keep him in the US, as this would "ignore accepted international practice in cases involving a sole surviving parent in the US, where we would expect the foreign country to immediately return the child to the surviving American parent".

The justice department also released details of interviews which immigration officials conducted with Mr Gonzalez in Cuba on December 13, in which he called Elian "his life".

"He is my first son. Wherever I went, he went with me. I taught him how to swim, do kayak, he has a parrot here, dogs, a bicycle and all kinds of toys. As a matter of fact, I haven't been to the barber because he isn't here, since we always go together."

In separate comments made yesterday, Mr Gonzalez blamed Cuban exiles for the difficulties during the meeting between Elian and his grandmothers.

"I felt very indignant," he said. "They just ruined everything." Mr Gonzalez claimed that the grandmothers' cellular phones were confiscated, making it impossible for him to speak to Elian without the presence of their Miami relatives for the first time since the boy's rescue.

But the nun who hosted the reunion said she favoured letting the boy remain in the US. Sister Jeanne O'Laughlin said that before the interview, her view was that she would "go with the law that the child should be with the father. But what I saw and felt really frightened me for the child."

On Capitol Hill, the Republican leader, senator Trent Lott, said yesterday he had "no solid plans" for pursuing legislation to give the boy US citizenship.

However, in an interview broadcast on a Miami-based radio station, Elian said: "Tomorrow they're going to make me an American citizen."

Ricardo Alarcon, president of Cuba's national assembly and Fidel Castro's top man for Cuba-US relations, accompanied Elian. He complained that anti-communist protests held near the home of Sister O'Laughlin, the president of Barry university, created "infernal conditions" for the meeting.

Mr Alarcon claimed that agreements made for the meeting had been violated, including that there would be no contact between the grandmothers and the Miami relatives during the encounter.

webTitle: Read heeds the sound of reveille

fields.headline: Read heeds the sound of reveille
fields.standfirst: Notts keeper pulls on the England gloves after being left out in the cold
fields.trailText: England's wicketkeeper Chris Read did more than almost anyone to pull off a remarkable win against South Africa here on Wednesday night and, although they finished just short, his assault on Shaun Pollock's bowling in the penultimate over of the match also revived hope within in him when faith was beginning to falter.
fields.body:
England's wicketkeeper Chris Read did more than almost anyone to pull off a remarkable win against South Africa here on Wednesday night and, although they finished just short, his assault on Shaun Pollock's bowling in the penultimate over of the match also revived hope within in him when faith was beginning to falter.

Only England, it is said, provide true artists behind the stumps, and Read is the latest from the academy. Even the likes of Alan Knott and Bruce French watched his brushstrokes with approval.

But when the Nottinghamshire wicketkeeper-batsman played in the first three Tests against New Zealand last summer he was a disappointment on both sides of the stumps. He scored only 38 runs and his keeping was flawed.

Surprisingly promised a tour place by the chairman of selectors David Graveney, he had to kick his heels while Alec Stewart played in all five Tests against South Africa. But when, even more surprisingly, Stewart was told to go home before the one-day series, Read did not exactly snatch his chance.

His form, in the limited amount of cricket he has played in South Africa, has been average, and the management has sometimes been disappointed by a laid-back attitude. Wicketkeepers are expected to hare around like dervishes. Read, 21, whose unbeaten 26 from 23 balls included a pulled six off Pollock and whose innings took England to within two runs of victory when 25 had been needed from the final two overs, is now sure of his place today, after seeing Mark Alleyne take over the gloves in the warm-up games in Potchefstroom last week.

Tour officials said they wanted to look at all their options. But the move was interpreted as a wake-up call for Read. He said last night: "Having spent three months on the sidelines I was disappointed. I wanted to play. But I made sure I was ready for the first international on Sunday. The real problem is that I have been desperately short of match practice."

He feels there is still work to be done on his keeping, particularly with spin bowling. Keeping at seamer-friendly Trent Bridge hardly helps.

His batting with Mark Ealham on Wednesday, when 17 runs came from that Pollock over, reminded everyone that here was a player good enough to bat at No4 for his county. "I really got hold of that six. webTitle: Pound too strong for monetary union, says CBI

fields.headline: Pound too strong for monetary union, says CBI
fields.trailText: Sterling would need to fall substantially from its 11-year-high on the foreign exchanges for hard-pressed manufacturers to cope with life inside monetary union, the Confederation of British Industry said yesterday.
fields.body:
Sterling would need to fall substantially from its 11-year-high on the foreign exchanges for hard-pressed manufacturers to cope with life inside monetary union, the Confederation of British Industry said yesterday.

Despite supporting membership of monetary union in principle, the employers' organisation warned that it would be a mistake to lock the UK into the euro zone at the pound's current rate.

"This is not the appropriate level to join the euro," said Nick Reilly, managing director of Vauxhall and head of the CBI's economic affairs committee. He added that the CBI's support for the euro depended on the economic conditions being met. "One of the conditions is that we have a competitive and appropriate exchange rate. Today's rate is not the right rate."

Sterling is more than 50 pfennigs higher than the level of DM2.65 to DM2.70 deemed acceptable by CBI members last summer, and Mr Reilly said the "abnormally high" level of the pound was acting as a brake on recovery.

Commenting on the CBI's quarterly industrial trends survey, Mr Reilly added: "Exports are stabilising but this is being driven by a rise in world demand. The strength of sterling is still holding back firms as they battle to compete."

The report showed demand in manufacturing rising for the first time in two years, with a pick-up in business optimism, healthier order books and rising output. But industry is still facing stiff competitive pressures, with jobs continuing to be shed in response to the squeeze on profit margins from falling prices.

The CBI said that concern among firms that investment would fail to yield decent profits had reached record levels and was the main factor behind the weakness of spending on plant and machinery. "Companies are having to run much harder to stand still," said Mr Reilly, urging the Bank of England to hold off from further interest rate increases. "Many firms are hanging on by their fingertips and the two-speed economy remains very much in evidence."

webTitle: Warburg predicts £150bn online sales in two years

fields.headline: Warburg predicts £150bn online sales in two years
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
www.wdr.com
www.abnamro.com
fields.trailText: Online spending is forecast to explode to £150bn by 2002 across Europe threatening those conventional retailers who are already facing poor trading conditions and heavy price competition.
fields.body:
Online spending is forecast to explode to £150bn by 2002 across Europe threatening those conventional retailers who are already facing poor trading conditions and heavy price competition.

A report yesterday by Warburg Dillon Read, the stockbroker, forecast a threefold rise in European e-commerce by consumers and business by 2002 with a market possibly worth "no less than a quarter of a trillion dollars".

Dutch bank ABN Amro said in a separate report that where the price pressures from online retailers "spills over into traditional retail channels the implications will be potentially serious".

The report by Warburg suggest that European retailers have been slow to enter the internet race and are unlikely to gain a competitive edge in the long term over US operators.

"European retailer valuations have barely been affected by the internet, but we believe it is only a matter of time before online shopping has a significant impact," it says.

The report's authors did not expect that "e-tailers will condemn traditional retailers to extinction".

They claim that internet penetration equivalent to only 10% of Europe's population is where the US was three years ago.

However, this still should be sufficient use of online trade to trigger greater investor interest, particularly from corporates.

ABN Amro said that while traditional retailers could be hurt by e-tailers cutting prices, price would not be the whole story for consumers beginning to shop online.

It argues that privacy and security considerations remained a deterrent from buying online as well as the lack of value added service.

"The impact on retailers, however, is likely to be negative in product categories which are wholly dependent on the manufacturer-brand and entirely product driven, electricals for example," the ABN Amro report said.

"The retailer struggles to add much value and the retail brand is not a differentiator. We would argue that retailers who ignore the advent of online retail will not prosper.'"

ABN Amro lists products which are most adaptable to online sale as being low fashion clothing, books, CDs, videos, toys, cheap jewellery, white goods, toiletries and computer parts and software.

fields.headline: Report on banks 'upbeat'
fields.standfirst: Cruickshank review expected to clash with government hopes of hard-hitting attack
fields.trailText: Don Cruickshank has told bankers that his much-anticipated report into banking competition will show the chancellor, Gordon Brown, that they are innovative and competitive rather than stifling the "enterprise" economy.
fields.body:
Don Cruickshank has told bankers that his much-anticipated report into banking competition will show the chancellor, Gordon Brown, that they are innovative and competitive rather than stifling the "enterprise" economy.

Mr Cruickshank, a former telecoms regulator, has told bank bosses that he is braced for conflict with government ministers who had hoped for the opportunity to make an attack on "rip off" banks.

While the Cruickshank report, which will be published in March, is expected to make recommendations to make it easier for customers to move their bank accounts, its tone will not be aggressive or overly critical of the sector in general.

His apparently conciliatory approach to the banks - after attacking them for being uncooperative six months ago - is still causing some concern that he might be massaging expectations to increase the impact of the report.

Senior bankers remain concerned about the timing of the report, which is due to be published just days after big banks report their results for 1999 and which are expected to show record profits. They are also unclear whether Mr Cruickshank will reach any conclusions about whether banks "cross-subsidise" products - such as current accounts and credit cards - and whether the practice is uncompetitive and should be ruled out. That could have an impact on the pricing of such products.

He might also raise the issue of whether banks provide enough information to customers when they offer new products which are more attractive than the ones they already have at the bank. The review was set up by Mr Brown in November 1998 to scrutinise the level of innovation, competition, and efficiency in the banking industry to establish if it met the needs of business and other consumers. In its broadest interpretation, it could be regarded as trying to establish if banks - in their role of lending money to business - aid or hinder the smooth functioning of the economy and facilitate the government's aim to create an enterprise economy.

When he published an interim report last summer he refused to say whether he had uncovered any uncompetitive behaviour because he had not been able to test any of his hypotheses because of the refusal of some of the big banks to provide him with the necessary statistics.

Some of the larger banks have since established new departments to deal with Mr Cruickshank's demands for information about the profits they make from customers and and individual products.

Mr Cruickshank, who refused to comment last night, is likely to warn the government that it faces issues over social exclusion through its aim for banks to offer basic bank accounts which do not require credit scoring. This makes it impossible for the banks to chase customers to collect debts from those who accidentally overdraw and might have implications for the government's plans to have all social security payments made directly into bank accounts rather than in cash.

As part of his analysis, Mr Cruickshank compared the British banks with their international counterparts and apparently concluded that they stood up to the comparison on competitive grounds.

webTitle: Takeover panel to rule on Pru's vote in NatWest bid battle

fields.headline: Takeover panel to rule on Pru's vote in NatWest bid battle
fields.trailText: The takeover panel is expected this morning to rule over whether the Prudential can vote in the NatWest bid battle.
fields.body:
The takeover panel is expected this morning to rule over whether the Prudential can vote in the NatWest bid battle.

Speculation was mounting last night that Prudential could be banned from casting its crucial shares in the NatWest takeover saga because of a deal the insurance company had struck with Bank of Scotland, which itself yesterday rejigged its bid for the clearing bank.

The controversy over the Pru stake came as Royal Bank of Scotland seached for new supporters to help it raise its bid for NatWest and beat the latest price offered by BoS.

The Pru, which holds the largest single stake in NatWest of 5%, was last night the subject of delicate negotation at the takeover panel, which polices bid battles, and a statement about the position of the Pru fund managers, who fiercely defend their independence, is expected this morning from the panel.

The Pru has been a topic of hot debate since its management stuck a deal last week to buy NatWest Life and sell its insurance products at NatWest branches if BoS's bid is successful. At the time it insisted the arrangement would not affect any decision by its fund management arm.

Four days before Monday's deadline for final offers for NatWest, BoS yesterday altered the terms of its bid, eradicating a confusing "special dividend" which allowed it to claim its bid was worth £25bn, or £14.87 a share.

While the new structure of the deal - which now involves a complex guaranteed stock unit - allowed BoS to claim its offer was worth more, Nick Lord, banking analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, said: "This was an attempt to clarify the situation. It hasn't really added to the value of the offer".

The new structure of the deal raised speculation that Peter Burt, BoS's chief executive, would up his offer on Monday - his last chance - possibly to as much as £26bn.

He was careful yesterday not to rule out the possibility. "I'm satisfied that we have the resources to pay as much as we think NatWest is worth, " he said. The two banks are expected to play a tactical game in the hours before Monday's deadline.

fields.headline: £200,000 for reference refusal
fields.standfirst: Payout to woman 'crucified' by ex-employer
fields.trailText: A woman whose former employer refused her a reference was yesterday awarded nearly £200,000 in compensation.
fields.body:
A woman whose former employer refused her a reference was yesterday awarded nearly £200,000 in compensation.

Belinda Coote, 38, left her job as manager of an east London bowling centre run by Granada Hospitality Ltd in 1993 after receiving a settlement of £11,000 following a sexual discrimination complaint against the company.

Mrs Coote subsequently found that her attempts to get work were being "crucified" by Granada, which refused to supply employment agencies with relevant information regarding her record at the firm.

An initial proceeding for victimisation was thrown out when a tribunal ruled that victimisation arising after a term of employment had ended was not covered by employment law. However, the European court of justice set a precedent by overturning the judgment, ruling that the sexual discrimination act was incompatible with European law, and that Mrs Coote had won her case.

Mrs Coote, who has one son and is working again, was delighted at the compensation, the bulk of which covers loss of of earnings.

"I knew I was being victimised so I decided to seek justice because my career was being crucified," she said.

"It's been a long struggle. At the time I had little choice but to go to tribunal because I couldn't get work. In total I was out of work for two years, and in lesser-paid jobs for much of the rest of the time.

"I carried on with the action because I knew I was right. The fact that the law provided no protection for people also spurred me on."

The equal opportunities commission, which backed the case, said the award was a landmark settlement for others denied references. The compensation, negotiated by solicitors acting for Mrs Coote and Granada, takes into account tax and should give Mrs Coote a net £110,000. The first £20,000 compensates for damage to her feelings, and the remainder is for loss of earnings over six years.

She had been earning "in excess" of £20,000 at Granada, and claimed to have been forced to take less responsible and less well-paid jobs as a result of victimisation.

Pauline Matthews, the equality commission's solicitor who took the case, said: "This is a highly significant legal victory: discrimination arising after the end of employment is actionable and is now covered by the sex discrimination act."

Julie Mellor, the chairwoman of the commission, said: "It takes courage to fight cases like this over a long period of time and I warmly congratulate Belinda for her persistence. It also sends a clear message to employers, yet again, that equality pays and discrimination costs."

In a statement, Granada Hospitality accepted mistakes had been made, and said it fully accepted the findings of the tribunal and apologised to Mrs Coote for the "breakdown in procedures that led to this unfortunate situation".

It went on: "Granada seeks to be one of the UK's responsible employers, and had led the way in implementing employment measures beyond the letter of the law particularly in equal opportunities. We have taken steps to ensure that mistakes made in this case never happen again."

The GMB union, which also backed Mrs Coote's claim, commented that references were still vital in applying for jobs. "Most companies ask for two or three. A good reference can be all-important," said a spokesman. "Many potential employers want the word of another manager who has experience of the candidate, and see it [the reference] as a failsafe.

"If they don't get a reference or a previous employer refuses to supply one, it is assumed to be a sign that there has been a problem with the person."
