webTitle: Euro loses battle to stay above dollar

fields.headline: Euro loses battle to stay above dollar
fields.standfirst: Single currency falls victim to US economy's strength and Wall Street pundit offers no prospect of respite
fields.trailText: Europe's beleaguered single currency was worth less than a dollar on the world's foreign exchanges last night after a wave of selling by financial dealers sent it plunging against the surging greenback.
fields.body:
Europe's beleaguered single currency was worth less than a dollar on the world's foreign exchanges last night after a wave of selling by financial dealers sent it plunging against the surging greenback.

The euro closed below parity against the US currency for the first time since its launch just over a year ago as it finally lost its long battle to remain above the $1 level.

Despite desperate attempts to talk up the value of the currency in Europe, there was no respite for the euro as speculators switched into dollars. Dealers said there was no underlying economic reason for the single currency's drop, which they suggested was the result of money pouring into New York on the back of strong US economic figures.

However, the descent to fresh lows on the foreign exchanges was a blow to the European Central Bank, which has seen the value of the euro fall by a sixth since January 1 last year.

Billed as a strong currency to rival the dollar, the euro has flirted with parity repeatedly in recent months but previously always managed to bounce back.

After closing on Wednesday night in London at $1.0014, the euro fell by more than a cent in European trading to close at $0.9884 in the City. Dealers said that the single currency had broken through significant support levels and this had aggravated its downward spiral.

Some predicted that it could fall to $0.9550 over the next few days, particularly if today's US growth figures show that the American economy is continuing to boom.

Traders had expected the euro to find support in the markets at $0.9980 and $0.9950 but it rapidly broke through both as it became clear that there was nothing to halt its fall.

Comments by leading European Union politicians and central bankers aimed at reassuring the currency markets were shrugged off in the frenzy of selling.

Jesper Dannesboe at ABN Amro said that, while the euro was looking heavily oversold, its rapid fall had triggered some panic.

Sterling rose in tandem with the dollar, closing at an all-time high against the euro and rising to the equivalent of 3.24 German marks.

The euro's collapse reverberated in other currency sectors, even those outside the single currency zone, such as the Swiss franc.

Tamita Bayliss at Commerzbank, said there was no real news to explain the volatility of the currency markets. Europe's economy was looking stronger, with growth picking up, but this was being ignored by the markets.

Some dealers believe that the euro might recover over the coming months, expecting action by the US Federal Reserve to cool the American economy.

They believe that slower growth in the US and further signs of expansion in Europe will eventually prompt a re-evaluation of the strength of the two currencies.

However, reports suggested that some speculators who had their fingers badly burned by yesterday's events would be in no hurry to hold euros again. Investors who had bought the single currency at just below dollar parity in anticipation of being able to make a quick killing were forced to bail out when it hit $0.9925.

Dealers said those nursing losses were unlikely to show an interest in the euro unless they could pick it up much more cheaply.

In early trading in New York, the euro was still at below $0.99 against the dollar, despite some tentative attempts at a rally. Dealers said the prospects of any rapid recovery looked slim.
fields.bodyText: Europe's beleaguered single currency was worth less than a dollar on the world's foreign exchanges last night after a wave of selling by financial dealers sent it plunging against the surging greenback. The euro closed below parity against the US currency for the first time since its launch just over a year ago as it finally lost its long battle to remain above the $1 level. Despite desperate attempts to talk up the value of the currency in Europe, there was no respite for the euro as speculators switched into dollars. Dealers said there was no underlying economic reason for the single currency's drop, which they suggested was the result of money pouring into New York on the back of strong US economic figures. However, the descent to fresh lows on the foreign exchanges was a blow to the European Central Bank, which has seen the value of the euro fall by a sixth since January 1 last year. Billed as a strong currency to rival the dollar, the euro has flirted with parity repeatedly in recent months but previously always managed to bounce back. After closing on Wednesday night in London at $1.0014, the euro fell by more than a cent in European trading to close at $0.9884 in the City. Dealers said that the single currency had broken through significant support levels and this had aggravated its downward spiral. Some predicted that it could fall to $0.9550 over the next few days, particularly if today's US growth figures show that the American economy is continuing to boom. Traders had expected the euro to find support in the markets at $0.9980 and $0.9950 but it rapidly broke through both as it became clear that there was nothing to halt its fall. Comments by leading European Union politicians and central bankers aimed at reassuring the currency markets were shrugged off in the frenzy of selling. Jesper Dannesboe at ABN Amro said that, while the euro was looking heavily oversold, its rapid fall had triggered some panic. Sterling rose in tandem with the dollar, closing at an all-time high against the euro and rising to the equivalent of 3.24 German marks. The euro's collapse reverberated in other currency sectors, even those outside the single currency zone, such as the Swiss franc. Tamita Bayliss at Commerzbank, said there was no real news to explain the volatility of the currency markets. Europe's economy was looking stronger, with growth picking up, but this was being ignored by the markets. Some dealers believe that the euro might recover over the coming months, expecting action by the US Federal Reserve to cool the American economy. They believe that slower growth in the US and further signs of expansion in Europe will eventually prompt a re-evaluation of the strength of the two currencies. However, reports suggested that some speculators who had their fingers badly burned by yesterday's events would be in no hurry to hold euros again. Investors who had bought the single currency at just below dollar parity in anticipation of being able to make a quick killing were forced to bail out when it hit $0.9925. Dealers said those nursing losses were unlikely to show an interest in the euro unless they could pick it up much more cheaply. In early trading in New York, the euro was still at below $0.99 against the dollar, despite some tentative attempts at a rally. Dealers said the prospects of any rapid recovery looked slim.

fields.headline: Perky Sid's soap slip-up
fields.standfirst:
The Archers
The Archers Addicts
fields.trailText: After days of (mildly) fevered speculation, the nation finally got the chance to be appalled by Radio 4's The Archers last night, with the broadcast of the "sex in the shower" episode featuring Sid Perks, landlord of the Bull, and Jolene Rogers, the Borsetshire bombshell.
fields.body:
After days of (mildly) fevered speculation, the nation finally got the chance to be appalled by Radio 4's The Archers last night, with the broadcast of the "sex in the shower" episode featuring Sid Perks, landlord of the Bull, and Jolene Rogers, the Borsetshire bombshell.

The interlude, which prompted the Conservative MP Julian Brazier to denounce the BBC for "clambering on the bandwagon of the cheapest kind of populism", was much taken up with the quest for the hot tap and the coal tar soap in Jolene's love-nest.

As so often in England, plumbing will out. Even if more than steam was rising in The Archers, the coitus remained interruptus.

"A girl," Ms Rogers observed to the priapic Perks, "might start to wonder where your priorities lie." Listeners might have shared her concern. Not since Arnold Schwarzenegger started pumping iron has keeping fit so transformed a body, a show, and, for Sid, a soul. Just weeks ago he was the husband of (currently) faithful Kathy and father to one of Ambridge's puking, mewling infants. Then he followed the trend into middle-aged keep fit classes.

But seasoned listeners know that Sid, of all people, knows the runes in Ambridge.

Only minutes before Jolene slipped out of her kimono and wielded the loofah on Sid's rippling muscular back, top Ambridge moralist Mike Tucker had been wading through a double-edged discourse on childminding.

Tucker had begun the job of setting listeners straight. "One big sloppy kiss," he declared, "and you forgive them everything." But the "them" for Tucker were the progeny of the village's inexplicable baby boom, decent and pure.

There will be no way out for Sid and Jolene, particularly since Jolene was being recklessly free with the scented shower gel. In Ambridge no femme fatale can sleep easy. The Straw Dogs there don't take kindly to other people's operas. They have ways.

webTitle: Edelson engineers Oxygen listing for daughter

fields.headline: Edelson engineers Oxygen listing for daughter
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Edelson, the stock market sorcerer behind Knutsford's "awesome foursome" has assembled a new foursome of twenty-something apprentices.
fields.body:
Michael Edelson, the stock market sorcerer behind Knutsford's "awesome foursome" has assembled a new foursome of twenty-something apprentices.

Mr Edelson, the Manchester United director whose cash shell Knutsford became one of the stock market sensations of last year after Archie Norman, Nigel Wray, Julian Richer and Nick Leslau said they would use it to mount a bid for a major retailer, is engineering the Aim-listing of his daughter Emma's internet incubator fund.

Dealers believe that when Oxygen shares begin trading next Friday they could mimic the performance of Knutsford shares, which rose from 2p to 232p on their first day valuing the company at £600m.

Oxygen plans to raise £2.2m from the placement of 110m new shares on Aim at 2p each. Ms Edelson, 25, has been running Oxygen for six months. She and her three friends plan to search out internet-related business ideas generated by young entrepreneurs on university campuses.

"Many of the best internet companies like Yahoo and Excite were spawned on university campuses," Mr Edelson said. "We never intended to float Oxygen when we set it up but the sheer volume of business proposals we are being sent has forced us to seek external funds."

The first move will be to sponsor a regular networking event at Cambridge University where two of the four studied.

Oxygen's investment portfolio includes a 1% stake in Toyzone, which is expected to float later this year for up to £250m, and four other start-ups. Its directors are the two Edelsons, PR executive Matthew Freud and Keith Harris, the former chief executive of HSBC Investment Bank.

Mr Edelson said the directors' skills, experience and contacts will be available to all the companies Ms Edelson and her colleagues invest in.

"The kids will bring in the best looking concepts the students are offering and the grown-ups will help them build their business models," he said. "We believe young entrepreneurs would much rather deal with people of Emma's age than boring suits. However, the experience of those suits will be available to them."

Ms Edelson previously spent two years working for IMG, the sports marketing business run by Mark McCormack. The rest of the foursome - Robert Jenkin, 22, Paul Harris, 25, and Kirsty Pinnell, 25 - have a variety of technology, merchant banking and legal experience.

Oxygen is likely to make investments of around £250,000 and is examining more than 30 opportunities. Individuals expected to back the placing include the original Knutsford four, Manchester United chief executive Martin Edwards and former footballers Alan Hansen and Steve Bruce.

Mr Edelson has been dubbed "Shellmeister" by the City after developing a specialism for listing cash shells on Aim that allow larger private companies easy access to a stock market listing. Knutsford, Prestbury, Media Content, Magic Moments Internet and Hartford, owner of Damien Hirst's Pharmacy restaurant, have all gained stock market listings through Edelson-sponsored shells.

fields.headline: Venus with a violin
fields.standfirst:
Viktoria Mullova/ Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
*****
fields.trailText: Secret Passions is the title of the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment's new series of concerts, which runs from now until the end of May on London's South Bank. The subtitle - Alter Egos and Personal Obsessions - is even more eye-catchingly dramatic, though quite what this ballyhoo signifies is something of a mystery. The emphasis is seemingly on an impressive line-up of soloists performing works which hitherto haven't formed a notable part of their repertoires.
fields.body:
Secret Passions is the title of the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment's new series of concerts, which runs from now until the end of May on London's South Bank. The subtitle - Alter Egos and Personal Obsessions - is even more eye-catchingly dramatic, though quite what this ballyhoo signifies is something of a mystery. The emphasis is seemingly on an impressive line-up of soloists performing works which hitherto haven't formed a notable part of their repertoires.

The opening concert featured the Russian-born violinist Viktoria Mullova playing and directing two Mozart concertos. We used not to associate Mullova with Mozart. After this, one suspects, her name will be firmly linked to his.

An uncompromising artist, bent on chiselling out the dramatic content of a work rather than indulging in glitzy virtuosity, Mullova is as alluring to watch as she is to hear. She swept on looking like some goddess of antiquity (Venus with a violin, perhaps) and proceeded to sculpt the phrases of the Third Concerto with a combination of seraphic radiance and humane beauty. The Third is an essentially operatic work in which the soloist spins out a succession of wordless arias, occasionally joining the orchestra in some wryly funny ensembles that pre-empt The Marriage of Figaro. In the slow movement, Mullova is an angelic diva and the long, tear-inducing melody seems disconnected from the earth, occasionally swooping down to touch it.

In the Fourth Concerto, she's very different. It opens in territory which suggests imperial formality, its rigidity relentlessly undercut until the work ends in the Dionysian swirl of a jubilant waltz. Galvanising the Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment into action with an imperious shrug of her shoulders, Mullova is more aggressive here, an Orphic figure whose playing seems to quell the orchestra into rapt submission. The opening flares upwards in a brief blaze of anger. The double-stopped cadenza of the slow movement is inherently bucolic, as if the violinist is finally warming up to lead that last great dance. Mullova is astonishing playing this music, and the orchestra are pretty damn fine, too.

When Mullova was absent from the platform they were put through their paces by Catherine Mackintosh, directing from the leader's chair. Salieri's overture to La Scuola De' Gelosi burbled with pleasurable glee. Haydn's Passione Symphony is a work which rewrites almost every rule in the musical book in the course of its intense meditation on the Crucifixion. It's rarely been played with such searing density and tragic grandeur as it was on this occasion.

fields.headline: Painting History
fields.standfirst:
Treasures of the North
Christies, London and touring
****
fields.trailText: The upper classes certainly know how to enjoy themselves. Hunting, art collecting, Satanism - it's all here in an exhibition from private collections in country houses in the north of England. Satanism is to be found in William Hogarth's portrait, Sir Francis Dashwood at His Devotions. Dashwood, an 18th-century MP, was the founder of a pseudo-monastic order whose members were said to indulge in orgiastic rites in an "abbey". Hogarth's painting is a precise, hilarious pastiche of European baroque religious art.
fields.body:
The upper classes certainly know how to enjoy themselves. Hunting, art collecting, Satanism - it's all here in an exhibition from private collections in country houses in the north of England. Satanism is to be found in William Hogarth's portrait, Sir Francis Dashwood at His Devotions. Dashwood, an 18th-century MP, was the founder of a pseudo-monastic order whose members were said to indulge in orgiastic rites in an "abbey". Hogarth's painting is a precise, hilarious pastiche of European baroque religious art.

As an advert for the English country house I'm not sure if this exhibition works. Or rather it does work, but too well. It is a portrait of the landed classes seen through the sometimes jaundiced eyes of their painters. Take Stubbs's The Grosvenor Hunt (1762). This grand, sweeping Cheshire landscape has a tragic stillness. Sir Richard Grosvenor and fellow landowners have hunted down a stag to a stream in the foreground. They sit unmoved on their horses, watching while dogs tear the animal apart. There's a fantastic conflation of civility and savagery: the disciplined hunt, the primitive ritual at its heart.

There are sugary, aristocratic children painted by Romney, Reynolds and Lawrence, children as precious to their parents as the silverware, giltwood sofas and jewels in this exhibition - perhaps even more so.

What was, and is, the value of art? In the country house, art is exhibited, as here, as not inherently better than the silverware in the same room. It's all treasure, and what treasure. There are Pre-Raphaelites, a glorious Monet, a Damien Hirst. The Duke of Westminster has lent two sublime landscapes by Claude Lorrain and The Surrender of Seville by Francisco de Zurbaran. Zurbaran gives the Moors a tragic nobility as they hand over the keys of Seville to the Christian conquerors. History is written by the winners, but sometimes it's painted in a way that gives the losers a look-in.

At Christie's, 8 King Street, London SW1 (0171-839 9060), until February 13, and at the Whitworth Art Gallery, Oxford Road, Manchester (0161-275 7450), from February 25-April 9

fields.headline: Treasure Island
fields.standfirst:
The Island
Lyttelton Theatre, London
*****
fields.trailText: At a time when British theatre seems scared witless of politics, it is exhilarating to see this play back on a major stage. Created by Athol Fugard, John Kani and Winston Ntshona and first seen 25 years ago at the Royal Court, it has, if anything, gained with time. Apartheid may have crumbled, but the play's celebration of defiance and awareness of the human cost of incarceration remain timeless.
fields.body:
At a time when British theatre seems scared witless of politics, it is exhilarating to see this play back on a major stage. Created by Athol Fugard, John Kani and Winston Ntshona and first seen 25 years ago at the Royal Court, it has, if anything, gained with time. Apartheid may have crumbled, but the play's celebration of defiance and awareness of the human cost of incarceration remain timeless.

Its setting is Robben Island and its subject is imprisonment: the way it both unites and divides, affirming the resisting spirit while punishing the vulnerable body.

John and Winston, the names of the characters as well as the actors, have shared a cell for three years and their relationship has become like an asexual Beckettian marriage. At first we see them mimetically shifting sand in a meaningless Sisyphean labour. Back in their cell, having tended each other's wounds, they prepare a scene from Antigone: John is bullyingly dominant, Winston fearful of public humiliation. But the crunch comes when John learns that a commutation of his sentence means he will be released in three months while Winston will do life.

This arbitrary divorce releases covert tensions and yet makes possible the performance of Antigone's trial and punishment.

Politics and art miraculously coalesce. Quite obviously, the play is a protest against a brutal system. But the play also makes a complex statement about imprisonment.

The two men enjoy the testy togetherness of married partners. But John's provisional release is also divisive. When Winston cries: "Your freedom stinks and it's driving me mad" it both expresses Winston's envious rage and questions the meaning of freedom in the South Africa of the 1970s. As in all good political theatre, and as in Antigone itself, there is both irony and ambivalence.

The piece is now inseparable from its two superb performers; and what is astonishing watching Athol Fugard's production, now supervised by Peter Brook, is how the passing years have enriched their molten relationship. It's not just that the opening scene requires even more Herculean effort. They are so finely tuned to each other's responses that they do seem to be cellmates.

This revival could have been an act of cultural piety, but has become a piece of living theatre: it transcends the moment of its creation to express permanent truths about strategies of survival wherever oppression and unjust imprisonment prevail. It also reminds us that the best political theatre is always vibrant, compelling art.

Until February 26. Box office: 0171-452 3000
